SECTION: Section 15; Page 10; Column 2; Retirement

LENGTH: 1258 words

HEADLINE: Building a Nest Egg: An Exercise in Constant Guesswork

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
HERE is a secret about the perfect retirement plan: It doesn't exist.
Here is another secret about all retirement plans: They are educated guesses, because they deal with that most unpredictable of things, the future. 
 Long ago, sea captains had to plot courses based on estimates of wind, tide and currents, set against faulty or nonexistent charts. Explorers often set out without knowing where they were headed, or how long it would take.
We are all in the same boat, but our task is simpler: not to run out of supplies.
"The biggest fear of the elderly is: What if I outlive my money?" said Raymond G. Russolillo, the director of personal financial services for PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Jerry Mason, who teaches family financial planning at Texas Tech University in Lubbock, put it another way: "I don't think there is much correlation between money and happiness above a certain point -- but if you wind up on the welfare rolls, there is."
Complicating the picture is the best news possible about retirement: it doesn't end as soon as it used to.
Most experts urge a person considering retiring early, at age 55, to accumulate resources sufficient to last 30 years. In contrast, according to Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm, that person's parents typically had only a 20-year retirement and their great-grandparents, a 5-year retirement.
What that means is that financial preparation is more of a process than a blueprint. Think of it as a series of midcourse corrections, to be made periodically or as personal circumstances and the economy change.
 
Retirement Quiz
Here is a short list of questions that sketch out the kind of factors involved:
* How long are you likely to live? Unanswerable, of course, but important. A starting point for that consideration is the life-expectancy tables published by MetLife and others (men who have reached 65 can expect to live another 15.9 years; women, 19). Family history and personal health should also be considered.
* How much money do you need each year? A rule of thumb is 70 percent or 80 percent of current annual cash flow, but it is better to do a careful individual cash flow analysis. A couple moving to a Florida condominium, for example, may have a very different situation from people who want to keep living in their large family home in Westchester County.
* How much will come in from pensions and Social Security?
* How much of a nest egg will be needed to make up the difference? This requires projections for inflation and rate of return on investment.
 
Mistakes Not to Make
One area of certainty, at least to financial planners, is the mistakes they see.
Mr. Russolillo cautions that one of the most serious errors in recent years has been fostered by the stock market boom. "People assume they are going to get 20 or 25 percent in the market because they have over the last few years," he said. "I always try to pull them back and think of 8 percent before tax," a figure that is more warranted by history than are the red-hot returns of recent years.
Martin Nissenbaum, the national director of retirement planning for Ernst & Young, said another common error among retirees is to let safety over-dominate their investment strategies. Many people move their assets into fixed income investments (bonds or other debt instruments) as they approach retirement, he said, seeking to avoid the risk of volatile stock markets. "But you have to continue looking for growth," so your nest egg can expand to modern longer lifespans. And that essentially means keeping a substantial part of your assets in stocks.
Avery E. Neumark, a principal in the accounting firm of Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company and the firm's director of employee benefits, offers a rough guideline for asset allocation: 120 minus your age equals the percentage of assets that should be in stocks; the rest can go into bonds.
Mr. Neumark cited another error, perhaps the most basic of all: "People start focusing on retirement later than they should." He added, "You cannot save enough for retirement because there are always surprises that come in -- inflation, life style."
Are there people who get so anxious that they compulsively save too much? "I have never seen that problem in my whole career," Mr. Neumark said.
Professor Mason, a former director of education for the International Association for Financial Planning, advises people to begin by putting away money systematically in any employer-sponsored plans like 401(k)'s, "because basically, we are all like children in the candy store." Money in our jeans will be spent. If it is withheld before we get it, we may be able to adjust our life styles to fit the take-home pay and leave the savings to grow for later years.
 
Playing Catch Up
People who address the issue relatively late may not be able to save enough in what are known as qualified plans, tax-deferred plans like employer-sponsored pension plans, 401(k) plans and Keogh plans for the self-employed. In that case, Mr. Neumark said, their options are the following:
* Supplement those savings with investments in regular brokerage or mutual fund accounts.
* Think about not retiring so early, or take a new job in retirement.
* Adjust the retirement budget.
One possibility for people who are contributing as much as possible to qualified plans, but who fear they will not have enough, is a tax-deferred annuity -- essentially a mutual fund sold with an insurance wrapper. The downside is that fees run higher than they do for a similar mutual fund.
Mr. Nissenbaum said he occasionally recommends annuities, but noted "you can basically create your own annuity" by investing in an index fund -- a mutual fund that mimics an index like the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index. There is very little current capital gains tax with such a holding, he said, because there is very little portfolio turnover. And when you sell holdings after retirement, capital gains are taxed at favorable rates. In contrast, any money that comes out of qualified plans or I.R.A.'s is taxed as ordinary income.
"What's not good is to have too optimistic a plan," Mr. Neumark said. "I'd rather have a cushion."
Mr. Neumark advises reviewing and updating a plan "no less than annually."
Indeed, when contemplating a 30-year retirement, think back to 1969, when the Dow Jones industrial average closed the year at 800; $15,000 a year was a reasonable middle-class salary, and a new car cost $2,000.
Who would have projected that inflation would gallop into double digits within 10 years and appear almost moribund 20 years after that; that within 25 years downsizing would dominate the corporate landscape, or that medical advances would make 85 a reasonable life expectancy?
This is not to say past is prologue -- just to say that although long-term financial planning is fraught with uncertainties, those who plan, and save accordingly, will surely be in a better position to deal with life's vicissitudes. "I'm amazed at the people I see who have not put a penny away," Professor Mason said, adding, "I think we are soon to see a real inflation of the welfare rolls, 75-year-olds in poverty," citing as an example the elderly man seen bagging groceries at the supermarket.
But remember, time is your ally. It irons out the volatility of the market, while compound growth multiplies your savings. Then, if your rate of withdrawal in retirement is equal to or below your rate of return, you will never run out of money.

HEADLINE: What Does Joy Schott Want? Wall Street Is Listening

BYLINE: By JON CHRISTENSEN; Jon Christensen is a freelance writer on business and the environment.

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
THINKING of starting or investing in a business to serve retired people? The monthly luncheon of the Desert Newcomers, a club for retired women who recently moved to Las Vegas, might be a good place to do market research, except for one hitch. The ladies do not like to talk business. Desert Newcomers is strictly a social club.
But when Joy Schott, 82, reeled off a laundry list of businesses that could serve retirees better, the other women at her luncheon table nodded in agreement at the needs and desires that someone might make money satisfying: 
 "Home nursing so people don't have to go to those horrid institutions."
"Rides to places."
"A handyman to fix the porch light" and other things around the house.
"Entertainment that is not all that right-handed stuff," Ms. Schott said, pulling on an imaginary slot machine.
"And food-catering services."
In fact, Ms. Schott said that she already has a custom cook: "He comes to my house twice a month and makes me a dozen chicken potpies just the way I like them with white meat only, peas and carrots."
Beyond the casinos, Las Vegas is turning into a kind of sprawling focus group for the future. The metropolitan area is growing faster than any other in the country, and the retirement-age population in Las Vegas is a big part of the boom, said Keith Schwer, the director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.
Las Vegas was practically designed for the graying of America, with three Sun City retirement communities, 47 golf courses, and cheap food and 24-hour entertainment in the casinos. Overall, the city is bursting with businesses that serve an aging population.
These kinds of businesses offer good investment opportunities, according to Robert J. Farrell, a senior investment adviser with Merrill Lynch in New York. The "aging population" is the most heavily weighted segment of Mr. Farrell's "theme and profile investing" recommendations. Mr. Farrell predicts growth in health care, financial services and advice, health clubs and gyms, golf, travel, home security systems and "death care," or funeral arrangements.
But the growth in the retired population also creates opportunities for small businesses and niche services. In a cramped warren of offices at the Small Business Administration in downtown Las Vegas, volunteers working for the Service Corps of Retired Executives talk to dozens of people each month who are thinking of starting businesses that could serve the retired population here.
"There's a lot of entrepreneurial spirit out there," said Norman A. Schroeder, 63, a retired retailer from Iowa who moved to Las Vegas in 1987. "Lots of people are going into business." Last month, a woman asked for advice about starting an apartment cleaning business. "There are a lot of 55-and-over apartment complexes," Mr. Schroeder observed. "This is a great retirement community." Others have sought Mr. Schroeder's advice about setting up a personal grocery shopping service, a service to transport people to and from doctors' offices and hospitals and an insurance claim processing business.
Mr. Schroeder has also heard some "pretty screwy, weird ideas" too, like a heated toilet seat, and a plastic rod with a sticky end for picking up money from the ground without having to bend over.
"I still have a sample," he said, shaking his head.
The volunteers counsel the majority of people to take their time, he said, get more work experience, save money, line up capital and do more research before making the leap.
"What do people my age need?" is the gist of his advice, Mr. Schroeder said. "Get out and talk to them. Know your market. Providing services to save people time seems to be the crux, anything that solves time or physical needs. That's why there are so many lawn-care services. And it doesn't take much to get started."
Las Vegas is crawling with these most grass-roots of start-up businesses.
Driving around the walled-off residential neighborhoods of Henderson, the fastest-growing suburb in the area, Hal Rothman pointed out a pickup truck filled with garbage cans sprouting rakes and a man with a lawn mower going back and forth across a well-groomed lawn.
"If you want to make money in the future, think of what older people need that you can deliver to them at a reasonable price," said Mr. Rothman, a professor of history at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas and a Henderson resident. "It's one of the most exciting sectors of the economy. And what's happening here will become far more common around the country when the baby boom starts to retire."
At 40, Mr. Rothman is just a baby in the baby-boom generation. But he has made a close study of his aging neighborhood. Retired people tend to live in smaller homes, he said, and their yards and gardens show a lot of care compared with those of busy young couples with jobs and children, and toys and bikes scattered round.
But in Mr. Rothman's neighborhood the generations blend. An Alzheimer's center sits cheek by jowl with a 24-hour gym. The surrounding shopping centers have a mix of coffee shops, bookstores, card stores, juice bars and fast-food outlets.
Everybody uses them, said Mr. Rothman, just in different ways at different times. At 7 A.M., the local Starbucks attracts parents on their way to work, he observed, while at midday, stay-at-home mothers come in and, at midmorning and midafternoon, retired folks.
Many businesses offer discounts or tailor their services in other ways to attract older customers. The Hallmark store has a well-stocked section with cards for grandparents. The Taco Bell gives free drinks to people over 65. But some customers seem taken aback when asked, "Are you a senior?" Appealing to the elderly on the basis of their age can be tricky when staying young is their primary goal.
Dave Harris, 62, a retired college administrator, and Betty Ann Montgomery, 60, a retired college professor, live in a three-bedroom house in Henderson, with a pool and a small backyard. Their home is often filled with younger friends, the couple said, and staying young at heart is important to them.
They insist their life style has not changed much since they retired.
But while lounging around the house on a weekday morning in loose sweat pants and sweaters, sipping gourmet tea and coffee, they admit they do spend less on clothes and more on food. "We shop differently because we're not dressing for work," Ms. Montgomery said. "For years, I looked for the best bargains; now it's the best food." A nearby Trader Joe's is her favorite grocery store.
Mr. Harris reluctantly conceded he has stopped golfing. "I was a serious golfer," he said, "but my game is just not there anymore." They employ someone to take care of the yard and someone to clean the pool. They plan to give away half of their assets before they die, and nonprofit organizations like The Nature Conservancy, Planned Parenthood and the American Civil Liberties Union are already benefiting from their largess.
The couple have retirement benefits from six jobs between them, and an investment portfolio that Mr. Harris manages using Schwab's on-line trading service. Mr. Harris also makes travel reservations and orders medicine on line. And they love e-mail.
"We're communicating with people we used to communicate with maybe once a year at Christmas," Ms. Montgomery said. "Now it's once or twice a week."
They use a local Internet service provider, Mr. Harris said, because they can get technical support within an hour.
Mr. Harris has invested in some of the businesses that financial advisers like Mr. Farrell of Merrill Lynch predict will benefit from an aging population. The aging theme covers "such a litany" that the predictions are "bound to be right" some of the time, Mr. Harris said.
And with life styles like their own, retirement covers an increasingly wider spectrum of businesses. "The key," he said, "is who really emerges as the top two or three players in each sector."

HEADLINE: Older Students Bring New Life to Campuses

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
AFTER teaching high school Latin for 38 years in Binghamton, N.Y., Nancy L. Hanover retired last fall to the mountains of western North Carolina with a hunger to learn all of those things she could never find time to learn as a working mother of three.
A North Carolina native, she knew she wanted to come home to retire. But her decision to move to Asheville, as opposed to other nearby towns, was influenced heavily by the presence of the Center for Creative Retirement at the University of North Carolina at Asheville. At the Center's College for Seniors, she found a smorgasbord of noncredit courses, some taught by university faculty and some by retirees, that has more than satisfied her intellectual appetite. 
 During the four-week winter term, Ms. Hanover, who is 62, took classes on pre-Columbian South America, practical law for seniors and theater as forum. For the 10-week spring term, she has enrolled in five courses, including Mark Twain, history of Ireland, poetry, the Roman Republic and the female face of heroism.
"I retired to be able to take classes," Ms. Hanover said during a break in a lecture about the culture and archeology of the Incas. "All those years I taught, I took classes that I had to take, but I could never take classes that I wanted to take. There are so many things that I don't know."
In this age of relative affluence and longevity, there are thousands of seniors like Ms. Hanover who are devoting their retirements to learning. And hundreds of colleges and universities are beginning to understand this burgeoning new market. All across the country, colleges are catering to retirees with a broad array of academic programs, cultural offerings, community service initiatives and even housing options.
Ten years ago, there were fewer than 50 colleges with academic programs designed specifically for retirees. Now an estimated 300 colleges have such programs -- known as Institutes for Learning in Retirement -- and they serve more than 60,000 retirees, according to Mary Linnehan, the director of the Elderhostel Institute Network, an association of the institutes.
A related nonprofit organization known as Elderhostel, which is 24 years old, offers thousands of courses at 2,000 colleges, libraries, museums and other locations. Participants must be at least 55. Last year, there were 263,000 enrollments. This spring, seniors can learn to play "The Plucked Dulcimer" or explore "The Art of Quilting" at Alice Lloyd College in Pippa Passes, Ky., or listen to "Women's Voices From the West: Survival on the Northern Plains" at Western Montana College in Dillon.
Scores of other colleges have affiliated, either directly or indirectly, with developers who are building retirement villages on or near their campuses. The developers view the colleges, with their course offerings, libraries, athletic events and performing arts centers, as marketing lures that entice retirees to their communities. The colleges see the seniors as eager students who can help fill concert halls and basketball arenas and, perhaps, include the schools in their estate planning.
In Birmingham, Ala., for instance, the Daniel Corporation has purchased 40 acres from Samford University and is building a retirement community of 120 independent living units, 120 assisted living units and 48 garden homes. The university has agreed to sponsor a lecture series by its professors and to provide access for residents to computer labs, gymnasiums, libraries and cultural and athletic events. The project has already drawn reservations from retired Samford alumni, professors and trustees.
A similar development is being planned at Penn State University on land leased from the school. Retirees there will be able to audit courses, play on the university golf course and swim in its pool. "We're getting reservations from people in Florida who say the weather isn't everything," said Mary Beth Fritz, marketing director for The Village at Penn State. "They want to be around a young atmosphere. They want to be around people who don't just talk about their health."
Indeed, all of the college-based retirement programs respond to the growing demand by retirees for ways to remain mentally and physically active.
"They are retiring a little earlier in many instances and they realize that they can only play so much golf," said Winston M. Fagan, a sociologist at Jacksonville State University in Alabama and an authority on retirement. "They want to keep their minds working, and they draw energy from the college students."
Leon A. Pastalan, a professor of architecture at the University of Michigan and the co-editor of "University Linked Retirement Communities" (Haworth, 1994), said that retirement programs at colleges are helping seniors discover how to make their elder years productive.
"The most critical problem we have with aging in our society is to give people a reason to get up in the morning," Professor Pastalan said. "It's terribly wasteful when we put people out to pasture and tell them that their important days are done."
VIRTUALLY all of the seniors interviewed on the Asheville campus during a two-day visit said they participated both because they were curious about the subject matter and because they wanted to keep their minds agile.
"It keeps us thinking about important things and it is tremendously entertaining," said Dorothy L. Kirschbaum, a 77-year-old retired teacher who moved to Asheville from Pittsburgh in 1982. "It's better than sitting home and watching TV."
Although the prototype for retirement learning was developed at The New School in 1962, the 11-year-old center at U.N.C.-Asheville is considered something of a national model. It prides itself on the diversity and responsiveness of its programs, which attract about 1,500 retirees a year in a county where 45,000 people are 55 or older.
The mountain terrain and temperate climate have long made western North Carolina a haven for retirees. But in recent years, the center has become a factor in numerous retirement relocation decisions.
The heart of the Center for Creative Retirement is the College for Seniors, which typically offers between 35 and 45 courses in each of four terms. Participants pay a $100 fee per term, allowing them to take as many courses as they wish and to use the university's library and fitness center. Most of the courses are taught by retirees, many of them former professors, while a few are taught by university faculty. Topics range from James Joyce's "Dubliners" to tap dancing to basic computer instruction.
On a recent Friday, 35 retirees, some wearing hearing aids and orthopedic shoes, listened intently as Walter Ziffer, a 71-year-old professor of religion at the university, lectured about the competing claims to the city of Jerusalem made by Christians, Moslems and Jews. Some students scribbled diligently in their notebooks, while others nursed cups of coffee and hot chocolate.
One of those seated in an orange-cushioned chair was Jack E. Ingersoll, a 69-year-old former I.B.M. manager, who has taken more than 10 courses since retiring here five years ago. "Education is wasted on the young," he said. "I think you appreciate it more with the experience of life."
Most academic programs for retirees at other colleges follow a similar model, but some are far less structured. At Victor Valley College in Victorville, Calif., for instance, participants in a program called Seniors With Inquiring Minds, or S.W.I.M., meet to discuss topics chosen by their own members, often plucked from their own backgrounds. In one class, a former Hollywood dog trainer explained his craft. In another, class members retrieved artifacts from their attics and then told the stories behind them.
At U.N.C.-Asheville, a compact liberal arts college with 3,100 undergraduates, officials have had great success with intergenerational courses that place 20-year-olds and 70-year-olds in the same classrooms. Ronald Manheimer, the director of the Center for Creative Retirement, recently taught an intergenerational course on "1946: The Meaning of a Year," and used two class participants -- one a World War II submariner and one a Holocaust survivor -- to bring history to life.
The Holocaust survivor, he said, movingly recalled holding his father's hand as they watched German soldiers march into their town. "Instead of the generalizations and abstractions that you get in history, here you could understand how something like this happened in a single neighborhood instead of on a large scale," Mr. Manheimer said. "By bringing together people of different generations, you can capture the transformations in individual lives and how they reflect larger social changes."
The center, which sustains itself on a $400,000 budget through fees and an annual appropriation from the State Legislature, also conducts a lecture series, local tours, community service programs and a retirement weekend that draws 150 prospective retirees to Asheville each spring to explore the benefits of moving here. Another popular program is Leadership Asheville Seniors, which builds a sense of community among new residents by staging discussions with local political, economic and cultural leaders.
"We found we knew more about Asheville after a couple of months than we did about Long Island after 30 years," said Ed A. Argue, a semiretired management consultant who moved with his wife from Westbury two years ago.
The center has become so popular that it is now trying to raise $3 million to construct a building of its own. The university has donated 5.5 acres of land, a local foundation has offered a $1.25 million challenge grant and the retirees themselves are hustling to raise the rest of the money.
Mr. Manheimer predicts that as the baby boom generation moves into retirement, centers like his will gain permanence on campuses around the country. "This is the wave of the future," he said. "This is where the country's going to be."

SECTION: Section 15; Page 1; Column 1; Retirement 

LENGTH: 2382 words

HEADLINE: Not an Age, but an Expanding State of Mind

BYLINE: By ROBERT W. STOCK 

 BODY:
FOR three years now, ever since abandoning a full-time job at age 66, I've been keeping track of the responses from friends and acquaintances to the statement, "I'm retired." In general, younger people have congratulated me on my new-found freedom: "You're a lucky guy!" The reaction from older people has been more reserved, even concerned: "What are you going to do with yourself? How will you manage?"
We all think we know what the word retirement means but our definitions vary wildly, and they are mostly wrong. We have been misled by a host of retirement myths. Among them: Retirees happily leave their jobs at age 65 and never work again. They live on their pensions, with a little help from Social Security. They either (1) Spend a few years playing cards until it's time for the nursing home, or (2) Endlessly travel the world while starting new businesses and rediscovering romance. 
 In fact, virtually everything about the way Americans retire and think about retirement has changed over the last few decades, and there is more change on the way. The baby boomers, who start entering their 60's seven years from now, say they are going to have the most exciting and fulfilling retirements ever, though just how they will pay for them is something of a mystery.
Daniel Perry, the executive director of the Alliance for Aging Research, a nonprofit organization in Washington, takes the long view. "Until this century," Mr. Perry said, "retirement was for the rich. Everybody else worked until they dropped. Social Security and Medicare made for retirement, and improvements in benefits enabled people to retire at a younger and younger age. Now, with improved health and longevity, it looks as though we may be moving back toward a longer-than-ever working life."
Something strange has happened: The decades-long decline in the age of retirement has come to an abrupt halt. And for many retirees, the next stage has become not the rocking chair but another, easier, often part-time job.
The notion that your arrival at age 65 automatically ushers you into retirement was fostered by large companies, which took that occasion to hand you a pension and show you the door. But the majority of workers labored for smaller companies that offered no pensions and had no mandatory retirement at 65, so that number held no particular charm: They just kept working.
Then the Federal Government weighed in, making 65 the age of eligibility for Social Security benefits in 1935, and Medicare benefits in 1965. Sixty-five was firmly established in our minds as retirement age, even though, as of 1950, 72 percent of all 65-year-old men were still in the labor force -- they had jobs or were actively looking for work.
After the Government programs kicked in, the average age of retirement began to slide down toward 65 -- and then simply kept going south. By 1985, just 30 percent of 65-year-old men were in the labor force. Americans had more money to spend on an early retirement, and Washington made it easier by lowering Social Security eligibility to age 62.
But then, the decline in retirement age halted and even showed signs of creeping back toward 65. Why? Changes in Social Security and private pension plans may be part of the explanation. The outlawing of mandatory retirement in 1986 surely helped. But surveys also suggest a new attitude in the ranks of older workers. "Many 62-year-olds today can look forward to another 15 or 20 years of healthy, active life," said Joseph F. Quinn, an economist at Boston College. "They may not want to quit at 65, or they may want to do their retirement in stages."
Dr. Quinn's research has found that among workers who had left career jobs of at least 10 years, almost half took so-called bridge jobs rather than simply dropping out of the labor force. About 60 percent of the bridge jobs were part-time. "For many Americans, retirement is not a single defining event but a process," Dr. Quinn said. There goes another myth.
In truth, there are almost as many kinds of retirement as there are retirees.
In my case, after 40 years as a writer and editor on the staff of various newspapers and magazines, I retired to my New York apartment. I still write and edit for various newspapers and magazines, and work on occasional books, but I do it all at my own pace, with no one looking over my shoulder -- at least, no one in the same room. Norman Brazee took a different tack. After almost 30 years with Con Edison, where he was a systems analyst, he retired in 1992 at the age of 58. He and his wife, Theresa, a former secretary in the New York State court system, have a home in Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J. They live on their two pensions and two Social Security checks.
"I don't miss work at all," Mr. Brazee said. "I don't have time to work." He is a volunteer driver for two organizations that distribute food to the homebound and the needy. He is helping his fishing club rebuild its headquarters. He is constantly remodeling and repairing some part of his house. He plays golf. "I adore being retired," he said. "It's the most beautiful thing that ever happened to me."
On the other hand, surveys show that up to a quarter of older men who are out of the labor force would leap back in if they could find a suitable job. William H. Mansfield 3d of Bethesda, Md., has retired three times, and at 66, he's still looking for work.
In 1989, he left the State Department, where he had been a foreign service officer specializing in environmental matters. He was hired by the United Nations, but had to retire when he reached 60. His last full-time job was with the Worldwatch Institute, and that ended in the spring of 1997. He has had some consulting assignments since, and he would like more.
"I don't like to say I'm retired," Mr. Mansfield remarked. "I like to think I can keep on working because I enjoyed it a lot."
Money is not a major issue; among other income, Mr. Mansfield has both Federal and U.N. pensions. I asked him for some other reasons why people seek to hang onto their jobs. "Much of their status depends upon the organization and position they hold," he said. "Once that's gone, you are groping around to find out where your status, your distinction, comes from."
Today, the whole sense of what 65 means has been twisted out of shape. "Sixty-five used to be the start of your retirement, your well-deserved rest time," said John Rother, the director of legislation and public policy for the American Association of Retired Persons (A.A.R.P.). "You were officially elderly. Now, it means you're at the peak of your powers in many ways, free of pressing responsibilities like child-raising and with a lot of good years ahead."
That is what Mr. Rother calls the first stage of retirement, which eventually segues into a second stage, when disabilities place new limits on your freedom.
For most men, the first stage now starts before 63; for most women, before 60. And the second stage doesn't arrive until 75 or 80.
Goverment studies show that the financial circumstances of today's retirees, as well as their health, have substantially improved. When asked, they overwhelmingly say they are happy. But this rosy picture glosses over the financial and emotional problems that plague millions of retirees. Another myth exploded.
THOUGH the median income of those 65 and over has doubled in constant dollars since 1962, it still amounts to only $16,000. The majority receive no company pensions. Two out of five get 80 percent of their income from Social Security payments, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Older women in general are twice as likely as older men to be living below or just above the poverty line, and older women living alone are at the bottom of the heap. Their pensions, incomes and assets don't compare to those of single men or married couples. Even their Social Security payments are lower, since they typically have not worked as long nor been paid as much as their male counterparts. And because they last six years longer than men, they worry about outliving whatever savings they have and spending stage two of retirement in a nursing home. In this age of the family diaspora, they often lack a dependable support system.
"I find something missing about retirement," said Kathleen Sheehy, 69, of Manhattan, who has been out of the work force for 16 years. "For one thing, it's better for people with families." During her 35 years as a secretary, she said, she enjoyed the structure work gave to her life, and the office camaraderie. Toward the end, though, she was feeling burned out. When she came into a little money, as she put it, Ms. Sheehy decided that her new inheritance plus her savings would provide for her immediate retirement.
She has spent the years since doing volunteer work and some babysitting -- "for the involvement with people and especially children," she said -- and she has also taken some trips. But she would like to have some kind of regular work again: "a fun job, part-time and not too responsible; maybe as a hostess where I could meet and greet people," she said.
Whatever the kaleidoscopic reality of retirement today, a new public perception is being honed. Men and women with gray hair have invaded ads and sitcoms alike, smiling lovingly at each other from adjoining Nautilus machines, enrolling in peer-taught college courses, marching across Europe on ElderHostel tours. Doctors, columnists and the A.A.R.P. insist that 65 is the start of something great, not the end, if only you will keep mind and body active.
Even the Federal Government is in on it, enacting measures that make work more attractive to oldsters. The age at which you can collect Social Security, no matter how much else you earn, has been cut from 72 to 70. And the amount you can earn before that age, without loss of benefits, is rising gradually from $13,500 to $30,000 by 2002. At the same time, the age at which you receive full retirement benefits will increase over the next quarter century, from 65 to 67.
John Heston, of Hanover, N.H., goes with the flow. At 66, he has been retired from his career in advertising and communications for three years, but his days are full. He does paid consulting; he teaches a class at his alma mater, Dartmouth College, and is an adviser to its alumni magazine. "I can't imagine retiring and doing nothing the way my Dad did," Mr. Heston said. "Now we look for new challenges. We're expected to. It's the spirit of the times."
A somewhat different set of challenges awaits the next retirement generation. Christopher L. Hayes, the chairman of the graduate program in gerontology at Long Island University, Southampton, offers this summary: "Baby boomers are a very present-oriented and self-oriented generation. They have dreams of retiring early, starting new careers, spending more time with family, travel. But they have given little pragmatic thought to how to fund those dreams. So far, the economics are not there."
Part of the problem is that governments and larger companies have been shifting retirement risks and responsibilities onto their employees. Instead of promising you a pension of a particular size, the company sets up a 401(k) plan, agrees to contribute a fixed amount and leaves the investment decisions to you. Your retirement prospects depend upon how much you put in and how well you make those decisions. Many companies are also cutting back their contributions to employee health insurance and cutting off retiree medical benefits. The number of people without health insurance in the United States has been growing at the rate of a million a year.
So the boomers find themselves out on a limb, having to plan and save for their own retirement with little understanding of how to go about it. What they do know is that their children's college education is costing them more than they ever imagined, and that the financial support of their ever-longer-lived parents is going to cost them in the future. They also fear that Social Security and Medicare, the traditional safety nets, will not be there when they make the leap into retirement.
Dr. Hayes wears an extra hat as the director of the National Center for Women and Retirement Research. Together with Scudder Kemper Investments, the center has conducted a three-year study of boomers' attitudes toward and preparation for retirement. Among the results: 70 percent say they are worried about their financial future, and 80 percent say they have made plans to insure a financially secure retirement, but the median investment among those with 401(k)s and similar accounts is only $35,000. According to a Merrill Lynch study, the average boomer couple saves 39 percent of what they would need to carry their current standard of living over into retirement.
FOR today's retirees, as for the boomers, financial security is a key to successful retirement, but it is not the only key. The woods are full of resourceful, resilient retirees who have managed to do more with less. Consider Norman and Maja Weiner of Mount Pleasant, S.C. Mr. Weiner was the Ohio-born manager of an airport in Keflavik, Iceland, back in 1958, when he met his wife-to-be.
"I was 18, he was 27," Maja Weiner recalled recently. "He spoke no Icelandic, but he charmed his way into my life." In short order, they were married and eventually they settled in Comack, L.I., where Mr. Weiner set up a furniture store. They had three children, and after a while, he had three furniture stores. "I had a really comfortable retirement all planned out," he said.
Then Mr. Weiner had to have heart surgery. After liquidating the business, the couple moved to South Carolina. "We could probably get by on what we have," said Mr. Weiner, who is now 68. "But we wouldn't be able to visit our children, or get to Iceland to visit Maja's family."
So Mr. Weiner has taken a part-time sales job at a department store in nearby Charleston. "I work around young people, and I love it," he said. His wife, who is 59, waits on tables three days a week at a local Waffle House. "Retirement, I think, is very boring," she said. "I enjoy being with people, someone other than my husband."
She giggled as she said it, and her husband growled happily in the background.

SECTION: Section 15; Page 12; Column 1; Retirement 

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: A Growing Gap Between the Savers and the Save-Nots

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
IN two years, when the first of the baby boomers turn 55 and become eligible for early retirement, a new trend should begin to emerge that will separate the ants from the grasshoppers.
And two decades from now, when half the boomers will have ended their working years, that trend will have grown into a major economic divide, one much bigger than the current split between the few at the top with rising incomes and the many struggling from paycheck to paycheck. 
 The great divide will be wealth. Wealth is not income. Indeed, some people with modest incomes are prodigious savers, while many high-income people save little or nothing.
Wealth will affect how long boomers live (the better off people are, the greater their life expectancy) and how happy they are in retirement, although the relationship between wealth and happiness in retirement is not simple, the few experts who have studied the issue say.
For four decades much of the national debate about economic well-being has focused on incomes and, especially, on their growing disparity: Nearly all real growth has gone to the top 5 percent of workers, while those at the bottom have lost ground.
But now that debate is encompassing wealth. The Ford Foundation, whose grants have had enormous influence on policies affecting the poor, has begun steering academic and Government attention to helping the poor not just by raising their incomes, but by helping them acquire assets, especially savings accounts and homes.
And the disparity in wealth is far greater than in incomes. Four out of five working-age Americans essentially have no wealth, except for equity in their homes, while in 1997 the top 1 percent owned 48.6 percent of all financial assets like stocks and bonds. That is the greatest concentration in the nation's history, said Prof. Edward N. Wolff, a New York University economist who studies wealth.
The most important division among today's retirees is between those who own their own homes and those who don't: homeowners retire with an average net worth of $115,000, while nonhomeowners have $800.
In the years ahead this gap will grow. The ants, the thrifty boomers who have saved and invested, will have plenty of money to spend. Some ants will be able to spend twice as much in retirement as they did in their working years, said Jonathan Skinner, a Dartmouth College economist who studies retirement savings.
But the much bigger group is the grasshoppers, who spend what they earn, whether it is a little or a lot, and are slaves to minimum monthly payments on their plastic debt, have 125 percent mortgages on their homes and who, when they change jobs, dip into their 401(k) savings.
The differences between the current crop of retired ants and grasshoppers are masked by traditional, or defined benefit, pension plans, which guarantee a monthly check for life. Combined with Social Security and home ownership, such pensions have changed retirement in America from a time of widespread poverty four decades ago to an era of comfort for many and golden years for more than a few.
Social Security and Medicare, that other pillar of retirement, are, of course, at the heart of a huge Washington debate. But despite all that well-publicized uncertainty, the baby boomers who start retiring will find the rest of their lives shaped by a change that happened with next to no public discussion: the switch from traditional pensions.
Far fewer boomers have such check-a-month plans than do retirees today. Many of them have changed jobs so often that their pensions will replace only a tiny slice of the incomes in their working years, because these plans bestow most of their benefits on people who stay with one company for their entire career.
Instead, the boomers are much more likely to rely on 401(k) savings plans and other so-called defined contribution plans in which they assume all or most of the risks of investing.
Overly conservative investment choices, too much ownership of employer stock and the fact that 84 percent of people dip into their 401(k) plans each time they change jobs means that in the new world of retirement plans, many boomers will retire with too few resources to live the retirement life they want.
Of course, this system will also produce a few big winners among people who saved a lot or bought stocks that exploded in value.
How much will this matter? Lacking a crystal ball, the best indicator of what this will mean to future retirees is the insight scholars have gained into how money affects the happiness of people nearing retirement and those already retired.
The first finding is that people generally do just fine with less. Most people experience a sharp drop in spendable income when they retire, and most adapt quickly and easily, said Sylvester J. Schieber, the research director for Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a compensation consulting company, and a noted authority on pensions and Social Security.
In general, retirees do well if pensions, Social Security and savings replace 60 percent to 70 percent of their job earnings, percentages that Mr. Schieber said may be a bit higher than what people need simply to feel comfortable.
Problems arise when the drop in income is more severe, especially if it plunges a person down the social ladder.
According to Professor Skinner of Dartmouth, "There are a bunch of people who have done pretty well in terms of getting ready for retirement, some because of good pension coverage and some because of wealth."
But there is a large group of people -- perhaps 20 percent -- who seem to be walking into a brick wall at retirement, he said, discovering that their resources are woefully inadequate.
Ultimately, Professor Skinner said, how well-off people are in retirement is not an economic issue, but one of well-being and contentment.
"We don't know a lot about these issues," he said, "except that severely ratcheting consumption downward leads to stress and that people who don't save much die earlier."
Prof. George Lowenstein of Carnegie Mellon University, who is an economist and a psychologist, is one of the few scholars who have looked at how retirement income affects happiness.
Professor Lowenstein found that white-collar workers in low-status jobs enjoyed retirement more than either high-status white-collar workers or blue-collar workers. And he found that except for people who found themselves plunged into poverty, or into an income level so far below their working life style that their social status changed, most people are happy in retirement.
His surveys also found that people worry more about having enough to retire in the five years before they stop working than after they quit.
"The financial press and the mutual fund industry are telling people that you need to save a lot, that you should be worried, and people work themselves into a state of anxiety," Professor Lowenstein said. "But even though income drops after retirement and consumption drops even more, people find it is not nearly as bad as they expected. People adapt to adverse circumstances much faster than they expect."
He added: "The amount of misery they experience worrying about whether they have enough to retire is far out of proportion to the misery people actually experience after they retire."
Curiously, he observed, surveys show that people who have accumulated assets worry more about not having enough than do those with few assets. In that way, the shift from traditional pensions to owning assets and having to manage them is taking a psychological toll.
The least happy retirees, Professor Lowenstein said, are those forced into retirement because of layoffs or poor health. Indeed, poor health is by far the No. 1 factor cited among unhappy retirees. Baby boomers are expected on average to live a bit more than 17 years after reaching age 65, with those with more money enjoying better health and longer lives because of generally better medical care and diet and more healthful life styles.
Facts like that reinforce economists' tendency to equate greater wealth with greater happiness, Professor Lowenstein said, but a review of surveys from around the world shows such a relationship is weak.
A great divide may be coming, but he believes only those grasshoppers who have lived well and saved nothing so that their circumstances change drastically for the worse are likely to experience much psychological pain in retirement.
"Almost all the research," he said, "points to the conclusion that retired people, for the most part, are happy and satisfied with their lives to a degree that they had not anticipated prior to retirement."

HEADLINE: Rainy City, Sunny Mood

BYLINE: By DENISE FAINBERG; DENISE FAINBERG is a teacher and writer who lives in Bend, Ore.

 BODY:
ONE snowstorm after another had pummeled my high-desert home east of the Cascades in this winter of La Nina (who looked suspiciously like her brother, El Nino). Green leaves, soft air, early spring and a laid-back university town were temptation enough to bolt. The city of Eugene, on Oregon's mild side, was calling.
Situated on the Willamette (pronounced wil-LAM-it) River between the Cascades and the Coast Range, Eugene is informally called the Emerald City. With a population of 130,000, it's neither a big city nor a small town, but has the amenities of both: It's the state's main cultural and population center after Portland, and boasts a relaxed, environmentally oriented style of life. Recycling is a social obligation, and riding bikes and buses is at least as respectable as driving a car. (The bus system extends from the coast to the Cascades; university students ride free). 
 Livability makes it not only a good home, but an attractive weekend getaway. A generation ago, western Oregon was a magnet to hippies and back-to-the-landers; a lot of them are still there, older and grayer, and their legacy lingers in Eugene's organic food stores, arts scene and some local events. The Saturday Market, held from April to November, dates from the 70's, with everything from clothes (remember Indian drawstring skirts?) to organic vegetables to local crafts on sale. The Oregon Country Fair is a happening: a week after the Fourth of July, thousands of young people and counterculture veterans gather in a bucolic setting for three days of whimsy, music, food and art booths, exhibitions on alternative energy and housing, and general togetherness. Mimes and jugglers roam the crowds. In a sign of the changing times, the fair is now drug- and alcohol-free.
It was too early for all this when I headed over the Cascades late in February, but I cared little. Belying its reputation, Eugene's sky when I pulled in was sunny and blue. Crocuses budded along the sidewalks, and the quadrangles of the University of Oregon could have been shipped directly from the Emerald Isle. Green all year, the place is a riot of flowers in spring and summer, thanks in part to the 46 inches of rain annually. There's a reason, after all, that the University of Oregon football team is called the Ducks.
The other big state team, in Corvallis, is the Beavers. I like that about Oregon: Rather than aggressively macho panthers, bears or eagles, it represents itself with creatures that are inoffensive or downright cuddly. Why swagger?
Town and university grew up together. Settled by the pioneer Eugene Skinner in 1846, Eugene became a hub of the Willamette Valley, the fertile magnet for Oregon Trail followers. Soon timber edged out farmers' markets as the main moneymaker; today most of the active mills are across the river in Springfield, Eugene's alter ego. The university, since joined by several other colleges, is a large employer. Tourism is a third leg of the economic base (the microchip industry is a quickly growing segment, too); with the coast an hour away to the west, and Cascade mountain-recreation areas an hour to the east, Eugene is a comfortable and convenient base.
Having taken off on the spur of the moment, I found the homey, reasonably priced bed-and-breakfasts full, and checked into a predictable Best Western. The only surprise was that shower cap, shampoo, etc. entailed a special request and a trip back to the receptionist. Then it was out to dinner at the Cafe Soriah in Eugene's lively downtown.
Intimate and elegant, yet casual in a northwestern sort of way, Soriah offers a selection of Pacific Northwest and Mediterranean dishes. I enjoyed a garlicky garbanzo-stuffed eggplant and a glass of kir, but could, for example, have had seared tambo tuna, boeuf bourguignon or lasagne. It all looked good. Regretably, I declined dessert (including chocolate chunk cake, for $3.75.) and headed for the Bijou Art Cinemas.
A college-town classic, the Bijou specializes in art films and is housed in an old converted church. Instead of previews, you get a series of slides by local photographers, featuring Oregon scenery and the theater's mascot cats. One of these sat impassively by the entrance inspecting the clientele. If you wish, you can get nutritional yeast on your popcorn and organic fruit juice. To see "Life Is Beautiful," I sat in the nave, beneath long beams soaring to the ridgepole.
There are other entertainment choices: The town's intellectual mix provides something for just about everyone. The Hult Center, which is said to have some of the best acoustics on the West Coast, is the home of the Eugene Ballet Company, the Eugene Concert Choir, the Eugene Opera, the Eugene Symphony and the Oregon Mozart Players -- not to mention the Oregon Bach Festival, which takes place June 25 to July 11 this year. Clubs and pubs offer all kinds of live music, from Celtic to blues to rock to salsa.
Next morning, I headed down 13th Avenue for breakfast. The little streets around the edge of campus are naturally full of small cafes and restaurants; I chose Cafe Siena, an informal hangout specializing in crepes as well as American breakfasts and soups. It was a busy little place, full of young people waking up to the weekend. A simple but hearty dish of scrambled eggs, home fries and toast fortified me for the day, which was clearly reverting to its usual form -- i.e., gray and wet.
But there was another culinary stop I had to make. Eugene is the home of the Euphoria Chocolate Company, a premier brand in the Northwest and -- I can say as something of a connoisseur -- worthy of its name. The flagship store is at 17th and Willamette, not far from downtown. The goodies are pricey, though; I picked up a couple of truffles (hazelnut and Grand Marnier) for $1.75 each.
Shopping can be pleasant here even for congenital nonshoppers like me. You can find malls on the outskirts, but downtown is full of small and relaxed shops. Balladeer, an eclectic music store, is one I usually visit. You can find not just Celtic or Irish music, but Breton and Galician CD's. (I came away with a recording of accordion music from Brittany.) Across the way, the Fifth Street Public Market is an urban arcade in a renovated feed mill. It was originally a populist-alternative sort of shopping center, but has become more upscale of late, housing galleries, clothing boutiques, cafes and restaurants, and now a Nike store. Making a purchase is low key; at one musical instrument outlet, I took half an hour to choose among a few Baroque recorders, tootling merrily on each while the proprietors attended to other customers.
For other types of recreation, you don't have to go far. Several sizable parks provide opportunities for hiking, biking, bird-watching and botanizing. Skinner's Butte Park and Spencer Butte, each on an old volcanic hill, also allow terrific views up to the snowcapped Three Sisters and Mount Jefferson, each over 10,000 feet. The Owen Memorial Rose Garden, along the wide Willamette River, contains 4,500 plants that bloom through the summer. The city is bike friendly (20-year-old three speeds are common fixtures on lampposts and racks), with over a hundred miles of bike paths through the city, along the river and in parks. From spring through fall, you can rent a kayak or canoe on the Millrace Canal right in town.
But it wasn't spring yet, though camellias were beginning to bloom, opening like glorious, spreading stains against dark foliage. I chose the University of Oregon Art Museum, a collection housed on campus. The brick building has a vaguely Moorish aspect; an inner courtyard with garden and fish pond provides a quiet, contemplative center. It houses Pacific Northwest exhibits, but the main focus is its Asian collection, with rooms dedicated to Japanese, Chinese, Cambodian and Tibetan objets d'art. It has acquired some mingqi, Chinese funerary figures of humans and horses from the Han and Tang dynasties; I was more taken with the whimsical netsuke, small Japanese weights carved of stone or ivory in the shapes of fanciful animals or mischievous children. Also intriguing were casts of bas-reliefs from Angkor Wat. Demigods mounted on elephants marched through thick jungle with flocks of retainers, or held conclaves with their generals on the forest floor. Next to some Russian icons, a case displays unusual ecclesiastical art -- ornate crosses for liturgical use, and naive illustrations of Gospel scenes.
When I left the museum, the rain was coming down in sheets. Another winter storm was on the way. There was just time to burrow into the Fifth Street Market for a dish of hummus at Casablanca and a piece of chocolate cake from the Metropole Bakery. Cheerful Saturday crowds milled about the cafes and galleries. They knew how to spend a rainy Eugene afternoon. I had to high-tail it over the icy Cascades, ahead of the approaching tempest.
 
The road to the Emerald City
 
Accommodations
Eugene, which is 108 miles south of Portland on I-5, has abundant rooms in all price ranges. For the dozen or so bed-and-breakfasts, it's best to make reservations. Plentiful motels mean you can get a room almost anytime without notice, except at graduation in mid-June and on parents' weekend, May 14 to 16. The 9.5 percent room tax is not included below.
The Campbell House, 252 Pearl Street, Eugene 97401, (800) 264-2519, fax (541) 343-2258, was built in 1892 and resembles an old European country hotel with gardens. Some rooms have fireplaces and whirlpool. Doubles from $80.
I stayed at the Best Western New Oregon, 1655 Franklin Boulevard, Eugene 97403; (541) 683-3669, fax (541) 484-5556. Doubles from $72.50.
The Timbers Motel, 1015 Pearl Street, Eugene 97401, telephone and fax (541) 343-3345, is oriented to families and is downtown, within walking distance of just about everything. Rates: $38 to $69.
 
Dining
Cafe Soriah, 384 West 13th Avenue, (541) 342-4410, is a cozy spot for Mediterranean and northwestern dishes. Open weekdays 11 A.M. to 2 P.M., Sunday to Thursday 5 to 10 P.M., and Friday and Saturday 5 to 11 P.M. Dinner for two: $50 with wine and dessert.
Cafe Siena, 853 East 13th Avenue, (541) 344-0300, caters to a casual crowd. Breakfast and lunch: $2 to $6 a person. Open weekdays 6:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M., weekends 7 A.M. to 7 P.M.
There's plenty of choice at the Fifth Street Public Market, 296 East Fifth Avenue, (541) 484-0383. It is open 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., but cafes and restaurants have their own hours. Food choices range from ethnic snack bars to full-fledged restaurants. Casablanca, for example, serves Middle Eastern and Mediterranean dishes, salads and sandwiches ($3 to $7); (541) 342-3885.
 
Sightseeing
The University of Oregon Museum of Art, 1430 Johnson Lane, (541) 346-3027, specializes in Pacific Northwest and Asian art. Open Wednesday noon to 8 P.M., Thursday to Sunday noon to 5 P.M. A $3 donation is suggested.
Families with young children might want to check out the Willamette Science and Technology Center, 2300 Leo Harris Parkway, (541) 682-7888. It offers changing hands-on exhibits on subjects ranging from dinosaurs to atomic particles. Admission $4, children $3. Open Wednesday to Friday noon to 5 P.M., Saturday and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Adjacent is the Lane E.S.D. Planetarium (admission extra); (541) 682-7827.
From April to November, the colorful Saturday Market at 8th and Oak Streets offers a couple of hundred booths featuring local crafts, international foods and entertainment; (541) 686-8885. Open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
The Bijou Art Cinemas, 492 East 13th Avenue; (541) 686-2458. Tickets: $6 Thursday to Saturday, $4.50 Sunday to Wednesday.
The Hult Center, 7th and Willamette; (541) 682-5000.
Canoes and kayaks can be rented from March to October from EMU Waterworks Canoe Company, (541) 346-4386.
 The Oregon Country Fair is July 9 to 11; The Web site is www.efn
.org/ocf/.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Upstate New York May Get Air Fare Relief

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
FLYING between New York City and upstate New York, which can cost more than flying across the Atlantic, may get cheaper this fall, because investors in a proposed discount airline are working with a variety of elected officials to bring fares down. But there are formidable obstacles to the plan, and leisure travelers may not benefit nearly so much as last-minute travelers paying full coach fare.
High air fares are a hot business and political issue upstate, where Rochester has the fourth-highest air fares in the country, while Buffalo and Syracuse are among the 20 most expensive, according to Department of Transportation data. 
 In a recent search of air fares for tickets bought on short notice, it typically cost $384 to fly from Albany to La Guardia Airport and back the same day, or $1.39 a mile, while a same-day round trip from Albany to Miami on most lines cost $468, 19 cents a mile.
State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said that a subcommittee of the Economic Development Committee will be named in a few weeks to look into the situation and that a staff member was already collecting economic data.
Mr. Silver's inquiry follows complaints by corporations upstate that they are being gouged by the airlines. Eastman Kodak recently relocated some sales people from Rochester to Atlanta to take advantage of lower fares and more frequent service.
Upstate business and political leaders say the city whose air fares has attracted their interest is Providence, R.I., where the arrival in 1996 of the biggest and strongest low-fare carrier, Southwest, sent all carriers' average fares plummeting.
Southwest has shown little interest in upstate New York. But a group of investors, including George Soros, filed last month to start a discount airline that would use Kennedy International Airport as a hub. David Neeleman, the entrepreneur who has raised $130 million to start the airline, said he had promised that Buffalo, Rochester or Syracuse would be the first city his airline served.
Mr. Neeleman's airline does not have a name yet. But after he picks one, the airline faces the daunting task of persuading travelers that its fares are low enough to make it worth traveling via Kennedy instead of La Guardia, which is closer to Manhattan. Mr. Neeleman says Kennedy has fewer flight delays, which would compensate for the longer and costlier taxi ride.
The proposed new airline has powerful allies. In Washington, Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Charles E. Schumer, both Democrats, and four upstate Representatives have asked Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater to do whatever is necessary to insure low-cost air service for upstate cities.
Their Jan. 20 letter came three and a half months after a small low-cost carrier, Eastwind Airlines, gave up on Rochester after about two months of service to Boston, Trenton, Dulles Airport near Washington and Greensboro, N.C.
United and US Airways say their prices are fair and competitive. Richard Weintraub, a spokesman for US Airways, said upstate fares were high because most flights are under 300 miles and costs per mile fall as the length of flights increases. He said that the costs of operating 250-mile flights -- roughly the distance from Rochester to Philadelphia or Syracuse to Boston -- were about 25 percent more per mile than 300-mile flights and about twice as costly per mile as 1,000-mile flights.
US Airways and United call the Transportation Department air-fare data misleading because city pairs with mostly business travelers have higher average fares than those with mostly leisure travelers. "Average fares appear high for Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse because most passengers are on business fares," Mr. Weintraub said.
Representative Louise Slaughter, a Rochester Democrat who has been complaining that high fares are strangling business upstate, said: "Fares in western New York are subsidizing fares in other parts of the country that have low-cost competition. Fares really aren't going to come down until we get competition."
Tony Molinaro, a spokesman for United, denied that his airline used high fares out of upstate New York to subsidize fares elsewhere. But his remarks also lent support to the Congresswoman's point.
"We set prices according to a number of factors: supply and demand, population base in two cities, overhead costs such as landing fees, aircraft expenses, and competition is another big piece," he said. "To know if fares are high or not I would have to know what the competition is.
"But to compare upstate New York to Chicago to, say, Salt Lake City to Denver or Albuquerque to Denver would not be reasonable because of competition in those markets from Southwest, America West and other carriers. But it is not like we are looking at the whole country and saying these are low prices here in Utah so let's jack them up here in New York."

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 3-21-99 -- Questions for Abdul Hakeem Mujahid;
The Taliban's Man in the U.S.

BYLINE: By Amy Finnerty 

 BODY:
Q:
Has the adjustment to life in New York been difficult? 
 It was not difficult. Not for me, not for my family. I am living here in the Afghan community, so I didn't find myself among strangers. We are following the same culture, the same beliefs.
How are your children doing in school?
Excellent numbers! One of my boys is getting 99, 102. In my country you cannot get more than 100. He explained the teacher is giving about 100 marks and an extracredit question. So he is doing that one also. My daughter is in Muslim Center elementary school, but all of my boys are in public school.
It is good, but the way of education here, it is a little bit friendly. The teacher in all Islamic countries is more powerful. Here, the weakest is the teacher.
Do you allow them to watch television at all?
Sometimes, by chance, we see it, but the children are very busy with schoolwork, with family, with each other. They went several times on class trips, to museums and other educational trips authorized by the school. It's very important, very educational for them.
And what is life like in your neighborhood?
I am living here in the United States, in Queens, and I do not know the neighbors on the right or the left side. You know about the way of individualism here. One neighbor doesn't know the other one. In Afghanistan, neighbors will come to you, ask about you, who are you, what can they do for you.
Have you learned their backgrounds?
I think mainly they are Jewish people. With the small hats on their heads. Sometimes they are asking my son, because he wears a small hat, Are you Jewish? So much similarity we have with the Jewish people.
Is America a good place to rear children?
I think you have social problems. In Eastern societies, and Afghan society in particular, there are very strict social regulations.
Strict? Do you think they are too strict?
Yes, the masses, the public is too strict. For example, widows were forced to marry with the relatives of her dead husband. But this is Afghan culture, not Islamic ideology. I think when there is a competition between Afghan tradition and Islamic teaching, the tradition is the winner. And that is the Taliban plan, gradually to make public opinion for more and more freedom of the women.
Many Americans say your Government is too strict, not the people. What is your response to critics, like the Feminist Majority Foundation?
The Government in Afghanistan is running according to the will of 95 percent of the women there. If the campaign of the Feminist Majority were explained to Afghan women, Afghan women would find it ridiculous and insulting. They are neglecting the differences between the two societies. They are making our culture ridiculous, showing women wearing the burqa -- which most women in Afghanistan don't wear, but is a centuries-long tradition in Afghanistan. It is not Americans' right to impose their values upon us.
What is your impression of relationships between men and women in America?
From one side, they are very free. The freedom is a good thing. From another side, a woman is forced to use her own economic resources. For example, in our society, it is impossible for a woman to be used as a commodity -- or for publicity. But here, to sell one cigarette, she is being shown to the public from all different sides. For one cigarette.
Do you ever indulge in the local luxuries? What do you make of American culture?
Actually, I go only directly to the United Nations, here to my office, to my home. American culture has some positive and some negative aspects. But we don't want to criticize your society. We are a well-structured family, so we don't have any difficulty.
Have you read any books in English?
Only Shakespeare. And Henrik Ibsen. "A Doll's House." It has some positive points and some negative points.
And the end of the play, I do not like that. She wanted to start her first experience independently, by herself. This is the start of the separation between Western culture and Eastern culture.
So how would you have liked it to end?
Cooperating with each other. Amy Finnerty

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
As Caldor Leaves, Others Rush to Take Up Leases

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
A SIGN over the customer-service desk inside the 91,800-square-foot Caldor store on Hempstead Turnpike in Levittown read, "Committed to making you a satisfied repeat customer."
On the exit door, another said, "Come again soon. Thank you for shopping at Caldor." 
 But customers like Mae and John Fornasiero of East Meadow, who were wheeling a loaded shopping cart back to their car, knew better. There would be no coming back because the Levittown Caldor closed its doors last Sunday following a "going out of business" sale.
"I'm going to miss Caldor because it was convenient for us and had good value," Mrs. Fornasiero said. "Now we'll probably go to Wal-Mart, but that's 15 minutes farther away."
Long Island's 19 Caldor locations, from Garden City east to Bridgehampton, have been shutting down one by one following a decision by the Caldor Organization of Norwalk, Conn., in January to close all 145 of its stores in nine East Coast states. The Long Island stores will be closed by the end of May.
The discount retail chain, which sold everything from apparel to hardware, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1995 after competition from juggernauts like Kmart, Wal-Mart and Target, which sold essentially the same goods but had national clout and better management, began eroding its sales.
"Instead of competing with the giants, in my opinion, they should have found another niche," said Wilbur F. Breslin, the president of Breslin Realty in Garden City, which owns the 250,000-square-foot Carmans Plaza shopping center in Massapequa, which contains a 110,000-square-foot Caldor.
"We are sorry to see them go," Mr. Breslin added, "but the Long Island market is very strong, so if one store goes another usually comes in to replace it, which is what we fully expect will be the experience with Caldor."
In fact, 65 of Caldor's 145 locations, including 8 on Long Island, have already been spoken for "and we are making other deals as we speak," said Jeremy M. Sclar, a partner of W/S Discount Acquisition of Chestnut Hill, Mass., an affiliate of W/S Development Associates, a shopping center developer. The affiliate is assisting Caldor with the disposition of its real estate assets.
The eight Long Island deals, which have been approved by the Manhattan bankruptcy court overseeing the Caldor liquidation, include six locations for which Kohl's Department Stores of Menomonee Falls, Wis., was the successful bidder.
Kohl's is paying $142 million for a total of 33 locations -- 12 in New York State, 11 in New Jersey, 9 in Connecticut, and one in Baltimore. The six Long Island locations are in Levittown, Ronkonkoma, Melville, Deer Park, East Setauket and Shirley.
In addition, Wal-Mart will be taking over Caldor's lease in Riverhead. And Kmart will take over its Woodmere location.
WHEN retailers go out of business, the real estate they occupy is often a valuable asset even if they don't own it. A lease can give another company anxious to find large space quickly the opportunity to do so. And leases, which for large retailers typically extend over long periods, often were negotiated at rents below the current market rate.
If market rents currently are $18 a square foot annually, and a lease with 20 years to go calls for a $10-a-square-foot rent, the $8 differential could allow a company to pay as much as $80 a square foot for the right to take over that lease, estimated Stanley H. Schuckman, president of Schuckman Realty, a commercial brokerage in Woodbury.
Kohl's intends to spend an additional $165 million to refurbish its 33 stores. The renovated stores will open in the spring of 2000.
Gary Vasques, a spokesman for Kohl's, described the retailer as a "family-focused, value-oriented specialty department store selling moderately-priced national brand" merchandise.
Caldor's demise gave the 36-year-old Kohl's, which currently operates 213 stores in the Midwest and in the Mid-Atlantic region, the opportunity to enter the New York metropolitan area "with a critical mass of stores," he said.
Mr. Schuckman, the Woodbury broker, said newcomers need "critical mass" to enter a new market. When Caldor arrived on Long Island in 1982, he noted, it acquired a total of 14 locations, including some occupied by the Woolco Department Store chain owned by F.W. Woolworth Company. As Caldor's broker, Mr. Schuckman said, he helped arrange most of those deals.
Landlords and brokers, including Mr. Schuckman, say Caldor always did well on Long Island, with most of its losses occurring in upstate New York locations and regions like Philadelphia. High rents it paid for its New York City stores also hurt, they say.
The 95,000-square-foot Caldor in Oceanside was an example of a highly successful store, grossing $46 million annually, said Daniel H. Serota of Nathan Serota & Sons of Valley Stream, which owns the 212,000-square-foot shopping center where the Caldor store is situated. So far, no one has purchased the Oceanside lease, but Mr. Serota said he was not worried. "With the dollar volume they did there, someone will buy it," he said.
Landlords say that because of the strong economy, Caldor's closing could not have come at a better time.
"If I had a Caldor in a great location, I could make a phone call and have someone interested today," said Arthur D. Sanders, president of Spiegel Associates in Jericho, which owns more than a million square feet of retail and industrial properties on Long Island.
And most retail experts agree that the demise of the troubled retailer will have a positive effect locally. "It's bad for Caldor, but it's good for Long Island because the stores are being snapped up by good tenants," said Jeffrey Pliskin, the president of Pliskin Realty and Development in Carle Place.
THE Caldor situation is providing opportunities for major companies to enter or expand in an area that is one of the wealthiest in the country, said Steven B. Greenberg, president of the Greenberg Group, real estate consultants in Hewlett.
"There are limited locations on Long Island where you can find 30,000 square feet, and finding 110,000 square feet is a real challenge," he said.
The recent acquisition by Royal Ahold, the international food retailer, of 132 Pathmark Stores for $1.75 billion is another example of how a major company uses acquisition to broaden its market share in desirable locations, he said. Of the 132 Pathmark stores, 25 are on Long Island.
Keith Morris, director of community affairs for Wal-Mart stores, said the retailer's takeover of some of the Caldor locations "is a win-win situation for everyone."
"For us, it's a lot more cost efficient to go this route, and for a municipality it's a major economic boom to have a retailer like Wal-Mart move in," Mr. Morris said.
Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., successfully bid $72.9 million for 12 Caldor locations. In addition to Riverhead, they include one in Suffern, N.Y., six in Connecticut and four in Massachusetts.
Wal-Mart currently has stores in Centereach, Uniondale and Middle Island. The 112,000-square-foot Riverhead store, which Wal-Mart intends to totally refurbish, "gives us another presence to the eastern side of Long Island and was a great opportunity for us," Mr. Morris said.
Landlords are also hailing the changeovers. "When you have a large tenant going through serious problems, you worry," said Paul A. Bregman, a partner of the Bregman Organization in Plainview, which owns the 83,000-square-foot Ronkonkoma Caldor being taken over by Kohl's.
"What gives us a lot of confidence is to have a retailer like Kohl's, which has a good upscale operation and good financials, making such a commitment to the region," Mr. Bregman said.
The acquisition by Kohl's of the lease on the 113,275-square-foot Deer Park Caldor "is very beneficial to us as a shopping center," said Richard Birdoff, a partner of RD Management, which owns 250 shopping centers nationwide, eight of them on Long Island. "Caldor performed very well at our site," he noted. However, the fact that it had filed for bankruptcy protection "had a negative effect," he said.
"Kohl's is just a stronger company," summed up Stephen Lerner, a partner of Lerner Heidenberg Associates of Closter, N.J., which owns the 82,000-square-foot Caldor store in Shirley also being taken by Kohl's.
"We are not happy to see anyone go out of business," said Sam Jemal, a partner of Rockway Realty Associates in Manhattan, which owns the 450,000-square-foot Five Towns Shopping Center in Woodmere where a 110,000-square-foot Caldor is being taken over by Kmart.
"However, Kmart is one of the three top retailers in the country," Mr. Jemal said. "They have better brand recognition as a national chain, and the replacement is definitely a step up."
