HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Chamber Music, Traditional Arts, Virtual Sante Fe

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE B. JOHNSON; Lawrence B. Johnson is the music critic of The Detroit News.

 BODY:
WHAT began as a New York appearance by performers of the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival has evolved into a virtual weekend in the historic capital of New Mexico: a three-day musical and cultural holiday, beginning on Thursday, mostly within the confines of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And as befits Santa Fe, where controversy flows back through history to the city's founding in 1610, the music is likely to be accompanied by a note of political discord.
Chris Wilson, the author of the provocative book "The Myth of Santa Fe," will lecture on the emergence of the cultural profile that provides the city with its chief industry: tourism. David Warren, a Pueblo Indian and retired deputy director of the National Museum of the American Indian at the Smithsonian Institution, will discuss the Met's current exhibition of Indian art, "Native Paths." 
 Another hot topic: chili. Betty Fussell, a food historian, will retrace the converging influences of the Spanish and American Indian diets that shaped Santa Fe cuisine. Robert Morean, the owner of the Santacafe, and his chef, David Sellars, will bring a taste of the real thing, preparing an appetizer and main course for diners at the Mark Hotel, near the Met, on Friday and Saturday.
The idea of serving up Santa Fe whole came to Marc Neikrug, the artistic director of the chamber music festival, as he pondered the fact that neither his group nor its musical fare bore the unique stamp of their Southwestern locale.
"How do I make it Santa Fe instead of seven musicians from New York coming back to play at the Met Museum?" he said he had asked himself, referring to the likes of the pianist Max Levinson, the violist Cynthia Phelps and the cellist Peter Wiley. "Well, maybe we aren't all from New York, but you see the problem. Actually, it's the same problem everywhere. Travel around Europe, and see who's performing, and you'll find that 80 percent of the people who play concerts in the world live within five blocks of each other on the Upper West Side."
Since the conventional chamber music repertory offered no particular connection to Santa Fe, Mr. Neikrug said, he chose works for the Met concerts on Friday and Saturday that at least engaged ethnic issues: Brahms's G minor Piano Quartet, with its touches of Gypsy music; Hebrew songs by Ravel; the Third String Quartet of Viktor Ullmann, an Austrian Jew who perished in the Nazi concentration camp at Terezin, and a collection of Arabic songs composed by the young Egyptian baritone Kamel Boutros, who will sing them.
In Mr. Wilson's view, the absence of Southwestern and American music from Mr. Neikrug's programming is not an issue.
"Out of the whole range of activities in a given cultural setting," he said, "only a small proportion become public symbols of ethnic identity: usually cuisine, often architecture, sometimes music. New Orleans, for example, brings to mind the French Quarter, certainly the cuisine, jazz and zydeco music.
"But music in Santa Fe, a distant outpost in the period of the Spanish Baroque, largely consisted of a guitar and a fiddle playing dance music. Its history is one of struggle and defending against raids by Comanches and Apaches. It was a culture of poverty. The music was folkloric."
Paradoxically, Mr. Wilson said, European-style classical music has become an expression of modern Santa Fe. The summerlong chamber music festival has presented 26 seasons; the highly successful Santa Fe Opera has filled summer nights since its founding in 1955.
"For all its adobe appearance, Santa Fe is a very modern city whose citizens watch television and use the Internet," Mr. Wilson added. "A component of its population are followers of classical music."
Still, Mr. Neikrug said, he wanted to bring a vivid sense of Santa Fe to the Met. "I was left with the same question: How can I recreate as much of the Santa Fe experience as humanly possible without the audience being there physically."
For the answer, Mr. Neikrug, who was born in New York but lives in Santa Fe, turned to two fellow townsfolk, Mr. Wilson, an Iowa native educated at Yale University and the University of New Mexico, and Mr. Warren, who was born in the Santa Clara Pueblo, near Santa Fe, and earned a doctorate in Latin American colonial history at the University of New Mexico.
Mr. Warren said that his first impulse was to focus on Pueblo arts but that the richness of the Met's "Native Paths" exhibition prompted him to present a wider perspective on American Indian crafts.
"I would like to cause people to look at Native American art in slightly different ways than they might," he said. "For one thing, it's important to remember that the objects that the public in general regards as art were actually created for specific purposes, whether practical or ceremonial. The concept of esthetics isn't really a part of Native American culture."
And on that point rests a contemporary hot button. From the viewpoint of American Indians, Mr. Warren said, the wealth of material accumulated in collections like "Native Paths" represents an ancient patrimony. And increasing public consciousness of that view, reflected in the return of many items to Indians' hands, has stimulated what Mr. Warren called a cultural renaissance in American Indian society.
"This is just as true of the Pueblos as it is of other tribes throughout America," he said. "While it's quite important in principle that cultural and intellectual material be restored, it also has a direct bearing on contemporary cultural and artistic development. This is unprecedented, and the effects are yet to be fully appreciated.
"Thanks to the return of classical pieces, a revitalization of traditional arts is occurring that may not be immediately evident to the public. But there is a new force at hand, which is the Native American sense of responsibility to its own traditions. It's almost a paradox. The more rapid and complex and technological the world we enter, the deeper grows the sense of tradition."
Still, Mr. Warren added, American Indians in general -- more than 500 tribes across the country -- are not all clamoring to recover the objects of their patrimony now held in museums or private collections.
"Many tribes have said, for whatever reason, that they do not need to have them returned," he explained. "They are only concerned that the objects are properly cared for and to help the public gain a better understanding of the things they see. It's really a new relationship between the tribes and the museums, a mutual sense of responsibility."
MR. WILSON, in his book, grapples with a different sort of borrowing from American Indian heritage: the romantic image.
"Santa Fe is an El Dorado, an exotic outpost glowing in the sunset, a tourist magnet that has enjoyed a boom since the 1980's," he said. "And look what the mystique of Santa Fe is based on: Pueblo and Spanish culture. Yet those are the people of Santa Fe in need. It's not legitimate to use those icons as advertising images to attract people, then not pay attention to the people being displaced by gentrification and a real-estate boom."
Tracking the community's course from its founding by Pedro de Pe ralta as a Spanish territorial capital, Mr. Wilson's critical history underscores Santa Fe's character as a melting pot and analyzes the forces that have contributed to what he portrays as a conflicted and ultimately mythic self-image.
New Mexico was rejected in its bid for statehood several times before it was admitted to the Union in 1912, along with Arizona. At one point, Congress contemplated lumping the two territories together as a single new state, Montezuma.
Predominantly white America took a dim view of the predominantly Mexican and Indian mix of New Mexico, Mr. Wilson writes. Thus occurred a historic split in personality, as the state, holding out Santa Fe as its crown jewel, offered the look and feel of Anystate, U.S.A., to Congress while selling its Western exoticism to tourists.
In 1920, Santa Fe consolidated its bid for tourism by adopting what Mr. Wilson calls a myth that prefigured the Disneyland ideal: from that time forward, the entire community (or at least 90 percent of it) would present the same adobe facade to the world.
Or rather, stucco mixed with adobe pigment. But it would be one face, one lure, one myth.
"I do see that as symbolic of the larger problem, but I also have to say I feel a certain degree of optimism about the city," Mr. Wilson said. "I live there. I see its remarkable cultural vitality: the museums, restaurants, bookstores, opera, chamber music, the walking zones, the artist colony. And I think we're starting to see some understanding among our political leaders that they need to take an active role in counteracting displacement.
"Above all, I'm not trashing tourists and amenity migrants," he said, defining the latter as "people who move to nice places like Aspen, Colo., Santa Barbara, Calif., and Santa Fe."
"All of us take our turn at being a tourist," he said. "I'd just like to see people be more aware of the economic impact we can have, and not accept the stereotype."
Mr. Neikrug, the chamber music festival director, who has trimmed his role to that of cultural partner for this Santa Fe immersion, said: "I'd like to take something like this everywhere we tour. Everyone is looking for a broader experience. That's my goal with programming for the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, to offer dimensions beyond great music played well."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
First Accord Seen Near on Cleanup Reimbursement

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
TODD L. NORMANE calls the more flexible way the state works with developers to recycle polluted industrial sites "more like a handshake than a hammer." For the process includes a new financial incentive -- reimbursement for up to 75 percent of the cleanup cost.
Mr. Normane -- a lawyer at Maraziti, Falcon & Healy, a Short Hills firm that specializes in environmental and redevelopment law -- is representing Arc Properties of Clifton, whose project is the first approved for the reimbursement under the 1998 Brownfields and Contaminated Sites Redemption Act. A draft of the redevelopment agreement setting the terms of the reimbursement was completed earlier this month and the state and the developer are expected to sign an accord by the end of month, Mr. Normane said. 
 Arc is cleaning up the contaminants from a 30-acre site at the intersection of Routes 1 and 287 in the south-central portion of Edison Township in Middlesex County. At the same time, it is razing four interconnecting industrial buildings formerly occupied by a steel tubing manufacturer, which filed for bankruptcy in 1995, to make way for a 285,000-square-foot shopping center called Edison Crossroads.
The cost of the cleanup, plans for which have been approved by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, is estimated at $1.5 million; 75 percent of it, or $1.2 million, is expected to be returned to Arc under the reimbursement program, said Mr. Normane.
Eight tenants have signed on for all of the space at the project, which will cost a total of $25 million to develop. Among them are Home Depot, taking 138,000 square feet; Edwards Super Food Store, with 57,000 square feet; Worldwide Floor Coverings, 40,000 square feet, and Office Depot, 27,500 square feet. Completion is scheduled for early next year.
"The risk is always great in such redevelopment projects," Mr. Normane said, "but the reimbursement incentive helps to level the playing field and add a little more reward to the risk."
The 1998 brownfields act is the latest in a series of steps New Jersey has taken in recent years to facilitate the reuse of the 10,000 contaminated sites in the state, down from about 20,000 in 1985, that are the legacy of its industrial past. Of the remaining sites, about 1,130 are so-called brownfields --which the state defines as former commercial or industrial sites that are underutilized or abandoned and contain known or perceived contaminants -- that are being cleaned and redeveloped.
Besides the reimbursement, the act provides purchasers of tainted sites protection from private lawsuits related to past contamination problems and carries an assurance that the state will not sue once the site is cleaned according to its standards.
To qualify for the reimbursement, developers must, among other things, demonstrate that they were not the polluter, that their projects are economically feasible and that they will create jobs and fit with local, regional and state planning objectives.
The most important condition is that the projects must generate new tax revenue that exceeds the cost of the cleanup. The state uses projections of eight different state taxes, from sales to use and corporate taxes, to calculate a project's revenue.
DEVELOPERS must clean the site in accordance with a plan approved by the state's Department of Environmental Protection and enter a redevelopment agreement with the state approved by the Commerce & Economic Growth Commission and the state treasurer.
The agreement specifies the amount of the reimbursement and the frequency and duration of the payments. The latter is directly tied to the occupancy rate of the project.
"The aim is to entice developers to take a second look at abandoned and tainted properties that are not now producing revenue and get them back on the tax rolls," said Kelly A. Woods, deputy director of the Office of Urban Programs, within New Jersey's Commerce & Economic Growth Commission, which administers the reimbursement program.
"It's also a revenue neutral program for the state," said Ms. Woods, explaining that -- rather than go into the state treasury -- the taxes collected from qualified projects go into a special reimbursement fund and are filtered back to the project's developer. Thus, if revenue does not come into the state from the redevelopment project "the developer does not receive a penny," she noted.
Beyond the Edison project, applications for four others are in various stages of the review process and there have been pre-application meetings with developers for 13 more.
The success of the first project will be key, she added, because it will send the message that "the program does work."
Arc became involved with the Edison project in 1995 when it secured approvals from the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to buy the 30-acre tract. It closed the transaction last June. "The whole attraction to the site was its location," said Marc A. Perel, executive vice president at Arc.
He said that, along with being visible from and accessible to two major highways, the property was close to two regional malls and in a neighborhood of Edison that has been changing from industrial to retail use.
Contaminants on the site and in the groundwater include petroleum hydrocarbons and chemical solvent left behind from industrial users. "Though there may be easier sites to develop," Mr. Perel said, "ones of this size with this kind of location are difficult to find."
The former owner -- Berger Industries, the steel-tubing manufacturer -- had operated on the site for 14 years before it shut down in 1993, two years before filing for bankruptcy. Over the years other smaller companies also operated on part of the site, including a fragrance manufacturer. In recent years, sections of the 360,000-square-foot industrial complex Berger Industries once occupied were subleased to a collection of retail and commercial tenants.
BUT after Arc invested two years and over $1 million in the project Mr. Perel said it became apparent the magnitude of the cleanup was greater than expected. The company sought the reimbursement incentive last March soon after the state made it available.
"It became important to mitigate the cost overruns we didn't anticipate, making the project much more economically feasible," Mr. Perel said.
Under the cleanup plan, high levels of pollutants on portions of the property will be removed and carted off the site. Areas with low levels will be capped with an impervious surface.
What helped in pursuing the reimbursement incentive, said Mr. Normane, the lawyer, is that the Edison Crossroads redevelopment had all its approvals in place and tenants lined up, showing the viability of the project. In turn, he said, it will generate $4.5 million a year in sales taxes alone, which is $3 million more than needed to cover the cost to clean the property. He added that the property, when redeveloped, would create 800 jobs and rise in value to $31 million from $8 million.
Terri Smith, a legislative analyst at the Site Remediation Program, part of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, said Edison Crossroads "was a perfect match" for the reimbursement program and a good project for the state to support "because everyone involved stands to benefit."
Mr. Perel said the area's demographics also supported the project, which with its open-air design and collection of so-called big-box retailers, will be a "power center." He said some 280,000 people with an average household income of $69,000live within a five-mile radius of the site.
Richard Brunelli, who heads a retail brokerage in Old Bridge bearing his name, said the vacancy rate in strip centers and free-standing stores along the entire 30-mile Route 1 retail corridor -- where Edison Crossroads is situated -- had dropped to 6.3 percent by the end of 1998 from 7.7 percent a year earlier.
"There is demand in the Woodbridge-Edison trade area for another power center and for another half million square feet of space beyond that," he said.
(The International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan defines a power center as an open-air retail strip with 250,000 to 750,000 square feet of space and three or more big-box retailers.)
Mr. Brunelli added that with today's strong economy and real estate market developers across the state are tearing down old industrial complexes and replacing them with new uses.
"But often," he added, "the difference is making such projects economically feasible or not is the cost of the cleanup."

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
Mall Developers Battle for Regional Dominance

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
DEVELOPERS who have long contended with local detractors trying to block construction of malls in their communities now find themselves involved in another battle.
With a scarcity of land in the limited regions in the state where populations can support a mall, they are now campaigning against one another. 
 To gain or maintain dominance of a region, owners of new malls and expanding older malls are employing whatever means are at hand to take control of an area at the expense of smaller, weaker, or older malls. In economically depressed cities regional malls are welcomed as cash cows that will draw customers from miles around and jump-start the local economy.
In 1998, a year after the new 1.1-million-square-foot Brass Mill Center opened in Waterbury on the site of the historic Scovill Brass Works, the old 575,000-square-foot, 50-store Naugatuck Valley Mall closed down. Its anchors, Sears and Filene's, along with a dozen additional stores, moved a mile and half south into the new mall, and the remaining tenants left shortly afterward.
In New Haven, a plan for the 1.3-million-square-foot New Haven Galleria at Long Wharf was submitted to the city late last year, generating a lawsuit against it by the 794,000-square-foot Connecticut Post Mall, eight miles to the west in Milford, where fears of an inevitable drain on its customer base are intense.
Since 1986 the Wilmorite Corporation of Rochester had been trying to obtain approval for a 1.2 million-square-foot regional mall in Plainville, in the face of strong opposition by the Westfarms Mall in Farmington, five miles away. Eighteen months ago Wilmorite reduced its project to an unenclosed strip mall of 500,000 square feet, while Westfarms expanded by 300,000 square feet to 1.3 million square feet.
Wilmorite's subsidiary, Red Oak Associates L.P., has begun site work on what Al Friedrich, senior vice president of Wilmorite, calls "a $60 million Power Center -- a strip center with two or three large players." Kmart, Lowe's Home Improvement, and a Sony movie theater with up to 20 screens are committed and expected to move in late this year. The rest of the space will be marketed as 10,000 to 20,000 square foot stores, and surface parking for 3,200 cars will be available on the 77-acre site.
According to Mr. Friedrich, the Taubman Corporation of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., owner of the Westfarms Mall in Farmington, "publicly rejected our project at every level of development."
"Their adversarial activity delayed our project and enabled them to solicit and win over the same anchor department stores with whom we were negotiating," he said. "Once they expanded it changed all the market criteria."
Kevin Keenan, general manager at Westfarms, said that the company had indeed opposed the Plainville project, but he said he did not have the details. The Michigan headquarters did not respond to calls for information.
COMMENTING on the demise of the Naugatuck Valley Mall, Waterbury's Mayor, Philip A. Giordano, said: "It's been a tough year or so, but there's a light at the end of the tunnel. Louis Ceruzzi, a developer, is in the process of buying it. He plans to demolish it and built a new retail center in its place."
John L. Bucksbaum, executive vice president of General Growth Properties in Chicago, owner of the two Waterbury malls, said that he had had inconclusive discussions with Mr. Ceruzzi, who did not respond to telephone calls. General Growth owns 119 malls in 39 states, totaling 100 million square feet. It bought the Naugatuck Valley Mall from Naugatuck Valley Associates last year.
"We felt we could figure out other retail opportunities for developers who would be interested," said Mr. Bucksbaum. He suggested that "other retail formats that you wouldn't typically find in a mall -- big box stores, for example," could be successful where the old mall failed.
The lawsuit brought by Connecticut Post Mall L.P. of Milford was filed Jan. 20 in Superior Court in New Haven against the city, the South Central Connecticut Regional Planning Commission and its parent, the South Central Connecticut Council of Governments. The three entities reviewed the New Haven Galleria at Long Wharf project and approved it.
"It's a ridiculous lawsuit," said John DeStefano, Jr., Mayor of New Haven. "Milford doesn't want any competition, and they are doing what New Haven did to them in the 80's, when we intervened to stop the Post Mall from expanding in order to protect Macy's and our downtown retail development." Macy's closed in 1993 and the Milford mall doubled its size in 1991 to 793,900 square feet, and is currently expanding again by another 235,800 square feet.
Concerned about New Haven's needs, the Mayor said that "the major issue here is school improvement and construction, reduction of crime, and job creation," noting that in some parts of the city there was 12 percent unemployment. New Haven, he said, is the only Connecticut community to have been designated a Federal Empowerment Zone, through which it will receive $100 million over 10 years for whatever purposes it decides are important. Empowerment zones are created in areas of high unemployment.
"The mall," the Mayor said, "will bring 2,500 permanent jobs, 3,000 construction jobs, and $6 million in property taxes, half of that to be used to retire debt over 20 years." A sum of $60 million acquired through a state bond issue would be given to the city, which would repay the money out of property and sales tax revenues generated by the mall. The city expects to issue an additional $25 million in bonds, also to be repaid by mall revenues and taxes; the remaining $407 million of the total estimated cost of $492 million is to be raised privately.
THE lawsuit against New Haven and others charges that in approving the mall the defendants violated a 30-year-old regional plan that originally included a mall at Long Wharf, but was corrected to exclude it. A second complaint, according to Ronald J. Cohen of Tyler Cooper & Alcorn, a New Haven law firm representing the Milford mall, charges that repayment of state and city bonds is not sufficiently guaranteed. This constitutes "a boondoggle for a competing shopping center, completely skewing economic rationality," he said.
Joseph L. Rini of Hogan & Rini, P.C., the law firm representing the defendants, filed motions on Feb. 3 challenging the complaints, saying that "the Connecticut Post Mall does not have standing because it is not affected differently than any other retailer."
The New Haven mall will be built by New England Development Corporation of Newton, Mass., in partnership with the Fusco Family Partnership, an arm of the Fusco Development Corporation of New Haven. Arrowstreet Inc. of Somerville, Mass., architect for the Brass Mill Center in Waterbury, is designing the Galleria at Long Wharf.
Site plans and an application for a planned development district, an overlay zone that will supersede the existing industrial zone, were submitted earlier this month. They will be presented at public hearings before the Board of Aldermen and Planning Commission in April.
Commitments have been obtained from Nordstrom, Macy's, Filene's and Lord & Taylor as anchor department stores and parcels of land totaling about 100 acres are optioned, much of it for roads, according to William McCabe, general partner of New England Development Corporation, the mall's developer.
There will be 150 additional stores, 2,350 indoor parking spaces and 2,650 outdoor spaces. The three-story building will have as its signature eight steel squarerigger masts rising 120 feet in the air through a skylight, some 66 feet higher than the roof and topped with flags. They are designed to recall images of New Haven and Long Wharf's past as a major port.
Viewing the mall from Interstate 95 or the harbor will reveal the Pirelli-Armstrong Tire and Rubber Building standing squarely in front of the central portion of the mall. Built in 1969 and designed by Marcel Breuer -- noted for his Unesco headquarters in Paris and the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York -- its preservation was championed by the local Alliance for Architecture. It was listed on the Connecticut Register of Historic Places in 1997, and although it has no legal protection the developer agreed not to disturb it.
If construction on the mall starts in June as anticipated, it could be completed by the end of next year.
Rivalry among malls will continue and increase, said Mr. Bucksbaum of General Growth Properties. Competition in New England has been slower to develop, he said, "because of the high barrier to entry into the New England market."
Where malls serve as a catalyst for reviving cities with lagging economies, he said "they are the No. 1 or 2 tax contributor -- among the very few enterprises with the power to draw tens of thousands of outsiders into a community."
"From an economic standpoint, they are a very important source of revenue," he added.

HEADLINE: A Fan Saves an Art-Movie House in Baltimore

BYLINE: By CHARLES BELFOURE 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
FIVE years ago James Cusack, a fan of offbeat films, knew little about the movie-theater business. That changed when his nephew, John Standiford, told him that the Charles Theater, one of the city's two first-run art movie houses, was about to close.
Mr. Standiford, 34, was the assistant manager of the theater; his uncle has been a building contractor for the last 25 years. 
 "I had always gone to the Charles because I liked independent films more than the big studio movies," Mr. Cusack said. "I felt it would be a big cultural loss for the city if the theater closed." But the former operator of the Charles had walked away, abandoning its lease and leaving an intact movie theater, including projection equipment.
Mr. Cusack renegotiated the former tenant's lease with the owner, Bowling Inc., and reopened the 485-seat, 10,000-square-foot theater in 1994. Now he is about to complete a four-screen, 694-seat expansion of the Charles, using the rest of the space in a 23,000-square-foot building that was once used to garage and repair cable cars and then trolley cars.
 By putting together a $1.5 million package to finance the expansion, Mr. Cusack is not only giving Baltimore a new venue for nontraditional films, but is also bringing the first sizable commercial development project in four decades to a rundown section of Charles Street, Baltimore's main thoroughfare. The Charles Theater lies one block from Penn Station in a section that was once a major transportation hub.
The car barn was built in 1892 and used for its intended purpose until 1939. Then the United Electric and Railways Company sold the property to Bowling Inc., which wanted it used for entertainment activities. One initial tenant, at the south end of the building, was the Times Theater, the city's only all-newsreel theater at the time. Another tenant, at the north end, was a bowling alley.
During the 1940's a new second floor was built above the bowling alley, as the home of the Famous Ballroom, where jazz greats like Dizzy Gillespie and Buddy Rich played. The movie theater was renamed the Charles in 1958, and it became an art-movie house in the late 1970's. The rest of the space has been vacant in recent years.
Two years ago Alan Shecter, the vice president of Bowling Inc., gave Mr. Cusack a 40-year lease for the entire building. "I was impressed by Mr. Cusack's motivation and drive in operating the theater," said Mr. Shecter, who would not disclose the lease's terms. But then Mr. Cusack and Mr. Standiford had to find the financing for the expansion. They got help from Robert C. Embry Jr., president of the Abell Foundation, which provides money to organizations that promote economic growth here. The foundation agreed to guarantee a $720,000 loan from Mercantile Trust.
Help also came in the form of a $485,000 low-interest loan from the State of Maryland and a $79,000 grant from the Baltimore Development Corporation. Construction started a year ago.
 The building was put on the National Register of Historic Places last September and is eligible for the National Park Service's historic rehabilitation tax-credit program, which will raise additional equity to cover any cost overruns and pay down debt service.
To qualify for the program, the developers are restoring the original Romanesque Revival facade of the car barn. This involves the removal of a ceramic-tile facade added in the 1950's. It obscured three large windows with Romanesque arches.
Multiscreen operation is the key to survival in the movie-theater business, Mr. Cusack said, a lesson he learned soon after he took over the Charles in 1994. Without the current expansion, his business would have failed, he said. "With one screen, you're putting all your eggs in one basket to carry the business,' he said. "You don't have a move-over house to shift a movie." In a multiscreen building, when the popularity of a movie wanes it can be moved to a smaller screen and still produce revenue while a new film can be brought into the larger theater.
WITH Alex Castro of Baltimore as the architect, the space has been designed for four new screens with stadium seating. The new screening rooms will have 123, 151, 173 and 247 seats. In addition the original theater of 485 seats will be left intact and continue in operation, but its lobby will be available as sublease space for use as a cafe or restaurant.
The entrance will be relocated in the northern part of the building allowing the moviegoers to walk into a lobby 27 feet high, with the original theater to the right and the new screening rooms straight ahead. A box office and concession stand of glass, concrete and recycled industrial steel designed by an artist, John Maxwell, will greet patrons. The original brick walls will be left exposed in the lobby. A stairway will take patrons to a curving balcony leading to the top of the largest new screening room.
In late April the rebuilt Charles will open as host for the first Maryland Film Festival, which is to be an annual event presented by the Producers Club of Maryland, based in Baltimore, an organization that supports and raises funds for the State of Maryland Film Office.
It will run for four days, starting April 22, showing a mix of new films, documentaries and restored films. After the festival the theater will show first-run independent films as well as classic Hollywood and foreign films, as the Charles does currently. Its current offering is "The General," directed by John Boorman.
If the Charles succeeds, there is the expectation that new businesses will follow. "We would like to see more bar and restaurant potential once the Charles is up and running," said Jay Brodie, president of the Baltimore Development Corporation.
Although the theater is the most important project in the area, there are other evolving development efforts around Penn Station, according to Mr. Brodie. Amtrak is considering putting a hotel in the unused upper floors of the station as well as relocating the Greyhound station to a new facility in an adjacent parking lot. Three blocks to the south the University of Baltimore is planning a major expansion, including its first housing for students. There have been only a few isolated attempts to renovate the deteriorated housing to the east.
The Charles has developed a loyal following. Though the immediate neighborhood has had little new commercial investment, surrounding areas are more affluent, with the Johns Hopkins community a mile to the north, and the Maryland Institute College of Art four blocks to the south.
The presence of a new police kiosk now monitoring 20 new surveillance cameras in the surrounding blocks will, planners believe, draw many more people who were reluctant to visit an area they perceived as unsafe. In an attempt to lessen fears about car break-ins, there will be a reduced parking fee for patrons in lots surrounding the movie house.
One of the few historic elements on the interior of the car barn is a marble plaque with the names of the people involved in the original construction of the building in 1892. The last name listed will bring a smile to most Charles moviegoers. The superintendent of construction, John Waters shares the same name as the theater's most famous patron, the director John Waters, who is enthusiastic about the Charles's second life.
"The Charles is important to the cultural life of this city," said Mr. Waters, director of the 1972 cult classic "Pink Flamingos," whose latest film is "Pecker." "I know people who move out of cities because there aren't any good movies."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Restoring An Aging Bathtub

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
WHEN a car gets old and rusty you replace it. When a shirt gets stained and yellow you retire it. And when a carpet gets worn and shabby, you toss it out and get a new one.
But what do you do when the above conditions apply to an 800-pound hunk of porcelain in your bathroom?
"Did you ever try to get a bathtub into an elevator?" said Richard Toder, executive director of T/S Associates, a mechanical-systems consulting company in Manhattan. 
 Mr. Toder, a licensed plumber who has waltzed more than a few tubs out of tight corners, said that in addition to the logistical difficulties involved in hauling a cast-iron clunker out of a house or an apartment, replacing an existing fixture can also result in unexpected expenses when floor or walltiles are disturbed or broken or when a fragile old plumbing system must be replaced and brought up to code.
As a result, he said, it is becoming increasingly common for home and apartment owners to make the best of what they already have by restoring aging fixtures in place. And with coating materials and methods for applying them steadily improving, Mr. Toder said, there are now several cost-effective techniques available for refinishing, refacing, relining and generally rejuvenating deteriorating fixtures.
"If your tub holds water," he said, "restoration is probably the way to go."
The least expensive way to restore an existing fixture, he said, is to do it yourself.
"When economics are an issue, this would be the first approach," he said, explaining that homeowners can generally make at least a marginal improvement in the appearance of their fixtures by applying epoxy-based coatings made for that purpose and sold in most home centers.
But generally speaking, he said, such finishes do not hold up well and the quality of their appearance is dependent entirely on the skill of the amateur craftsman.
An alternative, of course, is to hire a professional and get the job done right.
"We do bathtubs, wall tiles, floor tiles, sinks and even toilets," said Francine Tumolo, an owner of Perma Ceram Enterprises, a Smithtown, N.Y., company that manufactures and distributes a "synthetic porcelain" reglazing product.
In most cases, she said, a bathtub can be reglazed with Perma Ceram in three or four hours and will be dry enough to use in 12. "To do a tub runs anywhere from $250 to $300," she said. "That comes with a five-year guarantee and a 15-year life expectancy." Ms. Tumolo said that her company could also reglaze ceramic-tile tub enclosures. "When we do tile, we spray right over the grout lines and seal them," she said. "That means no more scraping mildew with a toothbrush."
John Fred, president of Perma-Glaze Remodeling in Deer Park, N.Y., said that the finish material he uses is a polymer resin that provides the "look and feel of porcelain" when it cures. In most cases, Mr. Fred said, the first step in refinishing a bathtub or sink is to clean the fixture thoroughly, remove any existing rust or caulking materials, and fill any cracks or chips. Then, he said, the surface is "etched" with an acid wash to make it slightly porous, and primed with a rust-inhibiting primer.
The top coat of Perma-Glaze is then sprayed on, Mr. Fred said, and takes about 48 hours to fully cure. "We can accelerate the drying time with a heat lamp," he said, adding that in most cases, the Perma-Glaze top coat can be custom-matched to any color used by American Standard or Kohler, two large bath-fixture manufacturers. Perma-Glaze will also refinish wall tiles, Mr. Fred said, adding that the cost runs from $5 to $7 a square foot.
Donna Brennan, an owner of Worldwide Refinishing Systems in Ringwood, N.J., said that her company used a urethane-based finish originally developed for the aerospace industry. "We always use three coats," she said, adding that the finish material is sprayed on top of a special bonding solution applied after the surface is cleaned and etched. Ms. Brennan pointed out that since three finish coats are used, it is possible to completely change the color of the fixture being refinished.
"We've gone from hot-pink and black to all-avocado," she said. "And we have matching acrylic coatings that can be used to make any wood in the room match the fixtures."
Ms. Brennan said that homeowners should make sure that their refinishing contractor provides adequate ventilation of the potentially dangerous fumes that may result from the refinishing process.
"We use a filtered system that uses flexible tubing to vent fumes from the bathroom to the outside," she said. She cautioned that while mounting an exhaust fan in the bathroom window might remove fumes, it was also more likely to draw dust particles from other areas of the house and then deposit them in the finish coat on the fixture.
Ms. Brennan pointed out that, aside from the quality of the refinishing material used, the most significant determinant of the longevity of the restoration is the manner in which it is cleaned. "You should never scrub," she said. "And you should always use a nonabrasive cleaner."
For those who want a more durable finish than can be obtained by re-glazing, Ms. Brennan said, relining may be the answer. "Our tub liners start at around $700," she said.
With a tub liner, the existing tub is encased in the liner.
Linda Brakel, vice president of franchise operations for Bath Fitter, a liner manufacturer in South Burlington, Vt., said that her company could manufacture one-piece, quarter-inch-thick liners that are custom-tailored to fit each customer's tub.
"We have literally hundreds of molds," Ms. Brakel said.
The liners, she said, utilize existing plumbing connections and faucets and are typically indistinguishable from stand-alone bathtubs. And to complete the custom-made appearance, Ms. Brakel said, Bath Fitter franchisees can also install matching one-piece tub surrounds.
"It's completely seamless all around and from tub to ceiling," she said, adding that a typical tub-and-wall installation could run anywhere from $1,500 to $1,800. And though it may take a week or two after measurements are taken for the franchisee to install the unit, the actual installation can usually be completed in an afternoon.
Notwithstanding similar installation-time claims by nearly all re-finishers and reliners, Ms. Tumolo of Perma Ceram in Smithtown offered one final bit of advice applicable to all homeowners contemplating face-lifts for their bathtubs. "Bathe before we get there," she said.

HEADLINE: What Lies Ahead In White Plains?;
As a $175 Million Project Appears to Weaken, Many Merchants' Plans May Be Dashed

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
FOR struggling merchants in this city's downtown, hope for an economic recovery in what was once known as the City of 1,000 Stores is dimming again.
A proposed $175 million retail, entertainment and housing complex -- seen as the key to revitalizing downtown White Plains -- appears to be running into difficulty. After a series of delays and uncertainty over prospective tenants, Tishman Speyer Properties of Manhattan has sharply reduced the project's scope. Documents filed with the city show that the developer has cut to three from six the number of properties it wants to acquire. 
 Steven M. Wise, a senior project director, said the company is worried about recent glitches in the economy and the intense competition -- some of it from the Internet -- developing for consumer dollars.
"Clearly, we were disturbed at what happened at the end of last summer on Wall Street," Mr. Wise said. "We're rethinking and repositioning ourselves." The company, he added, fears the impact of on-line business transactions on traditional retailing.
As a result, city officials and merchants have increasingly expressed concern in recent weeks that their downtown's rebirth may yet be a long way off.
Last winter, news that Tishman Speyer and Sony/Loews would build one of the nation's largest movie theaters in the abandoned Macy's department store here -- and would combine the theater with upscale retailing, restaurants and apartments -- prompted officials and business leaders to predict that the complex would foster more development.
But the euphoria was short lived, and a pall has again settled over Mamaroneck Avenue -- the main downtown thoroughfare where retailers and restaurateurs have seen the number of empty storefronts increase. As is the case in many other small- and medium-size cities in America the malls here have thrived while the downtown has withered.
"Like I have for the past two and a half years, I'm surviving," Jose Ortiz, one of the owners of Nicoluna, a Mexican arts and crafts store, said last week. "But I can't say for how much longer."
Tishman Speyer's plans originally called for 540,000 square feet of retail, entertainment and restaurant space and 450 units of rental apartments and 2,350 parking spaces. As the developer, Mayor Joseph M. Delfino and Loews announced in February last year, a central feature of the project was to be a 24-screen, 5,200-seat megaplex theater operated by Loews Theaters, a Sony Retail Entertainment company.
By last December, however, Tishman Speyer announced delays and said the complex, expected this year, would not be built before the turn of the century at the earliest. Construction has still not begun, and final plans have yet to be submitted to the city. Mr. Wise said the company was still negotiating with potential restaurateurs and merchants.
One White Plains business leader, who agreed to speak only on the condition of anonymity, said the developer had courted Fortunoff and Filene's Basement to no avail and was probably encountering difficulty finding other retailers. Mr. Wise declined to comment on that.
In recent weeks, there has been more worrisome news from Tishman Speyer. Late in February, the company wrote to Mayor Delfino, saying the developer intended to acquire fewer properties.
As Rita Z. Malmud, a City Councilwoman, said: "We're all very confused. We don't know what this means." Mrs. Malmud said the city had indicated its willingness through eminent domain to help Tishman Speyer acquire the six properties it needed for the housing portion of the project. News that the developer was no longer seeking the city's assistance, she said, "sent a chill down our spines." She added, "We're all going to be very disappointed if this project doesn't happen."
Merchants also expressed confusion. At Gatsby's, a men's clothing store, Edwin Vega, the manager, said renovations to the store were on hold. "We're waiting for something definite to happen across the street," he said. "It's taking a long time, and no one seems to know what the situation is."
Antonio Lacarbonara, owner of Antonio's restaurant, said he was also depending on the movie theater project to give his business a boost. "I'm trying to support a family," he said, explaining that his lunch business was faring well but that the theater and shopping complex promised to bring customers to the downtown in the evening and on weekends.
Mr. Ortiz at Nicoluna was especially worried. The store he rents is among the six properties that Tishman Speyer had said it intended to acquire. Either way, he said he is facing problems. If the developer acquires the property, Mr. Ortiz will have to move, with the likelihood of higher rent elsewhere. If the project stalls or is scaled back, his business will continue to struggle.
Only a few shopkeepers said they would thrive no matter what happens. Like Neal Gerstein, the owner of Kids Specs, an eyeglass store for children and young teen-agers, some merchants described their businesses as "destination stores" -- where customers shopped because they needed a particular item, not because they were passing by. "My business will survive no matter what happens across the street," the optometrist said.
Several entrepreneurs accused the city of not aggressively encouraging new business and failing to meet the needs of small merchants. In that sense, too, the businessmen said, the current situation was a repeat of the past where there were promises of better times to come and no results.
In response, Mayor Delfino and Councilwoman Malmud said the current administration had actively courted Tishman Speyer from the beginning and continued to do so, and at the same time it was addressing the needs of individual shopkeepers.
"In many situations, a city is the stumbling block, but that's not the case here," Mr. Delfino said. "The economy has slowed down, Tishman Speyer is relooking at the project and we have no choice but to wait to see what will happen."
Meanwhile, some say the city has never looked so down and out. "Over the years, I've seen White Plains go through many changes," said Alan Weinberger, owner of Handy Andy, a store that sells window treatments near Mamaroneck Avenue, "and I can't remember ever seeing so many empty storefronts as there are today."
Yet others say there are signs that a rebound is in the making. On Mamaroneck Avenue in recent months, the Westchester Council for the Arts recently moved into an empty bank building, Foot Locker opened where its ailing parent company Woolworth's stood and a Kinko's copying store took over space from a former Wallach's clothing store.
But what will actually happen is difficult to predict, observers said. Malachy Kavanagh, a spokesman for the Manhattan-based International Council of Shopping Centers, said significant changes are ahead in the retailing and entertainment industry, causing many developers to rethink strategies.
"Everyone these days wants a Disney-esque experience," Mr. Kavanagh said, citing the 1.9 million-square-foot Palisades Shopping Center in Nyack with its IMAX Theater, skating rink, Ferris wheel and amusement park. "It's happening because there is extreme competition today in the retail business."
Mr. Wise described a trend toward "entertailing," combining entertainment with shopping. For the proposed downtown complex here, Mr. Wise said it was especially important to find the right mix of entertainment, dining and retail establishments.
He denied reports that a overabundance of movie screens in Westchester had prompted Tishman Speyer to reconsider its project. About 130 new screens are being planned or seriously considered in communities like Port Chester, Tarrytown, Cortlandt, Elmsford and Ossining. The county now has 65 movie screens.
That trend mirrors what is happening elsewhere, with more than 2,000 screens opening across the United States last year, the most ever in a single year. Statistics also show that Americans went to the movies 1.4 billion times last year, spending $6.4 billion in tickets.
At the same time, the movie industry is going through a major change, transformed in recent years by new technologies ranging from computerized dinosaurs and other special effects to the collection and analysis of box office data. And within two years, movie theaters are expected to begin installing the first generation of digital projectors.
As Mr. Wise explained, "We have to plan not just for today but for tomorrow as well."

HEADLINE: Shelton or Huntington, What's in a Name?

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
WHEN it came to naming towns, settlers in Connecticut played it pretty safe. They simply named most of them for the communities they had left behind in England (Greenwich, Manchester, Oxford), some for biblical places (Bethlehem, Goshen), and a few for heroes of the new world (Washington, Madison). Most likely, the theory was that if a place got a nice name, it would last forever. And then there is Shelton.
In a way, Shelton is Connecticut's what's-in-a-name town. Or perhaps that should be what's-in-two-names town. In any case, it is the only town, out of 169 in the state, to change its name from that of one man to another, from a leading patriot of the 18th century named Huntington, to a leading industrialist of the 19th century named Shelton. 
 For most of this century, the town has been coping with the name problem it inflicted on itself. And particularly in the past few decades, many residents have opted to say they are from Huntington -- the town's first settlement area, which still looks like a picture postcard of rural New England -- rather than identifying themselves as being from Shelton, the section along the Housatonic River that became a industrial powerhouse in the last century and then faded into a cluster of grimy old factories.
"Today, 90 percent of the people in this town say they live in Huntington," says Beverly M. Brown, the town clerk of Shelton. "Sometimes I think we should change the name back to Huntington."
A recent news story out of Shelton might be used to demonstrate the dual-name nature of the town. The story was about what happened when the father of a 10-year-old girl objected to a sight to which the child was subjected when on the school bus: a full-scale reproduction of Michelangelo's David that adorns the grounds of a spiffy office park, Enterprise Towers. The statue of David, of course, is as nude in Shelton as it is in Florence, Italy.
In the accounts of what might be called the Battle of the Bare David, the location of Enterprise Towers is listed as Shelton, which is correct. But what is also correct is that if you asked most citizens of the town where Enterprise Towers is situated, chances are you would get the answer, "Oh, that's in Huntington," as if Huntington were a separate community out there somewhere, not simply the oldest section of Shelton.
The story of the town that changed its name, and now might wish it had not, goes back to 1789 when a new community was officially incorporated on land taken from the older town of Stratford. The name selected by the original settlers was Huntington, for Samuel Huntington, and that was a fine choice.
You couldn't find a more revered name for a new town in Connecticut at the time-- except perhaps Washington, but the Father of Our Country had a Connecticut town named for him 10 years earlier.
In 1789, Samuel Huntington was the governor of Connecticut, serving the fourth of 10 consecutive one-year terms before he died in office. Of even more note, he had been a very important person during the Revolutionary War, first as a signer of the Declaration of Independence, later as president of the Continental Congress when the Articles of Confederation went into effect, creating a unified country. Even today, particularly in his home town of Scotland in the eastern part of the state, he is regarded by some as the real first president of the United States, George Washington notwithstanding.
In any case, in 1789, Mr. Huntington was undoubtedly honored by having a town named for him. And a fine town it was, an uncluttered place of farms and gently rolling hills, leading to the Housatonic River on the east and with the green, to the west, situated far from the water. In the census of 1850 the town's population was listed at 1,301.
In the second half of the 19th century, however, the section of the town along the Housatonic would become an industrial powerhouse, primarily because of one man: He was Edward Nelson Shelton, born in Huntington in 1812 and a very rich man by the time he was 40. His first major venture was the Shelton Tack Company, making products that turned out to be as valuable as gold during the gold rush in California. A pound of gold there was worth $192; so too was a pound of tacks from Connecticut.
After the Civil War was over, the enterprising Mr. Shelton decided to harness the power of the river at the back door of his hometown. He organized, and was first president, of a water power company that built a dam across the river from Huntington to the community of Derby on the other side.
He was hands-on in his approach. According to a history of Shelton published by the League of Women Voters, Mr. Shelton "promoted industry along the section served by the new dam, using every means at his disposal. He furnished capital to companies that would build there, offered favorable water power franchises, and even built factories."
The effort was well worth it. What resulted was a boast by the town that its riverfront was "a mile of busy factories making everything from pins to pianos."
There was a cost, of course. Shad fishermen to the north of Huntington had warned that the dam would ruin their fisheries. And it did. In addition, the color of the river water at Huntington was constantly changing, depending on what chemicals were being discharged from the mile of busy factories. But no one was bothering much about such matters at the time.
Edward Shelton was so identified with the success of the dam that the waterfront area of mills and adjacent enterprises became known as Shelton and in 1882 became a borough of Huntington under that name.
Edward Shelton died two years later, at the age of 82, with his legacy secure: a town that had grown considerably -- the census of 1900 listed the population at 5,572 -- and was prospering mightily because of the industry on the river.
In 1915, with a huge war starting in Europe, and the mills on the Housatonic throbbing with activity, the waterfront borough of Shelton was incorporated as the city of Shelton for the same reasons other mill towns created cities within their borders: The congested factory and commercial areas needed more fire and police protection, sewers, sidewalks, social services, and a political entity to provide them.
Unlike other Connecticut towns that established cities within parts of their territories but kept their original town names, the political leaders of Huntington decided to sever the original name.
A townwide vote was held on changing the name of the entire town to Shelton. It passed, and was submitted to the state's General Assembly for approval, a legal necessity. On April 15, 1919, the state legislators voted to change the name.
As if by magic, the town of Huntington no longer existed, replaced by a town named Shelton, creating a name change on maps and unquestionably a bonanza for lawyers working on real estate documents.
The name of Huntington lived on, unofficially, as the section of the town to the west that contained the old town green. Shelton, nee Huntington, flourished during the postwar period but suffered in the Great Depression when industry nearly came to a standstill. At one time, a quarter of the population was on some sort of public assistance and some companies shut down forever. Business picked up during World War II and the cold war that followed but some of the mills were becoming obsolete. And the worst was yet to come.
Toward midnight on March 1, 1975, a series of explosions and fires destroyed a plant of the Sponge Rubber Company on the river in what the F.B.I. later described as the biggest case of industrial arson ever in the United States. No one was killed but nearly 1,000 people were suddenly out of work. The city was declared an economic disaster area.
In the nearly quarter of a century since, the population of Shelton has increased steadily -- the 1990 census recorded it as 35,418 -- but not in the old downtown and industrial section by the river.
The growth has come in the outlying sections known by such enticing names as White Hills, Sunnyside, Pine Rock Park and, ah yes, Huntington.
To a great many residents of the town, the Huntington section -- with its blend of lovely old green, stone walls, stately homes, meandering brook, coupled with a modern golf course, new houses on spacious lots, enterprise zone for industry, low-key commercial development, even a full-size statue of David -- represents Shelton, not the grimy old downtown and industrial area over there on the river.
Indeed, many residents of Shelton, no matter where they live in the town, identify it as Huntington.
It is a matter of status, of course. "There's a lot of class differential in this town," says Beverly Brown, the Town Clerk. "Real estate people never, never mention the word 'Shelton,' here," she adds.
Mayor Mark A. Lauretti does not enjoy talking about the name aspect of his town. "Oh, oh," he says when it is first brought up. "I try not to get into that issue too much." But he is an agreeable man, and good politician, and explains that he thinks the latter-day substitution of the name Huntington for Shelton "kind of involved the promotion of the town by real estate people. It's easier to portray the residential development in the outskirts, from an image standpoint, than a blue-collar mill town.
The back-to-Huntington movement, he adds, "is a long standing joke in town. But most people are not serious about it. If you don't pay too much attention to it, it might disappear. One never knows."
Besides, says the Mayor, things are looking up for the part of the town on the Housatonic. "We're doing great things on the river," he says. "We have a huge rehabilitation project going on, between the state and the town. And downtown is alive and well. The vacancy rate is way down and we've got lots of interest by private developers."
At age 44, he is in his fourth term as Mayor and says he is going to run for a fifth term in the fall, no matter what anyone calls his town.

HEADLINE: Q&A/The Rev. John Thompson;
Battling for Children's Lives Amid a War

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IT could have been Germany in the 1940's, but it is Sierra Leone today. Soldiers arrive at the door searching for people to conscript or shoot. Upstairs people silently huddle together, hearts racing.
This is the Sierra Leone that the Rev. John Thompson knows. He was sent there by the Salesian Provincial House in New Rochelle, where he is based. Born and raised in the Panama Canal Zone (his father was American, his mother had British citizenship) Father Thompson came to the United States in 1965 and did his seminary work in Goshen in Orange County. He studied philosophy and was ordained as a Salesian priest in the Roman Catholic Church in 1979. 
 Since 1980, he has worked on various assignments with the Salesians, first in Liberia and now in Sierra Leone, which has a continuing civil war. A monitoring group established by the Economic Community of West African States, known as Ecomog, restored a civilian government after a 1997 coup, but rebels remain active. Father Thompson, 48, works with street youths in Freetown, which has not routinely been under rebel attack; his ministry has about 150 children in programs. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Father Thompson, who expects to return to Sierra Leone next month:
Q. What is the Salesian philosophy?
A. The Salesians of Don Bosco are about 100 years old, specializing in taking care of poor and abandoned youths. They run schools, especially vocational schools, and youth centers and street children's programs for poor and abandoned youths.
Q. When one hears that even United Nations monitors are committing atrocities in Sierra Leone, how can you keep from becoming immobilized?
A. I guess you have a calling to be a missionary and when the war gets close to you and you start seeing mutilations, start seeing the useless slaughter of people, it's tough. But you go on because the war is there and you have to. I don't know, it's not everyone who can do that. And then, of course, you have all the other problems there. I can tell you that the monitoring group does have its failings. They do kill rebel sympathizers instead of taking them prisoners. But they also take a lot of them prisoners; the other side does not. The rebels mutilate left and right, torture and kill.
Q. You must wonder how people can do these things to one another?
A. You're always thinking that, especially when you talk about mutilations. You're talking about people taking a machete and chopping people. One man I know of was hit 15, 16 times with a machete. I've seen many people brutally hurt like that. You think war is just so terrible. And especially when we're talking about the rebel side, a lot of them use drugs when they go into battle. Uppers and at times Valium, and most of them are all smoking marijuana.
Q. What is this war doing to the children?
A. You have children who have missed their childhood and are being thrown into being murderers. I have seen so many 11-, 12-, 13-year-olds who start out with the rebels by carrying the guns and ammunition. Later on they learn how to fire the guns, and they become full-fledged commandos when they are 13, 14 and 15.
Q. At that age is it a macho reaction?
A. Yes. It gives them such power. I have seen a 13-year-old boy stand in front of a person who was his total superior, his chief in the village and go to a tribal chief and yell at that chief, Sit down, do this. With the gun, he's now god. He can say, "Girl, come here and take all your clothes off." There is tremendous power. And when they feel that, they are so happy; it's a narcotic.
I have seen nice girls all of a sudden hanging around with these guys because they want a few diamonds or whatever. Even they start changing and acting very bad. I have seen such terrible changes. But then on the other hand, what we are doing is taking kids and getting these ex-killers and seeing if they can be rehabilitated. And surprisingly some of these kids really are not just as devastated as we would think. Some of them come back to society, with love and some discipline. It just keeps hope out there. But when you see them doing these things it's so terrible.
Q. Who are these children?
A. Our children are the kids who sleep in the marketplace. Our kids are market street children who have either left their families or been thrown out by their families or are war orphans.
Q. Are they killers themselves?
A. Our children are not involved in any fighting. The war has not been heavy in Freetown, where we're located, until recently. The danger is that our children will get abducted by the rebels. Then they have them start carrying the loads. After a while they say, Fire this, fire that and say, "We're fighting for a better Sierra Leone." Then when the kid gets the gun in his hand, he feels the power. Some of the kids say, I'm not going back to my family. Others want to go back to their families.
They're hoping to get young men. Four of our boys were abducted, but all four returned to us, two within about three or four days, the others within a month. In other words, when they had a chance, they escaped. That already shows a good thing. Instead of becoming a good rebel they came back to us. That gave us great hope.
Q. How old are the children you work with?
A. Ages 10 to 17 are the main ages for our night shelter. We take these children, only boys at this time, and try to give them reading, writing and arithmetic. Then we try within six to nine months to put them back into regular schools and back with their families, maybe an aunt or an uncle. If that doesn't work, we stay with them another year, and then we try again to put them in foster families if it doesn't work out with their own families. And we have a program begun this last August for the older boys, 17 to 25. These are the big young men on the streets who don't have jobs.
Q. If there had not been a civil war, Sierra Leone, because of the poverty, would still need these kinds of services, correct?
A. The war brings more onto the streets but even without the war, Sierra Leone is comparable in poverty to say, Haiti in the Western Hemisphere. Sierra Leone is about the poorest country in Africa. It does have the wealth of the diamonds, which a lot of white people are jumping at and trying to get at, even black people, too. But the country is dirt poor and had a problem with street children even before the war.
Q. These children may be relatively street smart, but aren't they still children who need love and the other things children generally need?
A. You know, it's funny; all that is there. When you see them on the street, they're dancing with us, they're shouting, singing and they have a life. They're living. They're not always looking terrible. They're happy. But when we start interviewing them and asking them questions about families, they're all saying the same thing: I want to get back to my family, or my father doesn't love me, my mother doesn't love me.
They really just want a stable place and some happiness in their lives, and they also want to get back into school because they see many schoolchildren passing them every day. While they may taunt these schoolchildren, they secretly admire their life.
It's a sad situation. It's aggravated by the war. But when you start working with them you can see a lot of progress and hope. In Liberia and in Sierra Leone, we have been so bolstered by our children. We have a three-floor building in Middletown, about four blocks from the American Embassy. The rebels came around our building outside with their guns looking for people, shouting. Our children were up on the third floor dead quiet. Nobody would talk, and the staff was with them. And our children had to sneak in and out for two or three days until the rebels were driven out by the Ecomog forces. We were so fortunate because so many times the rebels were right at our door, and they could have found out we had 125 kids, a gold mine for their kind of labor. It was our Lord taking care of them.
Q. It sounds so much like people hiding out from the Nazis.
A. It's just like that. If you revere life, you don't want to be abducted. And let's say they were to catch our 125 children. To get their attention quickly they may tell a couple of kids to put their arms on the block and then cut off their arms, just to get the attention of the other kids that they better do exactly what they are told.
Q. What should the United States or individual Americans do to help?
A. I really think the U.S. should actively help the forces of good against the forces of evil. The democratic-elected government is for peace. I'm not against investigating crimes on both sides, but the Ecomog forces basically have restored the legitimate authority and are generally going by law and order.

HEADLINE: State's Insurance Industry Reinvents Itself

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
THE darkest clouds have finally parted over Connecticut's insurance industry. Mergers are smaller; layoffs are a sprinkle of what they were earlier in the 90's, and many companies have begun hiring again.
Still, the gloom hasn't completely disappeared, and the industry's future, say economists and analysts, won't ever be as bright as in decades past. 
 "The shakeout is over, the restructuring is over, the situation is not going to get much worse," said Kevin H. McIntyre, a senior economist with Regional Financial Associates, an economic forecasting firm in West Chester, Pa. "But most of the jobs that are gone in insurance in Connecticut are gone for the foreseeable future."
That means the end of an era for the state and especially for Hartford, often called the insurance capital of the world, though for reasons that have to do more with history and hyperbole than with statistics.
Never again will a thick queue of somber suits walk each weekday -- the poet Wallace Stevens was once one of them -- to insurance jobs from downtown Hartford neighborhoods like Asylum Hill.
Never again will Aetna be "Mother Aetna," a once-common reference to the insurance giant's now-abandoned, job-for-life paternalism.
Never again will Hartford depend on the heads of the city's largest insurance companies, known as "the bishops," who, along with a few other corporate leaders, guided the state capital as much, if not more, than any city council.
"All that's gone: the influence, the way the companies operate, the corporate culture," said David A. Ivry, a professor emeritus of insurance at the University of Connecticut in Storrs and at the University of Hartford. "It's not coming back either," he added. "The industry has shrunk and changed."
Indeed, statewide employment among insurance carriers based in Connecticut, excluding insurance agents, is still less than it was in its heyday of the mid-80's to early 90's. And it has only increased by slightly less than 2,000 since the recent low of 58,000 in 1995, according to Regional Financial Associates. The current level of 60,000 jobs is approximately how many were employed in 1984.
The projections aren't much better, either. The industry may post a net gain of only another 4,000 jobs in the state by 2010. That still leaves it 6,500 positions shy of its high of 70,500 in the spring of 1991.
That estimate, however, hasn't dampened the civic and economic enthusiasm these days in beleaguered Hartford, where about three-quarters of the employees of the state's insurance companies work.
"The optimism and energy in Hartford has not been this high for over a decade," said Jay S. Fishman, president and chief executive officer of Travelers Property and Casualty.
Fairfield County has also become a major insurance center, especially for reinsurance, the business of insuring other insurance companies' risks against losses from claims.
Thus many leaders in the insurance industry in the state wonder if the current economic forecasts are too conservative. Officials at Travelers Property and Casualty, for instance, project modest growth, possibly hiring as many as 1,000 people in 1999.
This new hiring, though, should it come to pass, comes not only in the wake of much larger layoffs at Travelers in the mid-90's but also more recent job shedding. The company laid off 308 people last October, when a subsidiary failed, and another 550 in 1997, a bad year for many Connecticut insurers.
"Our company was under a great deal of financial stress, as were many others, as a result of the collapse of the United States real estate market," Mr. Fishman said. "But over the last five years we've brought our company back to health and are now in the strongest financial position ever. At this point," he continued, "I don't see anything on the horizon to dampen that optimism; in fact, we see many positive signs in our industry."
A spokesman for Travelers Property and Casualty, Keith F. Anderson, added that new employees are not surprised that companies almost synonymous with layoffs in recent years are hiring again.
"There was always hiring going on, even during the downsizing," he said, noting that attrition rates at large companies run from 3 to 8 percent a year, which, paradoxically perhaps, can force the need for new workers even during layoffs.
Perhaps, but the Travelers company rebound is a small one. In the mid-80's, when the Travelers was one company including property and casualty, life and health, the Connecticut work force was about 14,000.
Since then the company has since been split into Travelers Property and Casualty and Travelers Life and Annuity, owned either largely or entirely by Citigroup in New York City. Together, the companies now employ 6,500 in Connecticut, all but a few in Hartford. But Travelers is an extreme example since it was hit hard by bad investments and the recession earlier in the 90's as well as by industry-wide changes and consolidation.
If one blue chip insurance company in Connecticut has weathered the 90's well, and seems to be carrying on in the manner of old, it is probably The Hartford. The company's work force has increased from 9,100 in 1996 to 11,200 as of early February. The company is broadening into financial services; indeed, it is now called the Hartford Financial Services Group. "We're a growing company and Connecticut is our home," said Joyce Willis, a vice president at The Hartford. "Proof of that is the number of new jobs we've created. But we haven't stopped there. We're active in several initiatives to revitalize Hartford, particularly education and downtown Hartford."
Aetna, the third of the big three insurers based in Hartford, however, is barely recognizable from a decade ago. Perhaps for the best, though some might say bloodily, the company has transformed itself into a health care insurer from an old-fashioned multi-line insurer; it has done so by selling off its life insurance as well as other lines and buying companies like U.S. Healthcare.
Aetna currently employs 11,600, up from 10,000 in mid-1996 but still down from 15,000 in 1995. Company officials had no earlier numbers on employment statewide. "We have been completely reengineered," said a company spokesman, Fred Laberge.
At smaller insurance carriers in the state there have been continuing layoffs, although nothing like the job losses of five years ago. In December 1998, for instance, North Dakota-based Reliastar Financial Corporation, which owns Security-Connecticut Life Insurance Company, announced that it would eliminate 165 jobs at Security-Connecticut's operations in Avon, near Hartford, starting in June of next year.
There have also been several recent mergers, which always raises the specter of more layoffs.
Last year, the Berkshire Hathaway company of Omaha, Neb., run by Warren Buffett, bought the world's third largest reinsurance company, General Re in Stamford for $22 billion. And earlier this month, the Chubb Corporation, of Warren, N.J., annouced that it was buying Executive Risk in Simsbury for $810 million.
"We expect the insurance industry to continue to consolidate," said Jeffrey L. Sawyer, an insurance expert with Deloitte Consulting.
"The low growth rate in the insurance sector is forcing organizations to seek growth through mergers and acquisitions, expansion of product lines into other financial service-related areas, or through global expansion into markets that have a higher rates of growth," he said. "Given those dynamics, it's likely that this consolidation is affecting Connecticut -- as well as other parts of the country," he said.
Mr. Sawyer said that another major industry change is a move away from multi-lined business toward very specific lines, as Aetna has done by moving aggressively into health care insurance or The Hartford has done with financial services.
Why the consolidation in the insurance industry? One reason, analysts say, is the decline in life insurance, which has been largely supplanted by mutual funds as an investment tool. And the property-casualty business has become an increasingly competitive area with low growth and low return on equity.
There are more complicated reasons as well. Robert Carter, an insurance lawyer in Washington, said that many companies today buy their insurance in a much different way. "Traditionally, a company would buy liability insurance with a low deductible or self-insured retention,"he said. "Today, corporations self-insure or only buy insurance for catastrophic losses. As a result, a lot of United States insurance companies have found it necessary to consolidate to survive."
Another trend is that gradually several Connecticut-based insurers have sold their lines to Bermuda-based insurance companies.
For instance, Cigna, which is based in Philadelphia but has a large number of employees in Connecticut, sold its property and casualty insurance lines to Bermuda-based ACE for $3.45 billion. And Greenwich-based NAC Re, a reinsurer, is about to be acquired by the Bermuda insurer XL Capital for $1 billion.
The Cigna and NAC Re transactions may not result in layoffs, at least not immediately, as ACE intends to keep open several Cigna departments in the state, and XL intends to use its purchase of NAC Re as a foothold to expand its business in the United States.
But Mr. Carter added that for several reasons Bermuda has become the most effective place to run an insurance operation: companies there can offer insurance for punitive damages, for example. "Bermuda has always been known as an insurance mecca," he said. "It is the go-to market for excess insurance and the go-to market for insurance companies to buy reinsurance. It is not surprising that Connecticut-based insurance companies are relocating."
