SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 8; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1044 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Treacherous Days Recalled

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT was a golden time when a group of theater artists had a communal cause and the cause was theater art. How fitting that they would create a company and call it the Group Theater.
That was in 1931, which was anything but a golden time for the world. But the Great Depression informed the Group Theater's work, which became emblematic of the artists' bread and butter. 
 The Group Theater "aimed to do something fundamentally different from Broadway," in the words of the director and critic Harold Clurman, one of the theater's founders with Cheryl Crawford and Lee Strasberg. The members used "scripts not as economic bait but for the pertinence of what they have to say," Mr. Clurman wrote. When the fabled theater folded after nine years, Mr. Clurman explained that "when you have chosen to sustain a permanent acting company, persistence in pursuing the ordinary cause of theatrical production becomes folly." The Group Theater had no stars. But it begat stars.
Charter -- and stellar -- members included Clifford Odets, a resident actor who developed into its leading playwright; Elia Kazan, also an actor on his way to theater and film legend as a director, and the actor Morris Carnovsky.
After the Group disbanded, many members -- Odets, Carnovsky and Kazan among them -- went to Hollywood in search of fame and fortune. And the treacherous days of Hollywood blacklisting were not far behind. Odets cooperated with the House Committee on Un-American Activities. He named names. So did Mr. Kazan, to many of the unforgiving still champion of the nefarious informers. Mr. Carnovsky would not name names. He was blacklisted but, he later said, nurtured and strengthened as an actor. Banished from Hollywood, he finally became a star in New York -- and an incomparable Shakespearean actor at the age of 60.
Phoebe Brand, one of Connecticut's treasure troves of living history, saw and survived it all. And she wants to talk about a renaissance of the dream part. But not about Kazan.
Ask Ms. Brand about the 89-year-old director who is to receive an honorary Academy Award tonight amid protest by blacklist survivors and others, and Ms. Brand says simply: "Let's just leave it." Actually, she pares her reaction to Kazan the director, Kazan the honoree and Kazan the man to just two words: "Enough already."
The 91-year-old actress and director, a Group Theater alumnus, had a marriage of 60 years to Mr. Carnovsky, who died in their home in Easton in 1992 at the age of 94. Ms. Brand is staging two current readings of Odets's "Golden Boy," one at the library in Weston on Friday at 8 P.M., the other at Theater Artists Workshop (5 Gregory Boulevard in East Norwalk) on Saturday. Ms. Brand played Anna Banana, who has been described as a sweet naive sexpot, in the storied original 1937 Group Theater cast of one of Odets's best-known works. That cast included Frances Farmer, Luther Adler, Lee J. Cobb, Mr. Carnovsky, Kazan, Howard da Silva, Karl Malden and Jules (later to become John) Garfield.
Although it is subtitled "A Modern Allegory," "Golden Boy" is still perceived as a morality play -- and to some, just a melodrama -- about the conflicts of an artistic soul in a material world. Joe Bonaparte (played by Mr. Adler in the original production, William Holden in the movie, Sammy Davis Jr. in a Broadway musical version, Michael Lombardi in the Connecticut readings) is a promising violinist who chooses to become a prizefighter. The plot involves a killing and a suicide.
In its last production in New York in 1995, the play had strong ties to Connecticut, with Greg Naughton as Joe and his real life father, James Naughton, who lives in Weston, as Joe's manager. Joanne Woodward directed.
Of "Golden Boy," Ms. Brand said, "it's still a knockout play. And young people have the same problem about the choice between what your heart says and what can make money, about what you want to do with your life."
"In those days, gangsterism ran the country," Ms. Brand continued. "It's really easier today. Too easy." Without reaching for a metaphor, she added, "you had to fight just to exist. The play is about a fight." Among her "Golden Boy" memories, she recounted the play's London run. "The audience sat very quietly and we thought, 'They don't like us.' Then they just stood up and yelled. It was a language they fell in love with."
What Ms. Brand means about the relative ease of life today is the lack of passion in, and commitment to, theater. "But people do speak up," she said. "And I believe in the people. I don't know why -- but in the long run, they do come through. They don't put up with the nonsense in this country for too long." She talked of Watergate and Ken Starr, if only to believe that "the dirty business stopped."
Ms. Brand has been living in Easton for 33 years. She said that the blacklist "didn't bother us as much as it did our friends. They suffered." She mentioned Mady Christian and Canada Lee. "They had heart attacks and died. There was terror. We knew what Hitler had done. And we said, 'My God, it's happening here.' "
"It was a terrible, dreadful period. But we were saved by the people."
"People today," she said, "don't know what it was like -- the Depression, the blacklisting -- they can't believe it. We had no money but we had a theater. We all helped each other and worked together. It was difficult to see people in the streets -- dying, no coats. No one believed it."
Ms. Brand continued: "And my husband was able to work in the theater." They formed a touring company, the Actors Concert Theater, with Mr. DaSilva.
In 1953, Mr. Carnovsky began a two-year Off Broadway run in "The World of Sholem Aleichem." It was at the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford that John Houseman hired Mr. Carnovsky to play the Earl of Salisbury in "King John." His most famous roles -- Shylock (Katharine Hepburn was Portia) and Lear followed.
"I know money talks in this country," Ms. Brand went on. "But what is rich? Rich is talent and imagination and love and art. Say Germany and you think of Beethoven. England, Shakespeare. Italy, Greece, all the art. So what's more important for us here than keeping the theater alive? Art is life and all my life has been art."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Ruffling Fuzzy Conservatism Is Goal of Liberal Watchdog

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Liberals in other parts of the country have been rescued time and again from the consequences of their own silliness by the scary behavior of conservatives, but liberals in New Jersey have not had this advantage.
New Jersey conservatism may have a harsh underlying message -- that taxes are evil, and if you can't afford to pay the ones on your house, it's your own fault -- but the message is dressed up in fuzzy suburban good manners. ("No shouting, please -- we're from Jersey.") So what's a good liberal to do? 
 Jon Shure has spent all of his life in public affairs of one kind or another, first as a reporter for The Record of Hackensack, then as former Gov. Jim Florio's director of communications and most recently as a vice president of the Century Foundation in Manhattan.
And Mr. Shure says he has come out of half a lifetime of watching politics more hopeful and idealistic, not less. So for the last two years he has borrowed a page from conservative political tacticians and created New Jersey Policy Perspective (www. epn.org/njpp), a progressive research organization, scrupulously nonpartisan but unafraid to wear its bleeding heart on its sleeve.
"We're borrowing an idea that the right wing knows so well: that if you want to be in on the debate, you have to be in there at the beginning, setting the terms of the debate," Mr. Shure said. He offered an example: early talk of reforming welfare turned into a mandate to end welfare as we know it, Mr. Shure believes, because conservatives imposed on the debate a starting premise that welfare was a failure.
Mr. Shure intends to make Policy Perspective a player in the debates over New Jersey's future, particularly in the issues that will drive the 2000 Senate race, as well as the governor's race the next year.
"Our aim is to do good research, write it in a way that is useful and readable, and then market the hell out of it," Mr. Shure said. And one more thing: his research organization will have a point of view. "People have called us a liberal think tank, and I don't have a problem with that," he said. "I want people to know where we're coming from."
To hear him tell it, Mr. Shure has two main ideas that argue for a liberal research organization in New Jersey. One is that the state has, for all its silence, a sizable liberal population clustered around the universities and research institutions, as well as unions, who would be natural consumers of the his reports. And the second is a question: who else would do it?
"I doubt that a right-wing group would even bother to research and do a report on income distribution in the state," he said, showing just a little bit of steel, "not because their results would be different from ours but because they just wouldn't care."
New Jersey Progressive Policy has produced four reports so far, each focused on fiscal matters, questions of income, taxation and public spending that underlie just about every element of public policy debate in the state, H.O.V. lanes and public toilets named after radio personalities excepted.
The first report came in January 1998, when Henry J. Raimondo, a professor of policy at Rutgers University, spelled out the damage that would be done to Federal aid to New Jersey by the drive to balance the Federal budget: $2 billion in lost grants, brakes on Medicare payments, a squeeze in money for Washington-dependent state agencies like Environmental Protection, Community Affairs and Transpiration.
Then, in August 1998, David C. Mattek, a veteran New Jersey policy analyst, took on the Senior Tax Freeze, the Whitman Administration's program to indemnify low-income and elderly homeowners from real estate tax creep by having the state pay for any increases after 1998.
Mr. Mattek concluded that the Senior Freeze would cost more than forecast and would hand the state Legislature and the governor who takes over in 2001 a classic political time bomb: an untouchable entitlement that's running a deficit.
In January, Mr. Shure did the math and reported that even with a legislative proposal to raise the state threshold for tax liability (for a two-parent family) to $13,000 from $7,500, New Jersey would remain among the least generous, and behind its neighbors' more progressive thresholds, which run as high as $21,100 in New York State.
That report caught the attention of the legislative leadership and produced talk of raising the minimum tax liability.
But the most recent report, brought out this month, is a more conventional exercise in lamentation without solution for which conservatives like to chide liberals. Judith M. Fields, an economist at Lehman College, found what most people would guess: that the rich are hogging most of the income pie.
Why even bother to report such a commonplace?
"It is up to us to advocate economic and social policies and encourage political debate that measure our progress against the ideal, " Dr. Fields wrote. "And in order to do that, we need to know where we stand."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2812 words

HEADLINE: In the Suburbs, the Only Direction Is Up

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
BY just about any measure, 1998 was quite a year for the residential real estate market.
"A Mark McGwire housing economy," was the way James Hughes, dean of the Rutgers University School of Planning and Public Policy, put it, "like hitting 70 home runs." 
 "Essentially, for the housing industry," Dr. Hughes said, "all the economic and demographic stars were in full alignment." So, whether viewed from a national, regional or local perspective, a lot of people bought houses -- despite near-pandemic price increases.
In the suburban arc around New York City, every one of the 577 ZIP-code areas in 14 counties saw prices increase last year, according to repeat-sales figures compiled by Case Shiller Weiss, which surveys housing prices nationally. The year's performance was so strong that observers and interpreters of the market are debating its sustainability.
Lifting off from a launch pad of solid economic fundamentals -- low inflation, low unemployment, low and very stable mortgage rates -- the industry set records:
The 4.78 million sales of existing homes in the nation last year broke the previous record of 4.21 million sales set in 1997, which had broken the previous record of 4.08 million sales set in 1996, according to the National Association of Realtors. "You're talking 550,000 more homes sold last year than in 1997," said Fred Flick, chief economist for the association. "That's a pretty sizable increase."
The sale of 888,000 newly constructed homes last year broke the national record of 819,000 set in 1977, according to the Census Bureau. "You had all regions going full throttle," said Steven Berman, a statistician for the bureau's residential statistics branch. "The Midwest set a record of 166,000 new homes sold. The South set a record, 397,000. The West had its third best year ever, 244,000. And the Northeast had 82,000 sales, its highest since 1989, when it was 86,000."
Not surprisingly, the nation's home-ownership rate set a record in 1998, with 66.3 percent of all households owning their own homes, the Census Bureau reported.
New York State set a record for existing-home sales, according to the New York State Association of Realtors, with the 86,661 transactions surpassing by 14.3 percent the high of 75,796 sales in 1996. "It was a tremendous year for New York's real estate market," said Charles Staro, executive vice president of the state realtors association, "evidenced by the fact that 37 of our 40 local boards posted sales gains." In Westchester County, to cite one dramatic example, sales last year jumped 50.1 percent, spurring -- in the opinion of one real estate executive in neighboring Rockland County -- a 94.8 percent vault in Rockland's sales as house-hungry buyers widened their sights.
Those were extremes, to be sure. But sales-volume increases in neighboring states last year were certainly healthy: 13.4 percent in New Jersey and 13.9 percent in Connecticut. For the 10 counties of northern New Jersey closest to New York, the increase was 7.2 percent; for Fairfield County, Conn., it was 10.5 percent.
And as demand goes, so goes price. Throughout the three-state metropolitan region, according to the National Association of Realtors, median prices rose 5.7 percent, from $177,900 in 1997 to $188,100 last year. Around New York's City's suburban arc, price increases ranged from 3.4 percent for northern New Jersey ($199,300 in 1997 and $206,100 last year) to 24 percent in Westchester ($293,400 in 1997 and $363,900 last year).
Tracking real estate trends by the numbers defies absolute precision. Although single-family house sales are reported by local realty boards, not all real estate agents are members of the boards and not all sales are made through agents, so not all sales in a given area are recorded. At the same time, while one board may use median prices -- meaning half the sales are above that figure and half below -- others calculate an average. Still, the numbers serve as barometers of market patterns, especially when they all point in the same direction.
Last year's trend, if that term suffices, is borne out by the findings of the Case Shiller Weiss repeat-sale survey. Of the 577 ZIP-code areas in 14 suburban counties, according to the survey, as well as in the 130 ZIP-code areas in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island (the survey does not include Manhattan), every one experienced price appreciation. In 1997, by comparison, 56 ZIP-code areas saw prices drop, and the year before that the number was 117.
"The fundamentals are as good as ever," Dr. Hughes of Rutgers said.
On March 1, the nation's economic expansion entered its 96th month, or eighth year. In November, it surpassed the longest peacetime expansion of 92 months, which occurred from 1982 to 1990. The nation is now 10 months shy of matching the all-time record of 106 months, from 1961 to 1969.
"Over the past several years of this expansion," Dr. Hughes said, "the new information-age economy has finally started generating a lot of jobs, and labor shortages have appeared."
In February, said John L. Weiting, the regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, the nation's unemployment rate stood at 4.4 percent, matching its lowest levels in three decades.
In the 31-county area that the bureau designates as the New York region, 173,000 jobs were created in 1998, Mr. Weiting said, reaching 8.1 million. And while those jobs represented a "bit of a cooling off" from the 203,000 jobs created in 1997, he said, "the year still came in as the second best for the decade" -- and was part of the region's continuing rebound from the moribund days of the early 90's when information-age jobs were still aborning and the dreaded economic watchword was downsizing.
FURTHER fueling the housing market, demographers point out, is the fact that the peak year for the baby boom was 1957, when there were 4.5 million births nationwide; so more baby boomers than ever are now 42 years old. "Never before have we had such a concentration of individuals in their peak income-earning years," Dr. Hughes said. Twenty years ago, when the first boomers entered the market, they were at the lower rungs of the house-buying ladder. "Today, their house-purchasing power is immense," Dr. Hughes said, "so the trade-up market is the foundation for the demand."
The demand has been propelled by low mortgage rates.
"Certainly the big story in the last 12 months," said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage statistics company in Butler, N.J., "is that mortgage rates touched 31-year lows and climbed back only to 20-odd-year lows." Mortgage rates dropped to 6.68 percent during the week ending Oct. 2 -- a low last hit in 1967. On Wednesday, the rate stood at 7.03 percent.
As Mr. Gumbinger said: "The underlying story has been the unrelenting stability of interest rates. I mean, really, we have seen, almost no significant change, aside from that 31-year low." The range of mortgage rates in 1998, including the 31-year low, has been .6 percent. "That's the most stable year since 1977," Mr. Gumbinger said.
So the buyers came, and spent.
Throughout northern New Jersey, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors, sales rose 7.2 percent, from 63,100 in 1997 to 67,700 in 1998. The median price rose 3.4 percent, from $199,300 to $206,000.
By way of example, in Bergen and Passaic Counties, the median price rose from $205,400 to $213,500, or 4 percent. Middlesex, Somerset and Hunterdon, taken together, experienced a 4.2 percent increase, $176,700 to $184,200.
"What's spurring it," said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association, "is New Jersey's housing deficit." Mr. O'Keefe said that although New Jersey's population continues to grow, housing construction is down 40 percent from its 1980's rate.
"There is also," Mr. O'Keefe said, "a considerable wealth effect in northern New Jersey, particularly on the Gold Coast," the communities along the Hudson River, "which benefits from the dearth of construction in New York City. Therefore, even very expensive units on the Jersey side of the Hudson are in demand."
The profile of northern New Jersey's buyers, Mr. O'Keefe said, includes, particularly, empty-nesters and upwardly mobile young people. "At these prices they must be combining incomes," he said, "but I'm not sure of the marital arrangement; such arrangements have changed since I was young."
As confirmed by the Case Shiller survey, both groups seem willing to pay. The survey is based on a table showing the average price for all single-family homes sold in most ZIP-code areas, year by year (some areas are omitted because of insufficient data). To determine price fluctuations in 1998, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP-code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price the house brought the last time it sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier purchase price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1997. The 1998 sales prices for homes within each ZIP-code area were then compared with the estimated 1997 prices to compute the average change.
For the 318 ZIP-code areas in the 10-county northern New Jersey region, 58 saw prices rise by up to 4 percent, 100 by 4 to 6 percent, 107 by 6 to 8 percent, 46 by 8 to 10 percent, six by 10 to 12 percent and one (in the Monmouth County community of Rumson) by more than 12 percent.
Wedged between northern New Jersey and Westchester, triangle-shaped Rockland County stepped out of the shadows last year. Sales zoomed, the state association of realtors reported, with 2,267 transactions last year representing a whopping 94.8 percent increase over the 1,164 deals in 1997. The median price also jumped, from $203,400 to $235,350, or 15.7 percent.
"Rockland has been a secret for a lot of years," said Karen Glazer, past president of the county board of realtors and co-owner of Glazer Realty in Spring Valley.
The Case Shiller survey does not cover Rockland, due to insufficient data, but Ms. Glazer provided broad price estimates. "One-bedroom condos all over start about $100,000," she said. "Town houses, one- to three-bedrooms, start about $225,000. For the fancier ones in Suffern, Nanuet, top price would be about $300,000." A high ranch around the county, she said, "is going for $250,000, but there's new construction going for $500,000 to $750,000."
Asked about the soaring sales volume, Ms. Glazer said: "You know what it is? Because prices have skyrocketed in Westchester, people have gone farther north, over a bridge -- the Tappan Zee or the George Washington -- to discover reasonably priced homes."
Certainly, Westchester has not suffered.
Officials of the Westchester County Board of Realtors did not respond to several requests for comment, but according to the state realtors association, sales in the county jumped 50.1 percent, from 5,750 in 1997 to 8,628 last year. And the median price rose 24 percent, from $293,400 to $363,900.
The Case Shiller survey showed that of Westchester's 65 ZIP-code areas, six saw prices rise 4 to 6 percent, 20 by 6 to 8 percent, 17 by 8 to 10 percent, seven by 10 to 12 percent and in 15 -- or almost one-quarter of the total -- by at least 12 percent.
In Westchester's neighbor to the east, Fairfield County, according to the Case Shiller survey, nine of the 45 ZIP-code areas saw prices rise by 4 to 6 percent, 16 from 6 to 8 percent, eight between 8 and 10 percent, 11 by 10 to 12 percent and one (in Norwalk) by at least 12 percent.
Vincent Valvo, editor of The Commercial Record, a business weekly that covers the state, said that in addition to "enjoying the economic beneficence of New York City," most of Fairfield was building on "the continued development of Stamford and suburban areas like Shelton."
According to Commercial Record statistics, sales in Fairfield County increased from 17,743 in 1997 to 19,598 in 1998, or 10.5 percent. The median price rose 3.9 percent, from $203,500 to $211,500.
WITHIN Fairfield County, even long-struggling Bridgeport saw sales increase 14.2 percent, from 1,769 to 2,021, while the median price rose 12.1 percent, from $74,500 to $83,550. In New Canaan, where the 460 sales recorded last year represented a 3.1 percent increase over the 446 sales in 1997, the median price jumped 10.9 percent, from $505,000 to $560,000 last year.
There were good times on Long Island, too, said Joseph Mottola, executive officer of the Long Island Board of Realtors, "because of a confluence of things -- interest rates, mortgage products to fit unique needs, low unemployment."
"You don't hear about downsizing any more," Mr. Mottola said, "you hear about companies unable to fill jobs."
According to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, there were 8,199 sales in Nassau last year, 4.6 percent more than the 7,835 in 1997. The median price jumped 10.2 percent, from $209,466 to $230,791.
The Case Shiller survey showed that, of the 63 ZIP-code areas in Nassau, 19 saw prices rise 4 to 6 percent, 35 by 6 to 8 percent and nine by between 8 and 10 percent.
Asked to offer a range of median prices across Nassau, Mr. Mottola checked his records and said: "At the less expensive end, we have Levittown: '97 is $146,000 and '98 is $158,000; Baldwin went from $167,000 to $170,000, Glen Cove, $250,000 to $254,000."
In Suffolk, sales rose 7.4 percent last year to 11,244 from 10,470 in 1997, while the median price was up 7.5 percent, from $164,662 to $176,957. And according to Case Shiller Weiss, of Suffolk's 86 ZIP-code areas, one appreciated by up to 4 percent; 24 by 4 to 6 percent, 37 by 6 to 8 percent, 23 by between 8 and 10 percent and one (Wading River) by 10 to 12 percent.
Choosing three communities as examples in Suffolk, Mr. Mottola said: "For Brentwood, the '97 median was $106,700 and '98 was $112,000. Northport, '97 was $262,500 and '98 is $281,000. And in Cold Spring Harbor, '97 was $470,000 and '98 was $522,500."
Barely five months ago, in October, prospects for a booming residential market seemed, at best, imperiled. The so-called Asian economic contagion had begun to infect South America. The Russian economy virtually collapsed. The stock market swooned. And home buyers, particularly high-enders hooked to quarterly reports, headed for the bunkers.
But in some ways the turmoil bolstered the housing market. A world oil glut kept fuel prices and, consequently, inflation down. The flight of capital to the United States kept interest rates down; on top of which the Federal Reserve, in three quick hits, further lowered interest rates and, consequently, mortgage rates. The stock market roared back. And all of that meshed with the propitious demographics of house buying.
But is it sustainable?
With a realtor's institutional optimism, Dr. Flick, the economist for the National Association of Realtors, believes that even after the baby boomers settle into their trade-up homes and the so-called baby bust begins to siphon off demand, immigrants will plug the gap. "Immigrants are coming in at roughly 1 million a year, and analysts have found that after six years' residency about 70 percent become homeowners," Dr. Flick said.
Then, in about a decade, he said, the millennium generation -- those people currently 18 or 19 years old -- will enter the market. "The boomers were wealthy and fruitful and multiplied," Dr. Flick said. "There are about 80 million boomers and about 70 million millennium kids. So, like that Stephen King novel, 'Children of the Corn,' they will come with their scythes and harvest the housing market of the next, say, two decades."
All of that assumes, said Dr. Hughes of Rutgers, "that the economic stars will stay in alignment."
"We could have a real global economic meltdown that ultimately feeds back to the United States," he said. But at least for now the nation's housing fundamentals remain firm. "The nation and the region have none of the imbalances that caused the great real estate bubble of the 1980's," Dr. Hughes said. "Today's builders are the survivors of the debacle. They are more conservative, so overbuilding and speculative development are nonexistent today."
Rae Rosen, a senior regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is, well, reserved. "Certainly, for the region, we've probably hit the cyclical peak in terms of job growth, income growth and housing activity," she said.
Ms. Rosen wonders if the boom can last: "It will be difficult to sustain the '98 growth rate in '99. It will still be good, it just won't be great."
For Dr. Hughes, the nation's economy and housing performance in 1998 constituted a "go-figure" market. "We were an oasis of prosperity in a turbulent economic world -- go figure."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A New Stage Where There's Always a Doctor in the House

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Gabor Barabas, 19 years old and newly married, was a pre-med student at the University of Cincinnati in 1968, his 18-year-old wife, SuzAnne, who had taken acting classes with Lee Strasberg, had to do something to "maintain my sanity," as she put it.
Some people who are crazy for acting put on a show. With the help of her husband, Ms. Barabas put together a whole theater. "I owed her something, and this was payback time," Dr. Barabas explained. And that's how the Cincinnati Repertory Company was born. For startup money, the couple had $50. "But we begged," Dr. Barabas said. "For fabrics, for lights, for volunteers." 
 That was just entry level for the executive producer (Dr. Barabas) and the artistic director (Ms. Barabas) of the New Jersey Repertory Company, the state's newest Equity playhouse, which opened in Long Branch this month.
In Cincinnati, where Dr. Barabas was studying pediatrics and neurology for children, it followed that the couple would augment a community-type theater with a children's theater.
For his residency, Dr. Barabas moved to Haverford, Pa., and another new theater company came with the territory: the American Repertory Theater of Philadelphia in Bryn Mawr (1974 to 1979). In Cincinnati, they had played it safe for adults ("Cabaret," "The Fantasticks") and for children ("Winnie the Pooh," "Robin Hood"). In Bryn Mawr, they "blew it all" on "The Stronger" and "The Maids." And so Jones and Schmidt, Kander and Ebb, and peanut butter sandwiches paved the way for Strindberg and Genet. Ms. Barabas went on directing and acted in other theaters nearby.
"Medicine and theater became the rhythm of my life," Dr. Barabas said. "They complement each other in some strange way."
It's been a long-running complement, spanning the 31 years of his marriage. In 1979, Dr. Barabas became the head of pediatric neurology at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in New Brunswick. For 15 years, he has practiced pediatric neurology at Monmouth Medical Center with his brother, Ronald. He also works with disabled children at the Matheny School and Hospital in Peapack, where Ms. Barabas is directing an arts program.
The couple, who have lived in in West Long Branch since 1983 and in Hillsborough for six years before that, wrote a book (a history of the radio and television show "Gunsmoke," a three-year project). They wrote a play (produced Off Broadway in 1997) and a screenplay. Dr. Barabas wrote the libretto and the lyrics for two musicals, and he went on writing poetry. ("Russian Chronicles" is the title of his collection, published by Gray Falcon Press.) "I've been writing poetry since I was 6," said Dr. Barabas, who was born in Budapest. "It is the most appreciated art form in Hungary."
But the rhythm of their lives was missing an essential beat. No more. New Jersey Rep is here, and at last their lives are complete again.
The couple estimate that they were looking for the right space for three years, first in Asbury Park, then in Red Bank. In Long Branch, they found not only a welcoming place but also an irresistible offer: a three-story, 9,000-square-foot building that "found us," Dr. Barabas says.
David and Margaret Lumia, owners of a 100-year-old medical equipment business, were looking to donate the building to a nonprofit group. "Yes, they gave it to us," Dr. Barabas said. Estimated value: $325,000. Estimated restoration costs: $650,000. That includes a conversion of the current space (capacity: 62) to a 99-seat theater, and the creation of two additional performance spaces, as well as an Art Deco facade.
The company's mission statement refers to the theater as a catalyst for the economic rejuvenation of Long Branch that would "create jobs in a depressed area."
"I would drive through Long Branch to my practice and think about how we could have a social impact on this community," Dr. Barabas said. "In a town as ethnically diverse as Long Branch, with its little shops and bodegas and small-town charm, there is a need for a theater that speaks to everyone. Here we know the mayor and the fire marshal and the police chief, and everyone knows us. And here, people won't go to New York to see theater. Now, they have it in their backyard."
In its preparatory stage, the company held 18 readings of new plays, chosen from 1,000 submitted last year. "The main-stage program will develop and produce approximately six plays or musicals per year," the mission statement says. Kim Hunter and Bob Emmett have performed in two benefit readings and are expected to return in July for "On Golden Pond."
Eighty professional actors are members of the company. It is hardly necessary to add that the couple, who have a son working in real estate in New York City and a daughter who teaches high school in Old Bridge, envision a children's theater.
The company's first play, "Ends," by David Alex, a high school teacher in Chicago, concerns a 30-year-old black man in 1967 living in isolation in the woods since he was 12. Then a white Vietnam veteran barges in. "It is not a play about race relations, but about two characters betrayed by their country," Dr. Barabas said.
The season's second play, tentatively titled "A World I Never Made," by Bryan Williams, is about an Irish policeman and his sister-in-law, who is secretly in love with him. The three-character play, which also involves a drug dealer, has the "line of a modern Greek tragedy," Dr. Barabas said. It is to run from April 13 through May 2.
"North Fork," by Mark Dunn, scheduled for May 18 to June 6, is a seven-character comedy set in Texas. In September, the Barabases' own Holocaust play, "Find Me a Voice," produced Off Broadway in 1997, is scheduled. It is informed by Dr. Barabas's family stories: he escaped from Hungary when he was 7 with his parents, both survivors of Auschwitz. The play is about "the moral lessons not learned, about how people treat one another," he said.
One afternoon before opening night, Meryl Harris, a member of the acting company, was working the phones, and Ms. Barabas was vacuuming. "In a new company, everybody does everything," Ms. Harris said. "We're trying to prove that New Jersey is a part of America, not a suburb of New York."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Unemployment Rate Drops Below National Level

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate dipped below the national rate in February, the Federal Department of Labor reported last week. The state rate was 4.1 percent, down from 4.4 percent in January, matching the lowest monthly rate the state has seen since July 1989.
The national unemployment rate for February edged up slightly to 4.4 percent. Governor Whitman had long said that getting the state unemployment rate below the nation's was one of her goals. 
 The state had appeared to dip below the national rate in October, but when the state numbers were amended a month later, both rates were at 4.6 percent. New Jersey employers increased their payrolls by 9,300 workers in February, reversing a one-month jobs loss recorded in January.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Horowitz Gift

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Wanda Toscanini Horowitz -- daughter of the conductor Arturo Toscanini and widow of the pianist Vladimir Horowitz -- has left a five-story Manhattan town house on the Upper East Side to Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights.
The Horowitz home is now on the market for $4.2 million, and the proceeds will be used to establish a graduate assistance fund to help blind people care for their Seeing Eye dogs. Mrs. Horowitz died at 90 in August of last year. 
 The town house is the largest single gift in the 45-year history of Guiding Eyes for the Blind, said William D. Badger, the nonprofit organization's president and chief executive officer.
The organization breeds and trains guide dogs and trains blind people to handle them. But because 70 percent of the blind population is unemployed, the trust will provide up to $300 a year for those who need help feeding and caring for their dogs.
The organization, which spends about $25,000 to train a single team of a human and a guide dog and has an $8 million yearly budget, depends on private contributions, Mr. Badger said.
Mrs. Horowitz had been a benefactor of the organization, but the large gift at her death came as an "incredible surprise," Mr. Badger said. "We had no idea we were in her will."

LENGTH: 2449 words

HEADLINE: In a Gong Show for Start-Ups,The Best Business Plan Wins

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI 

DATELINE: NORWALK Conn.

 BODY:
SOMEWHERE outside the surreal economic world where 23-year-old entrepreneurs become $25 million executives lies the economy of everybody else, where smart people with good ideas struggle for years and then are never heard from again.
At the junction of those worlds lies the prospect of good television. 
"Money Hunt," a public television program produced in Connecticut, has figured that out. By aiming a camera at people who by their very nature can talk endlessly about their ideas and then pitting them against each other, the producers have created 30 minutes of sometimes corny, yet compelling, television. The program is now broadcast in most major markets around the country (55 stations in all).
The format is simple. Two entrepreneurs pitch their businesses to the show's two hosts and a guest executive -- someone like Guy Kawasaki, a longtime software executive at Apple Computer, or Brian Maxwell, the founder of Powerbar, a maker of food bars marketed to athletes, who started a $100 million company in his kitchen. The entrepreneurs are grilled on their business plans, and then the guest executive picks a winner. The prize is an on-air presentation of the executive's business card, handed over as if it were a gold cup, and a promise of an hour of his or her time whenever the winner wants to ask for advice.
"I'm going to wait until I have some crucial question," said Cora G. Yang, of IQ Foods, a company in Downers Grove, Ill., moments after winning her match at a recent taping. (Ms. Yang, whose company makes V. G. Burger vegetarian burgers, defeated Debra Root of Mrs. Malibu Gourmet Natural Foods, a Malibu, Calif., maker of low-fat peanut butter.) "It's like having a fairy godmother," Ms. Yang said. "I'm not going to squander it."
"Money Hunt" is riding the explosion of entrepreneurship in the American economy. For the 26 guest slots in its new season, the program received about 1,000 applications on its Internet site (www.moneyhunt.com). Its producers say they are negotiating agreements that would allow local versions of "Money Hunt" to be made in Japan, Europe and the Middle East. All this for a program that had a quiet start.
"Money Hunt" first appeared on a public access cable channel in Connecticut in 1996 and moved to public television a year later. But even though it now has major sponsors like Pricewaterhousecoopers and Yahoo Finance, "Money Hunt" still has a "Wayne's World" feel to it.
The program was created by Cliff Ennico, a lawyer who once worked on Wall Street, and Miles Spencer, an investment banker, friends who live near each other in Fairfield County, Conn.; the headquarters are in an office attached to Mr. Spencer's home. The nautical-themed set was designed by Mr. Spencer's wife; his mother, a former soap opera extra, sometimes operates a camera. And in keeping with the entrepreneurial theme, Mr. Spencer's dog is named Netscape.
The men in charge made themselves the program's hosts, but it doesn't take long to observe that television is their second language. They are often awkward, and their one-liners seem forced. In acknowledgment of their lack of TV experience, they have hired a coach to help develop their on-air personalities. Mr. Ennico, 45, who looks like a college English professor, is the funny one. Mr. Spencer, 35, with all the smoothness and confidence of the guy who sold you your Mercedes, is the serious one.
"This is not Louis Rukeyser," said Wai Wah Chin, an adviser to the program and a senior vice president of Charterhouse, an investment firm in Manhattan. "In the early stages they were thinking of doing something with a gong, but I think they were joking."
Yet the attraction of "Money Hunt" has nothing to do with its creators' personalities; it comes in those intense few minutes when they are peppering an entrepreneur with questions. It is obvious that the hosts have done their homework, and even though they are smiling, they can be merciless.
To a clothing designer: "Your plan calls for $70 million in sales in 2002. Isn't that a little aggressive?" and "How do you control quality if so much of your production is sourced out?"
To an executive of an Internet company: "You appear to have a significant reliance on service revenue versus licensing fees. Do you see that as a potential inhibitor to the growth of the company?"
And to the founder of another Internet company: "What's your competition on the Internet?" After an uncomfortable silence and the answer that there were about 2,000 similar sites, Mr. Spencer said of the man's concept, "I'm not really buying any of it."
 
Backstage, Nonstop Promotion
Many of the guests seem to enjoy the confrontation, saying it is similar to making a presentation to venture capitalists, although it's over much faster. They often parry the questions with answers that once again explain how great their ideas are.
During a week when "Money Hunt" is being taped, entrepreneurs come in from all over the country, and because three shows are usually taped at a time, there are six entrepreneurs going in and out of the studio here all day. These people don't just nod hello to one another. They gather in the greenroom and talk about their businesses, bragging about their products and handing out brochures like grandparents passing around pictures of their grandchildren.
"You want people to catch your fervor," explained Allen Miller, who was appearing on the program and is the founder of Corporate Carrier Networks, an Irvine, Calif., company that sells back-office software to telecommunications companies.
When the guest executive arrives, it's as if Bill Gates had walked into the room, because here is someone who was once where they are and is now where they so desperately want to be. Forget about a vague prospect of an hour of his time later; here's the guy now.
In a room full of entrepreneurs, nobody's shy. Ms. Yang and her husband, Mark Barnekow, the chief executive of their natural foods company, talked to Mr. Maxwell of Powerbar about how to instill the entrepreneurial spirit in employees. The three of them shared stories of developing their products in the kitchen.
"We would never get the opportunity to sit with Brian like this," Ms. Yang said. "It's worth its weight in gold."
Ms. Root, who had whispered, "Don't worry, I'm going to hit him up," shortly after Mr. Maxwell arrived, leaned forward in her seat and told him why her peanut butter would be wonderful in a Powerbar. He listened politely.
Mr. Maxwell shrugged off the attention, saying he was happy to offer advice.
"I was on the other side of the table 12 years ago," he explained.
Tom Scott, a co-founder of Nantucket Nectars and another of the new season's guest executives, did not mind being pounced on, either.
"That's how I am when there are people who can be helpful to me," acknowledged Mr. Scott, whose venture turned a fruit drink recipe into a multimillion-dollar company. "I don't have any incredible insights. I've just been through the battle."
The show is almost an extension of the action in the greenroom. It moves fast, and sometimes everybody tries to talk at once. The questions and answers come so quickly that the guest executive, whom the show calls a mentor, sometimes has to struggle to get in a comment.
"As soon as we started rolling, I saw that I would have to dive in," Mr. Maxwell said of the program on which he appeared. "There weren't any gaps. It made for pretty good television."
After both entrepreneurs have been grilled and have stepped off camera, but are still well within earshot, the hosts and mentor discuss the companies as Siskel and Ebert used to discuss movies: agreeing, disagreeing, sometimes rolling their eyes at each other.
But instead of offering thumbs up or thumbs down, Mr. Ennico and Mr. Spencer defer to the mentor for the verdict. Mr. Maxwell picked Ms. Yang. Mr. Scott, in his guest appearance, chose Chris Lohring of Tremont Brewery in Boston, saying he felt he could help Tremont more, even though the company it was up against, the on-line Kosher Grocer Inc. of Brooklyn, had more short-term potential.
Deborah Alexander, co-founder of Kosher Grocer, said later that she didn't think Mr. Scott understood her business. Still, she left the show feeling encouraged and has since received E-mail from Mr. Spencer, offering advice. "The two hosts favored my business plan, but the mentor didn't, which is a very realistic reaction to anybody's business plan," she said.
Larry Cowsert not only didn't win in his recent appearance on the program; he had to sit on the set and explain why his company went bust. Mr. Cowsert had been on the program last season and been beaten by an electricity reseller. Now the hosts had invited him back for a bit of show and tell, cautioning other entrepreneurs on what to avoid. ("He was in a train wreck," Mr. Spencer confided before the taping.)
Mr. Cowsert's company, Newstar Collaborative Technologies in St. Louis, had developed teleconferencing software and was doing pretty well until Microsoft and Netscape Communications got into the business. Now Mr. Cowsert is, well, doing something else, but he said he was happy to go over some dos and don'ts.
"You can always tell the pioneers by the arrows in their backs," he said.
Mr. Ennico said people have gone on the show with some unusual ideas. He remembers a man who wanted to set up an Internet site where people could mix and match existing music to make customized compact disks.
"It sounded great; he really had his technology down," Mr. Ennico said. "There was one problem. He didn't have a deal with the major record companies, and he couldn't understand why they wouldn't be interested. Our mentor had to explain, in no uncertain terms, why they wouldn't be."
 
Battling for a Special Audience
The entrepreneurs say they hope their appearance on the program will attract investors, but that doesn't seem to happen often. CMS Technologies of Livonia, Mich., which provides tracking and security systems for computer networks, said that after the appearance of one of its executives, an order was placed by a Princeton University official who had been watching the program, but no investors called.
Investors did contact Doug Monahan, founder of Sunset Direct, a computer sales and marketing company in Austin, Tex., but he turned them down. He did, however, hire Pricewaterhousecoopers as his accountant after the show.
Lucinda Duncalfe, chief executive of the Destiny Software Corporation, a Conshohocken, Pa., company that creates Internet systems for the financial services industry, said she heard from only a few individual investors.
"Venture capitalists don't look at TV for deal flow," she said.
Patrick Petersen of Rhino Naturals, a company in Los Angeles that makes liquid dietary supplements, said he got a call from an old school friend after appearing on the program.
"We've met with a dozen investors since we taped the show, and I've asked if any of them saw it, and they all said no," Mr. Petersen said. "So I don't know who's watching it except my high school friends."
Fred Haney, who is on the advisory board of a group in California that invests in nascent companies, said when asked about the program: "I never heard of it." One executive at a venture capital firm in the San Francisco Bay area, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he had seen "Money Hunt" but dismissed it as an infomercial.
"Maybe you're going to come across an insomniac investor who's up at one in the morning, but you're not going to attract important investors," he said, referring to the program's midnight Sunday time slot on KQED, a public television station in San Francisco. The program is seen in the New York area on WLIW, Channel 21, at 12:30 P.M. Sundays.
Tina Bachemin, the program publicist for KQED, said that about 14,000 households tune into the program on her station, although many may be taping it. The main audience, she figures, is other entrepreneurs.
"That's pretty good for midnight," she said of the audience. "The programmers think it's because the Bay Area is such an entrepreneurial area. They want to see what other entrepreneurs are doing."
Tom O'Malia, director of the Greif Entrepreneurship Center at the Marshall School of Business at the University of Southern California, said he had seen the program and felt that it provided a valuable service by spotlighting entrepreneurship. But he said the focus on money disturbed him. As a prerequisite for starting a business, he said, money is overrated, and many entrepreneurs fall into the trap of handing over too much of their businesses to get it.
"We all read about the heroes that made it, but many try to go from the minor leagues right to the major leagues," Mr. O'Malia said. "They go right into the money business instead of being entrepreneurs. Of all the myths of entrepreneurship, perhaps the greatest is that you need a lot of money to start a company. You don't. I mean, Apple started with $1,600."
 
A Show That Wants to Grow
"Money Hunt," of course, is all about money, and the show is itself an entrepreneurial enterprise. As one mentor said moments after a taping finished, "Someone should do a "Money Hunt" on 'Money Hunt.' "
Mr. Spencer certainly has plans to expand the television franchise.
"I will be a puddle of a man if I don't end up with commercial distribution of this enterprise," he said, suggesting that "Money Hunt" could be shown on the Fox network before football, on CNBC on the weekends or on CNN. "We're a little public TV show now, but that's just where we'll be from."
Moreover, he sees potential beyond television. The two hosts have written a book about entrepreneurs, still untitled, for Harper Collins; it is due out in the fall. Mr. Spencer also would like to find a way that he and Mr. Ennico might profit from one of the program's most valuable assets: the information on all those applications from entrepreneurs that is sitting in their computers.
"These are some of the fastest-growing companies in the United States," he said. "It's a heck of a data base, and the most attractive option is assigning the deals to pools of capital."
And even though many entrepreneurs report little response from potential investors to their appearances on the show, Mr. Spencer said he was already getting calls from investors about some of his guests and was using his investment banking skills to match the two sides.
"I skim the cream," he said. "Last year I generated six figures in fees. I'm very opportunistic, but there's always another bus coming in two minutes. Right now, I have buses lined up."

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Behind the Labor Peace at Ford

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich.

 BODY:
When the General Motors Corporation was paralyzed by a 54-day strike last summer, several Wall Street analysts offered the same solution: G.M.'s leaders should go to the home of Peter J. Pestillo, the longtime labor czar of the Ford Motor Company, and offer him any sum of money, no matter how large, to fix their problems.
G.M. never took this unsolicited advice, and the strike cost it $2 billion in after-tax profits. But Wall Street's perspective highlighted the reputation of Mr. Pestillo, one of the most influential yet least known executives in corporate America. 
 For nearly two decades, he has set labor policy for Ford and indirectly for the entire auto industry; by extension, he has influenced wages and costs across a wide range of industries. By encouraging factory managers to work closely with workers and union leaders, he has helped bring Ford's quality close to Japanese levels. More recently, Mr. Pestillo has quietly come to dominate auto industry lobbying, playing a role in issues from air pollution to fuel economy.
Perhaps most important, Ford has not had a single strike in the United States since 1986. By comparison, G.M.'s strike-related losses in the last three years approach the Microsoft Corporation's entire sales and profits last year.
For all his power, Mr. Pestillo, who will turn 61 on Monday, has worked almost entirely behind the scenes. Now he is being dragged into the limelight. An executive vice president for years, he became Ford's vice chairman and chief of staff at the beginning of this year when a longtime ally, William C. Ford Jr., became Ford's chairman. In January, Mr. Pestillo also became the chairman of the auto industry's new lobbying arm, the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, which has replaced the defunct American Automobile Manufacturers Association.
IN coming months, Mr. Pestillo may draw yet more attention. The United Automobile Workers' three-year labor contracts with Ford, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler A.G. will expire in September. The U.A.W.'s triennial convention to draw up bargaining positions will open next Sunday, the start of the negotiation process. Major issues will probably include medical coverage, wage increases and whether auto-parts workers will continue to earn as much as assembly workers.
In an interview, Mr. Pestillo said that he believed his relative anonymity had helped him, particularly in his many talks with the U.A.W. "To the extent you're less public, you can be more effective in private," he said.
Most auto company labor negotiators are former factory managers with M.B.A.'s, but Mr. Pestillo has a different background. The son of a union machinist, he grew up in Plainville, Conn., and worked his first summer after high school at a ball bearing company, where he was a dues-paying member of the U.A.W.
After graduating from Fairfield University, he worked his way through Georgetown University's law school in Washington by holding a series of Government jobs, including one as a Capitol policeman. The many hours of guarding Congress coincided with his course in labor law and contributed to a lifelong fascination with politics, both at the national level and within unions.
After stints at General Electric and B. F. Goodrich, Mr. Pestillo came to Ford in 1980, and he has been running its labor policy ever since. He has worked to transform the way Ford factories are run, transferring responsibility to assembly line workers.
He has also forced out factory managers who could not get along with workers or the union. "In the old days, they were happy to have loads of union grievances and disciplinary actions to prove how tough they were," Mr. Pestillo said. "Now we measure how effective they are." Last year, Harbour and Associates, a manufacturing consulting firm, reported that Ford ran 4 of the nation's 10 most productive car factories and 7 of the 10 most productive light truck factories. (Japanese auto makers operated most of the rest.)
The U.A.W. traditionally negotiates a three-year agreement with one auto maker and then demands that the others accept the same deal. For most of the last 20 years, the union has gone to Ford first because of its cooperative relationship, and Mr. Pestillo has used this opportunity to negotiate deals that have cut Ford's costs but done little to help its rival, G.M.
Auto makers can now pay much lower wages, for instance, to workers in their first three years of employment. Ford has been hiring thousands to build its popular sport utility vehicles, but G.M. has been thinning its ranks through attrition.
Some auto industry leaders dispute how much credit Mr. Pestillo deserves for keeping Ford free of strikes. Richard G. Wagoner Jr., the president of G.M., said Mr. Pestillo had an easy task because Ford closed unneeded factories in the early 1980's and has been expanding since. "I'm not aware of any special magic he has," Mr. Wagoner said.
But that view remains a minority opinion. Indeed, John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said in a separate interview that Ford seemed to have benefited from Mr. Pestillo's close relationship with the U.A.W. and its current president, Stephen P. Yokich.
Mr. Yokich said that while his union maintained a businesslike relationship with Ford, he considered Mr. Pestillo a friend, someone with whom he enjoyed having a beer, playing golf or simply talking. "That's the best reason we get along," he said. "We both can laugh at each other and enjoy it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
A Growing Market in Hot Technology

BYLINE: By REBECCA FAIRLEY RANEY 

 BODY:
CRIMINALS following the Willie Sutton rule -- go where the money is -- are not knocking over banks, as Sutton did. They are raiding shipments of computers, microchips and cell phones.
The direct losses that technology companies attribute to theft are $250 million a year, according to a new study, and the industry is spending a further $750 million a year on insurance and security measures. 
 The problems of truck hijackings, armed takeovers, burglaries and trucks that mysteriously turn up empty at their destinations have plagued Silicon Valley for years. Police in San Jose, Calif., estimate that in recent years, robbers have hit an electronics company once every five days, said John O'Loughlin, director of security at Sun Microsystems. Such thefts often involve goods worth $100,000 or more, while the typical bank robbery nets only about $2,000, he said.
A number of crimes in the mid-1990's prompted two industry groups, the American Electronics Association and the International Electronics Security Group, to hire the Rand Corporation to perform the study, said to be the first attempt to quantify the problem. Ninety-five companies were surveyed, representing 40 percent of industry sales; they reported 1,700 incidents of theft in a nine-month period in 1997 and 1998. Industrywide estimates were extrapolated from the results.
Losses to distributors, retailers and customers were not measured, but the researchers guessed that they might run up to four times what manufacturers lose, putting the total cost of technology hardware theft as high as $5 billion a year in an industry that shipped about $235 billion of hardware in 1997.
The Rand researchers found that insurance covered only about 25 percent of manufacturers' losses because of high deductibles and widespread self-insurance.
Thefts of computers and components from trucks were by far the most common crimes, usually occurring in transit. Some involved hijackings; in others, goods were replaced with boxes of rocks without the driver knowing. Fewer than 1 in 10 thefts occurred on manufacturers' premises.
Companies that stepped up security spending during the study period saw their losses decline, the researchers found. One useful measure: removing the company logo from trucks.

HEADLINE: Canada Faces New Pressure To Safeguard Rare Wildlife

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 20

 BODY:
In just one day, a North American grizzly bear can lumber across the border from Montana, where it is protected by law, to the Canadian province of Alberta, where it can be legally hunted and shot.
Similarly, the wetlands and forests where endangered species like the whooping crane and spotted owl live are rigorously protected by Federal laws in the United States. But Canada has no national endangered species law to protect wildlife or its habitats. 
 More than 25 years after the United States passed the Endangered Species Act, wildlife advocates are running out of patience waiting for Canada to enact its own law. Now two American wildlife organizations plan to increase the pressure on Canada by instituting a legal action that raises the threat of trade sanctions on Canada unless an effective law is passed.
"The message we're trying to send to them is 'Wake up, get going and move an endangered species act through the Government,' " said William J. Snape 3d, legal director of Defenders of Wildlife, one of the groups involved. "It's just getting sort of old."
The mechanism that will be used to bring pressure on Canada is the Pelly amendment to the Fisherman's Protective Act of 1967. The filing of a petition under this amendment requires the United States Secretary of the Interior to evaluate another country's efforts to comply with international programs to protect endangered species. If threatened wildlife is being harmed, the Interior Secretary can recommend to the President that trade with that country be suspended.
The amendment was initially passed in 1971 to give some teeth to international salmon fishing agreements. According to a draft of the petition that will be brought by Defenders of Wildlife and the Northwest Ecosystem Alliance, a coalition of wildlife groups, Canada's failure to pass its own endangered species law violates a 1942 convention to protect wildlife and nature in the Western Hemisphere.
But more immediately, the groups argue that Canada's inaction is hurting the United States' own effort at wildlife preservation.
"Canada's failure to protect such species," as the grizzly and whooping crane, the draft petition notes, "not only undermines the millions of dollars spent by the U.S. Government on endangered species protection and recovery programs but constitutes a de facto subsidy to Canadian landowners and enterprises which are not required to bear the costs of mitigating the harm caused to endangered species."
While the Pelly amendment makes trade sanctions possible, the likelihood of the United States acting against so important a trading partner as Canada is considered remote.
"The odds of trade sanctions actually happening as a result of this petition are 30 to 40 percent," said Mr. Snape. "But this 30 to 40 percent is precisely enough leverage to kick the Government in the pants."
Mr. Snape said the petition will be filed "imminently."
Canada's environmental ministry has been trying to get an endangered species law since at least 1995 and officials say they will not be bullied by any action from across the border.
"To us, all this represents or is indicative of is concern by a number of environmental groups that we're not doing enough in Canada," said Steven G. Curtis, associate director general of the Canadian Wildlife Service, a branch of the federal Ministry of the Environment.
Tensions between Ottawa and the provinces over who has responsibility for species that cross provincial or international boundaries has been at the heart of the delays. Mr. Curtis said the approach being considered in Ottawa now relies not on imposed federal minimum standards but rather programs that all Canadian provinces and territories agree on.
Canadian environmental groups criticized earlier approaches that left most habitat protection to the provinces. In one instance in British Columbia, biologists found a rare concentration of nesting sites for an endangered bird called the marbled murrelet in an old growth forest that was being clear cut. The province could only get the logging company to spare two lone yellow cedars with nests, but without the buffer of other trees, the ancient giants soon toppled.
Mr. Curtis said the federal Government is now considering a stewardship program that would offer financial incentives and, in some cases, compensation to landowners who agree to protect wildlife habitat.
A new endangered species bill could be introduced before Parliament breaks for summer recess, said Mr. Curtis.

HEADLINE: The World;
Two Different Tyrants, Very Much the Same

BYLINE: By ALISON SMALE 

 BODY:
BACK in the West's halcyon days, spring 1991, when Saddam Hussein had just been vanquished in the gulf war and Eastern Europe had apparently jettisoned Communism for good, few Americans had even heard of the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic.
Mr. Milosevic was cultivating ethnic hatreds and threatening war, but in a seemingly isolated corner of Europe known to few outsiders and apparently of little concern to Washington. The Iraqi leader, by contrast, had invaded a neighboring country and lobbed missiles at Israel, and was found to have a scary near-ability to launch weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East, an area of undeniable strategic importance. 
 At the end of the first post-cold war decade, however, the challenges posed by the Iraqi and Serbian leaders appear remarkably similar, at least in this: Both have become tactical experts at cornering the world's only superpower, frustrating its diplomatic strategists, tying down its military and periodically daring the United States to use force to get its way. Each has laid bare the lack of a Western strategy to deal with dictators who, simply by continuing in power, further weaken the ability of their peoples to resist.
For years, Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Hussein seem almost to have been playing tag team with the United States and its allies. A look back at the 1990's reveals some startling similarities in the ways they operate, and in the ways the West seems to have missed opportunities to weaken each of them.
Both leaders are skilled autocrats, easily able to exploit the inevitable differences that crop up in the coalitions, alliances or international organizations that have tried to rein them in. When it's convenient, each can count on support from Russia or China. At home, each is adept at manipulating power and at turning foreign embargoes, threats or bombing to his own advantage: Who, after all, would publicly oppose a leader who paints himself as defender of a victimized nation under foreign attack? Despite the occasional seeming defeat inflicted from outside, and the suffering of people in economies squeezed by embargoes and by the control of these leaders and their cliques, neither man seems in danger of being dislodged.
As far back as that spring of 1991, before the old Yugoslavia descended into war, demonstrators in Belgrade picked up on the similarities, chanting "Slobo-Saddam!" to demonize their leader. With the instinct born of the direct experience of repression, they sensed that both men were master players of high-stakes poker, prepared to use violence and even to gamble their very countries to preserve their own power.
IT is a lesson that the West, however, appears to have spent little time understanding: that the key to the survival of Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Hussein has been their intimate acquaintance with the yearnings and frailties of their people (Mr. Milosevic has even won several flawed but not entirely unfair elections).
The Serbian leader has retained power largely by stirring up crisis after crisis, then uniting Serbs behind his alleged defense of their interests. Long-term success is not required for his own survival -- he has, for instance, lost the territories he mobilized Serbs to seize in Croatia and Bosnia -- so long as the attention of his weary people can be channeled elsewhere. Even now, with NATO threatening to bomb Serbia if Mr. Milosevic does not allow the alliance to police his restive province of Kosovo, he appears secure. Indeed, he retains the power to ignite a far bloodier war in Kosovo and beyond, a power that commands the West's attention. He can survive in his self-cast role as his people's champion against the hostile, powerful outside world.
So too Saddam. Mr. Hussein has lost some formal control over Iraq. Foreign inspectors have probed his arsenals. The Central Intelligence Agency has reportedly tried to muster resistance inside Iraq. For more than two months, foreign jets have regularly bombed targets inside the northern and southern reaches of the country.
These regions are home to the Kurdish minority and the Shiite Muslim majority who oppose Mr. Hussein's Sunni Muslim minority, which has traditionally ruled Iraq. Yet Mr. Hussein, whose security apparatus is far larger and more ruthless than that of Mr. Milosevic, also seems in no obvious danger of losing control. He retains large oil reserves, and perhaps even an ability to build weapons of mass destruction.
Mr. Hussein, whose image entirely dominates public life in Iraq, brooks so little opposition that dissent can be openly voiced only abroad. America has been slow to engage the admittedly murky and bitterly divided opposition groups. Belated attempts to do so have yielded a new radio station, Radio Free Iraq, and a $97 million Iraqi Liberation Act that so far has dispensed none of the materiel it pledged to make available to opposition groups. Of the opposition groups targeted to receive support, at least one announced from its Teheran headquarters that it had no interest in Washington's backing.
In Serbia, a number of parties that are now arrayed against Mr. Milosevic sprang up largely as he was assuming power in the late 1980's. He has proven skilled at infiltration and at buying off these rivals. The opposition is now so feckless that even its members say they have little hope. Students or independent media that do challenge Mr. Milosevic are weak and immediately feel a repressive hand if they start to make an impact. They also lack any significant foreign backing.
Individual diplomats and outside groups have tried to support what Warren Zimmermann, the last American Ambassador to Yugoslavia, has called "the other Serbia." But during mass demonstrations against Mr. Milosevic that erupted in the winter of 1996, many Serbian students wondered why the rest of Europe was ignoring their movement. It was, they felt, as if they were being demonized along with their leader. The few foreign envoys who do come to Serbia see Mr. Milosevic and pay any others scant heed.
Critics of American diplomacy say that by ignoring Serbs and Iraqis who oppose Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Hussein the West has missed a chance to advance democracy in the Balkans, where the Serbs traditionally have played a vanguard role, and in the Middle East, where Iraq's middle class was once among the most enlightened and educated.
Instead, unwittingly, Western policy has helped smash that vibrant middle class in both countries. Official media drive home the siege mentality, playing on the threat from outside to squelch dissent. Tough sanctions have fostered rampant corruption, which gnaws ever deeper into the moral fiber of societies weakened by wars the leaders helped to launch.
Emigration has added to the ruin. In both countries, a new merchant class has sprung up, owing its wealth to smuggling. To ply their illicit trade, these people must make at least a tacit pact with their Governments and are thus a crucial source of support for Mr. Hussein and Mr. Milosevic. They help convey an illusion that the two countries are still part of the modern world; despite the United Nations' embargo, almost any consumer wares are available in Baghdad, as they were in Belgrade when it was under sanctions from 1992 to 1995.
In the Iraqi countryside, the Government reportedly gives seed, land or machinery to traditionally respected rural leaders, who in turn help insure obedience. In rural Serbia, the source of most of Mr. Milosevic's votes in elections, the leader and his Socialist Party can use structures inherited from the old League of Communists to exercise similar control.
CAN anything now be done to turn the tide in Serbia, or Iraq? In both countries, hopeful Clinton Administration officials suggest that the demise of Mr. Hussein and Mr. Milosevic is closer than either may believe. If NATO does bomb Serbia, the Yugoslav Army might turn away from Mr. Milosevic. But even if he is then forced to accept NATO's soldiers in Kosovo, he will remain in control of most of Serbia, with all of its new resentments of the West. High-ranking foreign visitors could invest in a different future by visiting Mr. Milosevic's critics, as was routinely done, say, in Moscow under the Soviets.
Neither country will change overnight. One journalist who has lived in Belgrade all her life recently wrote to a friend about a change she had seen in the last decade in how Serbs treat each other. A woman tending flowers in a park had hurled an ax at the journalist's dog, she wrote. Even after Mr. Milosevic goes, she concluded, "we will be left with all those semi-humans" that the recent past has created.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
If You Spend a Million, They'll Throw In a Jaguar

BYLINE: By JANE WOLFE 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
WHEN Sara M. Dunham regularly drives the seven hours from her home in Baton Rouge, La., to work on spending about $200,000 a year at the flagship Neiman Marcus store here, her rewards go beyond the clothing, jewelry and furs she buys. As a member of In Circle, the Neiman Marcus frequent-shopper club, she will be treated this year to a free week in Milan with her husband, with first-class flights and hotels. Last year, it was Paris.
But now Mrs. Dunham's loyalty may be tested. Other high-end retailers, especially Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf Goodman, whose two stores, in Manhattan, are owned by Neiman Marcus, are also trying to lure shoppers like her. The new competition has meant enhanced loyalty programs with more perks like special discounts, trips abroad and exclusive social events inside and outside the stores. 
 The retailers say the programs show how important those shoppers are to them. "Neiman's, Saks, and Bergdorf's all go after the richest 2 percent of the nation's people," says Howard L. Davidowitz, a New York retail consultant. "You're shooting for a class of people who spend $6,000 for a dress. You have to coddle these people constantly because you cannot afford to lose even a few of them as customers."
Which program is best? It depends on whether a shopper wants merchandise discounts or other goodies. The value of the bonuses usually ranges from 1 percent to, at higher levels, 6 percent of the amount spent. Because most programs require use of the retailers' own charge cards -- or special, affiliated cards -- shoppers should also compare their terms and interest rates with those of other credit cards, some of which offer frequent-flier miles or other rewards of their own.
The latest retailer to join the contest is Bergdorf Goodman. Hoping for quick gains, Bergdorf, unlike Neiman and Saks, will allow customers to earn award points on any credit card, although its own offers twice the points.
Saks, meanwhile, is making its biggest splash among the designer-label set with its four-year-old Platinum Events, each more lavish than the last. Last month, 40 Platinum members, who spend at least $10,000 a year, dined with their spouses and friends on leeks with caviar, lobster-filled zucchini blossoms and rack of lamb with gingered eggplant at Chanterelle in Manhattan. In attendance were Philip B. Miller, the chief executive of Saks, and Donna Karan, who told the guests that she would be in the flagship store the next day to help them design their wardrobes.
Both Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus offer their members shopping nights when the stores are closed to everyone but them. They are feted with cocktails and food and have a chance to chat with designers and executives. At Neiman events, there is another bonus: double In Circle points.
Loyalty programs are also offered by chains like Bloomingdale's, a unit of Federated Department Stores; Marshall Field, a unit of Dayton Hudson, and Nordstrom. The plans can provide discounts or gift certificates for users of the stores' charge cards or affiliated Visa cards. But Richard G. Barlow, publisher of the Colloquy newsletter, which tracks frequent-buyer and frequent-traveler programs, says these other plans, which require just $500 or $1,000 of purchases, are not snobbish enough.
"To make the customer feel important, you've got to be exclusive," Mr. Barlow said. "Neiman's realized before anyone else that since so many stores have the same merchandise, it's no longer sufficient to focus on what you sell but rather on who is buying it."
THE retailers disagree over how shoppers want to be rewarded. Members of the Saks First program, who must spend a minimum of $2,000, get points redeemable only at Saks. "We did extensive research that showed our customers really did not want trips," said Sheri Wilson-Gray, marketing vice president.
Still, serious shoppers appreciate things that they can't secure themselves. "Even if you have great wealth," Ms. Wilson-Gray said, "it's not necessarily within your power to call up Donna Karan and say, 'Will you personally help me create my spring wardrobe?' "
Neiman Marcus's In Circle, founded in 1984, gives one point for every dollar spent by its 150,000 members. It was inspired by the American Airlines frequent-flier plan, begun in 1981, shortly after American moved to Dallas. "Since they were in our own backyard, we were watching them very closely," said Billy J. Payton, Neiman's marketing vice president. "We knew that recognizing and rewarding customers based on spending was driving market share in the airline industry, and we were trying to develop the same kind of program."
Like the airlines' frequent-flier programs, the stores' plans encourage the notion that spending in the pursuit of ostensibly free awards is downright thrifty. "My secretary was reading my Neiman's statement and said to me, 'You're just $200 short of getting the award for 3,000 American Airlines points,' " said Nancy O. Lemmon, a civic and social leader here. "So I raced down to Neiman's and spent more than $200 for a sweater and got the points."
Those who spend $100,000 can choose tickets to the Super Bowl or the Kentucky Derby, with first-class airline tickets and hotel rooms. Spend a million and get a Jaguar S-Type, or a one-week annual stay for life (and for the lives of your children) at the Four Seasons Punta Mita resort near Puerto Vallarta on Mexico's west coast, or one million frequent flier points.
At her award level, Mrs. Dunham has missed a trip only one year in the history of In Circle, when she was in a hospital. Neiman sent over a food spread that included its chicken soup.
