HEADLINE: An Activist Shareholder TakesOn The World

BYLINE: By HILARY ROSENBERG; Hilary Rosenberg is the author of "A Traitor to His Class: Robert A. G. Monks and the Battle to Change Corporate America" (John Wiley & Sons, 1999).

 BODY:
ROBERT A. G. MONKS, money manager and shareholder rights proponent, has long been a sort of Lone Ranger of American investing, charging in to exhort companies to change their ways in the name of helping shareholders.
Now, profligate managements abroad are starting to pay heed to Mr. Monks, who is 65. The Lens Fund, the institutional investment vehicle he runs, is being folded into Hermes Pensions Management, a British concern with 40 billion ($65.3 billion) under management that is owned by a giant pension fund, BT Pension Scheme. He will help oversee investing at Hermes Lens International, which will be a holding company for the Lens Fund, soon to be renamed to reflect its new status. 
 After the deal's closing, which is imminent, the Lens fund will have a big-name backer. With new asset contributions from Hermes and extra marketing, the fund's assets under management will likely rise to about $220 million, from $100 million.
In Britain, Hermes Lens International will oversee U.K. Focus, a joint fund of Hermes and Lens which Mr. Monks already helps manage. It has been active since last October and has about 150 million in assets. Mr. Monks said Hermes Lens International would manage a family of funds, with new offerings in Europe and Japan.
Why did Mr. Monks, at an age when others ponder retirement, choose this new effort? Because it is a mission. "What I do is make power accountable," he said.
With its extra resources, the United States fund plans to step up its activities. There is plenty of corporate mismanagement about, Mr. Monks said; he contends that the strong economy has hidden many sins, which will eventually come to light.
One red flag is executive pay levels. Mr. Monks said excessive compensation signals that a company's board is not truly independent of its management.
Mr. Monks's brand of activism amounts to a kind of value investing. Lens buys large positions, typically under 5 percent, in a few underperforming companies and then tries to persuade their managements to make changes that Mr. Monks expects to benefit shareholders. If they won't, he rallies others with proxy fights or takes his arguments to the news media.
Lens's investing style pays. In six years of operation, through Dec. 30, 1998, it returned 25.1 percent a year, on average, compared with 20.5 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Mr. Monks "is the founder of the modern corporate governance movement and certainly its most effective advocate," said Richard Schlefer, the director of corporate governance at T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., the giant retirement fund.
Lens now owns shares in six United States companies, and, this month, Mr. Monks started a campaign for a board seat at Juno Lighting, a lighting fixtures manufacturer based in Des Plaines, Ill., in which Lens has a 6.7 percent stake. Lens began buying Juno shares in October 1997, at just over $18.
There are two problems at Juno, Mr. Monks said: Nearly half of its assets are in cash and only one of its five board members is an independent outsider. Juno did not return phone calls last week seeking comment.
In an analysis early last year, Lens stated its belief that Juno stock could rise to $31 a share if it put its cash to work. Juno shares closed on Friday at $20.875.
One successful investment has been Reader's Digest Association. Given its declining profits and lack of independent outside directors, it seemed an ideal stock pick for Lens. Although a pair of charitable foundations control the company as holders of the voting class of shares, Mr. Monks felt that Lens could influence the situation, so the fund started buying shares in December 1997 at just over $23 for each A share.
He has been pleased with the actions of the new chief executive, Thomas O. Ryder, to add independent directors, sell some noncore assets and reduce costs. Mr. Monks had figured the stock was worth $34 a share when he started buying; it is now at $34.875. Lens has taken some profits on the position.
In Britain, the U.K. Focus fund holds eight stocks. One is Mirror Group, a media conglomerate whose chief executive, David Montgomery, recently resigned after U.K. Focus led a campaign seeking his ouster because shareholders had lost confidence in him. The fund started buying Mirror shares in October at about 140 pence ($2.28). They closed on Friday at 204 pence.

HEADLINE: COPING;
East Harlem Provocateur on the City Payroll

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
"YOU come back in six months," Philip Reed said to me 13 months ago. He was just starting his first year as a member of the City Council. "I might have answers. I will surely have a carpet on the floor."
A practical blue carpet was on the floor when I got back to Mr. Reed's East Harlem office last week, but the boiler was broken. No heat or hot water. 
 Mr. Reed was waiting to hear from the landlord, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. We kept our jackets on. What about those answers?
"Rudy and I have similar styles," Mr. Reed said, warming up. His expressions and rhythms recall the comic and civil rights activist Dick Gregory. "We are provocative. We don't believe in politics as usual."
I rubbed my cold hands. "But what have you learned while on the city payroll?"
Mr. Reed flashed a smile even more dazzling than his newly shaved head. "I have learned that it is essential to have dialogue, to maintain an intimate, backslapping collegiality, interesting for a gay man, and that if you want to get things done, don't get on this administration's radar screen. Even when you're on the same side."
Because asthma is a major issue in Mr. Reed's district, the Eighth District, which includes chunks of East Harlem, the Upper West Side and the South Bronx, he has been involved with the Health Department, giving out information and medical equipment.
But that doesn't mean, he said, that as a Democrat he can just go chat with commissioners and department doctors. Kenny Scott, his executive assistant, and Delfina Cruz, his constituent liaison, plot elaborate "chance" meetings in hospital cafeterias and street rallies. Mr. Reed "bumps into" bureaucrats. Even his officially sanctioned meetings require an overseer from Mayor Giuliani's staff, he said.
"Sounds like Moscow in the 60's," I said. "Actually, I felt safer thinking my translator was KGB."
Mr. Reed smiled, too cagey to engage in any direct discussion linking the Mayor to a repressive foreign government.
"I have also learned," he said, "just how sophisticated my constituents are. They are willing to give me credit for working hard, even if I don't succeed, because they understand what we're up against. Take the Mayor's plan to cut the arts budget, which will affect El Museo del Barrio, a major cultural institution up here, not to mention a place where latchkey kids go after school.
"Meanwhile, he's dropping $65 million on the Museum of Modern Art. He can talk about economic impact. But we know it's about caring more for tourists than residents, who are not benefiting from this famous renaissance while he is grandstanding to a larger audience. He is setting himself up for higher office. That means looking tough on poor people and black people."
Mr. Reed's smile became chilly. Maybe it was the temperature. "If crime is really down, maybe we should rethink all the anticrime cops on the street. Four times more cops looking for fewer guns can translate into shooting Amadou Diallo."
This has been a busy year for Mr. Reed, who had back surgery in October, turned 50 last month and sponsored 108 pieces of legislation, remarkable for someone whose campaign was dubbed "Dead Man Running." He has been treated for Stage 3 multiple myeloma, a bone marrow cancer now in remission, and has been H.I.V.-positive since 1981.
Mr. Reed has been appointed to the Council's public safety committee, which has police oversight. He got $400,000 of the capital budget to build a bathroom at the ballfield on Second Avenue and 128th Street. In three years, Mr. Reed said, children won't have to urinate along the fence "and people driving by won't think they are animals who don't deserve museums, public schools, gardens and respect from the police."
The Republican Caucus's declaration that black and Latino Council members and their neighborhoods should be grateful for the reduction in crime infuriated Mr. Reed. the other hand, he is amused that Mayor Giuliani gets so much credit for the reduction. Mr. Reed's own name was set in cement on a local playground that was dedicated soon after he took office. He had nothing to do with it.
"Maybe Rudy is truly brilliant," Mr. Reed said, "and he is posturing to start a dialogue that wouldn't otherwise happen. Maybe it's just too much to also want him to stand for something other than himself."
Kenny Scott came in, wearing a windbreaker and a watch cap. He said, "H.P.D. is on the phone."
Mr. Reed jumped to take the call. He said to me: "Come back tomorrow. I might have answers. I will surely have heat."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Market

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of the Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Alexandria, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
DEEP within our psyches, many of us believe that good is inevitably followed by bad. Maybe we've been influenced by predictions like Joseph's in the Book of Genesis, that seven good years in Egypt would be followed by seven so severe that "all the plenty shall be forgotten."
With the Dow Jones industrial average's flirting with 10,000, it is a good time to re-examine this belief. What does history tell us to expect over the next, say, 10 years? Will they be bad years for the market, coming as they do on the heels of 10 fabulous years, when the market has gained 19.1 percent a year, on average? Or is that recent past meaningless? 
 Though they may not realize it, many investors have already answered those questions. Indeed, they assume that the recent past is irrelevant. Many financial planners, as well as economists at life insurance companies and actuaries at retirement plans, project that stocks will produce future gains at their long-term historical average -- between 10 percent and 11 percent a year -- despite the last decade's outsized gains.
Unfortunately, history suggests otherwise, according to the consensus of several finance professors I have consulted. When measured over a several-year horizon -- say, five to eight years -- returns on stocks tend to regress to the mean. That means that after several years in which stocks do better than their long-term average -- as they have in the 1990's -- there is a better-than-even chance that they'll underperform over the subsequent several years.
But by how much will they underperform? Specific predictions are hard to come by because the data are insufficient to make forecasts with much statistical confidence. But two economics professors, John Campbell of Harvard University and Robert Shiller of Yale University, have played out several what-if scenarios, all of which have profoundly bearish conclusions. The findings are even scarier in that they depend on just two seemingly innocuous assumptions.
The first assumption: Stocks will someday trade at their historically average valuations. That means stocks will eventually trade at an average price-to-earnings ratio of 14, in contrast to 31 today. That is unobjectionable, given that stocks have always returned to their historical valuations, even if they take their time in doing so.
The second assumption: Earnings per share at American companies will not grow appreciably faster than the economy. That also seems above reproach. Earnings per share may grow faster than the economy for a year or two, but it's hard to imagine that they can do so indefinitely.
Granted these two assumptions, how bearish should we be? It depends on how long we assume it takes for stocks to return to their historical valuations. If it takes 10 years, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, in inflation-adjusted terms, will end up a third lower than it is today, according to the professors. And if it takes less than 10 years, the index will have to fall even further.
Note that the two professors assume that P/E ratios will return only to their historical average -- around 14. They aren't assuming something far worse: the extremely low ratios seen at bear-market bottoms -- about 6, for example, in December 1974.
Of course, it may take longer than a decade for stocks to return to their average valuations, but that is small consolation. Over the last 130 years, it has never taken more than 20 years for stocks to do so. According to the professors, even if it takes 20 years -- until 2019 -- the S.& P. 500, in inflation-adjusted terms, will nevertheless be 20 percent lower then than it is today.
What has to happen for the professors to be wrong? Stocks must either remain at high P/E levels, or earnings per share must keep growing faster than the economy -- not just for a year or two, but for many years. Those are the twin hopes of investors who believe we've entered a new era, one in which anything is possible. Unfortunately, those believers include investors with a lot to lose: people who have but a few years until retirement, yet confidently keep their money in stocks.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
I'm the Fiscal Purist. No, I Am.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Federal budget deficit is history, and the strong economy is generating surpluses that could last for decades. But in Washington, pledges of budgetary austerity are emanating from both parties in a way they never did when the outlook was bleak.
Yes, Republicans are still fixated on a big tax cut, and Democrats still tend to want to throw money at problems. But both parties have built their agendas this year around the goals of reducing the national debt and keeping spending in check. 
 There are certainly great economic benefits to be gained from keeping the country's financial house in order and using any windfall wisely. Still, given that Washington's commitment to fiscal discipline was notably absent during the 1980's and early 1990's when it was arguably needed most, it seems fair to wonder whether this bipartisan outbreak of responsibility will prove more than a passing political fad.
Chances are that by the end of the year Congress and President Clinton will have broken the strict spending caps at the heart of the current budget law. As the $20 billion burst of last-minute spending outside the caps last year proved, it's hard to hold the line when faced with pleas for aid to hard-pressed farmers, or pay increases for the military, or more money for Head Start.
Moreover, even with the country as flush as it is, there is little evidence that the two parties will be able to turn their good intentions into agreements on shoring up the twin pillars of the social welfare system: Social Security and Medicare.
Implicit in the whole austerity effort, however transitory, is the broader question of whether it requires a crisis to take tough action or whether, as Mr. Clinton likes to say, the best time to fix the roof is while the sun is shining.
If political positioning were the standard, the answer would be clear. For now at least, Democrats and Republicans alike are determined to portray themselves as not just fiscally pure but purer than the other party.
Mr. Clinton started the bidding by proposing that three-quarters of projected surpluses be set aside, effectively through debt reduction, to deal with the looming problems in Social Security and Medicare.
Republicans countered last week with a plan to stop the longstanding practice by both parties of using Social Security's reserves to pay for spending and tax cuts. Then, in votes in the House and Senate Budget Committees, Democrats tried to up the ante by proposing to bar any tax cuts until the long-range solvency of both Social Security and Medicare has been assured (the Republicans defeated the effort). Finally, Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee voted with Republicans to reject Mr. Clinton's budget proposal because it dipped into Social Security money for a few years to pay for spending programs.
Behind much of the maneuvering is an attempt by each party to define itself for the new politics of prosperity.
Notwithstanding the reality that the deficit exploded on President Ronald Reagan's watch in the 1980's as they cut taxes, pumped up the Pentagon budget and did little to restrain domestic spending, Republicans have long laid claim to being the party of fiscal responsibility. Having seen the Democrats under Mr. Clinton co-opt them on so many issues, Republicans are eager to reassert themselves on this one.
"If we're not recognized as the party that wants to restrain spending and cut taxes, what's the purpose?" said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee.
For Democrats, the situation is more complicated. On one level, many Democrats, even some liberals, now seem convinced that the nation cannot afford to spend with abandon, and that keeping the Federal budget under control yields big benefits to working families by keeping interest rates, inflation and unemployment down.
But Democrats also believe that using the bulk of anticipated surpluses in a way that helps Social Security and Medicare works for them on both political and policy grounds. If they prevail this year, it will be because Mr. Clinton managed to link the idea of debt repayment to strengthening the two most popular social welfare programs.
FROM the Democratic perspective, the argument is simple: A sweeping tax cut now, before the expected surpluses materialize, risks squandering the best chance to deal with Social Security and Medicare while requiring painful and unjustified cuts in a wide array of popular programs. If they can block Republican tax cuts and in the process erase the tax-and-spend stigma they have been stuck with for years, so much the better.
The professed commitment to austerity within both parties appears to be driven in part by a palpable sense of skepticism among voters -- evident in polls and in meetings between elected officials and constituents -- that the promised surpluses will ever materialize.
"The Clinton Administration and Democrats more generally have discovered that the best route to achieving liberal ends may be conservative means, especially when those ends are defined as preserving the social welfare programs most highly regarded by the citizenry," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution. "That approach has the great benefit of matching the priority of the public."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
DangerousSelectivity About Rules of Global Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN peacetime, Washington starts trade wars. First there was the Battle of the Bananas, still being slugged out across the Atlantic. Then came the gleaming edge of steel, a fight that pits the workers of Weirton, W. Va., against their counterparts in Brazil, Russia, Japan, Korea and China. For this week, the White House has scheduled a beef over hormone-treated meat.
Listening to the rhetoric here in recent weeks, it would be easy to conclude that there is a theme to these epic struggles: enforcing the rule of law around the globe. All nations, the White House and Congress proclaim, must learn to live by the trading guidelines established under international treaties. 
 Sometimes this argument has the ring of sincerity about it. At other moments, like some last week on Capitol Hill, it smacks of disingenuousness and even rank political hypocrisy. Usually there's a little of both.
Consider the issue that has turned NATO allies into economic enemies: yellow fruit. The Clinton Administration argues that this only looks like a laughable argument over a product neither grown in America nor picked by American workers.
Yes, they acknowledge somewhat sheepishly, Washington is doing the bidding of Carl H. Lindner, the chairman of Chiquita Brands. Lots of industries complain about their treatment abroad, but Mr. Lindner, a big contributor to Democrats and Republicans alike, has been more skilled than most in getting the political establishment to take up his cause -- no easy task when barely a single American job is at stake.
It turns out that Mr. Lindner has a legitimate complaint. The World Trade Organization has consistently ruled that Europe discriminates against bananas grown in Central America, where Chiquita has long held sway, and in favor of those grown in Caribbean countries that were European colonies not long ago. Europe has openly defied the rulings, tinkering with its banana imports but never solving the problem.
Eventually, the Administration decided to hit Europe where it hurt, slapping 100 percent tariffs on luxury goods, including -- this is where it really gets nasty -- pecorino cheese. You could feel the chill in Zabar's.
President Clinton, who has spent far more time on the banana issue than one might expect of the leader of the free world, says the real issue is the rule of law. "If we're going to have a global trading system and a system for resolving disputes," he said recently, then Europe is going to have to learn to obey W.T.O. decisions. "I think most people in Europe believe we shouldn't have won, but sometimes we lose cases we think we shouldn't have lost," Mr. Clinton said.
He meant to be lecturing the Europeans, but the message hasn't exactly sunk in on Capitol Hill. American lawmakers, like their European counterparts, believe it is vital to obey the rules -- except, of course, when they run counter to American economic interests; then they are an intolerable interference with American sovereignty.
That explains how the House, in an overwhelming 289-141 vote on Wednesday, passed some of the most protectionist legislation in 60 years. It directed the Administration to limit steel imports from other nations by any means necessary -- quotas, tariffs or "voluntary" agreements with other countries. The House bill is unlikely to become law, but it sent a clear message heard around the world.
Most everyone in Congress knows that setting unilateral import limits violates the treaty that established the W.T.O. four years ago -- a treaty the Senate ratified. But the logic that won the day belonged to George Becker, the president of the United Steelworkers of America, who said a series of White House steps to punish countries that "dump" low-cost steel in the American market was not enough.
"Steelworkers and steel communities hold dear the notion that America's trade policies should benefit Americans first," Mr. Becker said. "That may be a novel idea in some quarters, but it was a winning idea today in Congress."
AMERICA FIRST is a thrilling campaign line, but Republicans and Democrats alike recognize the likely reaction: counter-retaliation, in equal disregard of the W.T.O.'s rules. It is one of the rare issues on which Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Dick Armey, the House majority leader, actually agree. "The dangers of drifting -- or in this case, racing -- toward protectionist policies are very real," Mr. Armey said. "Let's not kid ourselves. It will not make anything better; in fact, it will make things much worse."
It is a warning worth remembering this week as American negotiators try to strike a deal with China on its entry into the W.T.O. Why would America want a country that may be stealing weapons designs, and is certainly imprisoning dissidents, inside the organization that sets the world's trade rules and judges who is violating them? Not as an act of charity, but to enmesh China's leaders in a system that sets some standards of international behavior.
But which is more powerful, the standard or the example? When Beijing is faced with deciding whether it must comply with unpopular rules that may cost its workers jobs, it is likely to look closely at how Washington handles the same problem.

HEADLINE: The North Korean Threat

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has defused a dangerous crisis by persuading North Korea to permit unlimited American inspections of a suspicious construction site. Washington feared the area was being readied for secret nuclear weapons work. But the inspection agreement leaves many problems unresolved, including the future of North Korea's provocative long-range missile program.
North Korea seems to be running an international extortion racket, trying to trade in threatening weapons programs for food, cash and other forms of assistance. Even worse, it may hope to continue secretly developing these weapons, with which it could threaten South Korea, Japan and the United States in a future crisis. America needs to change the nature of the bargaining by developing a more comprehensive approach. 
 Washington's 1994 agreement with Pyongyang has frozen North Korean nuclear weapons development for nearly five years. But it has also encouraged the North to seek new rewards in exchange for restraining its missile program and for allowing inspections of the new construction site. In the latest agreement, the Administration rightly rejected calls for large cash payments and agreed instead to a modest increase in food aid. Private American groups will also help the North increase its potato crop.
Talks on the missile issue resume March 29 and American negotiators should make clear that Washington does not want another one-issue deal. Congress and the Administration are understandably frustrated with North Korea's seemingly unending series of threats and demands. To break out of this pattern, the White House last fall asked William Perry, the former Defense Secretary, to review American policy on North Korea. His recommendations are expected next month.
The Administration should offer North Korea a plan to reduce tensions between the two countries. The Administration should make clear that it would be willing to ease economic sanctions and move toward diplomatic recognition. In return, Washington should insist that North Korea make a verifiable commitment to cease all dangerous weapons production and sales.

HEADLINE: The Nation: The Perpetual-Motion Economy;
The Stronger It Gets, the Sweatier the Palms

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Dow Jones industrial average floats near 10,000. Jobs are plentiful. Wages are rising. Spending is everywhere. The economy booms, month after month. And nothing seems to shake the public sense of prosperity. So why are the oracles of the economy talking like Nervous Nellies?
Listen to Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who told Congress last month that the economy "appears stretched in a number of dimensions." That on top of his insistence last September that America cannot remain an "oasis of prosperity." Or hear out Warren E. Buffett, the celebrated stock market guru, who said on national television not three weeks ago: "The level of speculation is high by any historic standard. And you know that doesn't go on forever." 
 Or worry with Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics, who said in an interview last week: "We have had three awfully good years now, and an incredible fourth quarter. But any setback can start the dominoes falling. Who knows what's next."
The nervousness, in fact, may be appropriate. This is hardly a standard, predictable boom. Normally, there is a beginning, middle and end -- the typical post-World War II experience. After a recession or period of sluggish growth, spending picks up and so does investment. Low-interest loans and more jobs help the process along, and the economy expands briskly.
IN time, however, people find themselves pressed financially. Worried, they slow their spending, and investment drops off. Or shortages develop, prices rise and the Federal Reserve, fearing too much inflation, raises interest rates to discourage the borrowing that sustains good times. Either way, sluggish growth returns, or a recession sets in.
But the boom that started in late 1995 broke this pattern. It is like a perpetual-motion machine, each part keeping the others moving -- and moving indefinitely, many Americans have come to believe. "There is this sense that we don't have to worry about problems or adverse conditions," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. A "virtuous circle," economists call the new machinery.
The trouble is, if one part malfunctions, or breaks, the whole contraption may collapse. "A vicious circle would replace the virtuous one," Mr. Solow said, "and feed on itself."
The perpetual-motion economy, in brief outline, works this way: The rising stock market generates the household wealth that encourages the borrowing that pays for the spending that creates the jobs and the higher wages that generate the confidence that encourages people to invest in stocks and make the market rise some more.
"Many of us who have been doubters are starting to believe that this thing can go on forever," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "That is a complacency we may live to regret. But I cannot really substantiate doubt for a good analytic reason."
The stock market, a secondary player in standard booms, is the biggest cog this time around. As stock prices have shot up, household wealth has more than doubled in recent years. Wages have risen, but not nearly as fast as the rise in household wealth. And people are spending their new wealth, either by selling stock or borrowing against it. Not that the stock is the actual collateral. Instead, millions of people are putting up their homes as collateral, but with the thought, lenders and economists say, that they can sell stock to repay debt if necessary.
"The stock market has become a way of extracting equity from housing," said Wynne Godley, an economist at the Jerome Levy Institute.
Mortgage and home equity loans, as a result, are the fastest-rising form of consumer debt in recent months, the Federal Reserve reports. Why not? After all, stock prices won't go down that much, in the view of many Americans. "God, if we could only bottle all this confidence," Mr. Curtin said.
The perpetual-motion economy has other intriguing components. Inflation has stayed low, depriving the Federal Reserve of a reason to raise interest rates and provoke a slowdown. One big reason for the low inflation: Businesses here and abroad are producing more than people want to buy, even high-spending Americans. Oil and raw materials are particularly inexpensive, and the competition to sell all the excess production holds down prices. Not even a low unemployment rate and rising wages offset this downward pressure on prices.
The low inflation, in turn, produces low interest rates, which encourage people to borrow and spend on home construction, for example, and autos. Jobs are created, wages rise, confidence flourishes and more money is invested in the stock market, creating more wealth for households to borrow against. The flywheel keeps turning.
The global economic slowdown offers a separate contribution to this self-perpetuating mechanism. Asia's economies, including Japan's, are hurting. Europe is not particularly robust either. So corporate Asia and corporate Europe have turned to America, selling their merchandise here at what amounts to discount prices, helping to keep inflation down. There is one more link in this circle: Foreign investors take some of the dollars earned here and, rather than invest them back home, buy American securities, including stocks -- and share prices rise.
"I think the boom in America that seems so enduring will come to an ironic end," said John Makin, an economist and senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. "As the rest of the world does better, that will put a cap on things here for a while."
Mr. Makin is rather mild in his nervousness. So are Joel Prakken and Chris Varvares, partners at Macroeconomic Advisers, a forecasting firm in St. Louis. They see a gradual slowdown ahead because they believe stock prices will stop rising this year, and interest rates might edge up a bit.
BUT they don't see stock prices falling sharply enough to halt the perpetual-motion economy. Average stock prices would have to fall at least 30 percent and stay down for at least six months, an unlikely event in the view of most Wall Street economists and certainly in the view of many shareholders.
The Nervous Nellies are not mollified. What really seems to worry them is a new article of faith on Wall Street and among many Americans that if stock prices really drop, the Federal Reserve will save the day by lowering interest rates, thus adding fresh impetus to the perpetual-motion machine.
Such an optimistic expectation annoys Fed officials. One of Mr. Greenspan's top lieutenants, Michael J. Prell, the director of research, made the point in a recent speech.
"Might people -- business managers, consumers, investors -- be taking risks that they would not have taken were it not for an exaggerated confidence in the ability of the Fed to cushion the economy and financial markets against any and all shocks?" Mr. Prell asked. "If so, there conceivably could be a greater potential instability in the system than is readily apparent at this time."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Betting on a Good Hand"
The strength of the nation's economy, reflected in a soaring stock market, low inflation, rising household wealth and strong retail sales, can be compared to the strongest hand in poker: the royal flush, or all five of the most valuable cards of the same suit. One card different and the hand is destroyed. Likewise, if one of the indicators brakes from its current trend - especially if the stock market collapses - the economy's winning hand will be broken.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Taking Off;
Missile Defenses Leave Fantasy Behind

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT'S a far cry from the space-based, rocket-zapping shield that President Ronald Reagan envisioned more than a decade and a half ago in the depths of the cold war. But the country is suddenly jettisoning its qualms about forging a national missile defense and is moving fast toward building one.
The threat is not an all-out strike from thousands of Soviet missiles, which prompted Mr. Reagan to launch the anti-missile program popularly known as "Star Wars" in 1983. The fear now is that rogue nations like North Korea or Iran, with little or no warning, could lob a devastating missile or two into Los Angeles or Seattle. This anxiety has been heightened by suspicions that China stole American nuclear secrets in the 1980's to enhance its small nuclear arsenal. 
 Such developments helped prompt the Senate and House last week to vote overwhelmingly in favor of anti-missile defenses as a matter of national policy, while stopping short of actually appropriating money for construction. Even the White House has reversed its opposition to the legislation, lending conditional support and pledging $10.5 billion in preliminary funding over the next six years. Clearly, pressure is mounting on President Clinton to actually build a system, once proven feasible, and he says he will decide by June 2000.
There are two surprises here. One is that anti-missile defenses, once strongly opposed and even ridiculed by Democrats and others, seem to be almost magically melting away as a domestic political issue. The second is that anti-missile defenses are more contentious than ever as an international political issue -- even with Russia, America's main nuclear rival, in eclipse.
Moscow is now threatening to stop reducing its 7,000-warhead arsenal if the United States breaks out of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, which bars national defensive systems. China, meanwhile, says fielding missile defenses in Asia could seriously escalate tensions over Taiwan.
With the Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, arriving here on Tuesday for talks, and his Chinese counterpart, Zhu Rongji, due in Washington early next month, Mr. Clinton's foreign policy aides are bracing for a rough few weeks.
But first, why are things growing quiet on the domestic front?
For years, Republicans from Mr. Reagan onward tried to make missile defenses a national priority -- in an era when the threat of attack was arguably much bigger than it is now -- and for years they were opposed and even scoffed at by less hawkish opponents.
LAST year, however, a string of startling events prompted a sea change. A bipartisan commission headed by Donald H. Rumsfeld, a Republican and former Defense Secretary, warned in July that within five years, North Korea and Iran could have the potential to hit the United States with a ballistic missile.
Six weeks later, as if on cue, North Korea stunned American intelligence analysts by test-launching a three-stage missile with conceivably enough range to hit North America.
Congressional Republicans claimed vindication, and those claims have been enhanced lately by opinion polls showing that the public trusts Republicans over Democrats in matters of national security.
Shaken by the developments, many Democrats have been rethinking their opposition to missile defenses. And the ambitious plans for such defenses have been scaled back -- brought, literally, down to earth -- beginning with plans for about 20 interceptors that could shoot down a handful of missiles.
A crucial, recent convert is Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, the ranking Democrat on the Intelligence Committee.
"The Aug. 31 launch was a watershed moment," Mr. Kerrey said. "There is a growing recognition that there's a real danger of proliferation that produces either an accidental launching or an attack by a rogue nation."
Mr. Kerrey pulled along other centrist Democrats in support of the Republican-sponsored bill that passed in the Senate last week. Fearing that the votes weren't there to sustain a Presidential veto, the White House and Senate Democratic leaders settled for two face-saving amendments that seek to control the cost of any system and to insure arms control talks with Moscow.
"There's a change in Democratic ideology," said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "The old-fashioned Democratic doves of the 1970's are giving way to centrists who are less hostile to defense."
That is not to say that all Democrats have bought into missile defenses. In fact, half the House Democrats opposed such a move last week. After $55 billion invested in developing a national system since the early 1980's (when the Reagan Administration creatively interpreted the A.B.M. treaty to allow research), the technology is still unproven. Moreover, detractors say, terrorists and despots could thwart a sophisticated missile defense with other weapons of terror.
"It could be bypassed with suitcase bombs, pickup trucks and sea-launched missiles," said Representative Rush D. Holt, a New Jersey Democrat who is a physicist. "It would be billions of dollars down the drain."
Pentagon brass dismiss the naysayers, arguing that military contractors and engineers will work out the technical kinks and, by 2005, field a limited system of radars and missile-killing interceptors -- perhaps in Alaska, North Dakota or on ships at sea -- if Mr. Clinton gives the go-ahead.
The fast-emerging consensus for missile defenses at home, however, collides with growing anxiety abroad, particularly in Beijing and Moscow.
Russia has long opposed an American missile defense system, fearing that Washington would use it as an excuse to reprise the much grander Star Wars, which would be dauntingly expensive to match.
While the anti-missile issue is of little concern to ordinary Russians struggling with dire economic conditions, it is core national security for Russian politicians, and a matter of considerable national self-esteem.
With the United States moving ahead on such a system, Russian nationalists could use the argument that Russia was losing its nuclear deterrent -- since an anti-missile defense could encourage a nation with one (that is, the United States) to risk a nuclear exchange. That argument could undercut, for example, efforts by the Russian Parliament to ratify the second strategic arms reduction treaty between the two countries, or Start 2.
Russia's Foreign Ministry warned after the Senate vote last week that building even a limited system "poses a serious threat to the whole process of nuclear arms control, as well as strategic stability."
And for this reason, arms control advocates are nervous about doing anything to upset further nuclear arms reductions with Russia. After all, they say, North Korea may threaten America with one to five missiles, but instability in Russia is a much greater risk. "Our overwhelming and sustained concern has to be Russia," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat, who voted reluctantly for the Senate measure. "They got the most, they got the biggest, and they got the most accurate."
BUT Republicans and a growing number of Democrats say that building an anti-missile system is just as necessary to insure a safer world as reducing Moscow's nuclear stockpile, which is declining with or without a treaty because Russia no longer can afford to maintain it at cold war levels.
"It's a delicate balance with Russia," said Paul J. Wolfowitz, a senior Pentagon official under President Bush and a member of the Rumsfeld panel. "We don't want to alienate the Russians, but on the other hand we can't let them bully us."
In Asia, American-Japanese plans to develop a missile system to defend Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and the American troops in the region got under way about a decade ago, in anticipation of the possible missile threat from North Korea.
As that threat has become more real, the plans to defend against it have encountered growing criticism from China -- and even from key allies. Two weeks ago, South Korea's Defense Minister said a joint American-Japanese missile defense would be ineffective against North Korean missiles, and added that his Government would not help pay for it.
Then there is the possibility that such an anti-missile system might not be ready for years, when there is at least a chance that there won't be a North Korea left to worry about. This is a point not lost on China, which views the proposed missile umbrella primarily as a threat to its plans to reunify Taiwan with the Chinese mainland. Since the early 1990's, China has more or less doubled, to several hundred, the number of missiles on the Chinese coast pointed at Taiwan.
The fear among many national security analysts in Asia is that missile defenses could do to China what the creation of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization did to the Soviet Union: help to trigger a new escalation of arms.
"If we are for the development of advanced missile defense systems, we are going to touch off new rounds of an arms race," said He Yafei, a senior Chinese diplomat in Washington who has long experience in arms control.
And the idea of including Taiwan under any missile umbrella "is an obstruction on our course of unification of our motherland," he added. "Taiwan is part of China. Politically, that is an interference, a very serious interference in our internal affairs."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: March 15-19;
Asian Markets Gain, as the Dow Teases Teases

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
There are momentous thresholds, like the Dow 10,000, and then there is momentum.
 Hong Kong had a bit of both. The Hang Seng index of blue-chip stocks broke the 11,000 level on Friday for the first time in 11 months. The gain was 2.6 percent for the week, to 11,082.92. 
 In Japan, investors were happy to settle for momentum. On Friday, shares surged on the hope that a recovery of the battered economy was in the making. The Nikkei average gained 5.7 percent for the week, to close at 16,378.78. This strong momentum should continue for quite a while, Chua Soon Hock, a strategist at Sanwa Bank in Singapore, told Bloomberg News.
 In the United States, the cat-and-mouse game of the Dow Jones industrial average -- crossing 10,000 and then creeping back -- added a bit of March Madness to the market. Even so, lucidity in the form of an analyst's lower 12-month price target on I.B.M. again postponed a post-10,000 close. The Dow ended the week up just a fraction, closing on Friday at 9,903.55.
 No matter. It crossed 10,000 on Friday morning, and that sent markets in Paris and Frankfurt higher. The CAC-40 index closed up 1.1 percent for the week, while the DAX Xetra ended up 1.5 percent.

HEADLINE: ON (AND UNDER) MY DESK: RUSSELL READ

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
Books and papers are stacked 12 inches high on his desk and heaped in even taller piles under and in front of it. I feel papers and books are ideas, said Russell Read, an economist by training and now the director of investment-product design and risk management at Oppenheimer Funds. I like to be surrounded by ideas.
 On prominent display are two books by the physicist Richard P. Feynman. I like to explore alternative physical structures, Mr. Read said. Also on his desk is a black notebook full of mathematical formulas representing his thinking on how new investment strategies will work. 
 For all the cerebral cast to his work station, however, hints of more mundane pursuits poke through. There is, for example, a beeper that he says was forced on him by his staff. It was like belling the cat, he says. It's my bell. He also keeps an extra pair of shoes under his desk; he walks so much, he says, that he wears out a pair of soles every 10 weeks or so. Next to the shoes is a bomb pack, a gift from his employer. The pack contains a tiny flashlight and a bandanna with a bottle of water -- to combat smoke inhalation. Its presence is a constant reminder of where Mr. Read works -- the World Trade Center, which was bombed six years ago.
 VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN
 
HOMEMADE CALENDAR -- Created by his wife, Andrea, a poet, it features inspirational messages like, "A great man changes the way you see."
 
BEIGNET MIX -- From Cafe du Monde, his favorite cafe in New Orleans. The only problem, he says, is that when he makes the beignets (French doughnuts), they come out flat, not fluffy like the ones served in the cafe.
 
BUDDHA STATUE -- A gift from a friend and a reflection of his fascination with India.

HEADLINE: The World: Latin America's Contagion;
Where Taxes Aren't So Certain

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador

 BODY:
AS the year began, the Ecuadorean Government was nearing bankruptcy, unable to pay teachers, doctors and other public employees or to repair $2.6 billion in damage inflicted by El Nino. Another example of global economic contagion? Not directly. It reflected a much older, if related, problem in Latin America, tax evasion. Here it had become so bad that the Ecuadorean Congress took a truly unorthodox step: It abolished the income tax altogether in favor of a one percent tax on financial transactions.
Ecuador's move was "an act of extraordinary desperation and an admission of defeat," as one American aid official put it last week. In effect, it wrote off the 60 percent or more of taxpayers here who are thought to be dodging their obligations, in hopes that the new tax would be easier to collect. 
 Americans grumbling over their 1040 returns this month might be envious. But there is a sobering context: Governments all over Latin America are coming under pressure from the International Monetary Fund and other lenders to cut their yawning budget deficits and open their economies to the outside world to prevent the spread of the financial slump that has humbled Southeast Asia and crippled Russia (a country with severe tax collection problems of its own). Latin America may yet prove particularly vulnerable to this contagion because development and growth are already crippled by the inability to collect taxes.
"I don't think there is any more vital issue in Latin America right now," said Michael Shifter, a senior fellow at the Washington-based policy analysis group Inter-American Dialogue. "It's a vicious cycle that is very, very hard to break. People don't want to pay taxes because they say government doesn't deliver services, but government institutions aren't going to perform any better until they have resources, which they obtain when people pay their taxes."
One measure of the dimension of the problem is that Brazil, Ecuador and other governments that have been forced to carry out a "fiscal adjustment" have preferred to emphasize spending cuts over new ways to increase revenues. "Since there is a culture of noncompliance in the region," said Luisa Rains, an economist who heads the fiscal division of the Inter-American Development Bank, "you're going to run into resistance and affect various interest groups any time you attempt a real tax modernization."
When Guatemala, another glaring example, signed a United Nations-sponsored peace accord ending its civil war in 1996, it promised to nearly double its tax revenues, to 12 percent of gross domestic product. But the country has failed to comply, and therefore is unable to adequately finance the education, health and land reform programs the accord stipulates. A powerful coalition of agricultural, industrial and financial groups is simply refusing to pay up and has blocked all efforts at tax reform.
Guatemala, of course, is not the only Latin American country famous for the gulf that separates the few who are rich from the many who are poor, and sometimes governments tolerate tax evasion because they are simply too weak to do otherwise.
In other cases, as in Mexico, or in Brazil and other military dictatorships during the 1970's, they do so with political advantage in mind. Newspapers and television stations, for instance, were allowed to evade obligations with the understanding that their debts would be called in if they published material that angered the government.
Even today, many large Latin America companies simply hold onto the income tax and social security payments they deduct from their employees' paychecks. Bribery of tax inspectors, underdeclaration of income and hiding ownership of property are other popular forms of evasion.
"When Leona Helmsley came out and said only little guys pay taxes, she ended up with a jail term," Ms. Rains recalled. "But in any number of Latin American countries, tax codes do not even treat the failure to pay taxes as a crime that requires you to serve a jail sentence." Even when arrests are made, cases can drag on for years.
BECAUSE of their inability or unwillingness to collect income taxes, Latin American countries have traditionally relied on measures such as the value-added tax, which runs as high as Uruguay's 23 percent. But such forms of taxation are highly regressive, placing a heavy burden on the poor and stoking their resentment.
The problem may be especially acute in this Andean nation of 12 million people, which is in the midst of its worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. "Nobody pays taxes," a longtime diplomat here said. "Those in a position to pay the most pay the least, and then they cry the most." As a result, he continued, "the poor say, 'Why should we pay if the rich don't?' "
The flat tax on financial transactions that Ecuador enacted last January (and that resembles a measure approved by Brazil's Congress last week), was supposed to curb the possibilities for evasion. But once again, the citizenry demonstrated an exceptional ability to find a way around paying up.
As soon as the new tax was imposed, local bank deposits dropped 16 percent. Canny depositors simply converted their sucres into dollars and then spirited their money out of the country. That led to a run on the local currency that saw its value drop by more than 40 percent in just a few weeks. So last week, President Jamil Mahuad again gave up in desperation. He agreed to restore the income tax, though without specifying how he intends to enforce collection.

LENGTH: 2778 words

HEADLINE: LIFE AFTER WELFARE -- FIRST TIME FILERS;
On a Once Forlorn Avenue, Tax Preparers Now Flourish

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, March 20

 BODY:
It slopes up from the old Schlitz Brewery, past empty lots, storefront churches, Victory over Violence Park, and the Black Holocaust Museum. It burned in two days of racial violence in 1967. Since then, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, once a proud retailers row, has mostly been known as an asphalt emblem of urban distress.
But in the first tax season since the state completed its radical welfare reductions, King Drive has acquired an unlikely new identity -- as a battleground of bookkeepers. From the Federal Building at its southern base to the "Shalom Zone" of churches in the north, the tax preparers have arrived in droves, seeking the business of the neighborhood's new workers. 
 On a strip once so forlorn it drew a National Guard patrol, H & R Block has decorated a spiffy new office with posters of the Caribbean beaches that beckon those with refunds. Across the street, at its makeshift quarters in an abandoned bakery, Jackson Hewitt, another tax preparation service, has been so busy it has had to double its staff. A few blocks north, at Milwaukee Check Cashers, a tax business is booming behind the bulletproof glass. Tax preparation is such a growth industry here that even a welfare office on King Drive is offering a course in its numerical arts.
Up and down the avenue, the explanation is the same: tough welfare laws are good for business. "With welfare being cut off and everything, everybody's got to go back to work," said Lorenzo Cartman, who manages the H & R Block office on King Drive. "They either work or they starve, and I don't think they want to starve."
Indeed, Mr. Cartman was so confident in his theory -- less welfare means more work -- that he staked his fortune on it, choosing to manage the King Drive store, over other H & R Block offices, because he thought it would be easier to meet his performance goals. "I was thinking, 'First-time filers!' 'People finally moving out on their own!' " he said. "I liked the numbers."
But tax season on King Drive is more than a simple morality play of poor people going to work. It is a showcase of the competing dynamics involved in the makings of a new working class: low pay and large Government subsidies; old habits and new beginnings; streetwise versions of the white lies that accompany tax season everywhere, and a few outright scams.
Tumbling through a temp-job world, former welfare recipients often arrive at tax offices here with a half-dozen wage statements from a single year. (The record for W-2 forms seems to have been set at the Jackson Hewitt office, where one couple counted 22 between them.) But while earnings are low -- $9,087 on the average return prepared by the check-cashing store -- a growing program of wage supplements turns tax time into a bonanza. Few families pay income tax in poor neighborhoods like this, and many collect thousands of dollars in Government bonuses to the working poor.
Indeed, the $29 billion Federal program, called the earned income tax credit, now transfers more money to the needy in a single season than welfare did all year. And because Wisconsin is one of seven states with a similar program of its own, poor people in Milwaukee can receive combined state and Federal payments that augment their yearly earnings by 30 percent, 40 percent, or even 50 percent. A single mother with three children who earns $10,000, for instance, would qualify for the maximum wage supplement, of $5,371. That is in addition to the refund of any taxes withheld.
While the action along King Drive depicts a level of post-welfare success, it also frames deeper questions about the society being reshaped. More poor people are working, no doubt. And some do see themselves with expanded paychecks and dreams, as the architects of the new system had hoped. But others say that working in the entry-level economy is just another way of staying poor. Is this an old underclass? A nascent middle-class? Somewhere in between?
There are hundreds of answers along King Drive this time of year.
Some new workers talk of starting their own business.
"I want to do my own day care center in my house," said Debra Morton, who collected a $4,100 supplement on earnings of $6,900 and talks of buying paint and plaster. Ms. Morton has been on and off welfare for more than a decade, but she left about two years ago to become a cashier at a discount store. "Welfare's got a lot of rules now," she said. "It's better for me if I work."
Some want to thank the Lord.
"This has made my day!" shouted Toni Harris, 28, when she learned her earnings of $17,000 would bring her a payment of $1,600. A bank clerk by day, Ms. Harris has a second calling as an author of spiritual poetry, and she had a line ready for the occasion:
There are no words to explain my insight
I just praise God for his power and might.
Some want to take a break.
With $1,000 coming back on earnings of $3,100, Valerie Treadwell, a nursing assistant, plans to continue an annual tradition: taking her female partner to a resort in Green Bay, "to get buck naked and let all our inner feelings out."
Some have no plans at all.
"I don't know too much about taxes," said Derenda Turner, 27, who has been on welfare since her daughter was born 12 years ago. With $1,100 in earnings last year -- Ms. Turner worked at Burger King for two months -- she qualifies for a payment of $400. Puzzled but pleased, she made a half-hearted pledge to resume work. "What is it -- an 'earned income tax credit?' " she asked. "I really got to get me a job, so I can get some more."
Since 1990, the number of Wisconsin families receiving credits has grown by 42 percent. And the average payment has nearly tripled to $2,088, counting the state and Federal credits. For families with children, the payments rise until earnings hit $9,500, then level off and slowly decline. Families are ineligible if their earnings exceed $30,000.
While Congress has turned the Federal program into one of the nation's largest anti-poverty efforts, few people have asked what the poor do with the money.
Does it help them build new lives?
Some intriguing hints come from Timothy M. Smeeding and Katherin E. Ross of Syracuse University, who surveyed 830 beneficiaries of the program in Chicago. They found that 26 percent planned to use all the money for immediate needs, like food, rent, utilities or clothes. But more than half planned to spend at least some of it on investments in the future: moving (5 percent); sending themselves or their children to school (9 percent); buying a car (14 percent); or saving (28 percent).
Mr. Smeeding calls that reassuring news. "This program is not just enhancing consumption, but improving social mobility," he said.

New Welfare Law Helps Businesses
As a window into the city's soul, King Drive has a long history. It grew up as North Third Street in the mid-19th century and matured as a fabled stretch of stores. They dazzled an 8-year-old girl named Golda Mabovitch when she arrived from Russia in 1906. "Everything looked so colorful and fresh, as though it had just been created," she wrote decades later, as Golda Meir, after serving as the Prime Minister of Israel.
By the late 1950's, the stores were moving out to the malls, and a poor black neighborhood was left behind.
No one is quite sure how the rioting began on July 30, 1967. Detroit had burned just a week earlier, and Milwaukee was tense when the police responded to a report of broken windows at a Third Street business. When the violence ended 10 days later, 3 people had died and 1,740 had been arrested -- nothing like Detroit, where 43 people died, but enough to leave the neighborhood shunned for a generation.
Every state now has tougher welfare laws, but the program that has hit the Wisconsin streets is especially strict. Virtually everyone receiving cash assistance must join a work program. Rather than work for welfare, most recipients simply seek jobs on their own in the state's strong economy. The rolls in Milwaukee have now fallen 80 percent from their 1986 peak -- to 7,700 families, from 38,400 -- and more than three-quarters of the decline has occurred in the last two years.
Though data on their experiences remains scarce, a recent state survey found that 83 percent had been employed at some point after leaving welfare. In that sense, at least, the program, Wisconsin Works, is living up to its nickname: "W-2."
That has been good news for Jackson Hewitt, the nation's second-largest chain of tax preparers. In a typical year, the offices in Milwaukee see a 20 percent increase in new customers. This year the figure on King Drive is 38 percent.
Business has also increased at Milwaukee Check Cashers, a neon hub at the epicenter of the old riot zone. According to a computer analysis prepared for The New York Times, the store now cashes $129,000 less in welfare checks each month than it did two years ago. But the amount of payroll checks it cashes each month has risen by $355,000. In other words, on that corner of King Drive at least, for every dollar of lost welfare there has been a $2.69 increase in wages.
"We are doing more business than ever with our W-2 clients," said George Franco, the store's president. "Instead of one payment a month, they're cashing checks weekly or biweekly. It's been very positive for our business."
Nearby, sales are up at Nefertari's Beauty Salon, and T-Bone's Pagers is mulling an expansion into cell phones to keep pace with client demands. Among those monitoring King Drive's sidewalk economics is Patrick Hunter, 27, who peddles watches and videos outside the check-cashing store.
"There's a lot more money out here than there used to be," he said. "You got more women working. A lot of people waking up to that -- stability, morals, and values and things."
Then again, a lot of people are waking up to wages that may leave stability beyond reach -- often $6 to $7 an hour and less than full time.
Everyone has to start somewhere, of course. But as 30,000 Milwaukee families begin their post-welfare lives, it remains unclear whether their jobs will prove a stepping-stone or a treadmill.
At 39, Delores Jefferson has packed head cheese at a sausage factory for the last 14 years. But she has never been hired full time, and her wage leaves her whispering in embarrassment: $6.35 an hour. In the past, she has filled in the gaps with welfare. This year, she took a second job at the post office that literally leaves her working around the clock.
"I have to be at the meat-packing plant at 9 A.M.," she said, while having her taxes prepared. "I get off at 3:30 P.M., go home, eat my dinner, be in bed by 5 P.M. Get up at 11 P.M. Be at the post office at midnight, get off at 6 A.M. Get a couple hours of sleep -- be at work at 9 A.M."
"It works," she said.
 
Tax Preparers Find New Clients
Like their clients, the tax preparers themselves are no strangers to the entry-level economy: they, too, perform low-paid, seasonal work, with uncertain prospects for advancement. Software programs make the work routine, and wages in some offices start as low as $5.50 an hour (with modest end-of-the-season bonuses). Last year, about 22 of the preparers hired by H & R Block had come from the welfare rolls, a recruiting pool for other services, too.
"They're not going to get rich, and I tell them they're not going to get rich," said the manager of one commercial service. "You just hope and pray they don't find a good job, so they'll come back every year."
The low labor costs do not necessarily translate into low filing fees. The Internal Revenue Service sponsors four sites along King Drive where volunteers prepare returns for free. (One is run by the Opportunities Industrialization Center, a state subcontractor, as a job-training program for welfare recipients.) But with as much as half of their annual income tied up in the tax code, many poor people pay commercial services to get the money quickly.
At Jackson Hewitt, the charge for a basic tax return begins at $48. But 65 percent of the clients pay additional fees, starting at $54, for the firm's "Accelerated" electronic service, which secures the money in about two weeks. (It takes about six weeks through the mail.) Another 17 percent pay even more for the "Superfast" program, a loan through an affiliated bank.
The banks issue "Superfast" refunds within three days, and secure their repayment directly from the I.R.S. But the effective interest rate, if calculated on an annual basis, can range from 57 percent to 663 percent, according to bank disclosure forms. (It depends in part on the size of the loan.) Other companies offer similar products and rates. Desperate to pay the rent, clients occasionally surrender nearly $200 in interest and preparation fees on a $500 refund.
The lure of these electronic programs, in addition to their speed, is the absence of up-front costs. Those who file paper returns must front the preparation fees. But electronic filers can have the costs deducted from the refund.
"If I had my druthers, I'd rather not see a customer do "Superfast' or 'Accelerated,' " said Shelly Pipjaert, the manager of Jackson Hewitt's Milwaukee offices. "It's a shame. It's a lot of money. But if that's what the customer wants, that's what the customer gets."
While the tax credit's focus on work, not welfare, has bolstered its political support, there have been recent concerns about its susceptibility to fraud. An audit of the 1994 returns found improper payments in 26 percent of the claims, a worrisome rate with costs approaching $30 billion.
 
A Tax Bonus Susceptible to Fraud
Some errors simply stem from confusion over the rules. (To qualify fully, for instance, parents must live with their children for at least half the year.) Others come from wholesale fraud. (A woman outside the H & R Block office said she has sold her children's Social Security numbers, for $300, in years when she was ineligible because she did not work.) And still others arise from street-wise bartering that may be as socially sanctioned in some neighborhoods as it is illegal.
Consider, for instance, a single mother on welfare and her children's absent father. She has no earnings; he earns $10,000 a year. Without wages, she cannot receive a refund. Without the children, he is ineligible, too. But if they say their two children spent half the year with him, they could split a combined state and Federal payment of nearly $4,300.
Government auditors would call this fraud, and it is. But some poor families see it differently, especially if the father helps out by paying child support. Ms. Morton, the aspiring day care provider, said she would have no problem in letting her daughter's father claim the child even though he lives in Chicago. "She is his child and he helps me with her," she said. Because she has four other children -- and the value of the Federal credit is capped after two -- her refund would not be affected.
New anti-fraud efforts appear to have doused the more brazen schemes. But because eligibility depends on who lives where, a strict accounting remains difficult.
Among those caught in the Government's snare was Mr. Hunter, the street-corner apostle of new values. He now owes more than $2,000 for illegally claiming his girlfriend's baby by another man. "It wasn't like it was behind her back," he said. "I bought the baby some clothes."
These days, he is caught between self-reproach ("scamming the tax people is illegal") and the argument that filing creative tax returns is an American tradition -- a move toward mainstream values. "Rich people cheat on their taxes, too," he said. As long as people are working, he said, "it's not the same as welfare -- there ain't nobody getting played."
 
Change in Milwaukee: Life After Welfare
With the nation's welfare rolls down 43 percent, President Clinton, as well as his Republican critics, count the landmark 1996 welfare law as the cornerstone of their respective legacies. That law replaced a 60-year-old cash safety net with a program of time limits and work requirements.
No place has come closer than Wisconsin to the goal of "ending welfare." A decade ago, 100,000 Wisconsin families relied on public aid. Now 9,000 do.
The changes taking place in the state, particularly in its largest city, Milwaukee, continue to reverberate in broad and unpredictable ways. Throughout the year, The New York Times is returning to Milwaukee to plot the pattern of change.
 The articles and related coverage of welfare issues are available on The New York Times on the Web, at: www.nytimes.com/ politics.
