HEADLINE: Primakov Says Russia Will Fight Anti-Semitism

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 22

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov promised a group of American Jews today that the Russian Government will combat a rising tide of anti-Semitism.
Mr. Primakov provided the assurance in a meeting with representatives of the Anti-Defamation League, a division of B'nai B'rith. The Kremlin has condemned anti-Semitism, but Mr. Primakov has previously said little about the problem, although he himself has Jewish family roots. 
 As he prepared to fly to Washington on Tuesday to seek Western financial credits, however, he spoke out in an apparent effort to set a positive tone for his mission.
"I say unamibiguously that the Government takes a very strong position against any manifestation of nationalism, including anti-Semitism," Mr. Primakov told the Jewish group, its representatives said.
They also said Mr. Primakovpromised to support new legislation to clamp down on fascist and extremist groups. He was reported to have said he wants Jews to feel at home in Russia and to have condemned the anti-Semitic tirades of Albert Makashov, a former general and Communist lawmaker.
"I believe that Makashov has to be condemned fair and square and unambiguously for his pronouncements in an open and undisguised way," Mr. Primakov was quoted as saying.
Since the collapse of Russia's currency in August, there have been growing incidents of anti-Semitism. Many Jews in Moscow say they do not feel in danger, but the problem is more serious in the provinces. Earlier this month, for example, the lone synagogue in the Siberian city of Novosibirsk was vandalized.
Mr. Makashov has been one of the most vitriolic leaders of the anti-Semitic crusade. He has blamed Jews for the nation's economic ills. In a recent speech in the southern Russian city of Rostov, he virtually invited Cossacks to sack Jewish homes.
The Communist-led Parliament, however, has declined to condemn him. On Friday, 104 members voted to censure Mr. Makashov while 133 rejected the measure. Instead, the Parliament charged that the press is exaggerating the danger of Russian fascism.
Mr. Primakov plans to meet on Thursday in the United States with a group of American Jews. Abraham Foxman, the national director of the Anti-Defamation league, said Mr. Primakov's remarks today were important.
"It is his first signfiicant public statement condemning not only anti-Semitisim in Russia but the specific utterances of Makashov," Mr. Foxman said.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel also met here with Mr. Primakov today and expressed concern over anti-Semitism and the sale of Russian missile technology to Iran.
Mr. Netanyahu indicated in an interview on Russian television that he was prepared to discuss cooperation on high-technology projects and the possible purchase of air defense systems from Russia. That could be an incentive to Russia to cut off the sale of missile technology to Iran, a top Israeli and American priority.
In a speech at a Moscow synagogue on Sunday, Mr. Netanyahu condemned anti-Semitism and invited Russian Jews to immigrate to Israel.
"This is a terrible epidemic, which is above all dangerous for the society in which it is developing," he said. "I want you to come to Israel, but the choice is in your hands."

HEADLINE: Oil Executives Work the Room at OPEC Meeting

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 22

 BODY:
The Libyan oil minister's senior bodyguard kept a stern vigil outside his boss's 12th- floor suite at the Hotel Intercontinental today, but not to protect him from terrorists.
Rather, his mission was to insure the privacy of meetings among the minister, Abdallah Salim al-Badri, and American oil executives who were discreetly slipping in and out. The Americans did not want to attract attention from Washington, where communication with Libya is officially discouraged. 
 Such clandestine meetings are not uncommon surrounding important meetings of the 11-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, such as the one that begins on Tuesday. Scores of oil company executives and industry analysts are drawn to Vienna, OPEC's headquarters, hoping for an audience with an oil minister.
This is a city famed for its discretion, secret banking and effective security, a place where American oil executives can see Libyans, Iranians and Iraqis without stirring the ire of Washington for skirting sanctions imposed on those countries.
"Where else are you going to see all these people gathered in one place where you can further your commercial goals, don't have to worry about traveling to difficult places like Libya, Iraq or Iran and do it discretely?" said Nordine Ait-Laoussine, Algeria's former oil minister, now a prominent consultant who brokers such meetings.
If anything, the time and trouble may be worth the effort. There is hope here that the protracted decline of oil prices is coming to an end. OPEC is on the verge of cutting its production deeply to push up prices. The worst of the Asian crisis appears to be over, which could stimulate demand for oil.
There are other, politically sensitive reasons for American oil industry emissaries to take a particular interest in this gathering -- changes among three renegade members that suggest doing business with them may soon be allowed.
Iraq already is selling oil again under United Nations guidelines. United States relations with Iran have shown signs of a thaw. And there is even a crack in the ice with Libya, which made overtures last week to ease its isolation by agreeing to relinquish suspects wanted for trial in the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 11 years ago.
"Somebody has got to keep the contact with these huge oil producers when these sanctions come off," said Oscar Wyatt, former chairman of the Coastal Corporation, a large United States energy company. "The Americans don't know why they are doing what they've done and how to undo it." Mr. Wyatt is known for his contacts with some of the world's most frowned-upon oil producers, including a famous visit in 1990 with Iraq's Saddam Hussein to persuade him to release hostages then held by Iraq.
"We cannot come out of this world without any friends," Mr. Wyatt said today as two assistants waited to accompany him to a minister's rendezvous. He would not say whom he had met, but others said he saw both the Libyan and Iraqi oil ministers today.
A senior official from the Chevron Corporation, fresh out of talks with Iraqi oil officials, confirmed the notion of talks now, business later.
"According to the United Nations and American sanctions, we can talk. We don't sign on any deals, but we can talk," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
"The Russians are signing deals with Iraq, so are the French," he added. "We are behind. We should be ready too."
Iraqi oil already makes its way to the United States market.
Although Iraqis have refrained from selling oil directly to United States companies to make a political point, they sell their oil for food to the French and Russians, who make a profit by reselling it to United States companies. Robin D'Alessandro, an oil trader with Vitol, a large international commodities firm, says she buys Iraqi oil through Russian intermediaries.
American oil industry representatives are not the only outsiders who come to the such OPEC meetings. It is also important for oil industry analysts like Gary Ross to be here. He is president of a New York-based consulting firm, Petroleum Industry Research Associates, and sells advice to oil companies.
As he came over this afternoon to shake hands with Prince Salman, the deputy oil minister of Saudi Arabia in the lobby of the ANA hotel, Mr. Ross was mindful of the importance of such connections.
A meeting usually follows such handshakes and the knowledge acquired in that meeting translates into money and retainers. Asked if it was worth traveling from New York for this, Mr. Ross himself asked: "What do you think?"

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 331 words

HEADLINE: Rising Oil Prices

 BODY:
Oil prices are heading up, as Saudi Arabia and other oil producers seek to restrain the supply. Those higher prices will dampen the economic boom in the United States but will not cause severe problems for this country. The rise should serve as a reminder to Americans that energy conservation, largely forgotten as oil prices have fallen to their lowest level in years, remains an important goal.
The oil-producing countries, meeting in Vienna, are expected today to agree to reductions in production totaling about two million barrels per day. If the cuts are made, that would be more than enough to assure that oil prices will rise. 
 The increases have already begun. The benchmark price of west Texas intermediate crude oil, which fell from above $25 per barrel at the end of 1996 to under $11 at the end of last year, has rebounded to above $15. Demand for oil in Asia is beginning to rise as economies start to recover. American gasoline demand has been rising at a fast clip due both to the boom here and to the growing sales of inefficient sport utility vehicles.
There are rumors that Saudi Arabia, which is to make the biggest cuts, has threatened that, if other oil producers do not live up to their promises to cut, it will produce oil as fast as it can to disrupt their markets. Such a move would send oil prices plunging, so the threat may be enough to restrain production for some time, notwithstanding the fact that some countries have broken previous promises to reduce output. Frederick P. Leuffer, the oil analyst at Bear Stearns, thinks the price of crude oil could climb back to $20 by the end of this year.
Such a rise in oil prices would reduce the economic pain for major oil exporters, among them Russia and Indonesia, but it would slow economic growth in other countries. For Americans, the move means that inflation is likely to rise, albeit not by huge amounts, and that spending on consumer goods is likely to slow from the recent torrid pace.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Falter and Dow Slips 13.04 Points, to 9,890.51

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday, forcing investors to face the possibility that the Dow Jones industrial average might not close at more than 10,000 points any time soon.
The Dow average crossed 10,000 points several times last week in intraday trading. Yesterday, though, it failed even to do that, meandering throughout the session and ending 13.04 points lower at 9,890.51. Even so, the Dow remains up more than 8 percent so far this year. 
 Cable television and Internet stocks provided some upward momentum to the technology sector. But shares in personal computer manufacturers sold off, leaving the Nasdaq composite down 25.33 points, or 1 percent, at 2,395.94; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.28 points, to 1,297.01.
Edward M. Kerschner, stock market strategist at Paine Webber, said that unless interest rates moved significantly lower or 1999 earnings growth was substantially higher than current forecasts of 5 percent to 8 percent, he expects "in the best case, to see the market stall around these levels for a good few months."
There was no economic news to influence trading today. Interest rates edged higher in the bond market, reversing an earlier decline. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose slightly to 5.57 percent, from 5.55 percent Friday.
Cable television stocks rose on takeover news. Mediaone Group rose 7 3/4 a share, to 68 1/2, on the New York Stock Exchange after the Comcast Corporation offered to buy it for $44.3 billion. Comcast's series A shares lost 5 3/8, to 64 3/4, in Nasdaq trading.
Internet shares also continued to blaze higher, with America Online gaining 10 3/4, to 130, on the Big Board.
Among other issues that gained, Jenny Craig Inc., the diet and vitamin company, rose 1 1/16 a share, to 4 1/2. The company said that it would begin selling a line of vitamins, minerals and dietary supplements through a new site on the World Wide Web.
Shares in the Gucci Group N.V. rose 2 1/8, to 83 1/8, on the New York Stock Exchange, after a Netherlands court ruled yesterday that Gucci, the fashion group, must begin negotiations with the French luxury-goods maker LVMH Moet Hennessey Louis Vuitton over LVMH's $7.86 billion offer for Gucci.
The court restored LVMH's voting rights on its 26 percent stake in Gucci, which had been suspended March 3. The court also upheld Friday's agreement between the French retailer, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, and Gucci, which provides that Pinault will take a 40 percent interest in Gucci. But the court suspended all parts of the agreement that would hamper the negotiations between Gucci and LVMH.
Shares of the U.S. Filter Corporation fell 1/8, to 30 3/8, after Vivendi, one of France's largest industrial conglomerates, said it would buy the company in a $6.2 billion, two-step cash deal.
Personal computer stocks were weaker after Kevin McCarthy, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Securities, lowered his earnings estimate on the Dell Computer Corporation and said he expected the PC industry to grow only 8 percent in 1999; that is down from his previous estimate of 10 percent. Dell shares slipped 2 3/8, to 37 7/8.
Wall Street has been jittery for weeks about the health of the computer market. On Friday, I.B.M. led the Dow lower after Thomas Kraemer, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter & Company, issued a word of caution about the computer maker. Yesterday, Dan Niles, an analyst with BancBoston Robertson Stephens & Company, followed suit, and I.B.M.'s shares fell 1 9/16, to 167.
Technology stocks were largely responsible for leading the market out of its slump last autumn, said Tony Dwyer, chief equity strategist at Ladenburg Thalmann & Company. If the market is to continue to improve, he added, it is crucial that they begin to perform better, but that is not likely, given the extremely high prices on technology stocks.
"If you're an index watcher, and you're watching the Dow 30 stocks, you've got to be bullish," Mr. Dwyer said. "But if you're an investment adviser, you have to look at everything, not just 30 stocks. And if you're looking at the broader market, you've got to sell it right now."
Declining issues outnumbered advancers 1,743 to 1,240 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 662.4 million shares, down from the previous session.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.19 point, to 610.49, and the American Stock Exchange composite index rose 5.49 points, to 717.36. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies fell 3.38 points, to 393.20.

HEADLINE: China Says Los Alamos Scientist Gave It No Secrets on Warheads

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 22

 BODY:
Chinese officials say that Wen Ho Lee, the Taiwan-born American scientist suspected of leaking nuclear secrets, attended two scientific meetings in China in the 1980's.
But in a report issued late on Sunday night by the New China News Agency, Chinese scientists vehemently denied that Mr. Lee gave away plans for making advanced American warheads. 
 The case against Mr. Lee "is no more than a fabrication," the report quotes Prof. Li Deyuan of the Institute of Applied Physics and Computational Mathematics as saying. Mr. Lee has been dismissed from his job at the Los Alamos National Laboratory for violating security rules, but he has not been charged with a crime.
"According to Professor Li, Wen Ho Lee attended an international symposium on hydromechanics in Beijing in 1986, which was simply and totally a meeting about basic scientific matters," the news agency report said. "Lee delivered an open lecture about calculating the methods of hydromechanics in a research institute in Beijing, which was also fundamentally basic science and nothing to do with 'secrets.' "
American intelligence and law enforcement officials have said Mr. Lee has told them that he had unauthorized contacts with Chinese scientists, but they have not provided details of what he said.
The Chinese news agency account said Mr. Lee also attended the International Computation Physics Conference in China, with Professor Li as chairman, in June 1988. The meeting, attended by more than 200 scientists from various countries, was said to have been co-sponsored by the Beijing applied physics institute, Drexel University in Philadelphia and the American Government's National Science Foundation.
Mr. Lee attended the 1988 conference with the approval of his employers at the Los Alamos laboratory, the report said, and delivered a paper titled "Material Void Opening Computation Using Particle Method." Mr. Lee's presentation "covered general basic research and did not involve any confidential information," it said.
A scientist identified as the secretary general of that conference, Zhang Tianyuan, said the meeting had involved "general-purpose academic talks and never touched upon the secrets of the W-88 nuclear warhead."
American officials say they believe that China stole important design elements of the W-88, a miniaturized nuclear warhead useful for building multiple-warhead rockets.
The Beijing applied physics academy involved in the two meetings conducts research on nuclear weapons for the military as well as on peaceful uses of nuclear energy.
The news agency report also sought to refute the broader charges that China had taken advantage of economic and scientific exchanges in the last two decades to steal military technology. It said charges made by Congressional investigators that China stole secrets of the neutron bomb, of the W-88 warhead and of simulated nuclear explosions were "an obvious calumny."
Following a line espoused by senior Chinese officials in recent weeks, the report said false charges against China had been generated by Americans stuck in a "cold war mentality" who wanted to "sabotage Sino-U.S. relations." The hostile theories are fanned, it said, by partisan politics in the United States.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN RUSSIA;
Moscow Opposes Air Raids, but Is Miffed at Serbs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 22

 BODY:
Serbia's latest offensive in Kosovo is leading some of Russia's top foreign policy specialists to question Moscow's longstanding support for Belgrade.
With Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov set to leave on Tuesday for Washington, Russia's top priority is to wrest billions of dollars from the International Monetary Fund, not argue over the Balkans. 
 Given the economic stakes for Moscow, the decision by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to press the attack against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo is more than a matter of bad timing. An increasing number of Russian experts say it underscores Belgrade's indifference to the Primakov mission.
Within the Russian Government, senior officials talk quietly about their deep frustration with Mr. Milosevic. Some leading lawmakers are more vocal.
"We have invested too much into this problem," Vladimir P. Lukin, the leader of Parliament's foreign relations committee, told Russian television on Sunday. "We must know the limits of our support."
None of this means that Russia would welcome a NATO bombing strike. Moscow's long-range goal is to diminish the military and political utility of the Western alliance.
Nationalist sentiment at home further demands that the Russians give their fellow Slavs in Yugoslavia oratorical support, even though many ordinary people do not identify with the Serbian cause. Russian Foreign Ministry officials, for their part, continue to argue that NATO air strikes would make a bad situation worse.
Russia hoped to negotiate an accord that would obviate the need for NATO action. When he served as Foreign Minister, Mr. Primakov put Russia's prestige on the line by inviting Mr. Milosevic to Moscow last summer.
Afterward, Mr. Primakov sat by Mr. Milosevic's side in an ornate Russian Foreign Ministry mansion as the Yugoslav leader denied that Serbian forces had ever harmed ethnic Albanians and promised to ease the confrontation.
Earlier this month, President Boris N. Yeltsin sent a letter to Belgrade, urging Mr. Milosevic to seek a political settlement, Russian officials said.
But these days Belgrade does not seem to be listening to Moscow's counsel. The Serbs, in fact, may have timed their attacks against the Kosovo Albanians to coincide with Mr. Primakov's mission to Washington, calculating that NATO would be reluctant to strike when Mr. Primakov was in the United States.
The fact that a flare-up of the fighting might sour the atmosphere for Mr. Primakov's trip or force him to defer it does not seem to have mattered much in Belgrade.
And if Russia's influence with Mr. Milosevic has dwindled, it seems to have reached a low point with NATO. The alliance appears to have concluded that it must take action soon if the Serbian attacks continue, to salvage its own credibility, regardless of what the Russians think.
This is not the first time that Mr. Primakov has put Russia's authority on the line and come out on the losing end. Two years ago he engaged in an all-night negotiating session in Geneva, which Moscow later asserted had broken the deadlock over weapons inspections in Iraq.
But it only took a matter of months before the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, walked away from the compromise and the Clinton Administration began planning a retaliatory strike. These days, Moscow rarely objects to the United States air strikes in Iraq, apparently calculating that it can do little about them.
Unless a breakthrough is achieved in Belgrade, Moscow stands to be humiliated again. Even if there is progress, the credit is likely to go to Richard C. Holbrooke, the American envoy who arrived in Belgrade armed with the threat of NATO force.
Today Mr. Primakov repeated, almost ritualistically, Moscow's opposition to NATO bombing. But Moscow's senior diplomat in the region, Boris Mayorsky, said tonight that Moscow did not have any special plan.
Mr. Primakov appeared determined to go to Washington anyway. When the Echo Moscow radio station asked its listeners today to phone in their opinion, 69 percent of the 1,677 callers said Mr. Primakov should not cancel his Washington mission, even if NATO attacked Mr. Milosevic's troops.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Imports FaceHigher Tariffs On Beef Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The United States prepared to open a new front in its trans-Atlantic trade disputes today, publishing a list of $900 million in European goods like truffles and foie gras that could be subjected to 100 percent tariffs if American farmers are not permitted to export hormone-treated beef to Europe.
On the list were mainly food items, including Evian, Perrier, Ricola cough drops and imported Dijon mustard. But there also were some manufactured goods, like mopeds and smaller motorcycles by Bianchi of Sweden. 
 The announcement came in response to European Union statements that it would not be able to comply with a ruling from the World Trade Organization to end its ban on hormone-treated beef by May 13. The organization concluded that Europe's rules against the beef were based on faulty science.
European trade officials have long argued that there could be long-term harmful health effects to humans from treating beef with hormones, and that the effects may not be known for years. The United States counters that Europe's motivation is essentially protectionist, to the point of citing unreliable studies to keep the market closed to competition.
The issue has become a heated political topic in Europe, along with the arguments over whether European rules on banana imports are intended to discriminate against fruit handled by two American companies, Chiquita Brands International and the Dole Foods Company. The United States has begun to impose 100 percent tariffs on $500 million in European luxury good imports in retaliation for Europe's refusal to comply with the trade organization's rulings in that dispute.
Like the banana arguments, the battling over beef hormones has been going on for years, and, as in the banana case, the United States is moving quickly to threaten retaliation. The punitive import fees are intended to create pressure on European politicians from companies that will find themselves virtually unable to ship goods to the United States -- unless they pay a 100 percent tariff, doubling the wholesale price.
While the United States Trade Representative's office published a "target list" of $900 million in goods subject to retaliation, including Swedish hams, that list will be pared significantly before any tariffs go into effect. American beef farmers have put their losses from the hormone ban at several hundred million dollars. The final list is expected to contain about $300 million in European goods sold here.
Before the high tariffs are imposed, the European Union could negotiate some form of compensation for American beef farmers. But today Peter Scher, who heads agricultural negotiations for the Trade Representative's office, said that "compensation is meant to be a bridge to ending the ban, and the E.U. has never made it clear it will comply with the ruling."
Mr. Scher said that negotiations were under way to allow for the hormone-treated beef to be clearly labeled for European consumers, giving shoppers the option to avoid buying it if they chose. But Mr. Scher emphasized that "there is no evidence of any health risks" related to consumption of the beef.
For the Clinton Administration, more is at stake in these battles than beef and bananas. Mr. Clinton has argued that the European Union has to be taught to abide by W.T.O. rulings. The Europeans counter that the United States is jumping the gun, imposing retaliation before the appeals process is complete.

HEADLINE: Arab Web Censorship;
Pakistan Is Wired

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Internet's 'Open Sesame' Is Answered Warily" (Riyadh Journal, March 18) implied that the Internet is banned in many Muslim countries, and is just now slowly being introduced in some of them. But the examples cited include only a few Middle Eastern countries and Iran. 
 In Pakistan use of the Internet has grown quickly over the past five or six years. And Malaysia was planning a "cybercity" to attract business before the recent economic crises there. Even in Bangladesh, nonprofit organizations are providing Internet access to the poor.
Conservatives all over the world are concerned about the effect of pornographic, racist and propaganda on the Web, including the United States, where Congress passed the Communications Decency Act before it was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court in 1997.
 
SHAHBAZ CHAUDHARY
Ann Arbor, Mich., March 18, 1999

HEADLINE: Gas Prices Rise 8 Cents at Pump

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices have risen 8.5 cents a gallon over the last two weeks, and motorists, who had been enjoying the cheapest fuel in a generation, are likely to see further increases in the weeks ahead, energy experts said yesterday.
The increase -- to a nationwide average of $1.0869 cents a gallon at 10,000 gas stations for all grades of gas on Friday -- represents one of the steepest short-term surges since the Persian Gulf war in 1990, according to a report from the Lundberg Survey, a California company that tracks gasoline prices. 
 A coalition of major oil producers, including those from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, announced two weeks ago that it planned to cut production of crude oil by two million barrels a day. OPEC is expected to ratify that decision today. Anticipating these actions, refiners began imposing wholesale price increases weeks ago that are being passed along to consumers. Many experts believe that gasoline prices could increase another 8 to 15 cents a gallon as the summer driving season arrives.
Even after the recent increase, gasoline prices remain extremely low by historical standards.
"They went up? I didn't notice," Yolanda Etaeper said yesterday as she filled up her Toyota at an Exxon station on Dean Drive in Tenafly, N.J., where regular gasoline cost 95.9 cents a gallon, up from 90.9 cents last week. "What can you do? You have to buy gasoline."
Still, the speed and size of the increases at the pump have surprised many drivers and some industry experts, who said oil producers had not yet made a final decision on the level of cutbacks to be absorbed by each country. If OPEC ratifies the proposal made by the coalition of producers two weeks ago, supply would be reduced by two million barrels a day, amounting to 2.6 percent of current global daily production.
Ed Rothshild, a consultant based in Washington, said it was unusual for price increases to arrive at the retail level so soon, even before the production cuts, if they eventually occur, are actually made.
Frederick Leuffer, an oil analyst with Bear, Stearns, said refiners had been able to put through price increases of about 15 cents a gallon on the wholesale level during the last two weeks "because of very strong demand for gasoline."
"It's been up 3.5 to 4 percent this year," he said. "That's a huge jump."
He said refiners were using lower- cost crude that they had bought before the current increase in prices, which will help their profitability.
Generally, it takes several weeks to pass the higher cost of crude on to the wholesale level and then several weeks for retailers to catch up.
This time, Mr. Rothshild said, when crude oil prices began to rise in anticipation of the cuts by the oil producers, the oil industry acted quickly.
And many station owners have scrambled to keep up with their sharply rising wholesale costs. "It's been going up continually," said Denise Pristera, a manager at the Exxon station in Tenafly. "I think it will go up to $1.00 for regular," 5 cents higher than it is now.
Anticipating action by oil producers to cut supply, and seeing unusually strong demand for gasoline by motorists, refiners began to raise prices for gasoline at the wholesale level in some regions as early as mid-February, a few weeks before crude oil prices began to recover.
An informal coalition of oil producers meeting at The Hague, including Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Iran and Venezuela, which are all members of OPEC, as well as Mexico, which is not an OPEC member, resolved early this month to make further cuts in production. All have lost billions of dollars because of the oil glut, and all had made substantial production cuts over the previous year in an effort to raise prices.
Crude oil hit its lowest point this year in mid-February when the price of the benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude dipped to $11.37 in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Crude oil for April delivery rose 26 cents to close yesterday at $15.50 a barrel, the highest closing price since Oct. 2.
Crude oil has been recovering this month ever since major oil producers resolved to limit production, rising by well over $3 a barrel.
Alan Struth, an economist for Phillips Petroleum, said there was generally an increase of 2.4 cents a gallon in the price of gasoline at the retail level for every $1 rise in the price of crude.
Mr. Struth said the increase of 8 cents a gallon at the pump roughly reflects both the higher price of crude and the seasonal introduction of gasoline that produces less pollution but costs more to make.
The industry's profitability has been very low through early March, but is now beginning to recover, he said.
Whether the industry can continue to increase prices is still uncertain, although there are some favorable trends for the producers.
Inventories of gasoline showed a sharp drop last week. Demand has been unusually strong because of a seasonal upturn in driving, the strong economy and the continuing growth in the number of sport utility vehicles, which get lower gas mileage.
Mr. Struth said that if the price of crude rose from the present $15.50 to about $18 a barrel, retail prices could go up another 8 cents a gallon and possibly as much as 15 cents a gallon.
Even with the recent jump, prices were still only about a cent higher than last year and well below a high of $1.33 a gallon in September of 1997, before prices began to weaken. Retail prices can vary because of differences in state taxes.
Michael E. Lattif, the president of Gateway Industries, a company that imports auto parts in Danbury, Conn., maintains a fleet of six vans. He said the higher prices would increase his costs. He watches pump price carefully and keeps up with the latest news from OPEC on the Internet.
"It's been going up all week," he said as he waited for his bill at the Tenafly Exxon station. Still, he viewed the price, 5 cents a gallon higher than the previous week, as a good deal.
"At another station it's gone up about 9 cents a gallon," he said.

HEADLINE: 2 Huge Cable TV Companies To Unite in $53 Billion Deal

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Mediaone in a $53 billion takeover that would create the third-largest cable television company in the nation but would have little to do with television.
What is driving this deal is the cable industry's race with telephone companies to offer superfast access to the Internet. Page C1. 
 As the only two industries that have communication cables passing almost every house and business in the country, cable and telephone companies are positioning themselves to grab a share of the other's business.
Indeed, AT&T paid $55 billion this year for the cable provider Tele-Communications Inc. just to get access to wires that can carry phone and Internet services in homes along with television.
Customers of the two cable companies will probably not see their rates decline, even though one reason Mediaone was willing to be acquired was that a merger would reduce the cost the combined company pays for cable programming.
But those savings, as well as any increases in cable rates as industry regulation ends this year, will almost certainly be invested in technology to provide data services -- and eventually phone services -- to consumers.
"There is a race to be first to offer Internet access and ultimately telephone service to the upscale neighborhoods that will buy it first," said Howard Anderson, president of the Yankee Group, a media consulting firm. "It's called the 'first-move advantage.' If customers go with the phone companies, it will be hard, if not impossible to lure them back to cable. So cable companies want to get big so they have as much cash flow as they need to build their Internet business. Size is everything."
Comcast's president, Brian L. Roberts, said that both Comcast and Mediaone raised their rates 5 percent last year, which he called a conservative increase.
And he made a point of warning that any attempt by the Federal Communications Commission to institute price controls on cable rates would harm the cash flow the companies have been investing in upgrading their systems to handle Internet and phone services.
Sharon Ambrust, an analyst at Paul Kagan & Associates, a media consulting firm, said the 5 percent increase imposed last year by both companies was middle of the road.
Comcast has 5.6 million cable subscribers, primarily along the Northeast Corridor from Baltimore through Washington, Delaware, Philadelphia, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Mediaone has about five million customers, most of them in the Boston area, though it also has cable systems in Connecticut.
Philadelphia-based Comcast, with a market value of $24.4 billion, is controlled and managed by the Roberts family through 9.4 million shares that carry 15 votes each. That gives the family 80 percent of all votes. Individual investors own 30 million shares of single-vote stock, and 328.6 million shares of nonvoting stock are owned by institutions.
Since Mediaone is valued at $41.7 billion, Mediaone's president, Charles M. Lillis, was asked at a news conference yesterday why it was not his company that was doing the acquiring.
"The Roberts didn't want to sell," Mr. Lillis said.
But in fact, Mediaone was the more obvious target.
A spinoff of U S West, Mediaone is the only large -- and still independent -- cable company that is not controlled by a single shareholder or family. And it is viewed as having significant room for improved management. Compared with Comcast, whose profit margins on cable operations are about 48 percent, Mediaone has margins of about 38 percent.
Comcast is offering 1.1 of its shares for each of Mediaone's 664 million shares. The Roberts will keep control because all the shares that are being offered are nonvoting stock. Based on the closing stock prices on Friday, before the deal was announced, Comcast was paying $80.16 a share.
The one glitch could arise from Mediaone's relationship with Time Warner. Mediaone owns 25 percent of Time Warner Entertainment, the spinoff that includes Warner Brothers, Home Box Office and 10 million of Time Warner's 12 million cable subscribers.
Mr. Roberts and his father, Ralph J. Roberts, the company's 79-year-old founder and chairman, both said Time Warner's chairman and chief executive, Gerald M. Levin, was supporting the deal.
But some bankers and others suggested that Time Warner, with a market capitalization of $80 billion, could play spoiler by making its own bid for Mediaone.
"We have blocking rights on the sale of Mediaone," a Time Warner spokesman said, emphasizing that it had no plans to do so. But Brian Roberts insisted that Time Warner had no such rights.
Both sides agreed, however, that once the merger was completed, the combined company would not get Mediaone's seat on the management committee of Time Warner cable systems.
Still deals are like courtships, and an unexpected rival can inspire possessive behavior.
As one investment banker put it: "On the one hand, Mediaone has been sitting there for two years. No one made a bid, and Time Warner is the most logical guy given that they already have an interest."
He added, "When somebody says speak now or forever hold your peace," that can prompt a move.
Comcast shares fell $5.375 yesterday, to $64.75; Mediaone stock rose $7.75, to $68.50.
Comcast said cash flow for the merged companies in 2000 would be about $1.9 billion after all savings had been factored in. Brian Roberts said he planned a 5 percent cut to the combined 34,000-person work force. Assuming those factors, Comcast would be paying about 15 times Mediaone's cash flow.
"The deal is the upper end of recent transactions," said Salvatore Muio, who heads his own investment management firm. "However, in a stock deal, that is rather meaningless, since the stock price fluctuates."
When the merger is complete, Mediaone shareholders will own about 64 percent of the equity of the combined companies. Using Friday's closing prices, Comcast's offer represents a 32 percent premium to Friday's close of $60.75.
In the deal, Salomon Smith Barney and Davis Polk Wardell represented Comcast as banker and legal adviser, respectively. Mediaone's investment bankers were Lehman Brothers and Allen & Company. Weil Gotshal & Manges were legal advisers.
As President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico once remarked to me, at the end of the day every global dollar invested in Mexico ends up in a "local" Mexican bank, a "local" Mexican insurance company, a "local" Mexican factory. If Mexico does not have the operating system and rule-of-law software to manage and regulate that dollar, he said, no global institution can save it.
Bad lenders can be just as dangerous as bad borrowers, and some of the worst lenders in recent years have been big banks. A friend of mine in Hong Kong said that during the Asian economic boom, Germany's Dresdner Bank told its managers in Asia, "Lend, lend, lend, otherwise we will lose market share." Banks make money by lending and each one assumed that Asia was a no-brainer. So they shoved money out the door, just like drug dealers expanding their client base. Their message to the developing world was: "C'mon kid. Just try a little of this cash. The first loan's free."
Another form of bad lending is when banks recklessly lend millions of dollars to hedge funds so that they can "leverage" their bets. The hedge funds raise $1 from investors, borrow $9 more from banks and then use that leverage to magnify each of their bets in stocks, bonds, derivatives and currencies around the world. Generally speaking, there is nothing wrong with leverage. Your home mortgage is leverage. You want people to take risks, even crazy risks. This is how fledgling enterprises get financed and either go bankrupt or turn into Microsoft. The danger with leverage derives from the fact that the amounts of money that can be lent to hedge funds or emerging markets today are so enormous, and the system is now so greased and integrated, that when big risk-takers like Long-Term Capital Management make big mistakes they can destabilize everyone.
How to reduce that threat? To begin with, we need to proceed slowly and humbly. By this I mean that we have to understand that the global economic system is still so new and so fast that even the best minds don't fully understand how it works. Right now, our understanding of the globalization system is about as sophisticated as our understanding of the cold-war system was in 1946. Alan Greenspan is a lifelong scholar of international finance. But when I asked him in December about the logic of today's integrated global market, he gave me a rare on-the-record quote that should humble us all. "I have learned more about how this new international financial system works in the last 12 months," he said, "than in the previous 20 years."
Some have proposed that we put a little sand in the gears of the global economy to slow it down a bit. My response would be that I don't think it is ever very wise to put sand in the gears of a machine when you don't fully understand how it works. It might not just slow down. It could come to a screeching, metal-bending halt. Also, where do you put the sand when you are dealing with a fund manager sitting in Connecticut using the Internet to invest in Brazil via a bank domiciled offshore in Panama? Ever try to put sand in cyberspace? Well, then, how about setting up a global central bank? That may be a good idea, but it's not something that is going to happen anytime soon -- not as long as we all still live in 200-odd different countries.
So does that mean that there is nothing we can do? No. The good news is that in the wake of the crisis of 1998-99 the market on its own is brutally disciplining itself. You see signs of this everywhere. The chief executives of some of the biggest banks in the world -- Barclays P.L.C., BankAmerica, United Bank of Switzerland -- were all ousted in 1998, after huge losses in high-risk emerging markets.
In the wake of these beheadings, those major banks have restricted leverage, cutting off reckless fund managers, demanding more documentation from those to whom they are still lending and scrutinizing more seriously not just the balance-of-payments figures of emerging markets but also their operating systems, legal systems and overall software.
Banks and investors have started asking fund managers tough questions about their exposure to risks and what defensive measures they have taken. And the International Monetary Fund, the Treasury and fund managers have belatedly started asking emerging-market countries what they are doing to improve their financial and regulatory systems.
The only realistic solution for now is to take this ad hoc approach, intensify it and extend it into the future. If everyone from the I.M.F. to Merrill Lynch to my Aunt Bev would just ask these questions more often, and keep asking them, we'd have a chance of preventing two out of the next five crises and limiting the impact of one of the next five. That's the most we can hope for.
Sure, this doesn't seem very sexy -- calling on everyone in the system to become a better regulator, a smarter investor and a more prudent lender. But it's time we stopped kidding ourselves. Today's markets are so big and, with the advent of the Internet, becoming so fast that they can never be immunized from crises.
Global financial crises will be the norm in the coming era. In fact, let me leave you, dear readers, with one piece of advice: Fasten your seat belts and put your seat backs and tray tables into a fixed and upright position. Because the booms and the busts and the recoveries will all be coming faster. So get used to it, and just try to make sure that the leverage in the system doesn't become so great in any one area that it can make the whole system go boom or bust. Anyone who tells you that they have a plan for eliminating these crises is just pulling your leg. In fact, as you are reading these words, the next global financial crisis is already germinating somewhere.
 
Geopolitics
It is not easy for this generation of Americans to grasp how important the United States is to the world in the era of globalization. America today is the Michael Jordan of geopolitics -- the overwhelmingly dominant system. Now Jordan was good, and his opponents both loved and hated playing against him. Everyone wanted to be like Mike. But as good as Jordan was, he was nothing without all the other teams in the N.B.A. to showcase his skills -- and we're nothing without the rest of the world, which is why managing globalization is a role from which America dare not shrink.
Historically, the United States has either been isolated from world affairs or deeply engaged as part of a moral crusade to fend off an aggressive, threatening power. Isolation is easy to explain and understand. Engagement in a bipolar world -- with a menacing, nuclear-armed Soviet bear growling on the other side -- was easy to explain and understand. But what is not easy to explain or understand is engagement in a world in which America is the biggest beneficiary and the sole superpower, with multiple secondary powers and no immediately visible threat, but with many little threats and an abstract globalization system to maintain. But this is the world we have. And in this world we can't afford either to retreat into isolation or to wait around for some smaller adversary to become a life-threatening foe.
As I have noted before, globalization and economic integration will act, to some degree, as a restraint on those states that are plugged into the system and dependent upon the electronic herd. It's true that no two countries that both have a McDonald's have ever fought a war since they each got their McDonald's. (I call this the Golden Arches Theory of Conflict Prevention.) But globalization does not end geopolitics -- the enduring quest for power, the fear of neighbors, the tug of history. What globalization does is simply put a different frame around geopolitics, a frame that raises the costs of war but cannot eliminate it.
That is why sustainable globalization still requires a stable, geopolitical power structure, which simply cannot be maintained without the active involvement of the United States. All the technologies that Silicon Valley is designing to carry digital voices, videos and data around the world, all the trade and financial integration it is promoting through its innovations and all the wealth this is generating, are happening in a world stabilized by a benign superpower, with its capital in Washington, D.C.
The hidden hand of the market will never work without a hidden fist -- McDonald's cannot flourish without McDonnell Douglas, the builder of the F-15. And the hidden fist that keeps the world safe for Silicon Valley's technologies is called the United States Army, Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps. "Good ideas and technologies need a strong power that promotes those ideas by example and protects those ideas by winning on the battlefield," says the foreign policy historian Robert Kagan. "If a lesser power were promoting our ideas and technologies, they would not have the global currency that they have. And when a strong power, the Soviet Union, promoted its bad ideas, they had a lot of currency for more than half a century."
This is too easily forgotten today. For too many executives in Silicon Valley, there is no geography or geopolitics anymore. There are only stock options and electrons. Their view that Washington is the enemy, and that any tax dollar paid there is a tax dollar wasted, is grotesque. There is a saying in Silicon Valley that "loyalty is just one mouse-click away." But you can take that too far. Execs there make boasts like: "We are not an American company. We are I.B.M. U.S., I.B.M. Canada, I.B.M. Australia, I.B.M. China." Oh, yeah? Then, the next time I.B.M. China gets in trouble in China, call Jiang Zemin for help. And the next time Congress closes another military base in Asia, call Microsoft's navy to secure the sea lanes of the Pacific. And the next time Congress wants to close more consulates and embassies, call Amazon.com to order a new passport.
This doesn't mean America needs to be involved everywhere all the time. There are big, important places and there are small, unimportant places. Diplomacy is about knowing the difference between the two, and knowing how to mobilize others to act where we cannot or should not act alone.
In such a world, pure realism and pure idealism are rarely the answer. The realists would say, Stay away from Kosovo, even if the conflict could spill over to Greece and Turkey; the idealists argue that we should invade Serbia with NATO forces, break off Kosovo, make it an independent state and defend it forever. Both are wrong.
The lesson I learned from Bosnia is that Americans do not want to watch innocent civilians slaughtered in Europe, especially when we have the resources to make a difference at a reasonable cost. And they are right. But those who argued that no NATO peacekeeping operation would be workable in Bosnia until the parties were exhausted and there was a balance of power on the ground were also right. When you talk to American troops and officers who have served in Bosnia as peacekeepers, they don't tell you that they feel stuck in some morass. They are genuinely proud of what they are doing and vastly prefer that to parading around the flagpole at Fort Hood.
In Kosovo, the instinct of the Clinton Administration to nudge the parties toward a settlement before another massacre, and to leverage American power -- sending 4,000 peacekeepers to the Europeans' 25,000 -- basically makes sense. If the parties in Kosovo are ready to make peace, America, as a European power, should be prepared to play a part in patrolling the fence between them. If they are not, we should build a fence around them and use our leverage to foster a balance of power.
This same delicate balance applies to China. America's China policy oscillates between the Boeing School (just do business and everything will take care of itself) and the neoconservative school (China is a new version of the old Soviet Union and must be contained). Both are wrong. We do not want a cold war with China if we can avoid it.
China is not the Soviet Union, which made television sets that blew up and tractors that were more valuable as scrap metal. China is one-fifth of humanity and an economic powerhouse. It is also changing profoundly because of its openness to the world, and anyone who visits there regularly can see that it's Madison, not Mao, who's winning the day there. The right approach to China is to build bridges where possible -- to nurture that openness -- and draw redlines where necessary when Chinese actions become destabilizing. And some days you have to draw redlines in the morning and build bridges in the afternoon. We get in trouble when we do only one and not the other.
In order to sustain such policies, proponents of internationalism are going to have to build a new coalition to support it. The constituency that sustained internationalism for 50 years was the so-called Eastern Intellectual Establishment. That establishment, to the extent it even exists today, doesn't carry much weight with the I'm-an-idiot-and-proud-of-it Congressmen, who boast that they never travel abroad and, in some cases, don't even hold passports.
The next Administration, whether Democratic or Republican, will have to try to bring together the new globalizers -- from software writers to Web-page designers, from Iowa farmers to environmental activists, from human rights campaigners to high-tech assembly-line workers -- to form a new, 21st-century coalition that can sustain internationalism. This new coalition doesn't exist yet, so someone is going to have to put it together.
This won't be easy. Americans were ready to pay any price and bear any burden in the cold war because there was a compelling and immediate sense that their own homes and way of life were threatened. But a large majority don't feel that way about North Korea, Iraq or Kosovo, and while Russia may still have the capability to pose a lethal threat, it is not doing so at this time. That's why Americans are in the odd position now of being held responsible for everything, while being reluctant to die for anything. That's why in the globalization era, counterinsurgency is out; baby-sitting is in. House-to-house fighting is out; cruise missiles are in. Green Berets are out; U.N. blue helmets are in.
America truly is the ultimate benign superpower and reluctant enforcer. But history teaches us that if you take this reluctance too far, you can undermine the whole system. Paul Schroeder, emeritus professor of international history at the University of Illinois, is one of the great international historians of the 20th century. He once remarked to me: "If you look at history, the periods of relative peace are those in which there is a durable, stable and tolerable hegemon, who does the adjusting and preserves the minimal necessary norms and rules of the game. And that hegemon always pays a disproportionate share of the collective costs, even forgoes opportunities for conquest or restrains itself in other ways, so as not to build up resentments and to make sure the system stays tolerable for others.
"The difficulty," Schroeder continued, "comes when the benign hegemonic power, which is responsible for keeping the system stable, is unable or unwilling to pay the disproportionate costs to do so, or its hegemony becomes intolerable and predatory rather than benign, or when enough actors rebel against its rules and insist upon a different kind of system that may not benefit that hegemon."
That is what we must avoid. The global system cannot hold together without an activist and generous American foreign and defense policy. Without America on duty, there will be no America Online.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Comcast Corporation's acquisition of Mediaone misstated the name of the law firm that represented Comcast. It is Davis Polk & Wardwell, not Davis Polk Wardell.

SECTION: Section F; Page 12; Column 1; Health & Fitness

LENGTH: 577 words

HEADLINE: Early Eating Habits Tied to Adult Ills

BYLINE: By ERIC NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Two new studies lend support to the view that by the time children enter elementary school they may have eating and other health habits that will play a major role in the problems they may suffer in later life, including heart disease, high blood pressure and possibly diabetes.
Health experts said the findings suggested that it was never too soon to teach children good dietary habits, as well the importance of exercise. This is especially true for black and Mexican-American children. As early as age 6, one of the studies found, they show significant health differences, over all, in comparison with non-Hispanic white children. 
 One study, to be reported today in Circulation, the journal of the American Heart Association, was conducted by Dr. Alan R. Sinaiko of the University of Minnesota Medical School in Minneapolis and colleagues, beginning in 1977. It involved 679 public schoolchildren who were followed from age 7 through 23. Over the years, the children were periodically examined to determine their weight, body mass index -- considered a more accurate gauge of overall health -- and blood pressure. As adults, they gave blood samples that were tested for cholesterol and insulin levels.
The researchers found that body weight during childhood, and especially the rate at which the weight was gained, was a good indicator of whether an adult would exhibit risk factors for cardiovascular disease and diabetes. This was especially true for insulin resistance syndrome, a condition associated with obesity.
"The prevalence of overweight in youth is increasing," the report noted. "On the basis of the data from this study, it can be expected that there will be a steady increase in the number of at-risk individuals as today's children become adults."
The second study, described in the March 17 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, involved differences in cardiovascular risk factors among children in various ethnic groups.
It has long been established that blacks and people of Hispanic descent suffer from the disease at a greater rates than non-Hispanic whites. But the Stanford scientists report they could detect differences in the risk factors for the disease as early as age 6 in some cases.
They also found that while poor nutrition and low income often went hand in hand, the health differences between white and black children, and white and Mexican-American ones, appeared to transcend economic factors.
Among the health indicators researchers looked at were body mass index, fat intake, blood pressure and cholesterol. In most categories, they found significantly higher problems in the minority children studied.
While there may be many reasons behind the differences, from genetics to culture, the lead author of the study, Dr. Marilyn A. Winkleby, said many could be linked to a lack of knowledge about basic nutrition. She said more should be done to design nutrition education programs for blacks and Mexican-Americans. She also said much more should be done to encourage physical activity among children, and suggested that minority neighborhoods have not been provided with enough good sports facilities.
"That's just a priority of our society," she said. "It's something that it's not hard to do. It's cost effective in the long run."
The study drew on data gathered by the third National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, conducted by the Federal Government from 1988 to 1994.

SECTION: Section F; Page 11; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1303 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Dining a la Garbo: Alone, Not Lonely

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WE were four strangers. Each of us had happened upon a narrow, smoky Alsatian restaurant in an unfashionable part of Paris and taken a seat around the right-angled end of the bar. Before long, we found ourselves in a lively conversation about the rise of the supermarket in France and the decline of the small bakeries and food shops. We debated whether golf was a bore and argued over the Frenchman's insistence that Alsatian pinot noir was the only wine to drink with sauerkraut.
It was the sort of experience that is almost unthinkable in New York. 
 Dining alone in the United States is not exactly unpleasant, but it is often uncomfortable. Solo diners, escaping briefly from the office, may be common at lunch, but at dinner, when the demands of the workaday world are put aside, they are considered downright strange.
Americans think of dining out primarily as a social activity, an entertainment to be enjoyed with company. It falls into the category of going to a movie, where couples and groups are the norm, rather than a bookstore, where the lone browser is accepted. A solo diner, intent simply on savoring a dinner, is assumed to be missing out on a key element of the experience, and therefore must be lonely, sad or depressed.
"They look at them, and they say: 'He doesn't have friends. How come he's by himself?' " said Jean-Claude Iacovelli, who grew up outside Paris and who now owns three restaurants in downtown Manhattan, Jean-Claude, SoHo Steak and Velli.
More than a few times, I remember showing up by myself at restaurants in New York, only to be welcomed by the host's raised eyebrows of surprise and an almost imperceptible flash of pity. Seating is generally behind a pillar or near the kitchen, presumably to keep the lonely fly from spoiling the otherwise happy soup.
Things might be different at a local diner or cafe, where being a regular may take the sting out of solitude, but show up alone often enough and even a welcome familiarity may be tinged with pity.
"People in our society think strangely of people dining alone in restaurants," said Joseph Bastianich, an owner of Babbo restaurant in Greenwich Village. "It's much more a part of everyday life in Europe."
But if you talk with restaurateurs, solo diners are not actually that uncommon in New York. Often they are business travelers, on their own in a strange place and unwilling to settle for room service or the hotel dining room. But for the most part, solo diners in New York are like asteroids in orbit, circling endlessly without ever bumping into one another. That's why my experience at Alsaco, the little restaurant in Paris, seemed so unusual.
We made an odd foursome, for sure. A Frenchman in a dark blue sweater dotted with cigarette ashes who whipped out a wood-handled switchblade to saw off slices of his boiled pig's knuckle; an elderly Englishman in a fine old tweed jacket, who consumed a platter of grilled pork sausages slowly and meticulously; a Belgian shoe designer with the thick neck and powerful arms of a rugby player, who inhaled his soup as if he had a train to catch, and I, savoring a huge plate of juniper-scented choucroute garnie.
We didn't exactly burst into conversation. But a tarte flambee, my first course, was the icebreaker. They stared as the waitress set the huge tart in front of me. The flat, crisp crust was shaped like a map of western Europe, topped with cream, onions and bacon. It was delicious, as they all agreed after I gave them each a slice. Why not? It was way too much for me to finish, and soon we were all breaking bread.
"So," the Englishman asked the Belgian, "when you were just a small boy did you turn to your daddy and say, 'I want to be a shoe designer when I grow up?' "
American attitudes toward solo diners may not be relaxed enough to permit such acceptance or intimacies, partly because of restaurant economics. In New York, at least, the restaurant business depends more on volume than in Paris, and the sight of one person sitting at a table for two stirs visions of red ink among owners. What's more, lone diners usually drink proportionally less than groups, further cutting the profit margin.
But to an increasing number of New York restaurateurs, that attitude is shortsighted. Single diners may not maximize profits initially, but they may create new business. "Single diners are always the most open, and a lot end up being very interactive with the server," said Mr. Bastianich of Babbo. "It's a good opportunity to show what your restaurant is about."
Rather than sticking the single diner near the bathrooms or kitchen, thoughtful restaurateurs do things like making the bar comfortable for a meal, as at O Padeiro, a Portuguese restaurant in Chelsea, where the handsome bar is small but spacious enough to accommodate diners rather than just drinkers. More restaurants, like Mercer Kitchen, Tabla and Asia de Cuba, are adding communal tables, which would seem like natural places to seat single diners, although more often than not these seats go to groups. Most important, though, is simple consideration and sensitive antennae.
"We put them at a good table where they can be comfortable," said Mr. Iacovelli, who says he regularly serves solo diners from the Mercer and SoHo Grand Hotels. "If they have a book, we put them in a corner. If they want to talk, we pay attention."
Paying attention sometimes has its own rewards. In Paris, as I was wondering what to have for dessert, the Frenchman insisted I try the gewurztraminer sorbet. I did, and it was wonderfully refreshing, the perfect finish to the meal. Without the fellow sitting next to me, I never would have known.
 
Six Comfortable Spots for Solo Dining
 
NOT every restaurant in New York treats solo diners as annoyances. Friendly bartenders and waiters can be pleasantly social, though restaurants should also be sensitive to those who simply want to be left alone. A good list of wines by the glass is also a boon. Here are six places where lone diners can be especially comfortable:
BABBO -- 110 Waverly Place (Avenue of the Americas); (212) 777-0303.
Dining alone can actually be an advantage at this spare and casual trattoria, where tables are harder to come by than seats at the handsome bar. Many unusual wines are available by the glass.
CAFE DE BRUXELLES -- 118 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street); (212) 206-1830.
The small tables near the battered zinc bar of this venerable Belgian restaurant are good for solo diners. Mussels and frites make for a nice midsize meal, with one of the excellent Belgian beers.
CAVIAR RUSSE -- 538 Madison Avenue (54th Street); (212) 980-5908.
This old-fashioned caviar parlor is perfect for solitary celebrations. The star of the show is available in tiny tastes or in more serious portions.
GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL -- 12 East 12th Street (Fifth Avenue); (212) 620-4020.
Eating in Gotham's spacious, soaring dining room always feels like one of New York's great privileges. The lively bar along one side of the room caters to solo diners, beginning with the special trays, designed by the chef, Alfred Portale, that bridge the gap between bar and railing.
 O PADEIRO -- 641 Avenue of the Americas (20th Street); (212) 414-9661.
This combination bakery, cafe, takeout shop and restaurant offers a terrific selection of Portuguese tapas, allowing lone diners, seated at the bar or at one of the small tables, a variety of tastes without having to share. Portuguese wines are also available in small tasting portions.
 REPUBLIC -- 37 Union Square West (16th Street); (212) 627-7172.
The long slate counter with a view of the open kitchen at this stylish Asian noodle house is just right for solo diners and more pleasant than the backless benches at the noisy dining-room tables. ERIC ASIMOV

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 972 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Britain's Truckers Feel New Pressures

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: ISLE OF SHEPPEY, England, March 23

 BODY:
When European nations hang out their shingles to attract foreign investors, Britain's appeal runs something like this: come to Britain for low labor costs, low taxes, low overhead.
Ron Wood doesn't think so. 
 Mr. Wood, a trucker based on this marshy island at the mouth of the River Thames, runs 20 rigs carrying construction equipment the length and breadth of Britain. And, when the Government announced a 10 percent rise in the price of diesel fuel and a 50 percent increase in some truckers' license fees in its annual budget this month, Mr. Wood decided it was time to move, legally at least.
So, Mr. Wood plans to set up a subsidiary in the Netherlands -- R. W. Haulage International -- where his trucks will be licensed as Dutch trucks. As European Union vehicles, they will have the same access to British roads as any other European truck. But, since the Netherlands, like the rest of Continental Europe, has much lower license fees than Britain -- roughly $1,100 per vehicle in the Netherlands, compared with $9,000 in Britain -- Mr. Wood expects to save $160,000 annually for his $5-million-a-year business. Despite the Dutch registry, he will continue to pay relatively low British wages and British taxes.
Others are pondering similar calculations. After this month's budget, some 1,500 haulers called the Road Haulage Association, which represents about a third of Britain's haulers, to inquire about the technicalities of incorporating in Continental Europe, said Steve Williams, a representative of the association.
One of Britain's biggest operators, Eddie Stobart, whose fleet comprises 800 trucks each bearing a different woman's name, is thinking about registering 200 of his rigs in Luxembourg, and "may rename them Helga or Nicole," a spokeswoman for him said.
So incensed are Britain's truckers that hundreds of them, including Mr. Wood, clogged central London with their rigs yesterday in protest.
By moving abroad, the haulers will be reversing a trend of Continental companies seeking tax breaks in Britain, opening one of the first chinks in Britain's argument that alone among Europe's major economies, it is a haven from high costs.
"The problem is that haulage is now becoming a very European business," Mr. Williams said. "So European haulers can come in here and work without paying the same costs as we do. It's not a very level playing field."
The decision by Mr. Wood, 48, and others to "flag out" their vehicles in foreign lands is the latest sign of unease among Britons that while their Government tells them direct taxes are falling, a combination of indirect taxes and retailers' margins means they pay more for fuel, cars, computers, cigarettes, liquor and many goods than anyone else in Europe or the United States.
British truckers now pay the highest fuel and license fees in Europe -- more than $5 a gallon for diesel fuel, twice what it costs in Luxembourg -- and up to $9,000 a year to license a single 40-ton, five-axle rig, 17 times the cost in Luxembourg.
Since a European Union directive in 1998, moreover, all European Union road haulers have been permitted to carry loads not simply into and out of any country in the union but also to carry loads internally. Consequently, European trucking companies are rolling into Britain and offering to haul goods at one-third Mr. Wood's price.
A German truck, for instance, powered by cheap diesel fuel purchased in Belgium or France before crossing the Channel, can pick up a load of steel in Sheffield and drop it off in London -- a practice that was once banned -- without paying British license fees.
The British authorities, though, contend that the battle is really not about competitiveness but cleanliness, pitting pounds and pennies against environmental policies intended to meet Britain's international commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The price rises on pollutants like diesel fuel, said Vickie Sheriff, a spokeswoman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and Regions, are offset by lower prices for cleaner fuels like low-sulfur diesel and unleaded gasoline.
"The principle is that the polluter pays," she said. Trucks with six axles, similarly, qualify for much lower license fees than five-axle rigs because they do less damage to the highways.
According to the Road Haulage Association, Britain's 65,000 hauling businesses employ 500,000 drivers and a similar number of ancillary workers, carry 1.65 billion tons of goods a year -- four-fifths of all domestic freight -- and contribute over $7.4 billion of the $49.5 billion the Government collects in excise and fuel taxes and duties. The latest price increases, Mr. Williams said, will jeopardize 50,000 of those jobs.
Of course, jobs pay less in Britain than in much of Continental Europe because hourly wages are generally lower, and Britain does not insist on the same levels of social spending, personal taxes or corporate taxes. Indeed, John Reid, the Transport Minister, said, "Britain is not only cheaper than our major European rivals when it comes to road transport, but comes out almost on top of the list worldwide."
"Haulers who are thinking of relocating to other European countries should consider these facts very carefully before making a decision," he added.
What the authorities are not considering, Mr. Wood contends, is that continental European haulers operating in Britain "have already made their profit by the time they arrive" with a tankful of cheap diesel fuel. They offer internal hauling in Britain at a discount rather than return home empty.
"Originally flagging-out was meant as a threat," Mr. Williams said, "but now it's becoming a reality because so many people have had problems with the budget."
Or, as Mr. Wood put it, "I'd rather go to Holland than go out of business."

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 510 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Power-Plant Venture to Overtake G.E.

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ZURICH, March 23

 BODY:
ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the world's leading electrical-engineering company, and Alstom S.A. of France have agreed to combine their power-plant manufacturing units as recessions in Asia cut profits.
The joint venture, with $11 billion in annual sales, will leapfrog the General Electric Company of the United States to become the world's biggest maker of generating equipment. Alstom, the world's second-largest maker of energy-distribution equipment, will pay ABB $1.5 billion to set up ABB Alstom Power, and officials said some of the current 54,000 jobs would be eliminated. 
 Power-plant makers are combining as demand shrinks in Asia -- once the fastest-growing market -- and other developing economies, dragging down prices and profit. Last year, Siemens of Germany agreed to buy Westinghouse Power Generation from CBS for $1.2 billion.
"I have no doubt this can be a successful venture because size matters in this business," said Michael Krinner, a fund manager at Bank Fuer Handel & Effekten here.
Alstom, which was owned by Alcatel of France before its 1998 spinoff and share offering, also agreed to sell its heavy-duty gas turbine business to G.E. for $910 million, unwinding a 1989 technology-sharing joint venture. For G.E., the purchase will help it expand in Europe and bolster its business of selling service contracts with equipment, which is lucrative because it locks in revenue over many years.
ABB, a huge Swiss-Swedish company focused on energy, and Alstom are setting up the power plant unit, to be based in Brussels, as both try to increase earnings by reorganizing. Last year, ABB eliminated 14,000 jobs, or 6.5 percent of its work force, and acquired Elsag Bailey Process Automation N.V. for $2.1 billion to emphasize the profitable business of controls and measuring devices for industries ranging from electric power to drugs. And Alstom is streamlining operations after selling shares to investors last year.
ABB gets about a fifth of its revenue in Asia. Goeran Lindahl, its chief executive, said in Brussels today that the company planned to use the $1.5 billion payment from Alstom to make acquisitions similar to that of Elsag Bailey.
The two will own ABB Alstom Power equally, though ABB's power plant business is much larger, with $8 billion in sales, just below G.E.'s $8.5 billion. The joint venture may save $450 million a year by 2002, the companies said. Claude Darmon, the deputy chief executive of Alstom, will be chief executive of the unit, and Mr. Lindahl will be chairman.
Mr. Lindahl said today that Alstom's sale to G.E. of the turbine business removed concerns about regulatory approval of the joint venture. Approval is required from the European Union and individual governments, which Mr. Lindahl said he expected in three to four months.
The cost of setting up the new unit will result in a one-time charge of about 600 million euros, or $655 million, for the two companies, Mr. Lindahl said. He added that jobs would be cut at ABB Alstom Power, though he would not say how many.
