HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Up As Investors Focus on Issue From AT&T

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities rose modestly yesterday as investors focused primarily on the AT&T Corporation's record-setting global bond offering priced earlier in the day.
Treasury bonds received a lift from the huge corporate offering as securities firms that underwrote the issue bought back Treasuries they had sold as a hedge against losses. Also, a slumping stock market added to the buying momentum as investors sought refuge from equities. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 12/32, to 95 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.54 percent, from 5.57 percent on Monday.
To help meet strong investor demand, AT&T sold $8 billion of debt in a global offering, increasing the size of the deal from the $7 billion announced on Monday, which itself was an increase from the initially planned $5 billion to $6 billion. Appetite for the deal, which was underwritten by Merrill Lynch & Company and Salomon Smith Barney Inc., far outstripped supply, with about $12 billion in orders received, according to some traders.
The company had filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to sell as much as $13 billion of debt and plans to borrow more this year, possibly $3 billion.
The deal included $2 billion of five-year notes, up from $1.75 billion, and priced to yield 5.735 percent, or about 64 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity; $3 billion of 10-year notes, up from $2.5 billion, at a yield of 6.032 percent, or 84 basis points over Treasuries with a similar maturity; and $3 billion of 30-year bonds, up from $2.75 billion, priced to yield 6.582 percent, or about 94 basis points over similar Treasuries.
When it was priced, AT&T's debt offering became the largest investment-grade deal ever in the corporate bond market. And because of its size, it took on bellwether status, becoming part of the Lehman bond index. Inclusion in the index fueled demand from institutional investors.
Before AT&T's offering, Worldcom Inc., now known as MCI Worldcom, held the record for the largest high-grade deal after selling $6.1 billion in debt last August.
Joseph Battipaglia, chief investment strategist for Gruntal & Company, said the deal came in at a slight discount to where other single-A-rated corporate bonds are trading. "Yes," he said, "the securities have fair market value, which is where you would expect them to be selling if you wanted them to move from off the shelf and into the hands of investors."
Andrew C. Palmer, a managing director and corprate bond manager at ASB Capital Management, a company in Washington with more than $6 billion in bonds, said: "After all, the AT&T issue had been expected for quite some time and the bonds had been discounted over and over again, tightened a bit when they became too cheap, then discounted again. Right now I think the deal has a fair market value."
AT&T, based in New York, was in the market to sell bonds for the first time in almost four years to help pay for recent acquisitions. "This is going to be a bellwether corporate bond," Mr. Palmer said. "It will also be a popular deal for nondomestic investors who tend to buy the names they know, and AT&T they know."
Traders said another reason for the strong demand was that there was little likelihood that the company would turn into a high-yield company overnight.
The company recently completed its $32 billion purchase of Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's second-largest cable provider. It is also paying $5.5 billion to a TCI unit, Liberty Media, and acquiring I.B.M.'s global network business for $5 billion in cash.
AT&T's debt is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Treasury will auction $15 billion of new two-year notes today that were being offered at a price to yield 4.97 percent.

HEADLINE: California Utility Buying 16 Illinois Plants

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 23

 BODY:
Edison International, California's second-biggest utility, agreed today to buy 16 power plants in Illinois from the Unicom Corporation for $4.8 billion in cash to expand into the Midwest.
Edison, which serves 4.3 million customers through its Southern California Edison unit, will get plants that can produce enough power to light 9.8 million homes. Six of the biggest plants are fired by coal, the cheapest fuel used to generate electricity. 
 Unicom, the owner of Chicago's dominant utility, is selling the plants to prepare for deregulation in Illinois. Edison's California market was opened to competition last year and is looking for revenue sources in other states. The Unicom purchase gives it access to the fast-growing Midwest electricity market, where there is a shortage of power at times of peak demand.
"It's a shrewd move," said Edward Tirello, an analyst with BT Alex. Brown Inc. "The plants are right in the middle of the Midwestern hub."
The plants sold for almost three times their book value because they are in the Midwest, where power prices jumped during a heat wave last June to $3,200 a megawatt hour, more than 125 times the previous year's average.
Unicom, which serves 3.4 million customers through its Commonwealth Edison unit, expects a gain of $1.7 billion from the sale, while Edison said the plants would begin to raise earnings in 2002.
Shares of Edison rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $24.75. Unicom rose 6.25 cents, to $38.25.
The purchase, expected to be completed this year, includes a large plant that can be fueled by natural gas or oil and nine smaller plants used when electricity demand is high.
Though coal-fired power plants are cheaper to operate than gas or nuclear ones, they also pollute more. Edison's generating unit, Edison Mission Energy, said it was confident that it could operate the plants profitably even while investing $200 million to cut their emissions.
"There is a bit of a trade-off here," said Edward Muller, the chief executive of Edison Mission. "We will have to spend some money to improve the environmental performance of the plants, but we can make the economics work."
Edison Mission has stakes in 11 California plants, which it can maintain because it is legally separate from Southern California Edison. Edison Mission also owns plants in eight other states, including Nevada, Florida, West Virginia, New Jersey, Washington and New York, and has promised to build an additional 500 megawatts of gas-fired generation in Chicago.
This month, Edison, based in Rosemead, Calif., completed a $1.8 billion acquisition of a coal-fired power plant in Pennsylvania. The company plans to spend $200 million on pollution-reducing equipment for that plant.
Edison, which is second in California behind the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, a unit of the PG&E Corporation, is expanding outside the country as well. It said on Monday that it would pay $640 million to buy a stake in Contact Energy Ltd. from the Government of New Zealand.
Unicom, based in Chicago, plans to spend proceeds from the Edison sale on reducing operating costs at its nuclear plants as it prepares for competition in Illinois.

HEADLINE: Managed Care Squeezes Research Funds and Charity Health Aid, Studies Find

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
In the wake of the managed care revolution, health policy analysts have long suspected that financial pressures would threaten care for the poor and prevent academic health centers from financing their own biomedical research. Now, two new studies provide the first evidence that those suspicions are correct.
The studies, paid for by nonprofit health care research organizations, found that in regions of the country where managed care competition is most intense, doctors are less likely to provide free care to the indigent, and academic institutions are significantly less likely to use their own money for scientific research. 
 The findings, which appear in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, are based on surveys of more than 10,000 physicians and more than 2,000 faculty members of medical schools. Taken together, the studies suggest that as managed care takes hold, doctors and academic researchers are losing their ability to provide for "the common good," said Dr. David Blumenthal, director of the Institute for Health Policy at Massachusetts General Hospital, who is an author of the medical school study.
Health care economists, however, said society, not managed care, was to blame. Now that "cross-subsidies" -- the practice of shifting profits from patient care to pay for unreimbursed work -- have been squeezed out of the system, they said, Americans must confront the questions of how to finance research and how to care for the growing number of uninsured, now estimated at 43 million.
"Any economist would have predicted this," said Uwe Reinhardt, professor of economics at Princeton University. "I see in the medical establishment all this hand-wringing of saying the managed care industry is destroying all the good things in American health care. That's bull shine. Do we want this research? Yes? Then let's pay for it. Do we want to provide the uninsured care? Yes? Then let's pay for it."
In their analysis of charity care, researchers at the Center for Studying Health System Change, a nonprofit organization in Washington, surveyed 10,881 physicians in 60 randomly selected communities in 1996 and 1997, asking them about the amount of free care they provided in the month prior to being interviewed.
The study, paid for by the nonprofit Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, found that doctors who depend on managed care plans for 85 percent or more of their income spent, on average, 5.2 hours a month caring for indigent patients, while doctors who derived no income from managed care spent nearly twice that amount of time, 10 hours a month. Even so, more than three-fourths of the doctors provided some charity care.
The study also found that a climate of intense managed care competition had an effect on the behavior of doctors, even when they did not accept managed care plans themselves. In communities with the most competition, the researchers found, doctors on the whole provided about 25 percent less charity care than their counterparts elsewhere. In addition, doctors who did not own their own practices were also less likely to provide charity care.
The study did not compare the amount of indigent care today to what has been provided in the past. Nonetheless, Peter J. Cunningham, the lead author of the research, said: "The evidence suggests that the holes in the safety net are getting bigger. In areas where managed care is more highly developed, it is more difficult for uninsured persons to get care."
The analysis of academic research spending was paid for by the Commonwealth Fund, a nonprofit organization in New York that in 1995 created a panel to examine how the marketplace affects academic health centers. In surveying 2,336 faculty members at 117 of the nation's medical schools, Dr. Blumenthal and his colleagues tried to assess the amount of "unsponsored research" -- studies financed by faculty members themselves or by their institutions, as opposed to the pharmaceutical industry or the Federal Government.
The study found that nearly three-fourths of those surveyed conducted some unsponsored research, and about 4.4 percent of the total cost of research was paid for by institutions.
But the amount of institutional financing declined, the authors found, in communities where managed care competition was most pronounced. In the least competitive markets, including Chicago and Atlanta, financing for unsponsored research was more than twice as high -- 6.1 percent of the total -- as it was in more competitive markets like San Diego or Minneapolis-St. Paul.
Although the budget for the National Institutes of Health is scheduled to increase by 15 percent this year, Dr. Blumenthal said that would not solve the problem. To make use of additional grant money, many academic health centers would have to build more laboratory space. But in an era when revenue from patient care is declining, Dr. Blumenthal said, the centers might not want to invest money in building new labs.
If money for unsponsored research shrinks, Dr. Blumenthal warned, the training of young scientists will be compromised and creative work that is too nascent to warrant industry or Federal support will be lost. Indeed, the study found that unsponsored research was generally productive; almost four-fifths of it led to publications in peer-reviewed journals, and about 12 percent resulted in patent applications.
"It's a very uncertain time," Dr. Blumenthal said. "You won't see holes in the ground where academic medical centers used to be. You will see a great erosion of a capability which has been built up over many decades."

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 571 words

HEADLINE: 10 Years After the Big Spill

 BODY:
With the Administration's backing, a bill will be introduced in Congress today to give permanent wilderness protection to one of America's great natural treasures, the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The timing could not be more apt. Today is also the 10th anniversary of the day the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound, spreading 11 million gallons of crude oil over 3,000 square miles and causing horrendous damage to one of the nation's most sensitive ecosystems. Placing 1.6 million acres of Alaskan wilderness permanently beyond the reach of the oil companies would provide a measure of expiation for a major calamity. 
 In a sense, the Exxon Valdez incident has already left an important mark on the long struggle to achieve a better balance between energy and the environment. The spill forced President Bush to abandon his drive to allow drilling in the coastal plain and, in further repudiation of his friends in the oil business, to impose a 10-year moratorium on exploration in much of America's coastal waters, including the California coast and the Florida Keys. The spill also led to the 1990 Oil Pollution Act, which imposed severe penalties on oil companies and shippers for negligence and required safer double-hulled tankers by 2015.
More broadly, the sheer scope of the disaster did much to raise the country's environmental consciousness and taught it that a single accident could effectively cripple an entire ecosystem. In 1981, only 25 percent of Americans believed that the risks of offshore drilling outweighed the benefits. A year after the spill, that figure had risen to 55 percent.
There are still deep wounds, some of which only time and nature can heal. Of 20 animal and bird species affected by the spill, only 2 -- the bald eagle and the river otter -- have fully recovered. Eight others, including the economically vital herring and pink salmon, are slowly coming back, and 10 have shown no significant recovery. Exxon has shelled out more than $3 billion in cleanup costs and civil and criminal fines. But it has yet to pay $5 billion in punitive damages to thousands of Indians and commercial fishermen whose culture and livelihoods suffered severe damage. Nor has the Federal Government cracked down as hard as it could on the oil industry to upgrade its aging tankers.
Meanwhile, the companies and their Congressional allies are again hatching an assault on the coastal plain, which was left unprotected when Congress gave the rest of the refuge wilderness status in 1980. A narrow, breathtakingly beautiful stretch of land flanking the Beaufort Sea, the plain is home to an extraordinary variety of wildlife and, quite possibly, a major undiscovered oilfield. The Contract With America Republicans tried to open it up in the 1995 budget bill, only to be thwarted by President Clinton's veto. This year's vehicle is an innocuous-looking measure authorizing seismic tests that, if they showed oil, would inevitably strengthen the case for drilling.
That is why Representative Bruce Vento of Minnesota has offered his bill to put the coastal plain permanently off limits. As Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt once observed, drilling the refuge would be an ethical calamity, the equivalent of offering Yellowstone National Park for geothermal drilling. Furthermore, as this day reminds us, Alaska's landscape has suffered enough. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: High Court Expands Authority Of Judges on Expert Testimony

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
In a substantial victory for defendants in product liability suits, the Supreme Court gave Federal judges new authority today to keep expert testimony of questionable reliability out of the courtroom and away from the jury.
Expanding on a decision of six years ago that established Federal judges as powerful monitors of the quality of scientific evidence presented in their courtrooms, the Court said today that the approach it endorsed then was not limited to testimony about purely scientific principles. 
 Judges were obliged under the Federal rules of evidence to play the same gatekeeping role when it came to testimony based on technical or other specialized knowledge, Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote for a unanimous Court today.
In fulfilling that obligation, Justice Breyer said, judges should take a flexible, case-by-case approach, tailored to the potential witness's experience and field of expertise, whether it be engineering, economics, handwriting analysis or any of numerous other subjects.
"Life and the legal cases that it generates are too complex" for sharp dividing lines between different kinds of expertise, he said. Further, Justice Breyer said, "it would prove difficult, if not impossible, for judges to administer evidentiary rules under which a gatekeeping obligation depended upon a distinction between 'scientific' knowledge and 'technical' or 'other specialized' knowledge."
The lower court in this case, reflecting generalized confusion among the lower Federal courts over the scope of the Supreme Court's 1993 decision in Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, had ruled that the judge's gatekeeping role was limited to testimony based on "the application of scientific principles."
The jury should be able to appraise the value of expert testimony that relied on "skill- or experience-based observation" instead of scientific principles, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, ruled in a dispute over the reliability of testimony by an expert on tire failure in a lawsuit growing out of an automobile accident.
By overturning the 11th Circuit's limited view of the Daubert precedent and finding the tire expert's testimony inadmissible, the Court today added an important weapon to the arsenal of critics of the civil justice system who have complained that "junk science" has been finding its way into too many courtrooms and distorting the deliberations of unsophisticated jurors.
The case, Kumho Tire Company v. Carmichael, No. 97-1709, attracted briefs from a variety of business groups urging the Court to make it clear that the judge's role was an expansive one. Groups representing trial lawyers and consumers, on the other hand, urged the Court not to take from juries their historic function of evaluating evidence.
The case today was a lawsuit brought by a family whose Ford minivan was involved in a single-car accident on Interstate 65 in Baldwin County, Ala. Seven people in the minivan were injured and one was killed.
One of the vehicle's tires had blown out, and the plaintiffs, suing the tire manufacturer, wanted to present testimony by an expert in tire failures to prove that the accident was due to a manufacturing defect rather than wear or poor maintenance of the tire, which was bald in spots and had imperfect repairs of two punctures.
The Federal District Court in Mobile, regarding the proposed testimony as technical rather than scientific, nonetheless applied the approach of the Daubert decision. Finding the expert's analytical methods not sufficiently reliable, the court excluded the testimony and granted summary judgment to the tire company.
In reversing that ruling, the 11th Circuit said the trial court should not have applied the Supreme Court's guidelines in the Daubert decision for evaluating scientific testimony. These factors were: whether the expert's theory or technique had been tested; whether it had been subjected to peer review and publication; whether there was a high "known or potential rate of error" in the method, and whether the theory or technique enjoyed "general acceptance" within a "relevant scientific community."
In his decision today, Justice Breyer said a trial judge could pose any or all of those questions, as circumstances warranted. The Court then went on to apply the analysis to the tire expert's proposed testimony, concluding that the district judge had properly exercised his discretion in excluding it.

HEADLINE: Social Security: Divergent Paths

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
When the Clinton Administration put shoring up Social Security at the top of the national agenda early last year, White House officials said the first order of business was to make it politically safe to have a frank debate about the options.
Fourteen months later, the two parties have an array of choices before them, and from the White House to the Capitol to the scores of research and lobbying groups with an interest in the issue, the pros and cons of all of them are being examined in detail. 
 But while it has proved safe to talk about Social Security, the chances of talk turning to action remain questionable. Moreover, the positions staked out by the most influential forces in the debate reflect fundamentally differing visions of the role of Government.
The extreme difficulty of reconciling the faith among Democrats in the Government and the push by Republicans for a more market-based solution to social welfare problems was on full display this month when a bipartisan commission on Medicare collapsed in bitter disagreement.
Most Democrats, especially those liberals who view Social Security as Exhibit A in their argument that Government has a crucial role to play in insuring the well-being of citizens, are determined to maintain the system as much as possible in its current form.
They have rallied around the outline of a plan offered by President Clinton in his State of the Union address, when he called for keeping the current system intact, with its guaranteed retirement benefit. He proposed using a big chunk of expected Federal budget surpluses, in a somewhat circuitous way, to extend Social Security's solvency to 2049.
The President also proposed allowing the Federal Government for the first time to invest some Social Security reserves in stocks and bonds, a step he said would extend the system's solvency to 2055. To meet the system's longtime goal of 75 years of solvency, Mr. Clinton said, the two parties would have to agree on other unspecified steps, like cutting benefits or raising taxes.
Mr. Clinton also proposed an important change outside of the Social Security system. To promote retirement savings, he wants to establish a new form of private investment account, mainly for low- to middle-income workers.
Most Republicans are coming at the problem from a completely different perspective. They say the system needs a total overhaul, both to bring its finances into line with pressures it will face and to give individuals additional flexibility to amass wealth.
Republicans are considering a number of variants and are working on legislation they hope to introduce in coming months. But their basic approach is to establish personal investment accounts within Social Security through which individuals could invest in stocks and bonds.
Although such individual accounts would carry with them the risk of loss should Wall Street suffer a sharp or protracted downturn, most of the Republican plans contemplate some kind of guarantee that no retiree would be worse off than under the current system.
The details of both the Democratic and Republican approaches are complicated and confusing, even to economists and policy analysts. The arguments surrounding them touch on finance, demographics and human behavior.
But the battle is ultimately being fought over ideology, not mathematical computer models.
"There is a very deep ideological divide, and it's going to be very difficult to bridge," said Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Brooklyn Democrat who wants to retain the current system. "Republicans by and large want to privatize Social Security and believe in a system of personal accounts. The Democrats by and large believe that would destroy Social Security."
The optimistic view, which tends to be held more among Republicans than Democrats, starts with a belief that there is considerable common ground between the two sides.
The optimists say that both Mr. Clinton and the Republicans endorse raising Social Security returns in the stock market and that they differ only over whether individuals or the Government should do the investing.
They say Mr. Clinton and Republicans agree on the desirability of private investment accounts, and disagree only over whether the accounts should be established within Social Security or outside of it.
And they say both parties have an interest in dealing with the problem now, since every passing year will make the proposed fixes more painful for recipients and taxpayers.
But there are fewer and fewer optimists on either side these days.
"The different approaches really are irreconcilable," said Mark Weisbrot, research director of the Preamble Center, a liberal research group.
Even those who say a deal can be struck assume that it will be the other side that moves.
"There is the prospect of a deal once everybody understands the situation facing the system," said Representative Nick Smith, a Michigan Republican who favors private accounts.
Once both sides agree to put aside the demagoguery that has long inflamed the debates and study the facts, Mr. Smith said, there will be no choice but to quit having payroll taxes levied on today's workers pay today's retirees and begin having each generation save and invest for its own Social Security benefits. In other words, private investment accounts.
Forget it, say most Democrats, who argue that Republicans have exaggerated the crisis facing Social Security and the steps needed to insure the system's health.
Mr. Weisbrot said the country did not really need to be having this debate at all.
"What keeps it on the table is that you have Republicans who want to privatize or otherwise go after the system," he said. "You have Democrats who know it's a great way to win elections. You have a President who used the issue to beat back Republican tax cuts and is looking for a legacy other than impeachment."

HEADLINE: Sir Michael Caine, 71, Muse Behind Britain's Booker Prize

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 23

 BODY:
Sir Michael Caine, a corporate chief with a love of books who was the driving force behind the Booker Prize for Fiction, Britain's most prestigious literary award, died of cancer on Saturday in London. He was 71.
Modeled on France's Prix Goncourt, the prize was founded in 1968 when Sir Michael was an executive and board member of Booker P.L.C., an international group of companies involved in food distribution and specialized agribusiness. He served as chief executive of the company from 1975 to 1979 and then as chairman until his retirement in 1993. 
 For 23 years he was chairman of the Booker Prize Management Committee and host of the annual award dinner that is now televised live and ranks as London's greatest and most glamorous literary event. He drew admiration for his command of the evening because he had to overcome both a persistent stutter in his speech and a tendency of honorees to behave badly.
Beryl Bainbridge once spent the entire ceremony lying on the floor because she said she was most comfortable there. Philip Larkin, a judge in 1977, threatened to throw himself out of a window if a particular book he favored was not short-listed, and a presenter once stilled the proceedings with anti-Semitic jokes.
John Berger, the 1972 winner, used his acceptance speech at the Cafe Royal to denounce Booker's colonial past as an owner of West Indian sugar plantations and to threaten to give his prize money to the Black Panthers. The next year, J. G. Farrell used the occasion to denounce "fat cat" corporate officers and attack the royal family.
A voracious reader himself, Sir Michael was not interested in creating best sellers and was oblivious to criticism that the Booker sometimes went to writers who were obscure. "If that were all we wanted, there would be no need for judges, and the Jeffrey Archers would win," he remarked. His view of British literature before the creation of the prize was that it was "a bit peaky and down."
"The Booker," he said, "has cheered it up, made it more vibrant."
Michael Harris Caine was born in Hong Kong on June 17, 1927, the son of Sir Sydney Caine, a high-ranking civil servant who was to become the head of the London School of Economics. He received his bachelor's degree from Oxford where his thesis was on slavery and secession in the United States, and he went on to obtain a master's degree at George Washington University in Washington.
His early work for Booker in places like Guyana, Trinidad and southern Africa in the 1950's kindled a lifelong interest in activities intended to encourage education in developing societies and foster greater understanding in Europe of third-world problems. The $35,000 Booker prize was founded to encourage writing throughout the Commonwealth as well as in Britain.
He was knighted in 1988, and among the organizations he served as chairman were the Royal African Society, the Africa Center in London, the African Emerging Markets Fund and the United Kingdom Council for Overseas Students. Five years ago he organized Africa '95, a Britain-wide celebration of African music, art, dance and poetry.
He divorced Janice Mercer, his first wife and mother of his son and daughter, in 1987 and the same year married Emma Nicholson, a high-profile Conservative Member of Parliament who crossed the Commons floor in 1996 to join the Liberal Democratic Party. A year later she became a member of the House of Lords.
Asked in a telephone interview today if there were moments when people confused Sir Michael with the more famous Michael Caine, Baroness Nicholson said: "An enormous number of times. The phone would ring in the middle of the night, and there would be these inebriated women calling from Los Angeles saying, 'I'm coming over, I'm on the next plane, get my room ready.' "

HEADLINE: A Divisive Steel-Quota Debate Moves To the Senate

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Facing a wave of protectionist sentiment, two top trade officials argued today that a House measure to impose quotas on steel imports would hurt the American economy, lead to raw material shortages and rising prices and could set off a trade war.
Despite the warnings, steelmakers and some Senators vowed to push for quotas that they argue are needed to save a basic American industry. 
 Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, speaking before the Senate Finance Committee, said the quota bill, while "well intentioned," would be "neither in the national interest nor in the interest of the steel industry." She was joined in testimony by Commerce Secretary William Daley.
The measure, which swept through the House this month by a vote of 289 to 141, would roll back amounts of imported steel to levels from the mid-1990's. That vote came in response to a surge of low-cost imports from Asia and Russia late last year that brought down steel prices, which have just begun to recover.
"As our economy continues to grow, demand for steel products remains strong," said Ms. Barshefsky, who repeated the Clinton Administration's intention to veto any quota measure. "Imposing quotes at this stage, when it looks like the market is beginning to stabilize, could have the unintended effort of disrupting the market, with effects that could reverberate throughout the U.S."
Democrats and the Administration are wary of alienating organized labor, which is lobbying hard for the measure. Though it would violate World Trade Organization rules and faces a tough reception in the Senate, Senator Jay Rockefeller, a West Virginia Democrat and its sponsor, said: "Over the next two weeks, the United Steelworkers Union will unleash a terrific lobbying campaign in every member's district."
Under the measure the House passed, steel imports would be limited to volumes based on monthly averages gleaned from the three-year period before July 1997. The economic crises in Asia, Brazil and Russia hurt demand in the home countries; moreover, severe devaluations of their currencies made the steel inexpensive for markets here.
American steelmakers have brought anti-dumping suits against many countries, which have since cut steel exports to the United States. Russia, for example, has voluntarily agreed to reduce its exports.
Still, in testimony pitting protectionists against free-traders and the steel industry against the Administration, the bill's supporters said quotas were needed.
Critics of quotas, including Ms. Barshefsky and Mr. Daley, said they supported an alternative proposed in the House that would make it easier for the industry to seek remedies under existing trade law when faced with sudden surges in imports. This measure, sponsored by Representatives Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat, and Amo Houghton, a New York Republican, would lower the standards for bringing such cases to the International Trade Commission.
Steel industry leaders, however, insist quotas are necessary. "The real question is, do we want a steel industry in the United States?" George Becker, the United Steelworkers Union president, said. "We know there's an overcapacity of steel in the world. If we do not act decisively in the present crisis, there will be no American steel industry in the 21st century."
His views were echoed by Curtis H. Barnette, chief executive of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, who said: "We are in a period of record demand, and we are experiencing widespread losses in our industry. There is only one cause: imports."
But several users of raw steel criticized quotas, saying they would cut off the supply of specialty products that American steelmakers do not produce and could lead to retaliation against their own products.
Jack Porter, chief procurement officer for Caterpillar Inc., a maker of heavy equipment, said his company "strongly opposes the steel quota legislation." He added that it "could lead to direct retaliation against our exports and undermine the international trading system."
Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, sharply criticized the bill, calling it "a prosperity killer that would send the Dow down 2,500 points."
"It would be a move to protectionism," he said. "We're a prosperous country right now, and if we start a trade war, we will be the great loser."

HEADLINE: Jesse Jackson Will Skip 2000 Race, Advisers Say

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson will announce on Wednesday that he does not intend to run a third time for the Democratic Presidential nomination, advisers close to him said today.
Mr. Jackson commands a loyal following among liberal Democrats and would have complicated the campaign of Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Gore has long cultivated a friendship with Mr. Jackson and hoped he would sit out the race. 
 In an interview broadcast over the weekend on Black Entertainment Television, Mr. Jackson was asked whether he would run, and he said: "I'm inclined not to. I'm not very motivated to at this point."
Explaining that he wanted to concentrate on efforts outside Government, like pressing Wall Street to offer more start-up capital to minorities, Mr. Jackson said, "Beyond politics is a private sector challenge."
Today, speaking to reporters in Chicago, where he is to make his announcement, Mr. Jackson, ever mindful of the suspense factor, said: "You can rest assured that tomorrow we will share with you what we intend to do and how. We intend to impact public policy in a major way in 1999 and 2000."
But an aide said Mr. Jackson had decided not to run because he "simply believed that he can most effectively advance his work outside the context of a Presidential campaign."
Mr. Jackson also plans to announce his decision on Wednesday on the Web page of his son, Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. of Illinois. The Congressman has publicly urged his father to run.
The elder Mr. Jackson's decision leaves former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey as Mr. Gore's only rival so far. Other Democrats who seriously considered with running but bowed out are Senators Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, John Kerry of Massachusetts, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader.
Mr. Jackson, 57, is one of the most prominent black political leaders in the nation. He ran for the Democratic nomination in 1984 and again in 1988 and has weighed seeking the nomination in subsequent elections.
"He leaves a big gaping hole -- and the other candidates are going to scurry to fill it in," said David Axelrod, a Democratic strategist in Chicago who is not affiliated with any candidate. "He is a natural spokesperson for a large number of Democrats -- not just minority Democrats but poor, white working-class voters -- who feel disenfranchised. And it's a base that would be there for him any time he stepped into the race. Now those voters are up for grabs."
Although Mr. Jackson had insisted for months that he was still contemplating entering the race, many leading Democrats had not expected him to run. He had not established even a bare-bones campaign structure and had not begun soliciting donations, which is particularly crucial this year because the condensed schedule of primaries and caucuses puts a premium on early fund-raising.
Most recently, Mr. Jackson drew attention for his role as a spiritual adviser to the Clinton family during the impeachment and Senate trial.
Mr. Jackson founded Operation PUSH more than 25 years ago and is president of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, a merged nonprofit organization that seeks economic and political power for minorities.
Mr. Jackson is also Mr. Clinton's special envoy to Africa and host of the CNN program "Both Sides With Jesse Jackson."

 BODY:

U.S. Trade Officials Warn Of Danger of Steel Quotas
Facing a wave of protectionist sentiment, two top trade officials contended that a House-passed measure to impose quotas on steel imports would hurt the American economy, lead to raw material shortages and rising prices and could set off a trade war.
Speaking before the Senate Finance Committee, United States Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky and Commerce Secretary William Daley said the quotas could disrupt the steel market. In spite of these warnings, the steel industry and some Senators vowed to push for quotas. Page C6. 

Signs of Strain at DaimlerChrysler
The merger in November of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler, presented as a merger of equals, is producing considerable unhappiness among some American managers who contend privately that DaimlerChrysler has come to be dominated by Germans. C2.
 
Bank of New York to Buy Trust Unit
The Bank of New York agreed to buy the trust bank of the Royal Bank of Scotland for an undisclosed sum, making the Bank of New York the world's largest custodian of investor assets. The Bank of New York said the purchase would raise its total of assets under custody to $5.9 trillion worldwide, moving it ahead of Chase Manhattan. Shares of Bank of New York fell $1.25, to $36.9375. C6.
 
AT&T Sells $8 Billion in Bonds
Prices of Government securities rose modestly as investors focused primarily on AT&T's record $8 billion global bond offering. The yield of the benchmark 30-year Treasury fell to 5.54 percent from 5.57 percent on Monday. C10.
 
ARCO to Test Cleaner Diesel Fuel
Atlantic Richfield says it has developed a cleaner diesel fuel for trucks and other large vehicles that will soon be tested on the road in California, a national leader in pushing for the development of cleaner-burning fuels. C21.
 
SBC-Ameritech Deal Clears Hurdle
The Justice Department gave conditional approval to the planned takeover of Ameritech by SBC Communications, a deal that would create the nation's largest local telephone company. The deal, valued at $60 billion when it was announced last May, still requires the approval of the Federal Communications Commission, which is reviewing it. C6.
 
Power Plant Units to Combine
ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the world's leading electrical-engineering company, and Alstom of France have agreed to combine their power plant manufacturing units as recessions in Asia reduce profits. The joint venture, with $11 billion in annual sales, will leapfrog General Electric to become the world's biggest maker of generating equipment. Goeran Lindahl, the chief executive of ABB, said the company planned to use a $1.5 billion payment from Alstom to make acquisitions. C4.
 
Edison International, California's second-biggest utility, agreed to buy 16 power plants in Illinois from Unicom for $4.8 billion in cash as it expands into the Midwest. C6.
 
British Truckers Moving Abroad
Faced with far higher license fees and diesel fuel costs than their Continental rivals, British truck drivers are losing business, even within Britain. So some are "flagging out" -- incorporating elsewhere in Europe, but they will continue to pay lower British wages. C4.
 
Two Nissan Parts Units to Merge
Nissan Motor said two parts supplier subsidiaries, Calsonic and Kansei, would merge, furthering the troubled auto maker's efforts to simplify its sprawling operations, as it considers Renault's bid for a 35 percent stake. C4.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Plunge Over Concern On Earnings

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A broad selloff sent stock prices sharply lower yesterday as worries about high valuations and anxiety about corporate profits led investors to pare their holdings. Chances that the United States might soon be involved in air strikes over Kosovo only added to the anxiety.
The decline was worst among technology stocks, the group that has led the market's rise in recent months. But few areas were immune: nearly seven stocks fell for every two that rose on the New York Stock Exchange, the broadest drop since Oct. 8. Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, only AT&T rose in price. Eighty-seven of the 89 industry groups that constitute the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell. 
 "Things look pretty ugly to me," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "It has been a long time since we have seen breadth this negative. A lot of people are saying it doesn't matter, but I think it does."
By the close of trading, the Dow had fallen 218.68 points, or 2.2 percent, to 9,671.83, its biggest decline since Jan. 14. The S.& P. 500 had its worst day since Oct. 1, losing 34.87 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,262.14. The Nasdaq composite index shed 73.10 points, or 3 percent, to 2,322.84, the worst drop since Feb. 12. And Thestreet.com's index of Internet companies fell 36.82 points, or 5.8 percent, to 596.69.
"It was tech wreck," said one trader, who insisted on anonymity. "The next rally has to be driven by corporate earnings, not interest rates. And if we get good earnings, a lot of money will come into the market."
For some time, investors have been concerned that prices could undergo a fairly significant correction, if only because stocks have risen so far, so fast.
Between the end of August and last Thursday, when it peaked at 9,997.62, the Dow rallied 33 percent. According to the ISI Group, a New York consulting firm, there have been only four other times in the last 30 years when the Dow rose as much during a similar 143-day period.
Gains in broader indexes have been even more impressive.
Between Aug. 31 and last Thursday, when it hit a record of 1,316.55, the S.& P. 500 shot up 37.5 percent. And from Oct. 1 until Feb. 1, when it peaked at 2,510.09, the Nasdaq advanced 77 percent.
"A 10 percent correction would not be unreasonable on the Dow," said Louise Yamada, a managing director in technical research at Salomon Smith Barney. "Nor would a 15 percent to 20 percent correction on the Nasdaq."
Concern about earnings, particularly among personal computer makers, continues to hound technology stocks.
Dell Computer was the most active Nasdaq issue yesterday, losing 2 3/16, to 35 11/16, on concerns it faces another quarter of slowing sales growth. On Monday, Kevin McCarthy, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, lowered his earnings estimate on Dell and said he expected the PC industry to grow only 8 percent in 1999.
Microsoft, the dominant software provider, fell 6 1/4, to 166 9/16. And I.B.M., which sank last week after Morgan Stanley Dean Witter voiced concerns about revenue growth, dropped 1 5/8, to 165 3/8.
"Earnings will probably be good this year for most of these technology companies," said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment officer at BankBoston. "But expectations were unrealistic."
BellSouth joined the list of earnings trouble stories. The telecommunications company said that additional spending to build its data and wireless businesses would reduce profit growth in the first half of the year to the low end of the current range of Wall Street expectations. Richard Klugman, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, lowered his earnings estimate for the first quarter. The company's shares fell 2 13/16, to 42 3/4.
The price drop was not confined to technology shares.
Industrial giants like General Motors and General Electric were battered. So too were financial service companies and banks, including J. P. Morgan, the American Insurance Group and BankAmerica.
Shares of General Motors fell 4 11/16, to 85 9/16. General Electric lost 3 13/16, to 106 9/16. J. P. Morgan shed 3 11/16, to 122 3/4, while AIG slumped 5, to 117. And BankAmerica was down 3 1/2, to 69.
Elsewhere, Coca-Cola fell 1 13/16, to 65 7/8, after analysts at Merrill Lynch cut their earnings forecasts for the first quarter and the entire year, citing what appear to be deteriorating conditions in Latin America and Japan.
But the session's biggest loser was Pathogenesis, the pharmaceutical company. Its shares tumbled 22 3/16, or 65 percent, to 12 3/16 after it said it expected to post a loss this year on weaker-than-expected sales of its sole drug product, an inhaled antibiotic.
But shares of Autoweb.com, an on-line car retailer, soared 26, to 40, on their first day of trading.
Other Internet stocks did not fare nearly as well.
America Online, the most active issue on the Big Board, fell 9, to 121. Amazon.com lost 12 5/8, to 119 3/8. And Yahoo dropped 9 1/2, to 155 1/2.
Despite the sharp pullback, analysts at ISI provided a glimmer of hope: After each of the last 33 percent rallies in the Dow -- in 1975, 1982, 1986 and 1987 -- the analysts noted the index gained an average of 5 percent over the next three months.

HEADLINE: Milton S. Gould, 89, Legal Giant in a City of Lawyers, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Milton S. Gould, a classicist turned storied courtroom litigator who for years played the scholarly Mr. Inside to William A. Shea's gregarious Mr. Outside as a managing partner of one of New York City's most politically connected and ethnically balanced law firms, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 and since the disbanding of Shea & Gould in 1994 had continued his 65-year legal career with the firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae.
By the time he and Mr. Shea engineered the 1964 law firm merger that created what became Shea & Gould, Mr. Gould was already a prominent litigator and Mr. Shea had already developed his reputation as a master of the back-room deal. 
 Over the next two decades as the firm became closely associated with the local Democratic Party and a succession of mayors, it was the backslapping Mr. Shea who emerged as its media star, especially after his successful efforts to obtain a replacement team for the defecting Brooklyn Dodgers led the city to name the Mets' stadium after him.
But while Mr. Shea, who died in 1991, is recalled by former colleagues as having had a much sharper legal mind than he was generally given credit for, it was the largely apolitical Mr. Gould who built the firm's reputation as an effective courtroom advocate in corporate and other litigation.
In a career in which he represented clients in major business upheavals -- involving the likes of Twentieth Century Fox, Columbia Pictures and Curtis Publishing -- Mr. Gould became famous for winning millions for the stockholders of the old Fifth Avenue Coach lines after it was taken over by the city and for restoring the reputation of Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli Defense Minister, in a libel action against Time magazine, which had written that he had encouraged a murderous Christian attack on Palestinian camps in Lebanon.
A tall, informal man whose wardrobe tended to be more off-the-rack rumpled than courtroom chic, Mr. Gould had such a deceptively low-key manner during cross-examinations that rivals were sometimes lulled into complacency.
There was the time, for example, when Mr. Gould, defending a client in an apparently open-and-shut municipal corruption case, asked the key witness, an informant who had spent 10 months in the Federal witness protection program, how he had been spending his time, and the man replied that he had been reviewing, embellishing and clarifying his testimony.
The prosecutor, no doubt grateful that Mr. Gould had quickly gone on to other matters and had not underscored the implications of the statement with follow-up questions, obligingly passed up an opportunity to ask the witness to clarify what he had meant by "embellishing" and "clarifying," questions that would no doubt have elicited an explanation that the man had certainly not meant that he had altered his testimony or deviated from the truth.
Indeed, nothing more was heard about the statement until Mr. Gould got up to deliver his summation, one in which the word "embellishing" was used so often and with such effect the jury disregarded the informant's damaging testimony and found Mr. Gould's client not guilty.
A native of Manhattan who grew up reading Latin and Greek, Mr. Gould never abandoned his love of classics, but at Cornell, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1930, he gave up his plans to become a college professor and switched his allegiance to the law, graduating from the law school there in 1933.
At a time when the city's white-shoe law firms were notorious for shunning Jewish lawyers, Mr. Gould was surprised to receive an offer from the old-line firm of White & Case, but when he learned he was to be assigned to strictly research duties and forbidden contact with clients, he quit and joined a new and energetic Jewish firm, Kaufman, Weiztner & Celler, whose partners included a future Federal judge, Samuel H. Kaufman, and a powerful Brooklyn Congressman, Emmanuel Celler.
As a Catholic lawyer, Mr. Shea had similarly been stung by the city's Protestant legal establishment, and when Mr. Gould's firm, by then known as Gallop, Climenko & Gould, merged with Mr. Shea's firm, Manning, Hollinger & Shea, to create what was initially known as Shea, Gallop, Climenko & Gould, it was no accident that one firm was Jewish and the other Catholic.
Indeed, with their new firm instantly nicknamed Blarney & Chutzpah, the partners took pains to make sure the percentages of Christian and Jewish lawyers remained in the 40-60 range.
From the beginning, Mr. Gould and Mr. Shea, who rode to and fro work together, ran the firm. As Mr. Gould once put it, "There was only one boss, Shea and I."
As the firm grew, some of the younger lawyer's chafed at the managing partners' high-handed ways, and after Mr. Gould, then 74, had heart bypass surgery in 1984, the two men ceded power to a five-member executive committee. It proceeded to expand the firm so rapidly that it never recovered after a downturn in the economy and was dissolved in 1994.
Mr. Gould, whose wife, Eleanor Greenburg Gould, died last year after 61 years of marriage, is survived by three children, Jonathan of Woodstock, N.Y., Judson, of Washington, and Patricia Booth of New York; a sister, Hinda Rosenthal, and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE RUSSIANS;
A Phone Call From Gore and a U-Turn to Moscow

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Just after 1 P.M. today, an angry Russian Prime Minister, en route to Washington for some of the most important talks of his short tenure, ordered his pilot to turn his Ilyushin airliner around and return to Moscow.
Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov was a few hundred miles northeast of Newfoundland when he received a satellite telephone call from Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Gore grimly informed him that a diplomatic effort had failed and that the United States and NATO were preparing to deliver a barrage of air and missile strikes against Serbian targets in Kosovo and Serbia. 
 Mr. Primakov was in an untenable situation, having argued for months against the use of force against Moscow's allies in Serbia. Whatever he might have hoped to gain from three days of meetings -- with Mr. Gore, President Clinton, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and officials of the International Monetary Fund -- was now overshadowed by the likelihood of American-led military action in the Balkans.
"Primakov told the Vice President, 'We categorically oppose this,' " said a senior American official privy to the telephone conversation. "He was so committed to coming here that he took it as far as he possibly could, until he realized he couldn't avoid a situation that he found completely unacceptable. So he turned back."
 And when he returned to Moscow on Wednesday, he told the Itar-Tass news agency that air strikes would be destabilizing, Reuters reported. "I do not think that these strikes can bring stability in Kosovo," he said. "On the contrary, the situation will be destabilized. Oor relations with the United States and stability in Europe will suffer."
The Prime Minister's abrupt decision to cancel his visit to Washington was a mark of the significant souring in the American-Russian relationship. Administration officials said the split over Kosovo, which has been festering for some time, could poison discussions on a variety of matters, particularly Russia's desperate need for cash to cover its foreign debts and keep its economy functioning.
Mr. Primakov, like all Russian prime ministers under the unpredictable President Boris N. Yeltsin, is also in a precarious domestic political position. His mission to Washington was intended in part to bolster his standing at home by presenting him in high-profile meetings with top officials to negotiate for new commitments of Western financial aid.
Administration officials had warned Mr. Primakov for the last several days of the awkward timing of his visit, with the United States and its European allies preparing to carry an ultimatum to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia. But Mr. Primakov pressed on, even after Mr. Gore told him at 9:30 A.M., when Mr. Primakov was in Shannon, Ireland, for a refueling stop, that there was little hope that Mr. Milosevic would accept allied demands that he withdraw his forces from Kosovo.
At 9:50 A.M., Mr. Primakov left Shannon, intent on coming to Washington -- until 1 P.M., when Mr. Gore reached him on his aircraft with word that air strikes were imminent. Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States troubleshooter for the Balkans, had just left Belgrade, where his efforts to persuade Mr. Milosevic to back down were rejected.
Mr. Primakov was approaching Gander, Newfoundland, not far from American airspace, when Mr. Gore's call was connected. A senior Administration official paraphrased Mr. Gore's side of the conversation this way: "Yevgeny, my friend, this is what happened in Belgrade. We feel we must go to the next stage."
The official added: "In no sense did we uninvite him or make him unwelcome. We just wanted him to know what cards he had in his hand. The Russians had always said that if the bombing began while Primakov was in Washington, he would speak out strongly against it and go home."
Mr. Primakov and Mr. Gore are co-chairmen of the United States-Russia Joint Commission, which meets twice a year to discuss matters of common interest. This session was to have been devoted to Russia's dire economic situation, particularly its inability to make good on $17 billion in interest payments due this year to international lenders.
The agenda also included arms control, the environment, agricultural sales and efforts to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. But all that will have to wait. The two men did not set a new meeting date.
"The Prime Minister and I are both committed to a strong bilateral relationship," Mr. Gore said in a statement issued by the White House today, "and we are both convinced that work of the commission helps strengthen that relationship. We will take up the important work of the commission at a time when both sides can better focus their attention on the issues before us."
The bland words mask a deep division between Washington and Moscow over the Balkans that dates to the collapse of the Soviet Union and the unraveling of the former Yugoslavia. Friction over the expected NATO military action could affect the broader relationship between the two powers, Administration officials acknowledged today.
Mrs. Albright made an effort today to contain the damage with Russia from the dispute over Kosovo, according to aides. She spoke by telephone for more than half an hour with her Russian counterpart, Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov, said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman.
The United States has expended huge amounts of time and money to bring Russia into the global trading system as well as to keep its 7,000 nuclear weapons under close control. Russia's failing economy has produced a long-running crisis that has caused enormous hardship among the Russian people as well as jitters among Russia's global lenders. Moscow is also irritated at the expansion of NATO to include Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, even without the prospect of the alliance's intervening on the territory of another former Soviet satellite.
"This is putting a lot of strain on our ability to conduct some of these other negotiations," the official said. "Do we recognize that the Kosovo thing hasn't made it any easier? You bet."

HEADLINE: Saving Social Security: Comparing Three Plans

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
With more than three workers paying taxes today for every retiree, the Social Security system is running a surplus. But by the third decade of the next century, when most baby boomers will have retired, there will be only about two workers for every person drawing benefits. Without some change, Social Security will eventually be unable to pay all promised benefits.
 In his State of the Union Message in January, President Clinton offered a general plan, but the Administration has still not proposed detailed legislation to fill in the gaps. His plan emphasizes maintaining the existing retirement system, with its collective commitment to a guaranteed benefit, and strengthening the economy by using the Federal budget surplus to reduce the national debt. 
 Republicans are taking a different tack. To a greater or lesser extent, they would fundamentally transform Social Security from a Government program into a private system.
 Without having agreed on the specifics, Republicans in the Senate and House are developing plans that would give workers money through tax cuts to invest in the stock market. Each worker would have a private investment account.
 Under one approach, the tax cuts would be financed at first by the surplus and, when the surplus ran out, by money from general revenue. Workers would be promised that their individual retirement benefits would never be lower than under the existing system and might be higher.
 Another approach, which was adopted by a national commission sponsored by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, would finance the private accounts by diverting a portion of the payroll tax paid by workers and their employers into private investment accounts. To guarantee long-term solvency, this plan would require politically painful benefit cuts. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: The New York Times/Photographs by Alex Quesada (top) and Todd Buchanan for The New York Times
 
Chart
 
Advocates
 
PRESIDENT'S PLAN
This approach also has the support of most Democrats in Congress, labor unions and liberal policy institutes like the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.
 
REPUBLICAN PLAN
Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Representatives Bill Archer of Texas and E. Clay Shaw Jr. of Florida, all Republicans, are developing legislation following the principles developed by Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist and former economic adviser to President Ronald Reagan. Most Republicans and conservative policy institutes like the Heritage Foundation advocate this approach.
 
COMMISSION PLAN
An independent commission of politicians and others proposed a plan similar to the Republican approach, also built around private accounts. Commission co-chairmen included Senators John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, and Representatives Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, and Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona. Similar approaches are backed by Democratic Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska.
 
Basic plan
 
PRESIDENT'S PLAN
USING THE Budget surplus
About $2 trillion of the $4.4 trillion Federal surplus projected over the next 15 years would be used to reduce the national debt by half. In addition, $700 billion would be invested by the Government in stocks and bonds. Steps would be taken to insulate the investment from political interference. This $2.7 trillion is about 60 percent of the 15-year surplus, more or less the proportion expected to result from an excess of Social Security taxes over benefits. (Of the rest of the surplus, 15 percent would be set aside for Medicare and the remainder would be spent on the military, education and other programs.)
 
NEW BONDS
The Administration would then credit to Social Security's trust fund a new set of bonds in the exact amount of the public debt it had repurchased. The bonds -- an i.o.u. from the Government to itself -- would obligate the Treasury to pay for Social Security from general revenues starting around 2032.
 
EXTENDING SOLVENCY
The White House plan would extend Social Security's solvency from 2032 to 2055. To meet the test to which the system has historically been subject -- 75 years of solvency -- would require some tax increases or benefit cuts. The White House did not specify any such measures but said it believed they could be negotiated by Congress and the Administration.
 
OPTIONAL PRIVATE INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS
Separately, $500 billion would be set aside from the Federal budget surplus over the next 15 years to create what the President called universal savings accounts. The Government would give low- and middle-income workers money to invest in stocks and bonds. The Government would match a portion of additional contributions individuals make to retirement accounts the way many companies match employees' contributions to 401(k) plans. Such accounts could be passed on to a retiree's heirs.
 
REPUBLICAN PLAN
PRIVATE INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS
This approach would use a portion of future budget surpluses to finance investment accounts that would be owned by individual workers and give them a chance to reap the higher returns available on Wall Street.
Details remain in flux, but the idea is to let each worker place money in an investment account each year, financed directly or indirectly through a tax cut. Workers could invest the money in a range of mutual funds.
At retirement, the worker would have the accumulated investments in a personal account, plus a guaranteed Government benefit. The guaranteed benefit would be reduced somewhat based on the gains accumulated in the private account, but the net result would be to leave most retirees with a bigger total benefit than they would have without the private account. Under nearly all versions of this approach now under consideration, there would be a guarantee that no retirees would receive less than the benefits they would receive under the current system.
 
ANNUITY
When reaching retirement age a worker would be required to use at least some money in his or her personal account to buy an annuity -- a contract that pays a guaranteed sum of money each month for the rest of the recipient's life.
For example, if retirees received a monthly annuity of $800, they would not receive their full Social Security benefit, say $1,300 a month under current law. Mr. Feldstein's plan would reduce the guaranteed benefit by 75 percent of the annuity value, or $600, making it $700 a month. But combined with the $800 a month annuity from the personal account, the retirees would receive a total of $1,500 a month -- $200 more than the current system would provide.
 
COMMISSION PLAN
BENEFIT CUTS
Rather than being built around use of the budget surplus, a substantial reduction in benefits would pay for the shift from the current pay-as-you-go system to one in which workers are diverting a portion of their payroll taxes into individual investment accounts.
The main ways benefits would be reduced:
The age at which retirees are entitled to full benefits, now 65, would gradually be raised to 70 by 2029 and at a slower pace afterward.
Benefits to nonworking spouses and cost-of-living adjustments would be lowered.
The formula for determining benefits would be adjusted so that all but the poorest retirees would receive lower Social Security payments than they would under the existing system.
 
PRIVATE INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS
Workers would be allowed to place 2 percentage points of the 12.4 percent Social Security payroll tax into private accounts. The new system would not apply to anyone 55 or older. As is the case with the Feldstein plan, retiring workers would be required to buy lifetime annuities. And when they died, their heirs would inherit what remained in their accounts.
 
GUARANTEES
This plan differs from the Republican approach in that only the poorest retirees would be guaranteed a specific benefit. For others, the plan would ultimately reduce Social Security benefits by 25 percent or more. The sponsors calculate that the retirement system could be financed without draining resources from other Government programs.
The poorest retirees would be spared most of the cuts and affluent retirees would be most affected by the cuts.
 
Arguments in favor
 
PRESIDENT'S PLAN
KEEPS BENEFITS
Social Security would be maintained as a universal program in which all workers, employers and retirees would have a stake. Less affluent retirees would continue to receive higher benefits relative to their earnings than wealthier retirees.
 
REDUCES NATIONAL DEBT
Reducing the national debt would strengthen the economy by making interest rates lower than they would be otherwise and also by opening the way for more productive private investments. Entering the crunch years for Social Security with less debt, the Government would find it easier to borrow if necessary to pay benefits. Lower debt would free billions of Government dollars every year that would otherwise go to paying interest. And, theoretically, it would create jobs, generating more tax revenue.
 
LIMITS RISK
Because the bonds would be held in Social Security reserves, the retirement program would, as a political obligation, have the first claim on Government spending when funds ran short.
Investing some Social Security money would allow the Government to benefit from the higher rate of returns in the private financial markets. Because the risk would be spread so widely, retirees would not be adversely affected by drops in the markets.
 
REPUBLICAN PLAN
INDIVIDUAL RESPONSIBILITY
As a matter of principle, individuals and not the Government should be responsible for their retirement security. The existing Social Security system in which each generation pays for the retirement benefits of the previous generation is essentially a house of cards that is bound to collapse in insolvency.
 
LONG-TERM GROWTH
Private accounts allow retirees to take advantage of compound interest and of the fact that over a very long time the stock market has always increased in value and can be expected to in the future. The budget surplus will be sufficient to cover the transition for years and to pay benefits during downturns in the markets.
To the extent that their private investments are not used to purchase annuities, the plan would allow ordinary workers to build estates that they could pass along to their children.
 
COMMISSION PLAN
INDIVIDUAL RESPONSIBILITY LONG-TERM GROWTH
The arguments for private accounts involving individual responsibility and long-term growth are the same as those for the Republican plan.
 
REALISTIC ASSUMPTIONS
Unlike the Clinton and Republican proposals, this plan addresses a problem raised by nearly all impartial analysts: No solution is pain free and taxes will eventually have to be raised or benefits cut to keep Social Security solvent for baby boomers who have been paying taxes into the system for years.
 
Arguments against
 
PRESIDENT'S PLAN
LOW RETURNS
Social Security might remain a good deal for low-income Americans, but over a lifetime, most people would be better off if they invested their retirement savings.
 
LONG-TERM FLAWS
The plan relies on budget surpluses that might never materialize, and ducks a fundamental question of how the retirement system's costs will be reined in as the population ages.
 
SHELL GAME
The plan does nothing more than throw new i.o.u.'s at the problem and avoids the tough choices needed to keep subsequent generations from having to pay the bill for the retirement of the baby boomers.
 
POLITICAL PRESSURE
Investments could not be insulated from politics. Politicians would try to prevent some investments (gun makers, cigarette manufacturers, companies that make birth-control devices) and encourage others (companies that hire union workers, manufacturers that do not buy foreign-made parts).
 
REPUBLICAN PLAN
HELPING THE AFFLUENT
The country is already spending sufficient resources on pensions, so there is no reason, other than political expediency, to promise increased retirement benefits. Affluent retirees would receive proportionately larger increases in benefits than those who are less well off.
 
LONG-TERM FLAWS
Sooner or later, the budget surplus will run out. Under this plan, other Government programs would have to be cut to pay retirement benefits.
rosy assumptions
The benefits of private investment are based on rosy assumptions of stock market performance. There have been decades or more when stock prices have fallen.
Republicans underestimate the cost of transition to a private system and the money lost to the high administrative cost of managing small, individual accounts.
 
COMMISSION PLAN
ROSY ASSUMPTIONS
HIGH FEES
The arguments against private investment accounts involving rosy assumptions and high fees are the same as those made against the Republican plan.
 
RISK
In addition, because most retirees would not receive guaranteed benefits, a poor stock market performance would hurt.
 
SMALLER BENEFITS
Even with the returns from their private accounts, some retirees would doubtless receive smaller pensions than they would if current guaranteed benefits were maintained.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
PRITCHARD, DR. WILBUR L.

 BODY:
PRITCHARD-Dr. Wilbur L. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Dr. Wilbur L. Pritchard, a distinguished alumnus of the School of Engineering, Class of 1943. Dr. Pritchard, a pioneer in satellite engineering and an early advocate of satellite broadcasting, was the president of W.L. Pritchard & Co., Inc., a consulting engineering firm doing technical and economic studies in telecommunications for private firms and governments. Dr. Pritchard was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree from CCNY in 1993. He was a firm friend of his Alma Mater and a strong supporter of public higher education. On behalf of the City College community I wish to extend my deepest sympathy to his family. Yolanda T. Moses, President The City College of New York/ CUNY

HEADLINE: Magic Johnson to Resurrect a Movie Palace

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Magic Johnson, the former Los Angeles Lakers star whose post-basketball ventures include developing movie theaters, has reached an agreement with New York City to refurbish the historic Loews Kings Theate2 on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, officials announced yesterday.
The $30 million project will transform the movie house, which closed in 1977, from a dormant relic of the 1920's to a state-of-the-art, 12-screen multiplex. The project was a long-sought triumph for Mr. Johnson, whose company, Magic Johnson Theaters, failed in earlier efforts to build theaters in Jamaica, Queens, and in Harlem. 
 The city has owned the Loews Kings property since it was seized for nonpayment of taxes in 1978. By winning the support of the city and state governments, including tax breaks and low-interest loans, Mr. Johnson's project is almost certain to be successful, with a grand opening expected in 2001.
Mr. Johnson flashed a broad smile as he appeared yesterday afternoon with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at City Hall to announce the deal in which the city will sign a long-term lease allowing Mr. Johnson and his partners at the Sony Corporation to redevelop the Kings.
"We feel that we are going to have a great success here i. Brooklyn, a theater that everybody will be proud of and everybody will come and support," Mr. Johnson said at the news conference. "We will continue to be a community-based theater, that's what we do different than any other theater chain."
Mr. Johnson's company has built theaters in Los Angeles, Houston and Atlanta. The deal announced yesterday gives it a crucial foothold in New York, the most lucrative movie market in the country, with fewer movie screens per capita than any other large city. In building his theaters, Mr. Johnson has chosen sites in typically underserved, black communities. And all of his theaters offer community services not commonly found in movie houses, including free blood pressure tests and reading programs for children.
Mr. Johnson said he still hoped to build a theater in Harlem, where deals his company struck at two different sites fell through, and in Queens, where 17 months of negotiations ended unsuccessfully in January 1998 and where a competing theater developer then quickly signed an agreement.
In previous years, property owners, local officials and developers might have begged Mr. Johnson to join their projects and build on their sites. But his interest in New York City came at a time of intense competition among theater chains to build new screens to serve the city's millions of movie fans.
"We tried to work on a Jamaica, Queens, deal together and hopefully that will come back," Mr. Johnson said. "Now we have a deal in Brooklyn at the Loews Kings Theater. It is a historical theater and we want to preserve some of that history that it has, but also build a brand-new theater."
The old Loews Kings Theater was a legendary, mammoth movie palace with 3,200 seats and impressive, if jumbled, Art Deco, Renaissance and ornate Baroque architectural flourishes. It had a long pink marble lobby, dramatic staircases and heavy burgundy-colored drapery.
The old theater's facade and some interior features will be preserved, officials said, but the huge, single auditorium will be divided to create the modern multiplex. Built in 1929, the Kings is a landmark of Brooklyn memories, a place, for instance, where Barbra Streisand worked as an usher.
Mayor Giuliani, who visited the Loews Kings as a child, recalled its former glory and said the community is now filled with striving immigrants who speak more than 70 languages and are steadily rebuilding the neighborhood. "Those of you who are familiar with the old Loews Kings Theater as I was, remember this was a true entertainment center," Mr. Giuliani said. "Now with this redevelopment, it will help to revitalize and continue the ongoing revitalization of the neighborhood."
Charles Millard, the president of the New York City Development Corporation, which negotiated the deal with Mr. Johnson, credited the city's drop in crime and rejuvenated economy with making the new theater project possible. "This city is a different city and that neighborhood is a different neighborhood than it was five years ago," he said. At yesterday's news conference, he said his parents had gone to the old Loews Kings on dates before they were married.
Mr. Johnson said the project had particular sentimental value to his partners at Loews Theaters, Sony's movie chain, both because the old theater was an original Loews property and because the chain is based in New York City. The refurbishment is expected to create 175 construction jobs, and the new theater is expected to create 100 jobs for local residents, including after-school jobs for teen-agers.
When reporters asked Mr. Johnson if he had reservations about appearing with Mr. Giuliani at a time when many black elected officials and business leaders have been demonstrating over the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, the former basketball star maintained the cool confidence he had as a player on the rare occasions that he was grilled about mishaps on the court.
"We are trying to supply jobs for minorities and black people," he said, "and I think those black leaders will be happy about that because those people in Brooklyn will have jobs."
When the question came up again, he did not waver. "This is a big announcement, this is going to impact a community here in New York and in Brooklyn; if we can't see that then we're all here for the wrong reason," he said. "This is about 100 jobs for minorities. It's about another 175, just like we have done in Houston, Atlanta and Los Angeles. We have impacted a community. We have brought pride to a community."
