 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the redevelopment of the Loews Kings Theater in Brooklyn by Magic Johnson Theaters referred imprecisely to the company's partner in the project. It is Loews Cineplex Entertainment, not the Sony Corporation. (Sony is the largest shareholder of Loews Cineplex Entertainment.)
The article also referred incompletely to Magic Johnson's plans for a movie theater in Harlem. Although two previous deals for the company to build there fell through, it has signed an agreement to operate a nine-screen theater at Harlem U.S.A., a retail and entertainment complex under construction on West 125th Street.

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Tough Times: Rock's Incubator Turns Down the Heat

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 21

 BODY:
In the past at the South by Southwest convention, for years the rock business's most important cavalcade of performances and panel discussions, talent scouts came looking for tomorrow's rock stars. Acts like Fastball, Lisa Loeb, the Presidents of the United States of America, Cake and even Hanson set deals in motion here. But something was different this year.
The change was best represented by the agenda of one scout from a major label. Speaking on condition of anonymity, he said he had come here not to sign a band, but to prevent his label from signing one. The group's contract with his label had expired, he said, and he wanted tm make sure no one else at the label tried to renew it at the band's showcase performance. 
 During this convention, held from Wednesday to Saturday, it was impossible to ignore the effects of record-label consolidation and rock's cyclical fall from commercial grace. The atmosphere was like Bourbon Street in New Orleans after Mardi Gras but when even the die-hard revelers have gone home, leaving the streets dirty and desolate.
"I never thought I'd see the day when I didn't care about Sonic Youth," said another major-label talent scout, referring to the seminal New York alternative rock band. "It's sad what's happened to indie rock. This is the least exciting year I've been here."
And so it went. The number of major labels at South by Southwest severely dwindled this year, with almost no top executives in attendance and many lesser employees opting to stay home. Even the bulk of smaller independent labels didn't bother to bring their most popular bands, only the struggling ones.
The convention center and showcases for unsigned bands seemed emptier than usual, though a conference spokeswoman said attendance was up slightly from last year's 6,000. And most tellingly, a new music-industry class emerged: the great unemployed, laid off as a result of consolidation, chiefly Universal's recent acquisition of Polygram. Most were trying to find new opportunities but ended up just sharing war tales, like the Mercury employee who remembered colleagues being summoned to a room 50 at a time to get laid off one January afternoon.
Nighttime concert showcases were no longer just for unsigned bands: they were also for former Polygram bands like Radish and Robbie Fulks, both of whose record deals were recently terminated. Overall there was a sense that festivalgoers were no longer on the cutting edge. Speakers at panels agreed that the biggest thing happening in music today was setting beats to rhymes: rap. Yet here they all were, holding the rock banner in the air and wondering when people would start noticing it again.
"The economy is booming, the Internet is popping, the Dow is reaching 10,000, but the music industry is acting like it's waking up from a really bad hangover," said Andrew Rasiej, who heads the New York Nightlife Association and a charity called Mouse, which brings computer networks to schools.
This feeling of neglect, of having missed the bus, was also common at a separate convention in Miami, the Winter Music Conference, a five-day event for electronic dance music that ended on the day South by Southwest began.
When alternative rock began to wane commercially three years ago, major labels looked to electronic dance music to plug the gap. Instead, as pop veered back into the middle of the road with the Spice Girls, Hanson and fey boy bands like the Backstreet Boys, the contrarian fringe movement came not from white music (the rock of South by Southwest or the electronica of Miami) but from black music, showing just how little control the established industry -- denizens of conventions like these -- has over pop success.
(To be fair, the Miami conference isn't all electronica: it's also known for its component of Latin dance music, a genre with sales on an upswing and one that the established business is even less equipped to deal with than rap, despite a few visionary executives who began taking crash courses in Spanish this winter.)
The lack of a viable rock undercurrent in some ways made South by Southwest a success, signaling an end to mercenary concertgoing and a return to music for music's sake. Some at the conference simply chose to see the group Built to Spill perform three nights in a row, and they were better off for it. This ever-changing Boise, Idaho, group boasted its strongest lineup, blurring lyrically astute songs into sonically intense guitar solos and proving itself to be one of the closest things alternative rock has to a classic rock band.
Younger performers like Diane Izzo, a songwriter from Chicago, probably would have been the object of a major label bidding war three years ago, hailed as the next P. J. Harvey or Liz Phair. Instead, Ms. Izzo played her winningly dark-minded rock this year in a half-empty club with few record executives in attendance.
Thanks in part to Austin's deep well of songwriters, it was possible to go out every night and hear great music without ever attending a show by anyone under 35. (As talent scouts will tell you, with the same conviction with which they once said that rap was dead, no one over 35 is going to be the next big thing.)
Semi-reclusive artists well past their showcasing days, like Tom Waits and Jeff Beck, flew into town in hopes of building excitement for their new albums. The back garden of a Mexican restaurant played host to a high-spirited jam including Joe Ely, Freddy Fender, Rosie Flores and Ruben Ramos.
A fatigued Lucinda Williams turned in a lackluster performance in support of a terrific album. Guy Clark, Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown and the always talented, always inconsistent Terry Allen -- with a guest appearance by David Byrne -- performed to a packed house at Liberty Lunch. (Willie Nelson was scheduled to perform with Leon Russell, but the show was rained out.) Even Wanda Jackson, the 61-year-old rockabilly queen, played one night at 1 A.M.
In contrast to past years, when the shows with the most buzz (jargon that conjures images of both swarming and irritation) were by young alternative rock bands, this year's most talked-about show was by a pop star, Robbie Williams, formerly of Take That. He erected an elaborate arena-ready performance in the tiny garden of an Austin club to kick off an American campaign that he hopes will make him as big a celebrity here as he is in Britain.
As conferencegoers complained of the lack of hip-hop, only a handful of people ended up at the best of the week's few rap shows, by the savvy-rhyming Ugly Duckling, of Long Beach, Calif., at Bob Popular. They performed as teen-agers outside took turns demonstrating a loose-limbed style of break-dancing as part of what they called the Texas swing-hop scene.
The most interesting shows were the oddest. Todos los Manos were a German group featuring members from Chile, Brazil and Hamburg singing in Spanish, Portuguese, French and English (but not German) and playing hard-driving songs that switched styles every 30 seconds. Bellatrix, a mostly female quintet from Iceland, packed Bob Popular one night, mixing violin, drum loops, and wailing, biting avant-rock vocals.
Japanese bands once again matched their American counterparts in talent and diversity, from the big-beat dance-rockers Boom Boom Satellites to the obsessive record collector known as Fantastic Plastic Machine to the guitar-bashing girl pop group Seagull Screaming Kiss Her Kiss Her.
Despite so much good music, many people left the conference with the sinking feeling of having spent a week treading water with a rock tied to their legs.
"We need to give the music back to the people," Lucinda Williams said in a keynote speech that began the conference. "I don't think major labels are working anymore." On a panel on the closing day of the conference, David Byrne echoed her sentiments.
This moment in pop may seem like a time of low spirits and layoffs. But in retrospect it may prove to be one of the most exciting periods to be involved, especiaslly with the changes that will be wrought by the Internet; label consolidation; the sale of concert companies, record labels and options on song royalties to Wall Street, and the rise of easy-to-use computer programs enabling anyone to become a producer. Those out of work today may be the ones starting companies vital to reassembling the business in coming years.
All this hasn't gone unnoticed by the producers of South by Southwest: in recent years they've started conferences on interactive technology and film to surround the music festival, clearly envisioning a day when the rock convention seems as quaint as a television without cable.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: March 29, 1999, Monday

 CORRECTION:
The Pop Life column on Wednesday about the South by Southwest music convention held last week in Austin, Tex., misstated the status of a record deal by the group Radish. The group's contract was not terminated; it was transferred from Mercury to Island/Def Jam.
The column also misidentified a German band that performed at the convention. The group's name is Ninos Con Bombas, not Todos los Manos.

HEADLINE: Leadership Void Hobbles CUNY as It Faces Severe Problems

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Two years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki gave the trustees of the chronically troubled City University of New York a new chairwoman with a mandate to steer the university in a new direction. Less than five months later, the trustees got the chance to shape their own management team when they forced the resignation of Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds.
But in the 20 months since, the opening the trustees created at the top of the university has turned into a yawning gulf. 
 Not only has the board failed to find a permanent chancellor. Other top executives at the university have been leaving one by one. Five of CUNY's top jobs are now filled by temporary appointees: there is an acting chancellor, an acting deputy chancellor, two acting vice chancellors, and an acting dean for student services.
The presidencies of 5 of its 17 undergraduate campuses are open or about to open, and at least 2 more presidents have been seeking other jobs.
While CUNY continues to function despite all these openings, there is a pervasive sense of crisis and lost opportunity as the university awaits a report from a task force appointed last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The panel, led by the former Yale president Benno C. Schmidt Jr., was asked to investigate CUNY and draw up a plan for the future; the report is expected next month.
There are few hard numbers by which to gauge the cost of the leadership vacuum. But officials and faculty members say it has had tangible effects.
*Long-range planning has virtually stopped.
*Major administrative functions, like preparing budgets, are now being performed by the board itself.
*Morale has suffered. "The level of morale is in the basement," said Sandi E. Cooper, a history professor at CUNY's College of Staten Island who is a former chairwoman of the faculty senate, "because of the insecurity of not knowing whether you are going to be rewarded or blown up at, respected or not believed."
*Recruiting of faculty members and high-level administrators has been handicapped.
"The number of people applying for the college presidencies is much lower than it used to be," said Edith B. Everett, a trustee. "Without a permanent chancellor, they have no idea of the kind of leadership they will be operating under, the direction of the university, what its philosophy is and the support they will receive. Right now, there is a perception of chaos."
The trustees had hoped to have a new chancellor in place months ago, and their search committee had selected three finalists last summer. But the process broke down when the Governor and Mayor failed to approve any of them; they did not even summon them for interviews.
To some, the stalled search was a sign that the university and its trustees, who are responsible for appointing the chancellor, did not control their own destiny.
While the acting chancellor, Christoph M. Kimmich, has earned great respect inside CUNY and outside -- Governor Pataki's office last week said he had done an "excellent job" -- there is a widespread awareness that he and many of his staff are caretakers. "It's not that we don't like Christoph Kimmich; he's done an unbelievably great job under the circumstances," said William P. Kelly, provost at CUNY's graduate center. "But how can you plan when you don't know who is going to be in charge in a year or two?"
And Herman Badillo, the vice chairman of CUNY's board, says the interim appointments also color the way the university is perceived on the outside. "You have to have a new chancellor for the Governor and the Mayor to have confidence in CUNY," he said. "An interim chancellor doesn't do it, because he doesn't have the authority to move."
Even Dr. Kimmich says the university is "not best served by a state of uncertainty."
"There is a sense of being a bit on hold," he said.
A permanent chancellor could be expected to grapple more forcefully with the critical problems facing CUNY: its tattered reputation, its shrinking financial resources, the demands for changing the way it operates.
Without such a leader, the trustees and the Mayor and the Governor have involved themselves in policy matters on an unusually detailed level.
"The gap in leadership has empowered the worst aspects of the trustees, who are trying to micromanage the university," said Bernard Sohmer, the faculty representative on the CUNY board. "Most of the presidents are terrified about what might come next."
In addition to the lack of permanent leaders, CUNY faces challenges on many fronts.
It has come under fire from the Governor and Mayor, among others, over academic standards they say are far too lax.
Enrollment has fallen, at a time when other New York colleges are seeing their applications soar. This semester's total of 193,505 students is off about 2 percent from last year, and down 9 percent from the 1994 peak of 212,634, raising questions about underused capacity on some campuses.
The university is in severe financial straits. Its budget has risen little since the early 1990's after inflation is taken into account. State and city support have fallen sharply, leaving CUNY more squeezed than many public universities. Both the Governor and Mayor are refusing to pay for faculty salary increases approved in the union contract for next year.
The trustees themselves are sharply divided over CUNY's direction and priorities, and have lacked both strong leadership and the confidence of elected leaders in Albany and New York City.
 
Instead of a Buffer, 'A Conduit for Politics'
The largest urban university in the United States, CUNY was once a beacon in public higher education, and in some ways it still burns brightly. But in other ways it is under siege.
"I wouldn't want to characterize what happened before as higher-education nirvana," said Patrick M. Callan, president of the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, in San Jose, Calif. "But CUNY is now caught in the middle of a partisan, ideological circus."
It is not unusual that the trustees are political appointees. At CUNY, the Governor appoints 10 of the 17 trustees and the Mayor 5. (There is also one faculty trustee and one student trustee.)
What is unusual is the Mayor's and Governor's close involvement in shaping CUNY's policies -- and in choosing a new chancellor.
"Usually, boards are meant to be a buffer from the politics," said Joseph Burke of the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany. "Here, it is more like they are a conduit for the politics."
For his part, the Governor is happy with the trustees' progress, his chief of staff, Bradford J. Race, said.In particular, Mr. Race commended the passage of a hotly debated measure in January that will bar students from bachelor's degree programs if they need remedial work in reading, writing or mathematics, although they can still enroll in the community colleges.
He added that the Governor's office was also now pleased with CUNY's chairwoman, Anne A. Paolucci, whom Mr. Pataki had attacked after he grew dissatisfied with the slow pace of change.
But as the trustees themselves note, much of the board's progress has come in close, hotly contested votes. Although the votes of the Mayor's appointees have generally been consistent with his vision, Governor Pataki's appointees have splintered.
Dr. Paolucci denies that anyone outside the board is affecting policy. But others on the board say that the Mayor has been a primary force in drawing up policies like the one on remedial education.
The Mayor's press office did not respond to several telephone calls seeking comment about CUNY.
 
Trying to Provide A Sense of Direction
Dr. Kimmich, the mild-mannered historian who was appointed interim chancellor in November 1997 and had expected to return to his job as Brooklyn College's provost long ago, has tried to provide a calming influence and a sense of direction amid the disarray.
In the fall, for example, he worked with the trustees to draw up a five-year budget proposal for Albany, rather than the usual one-year request. This month, he led college presidents and other top administrators on an off-campus retreat to discuss long-term planning.
"Regardless of my tenure, we need to set targets and engage people in forward planning process and make sure things do get done," Dr. Kimmich said. "It may not be the norm for someone who is in a temporary position, but I don't think we can wait."
The trustees set up a committee to find a new chancellor in late 1997. With the help of a search firm, the committee conducted interviews and by last summer had produced a short list of finalists: David Adamany, the former president of Wayne State University; Richard H. Ekman, the secretary of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and Warren H. Fox, the executive director of the California Postsecondary Education Commission.
What was most notable about the list, however, was that it did not include the man described as the Mayor's and Governor's candidate, SUNY's provost, Peter D. Salins. Although CUNY's search committee interviewed Mr. Salins, trustees on the committee said last summer that his presentation went poorly. Mr. Salins has declined to discuss the CUNY search.
Neither CUNY's bylaws nor state or city laws call for the Governor or Mayor to approve the appointment of a chancellor. CUNY's trustees hold that power. Although the chairwoman called the forwarding of the three candidates' names to the Mayor and the Governor last summer a courtesy, other trustees say it is one more sign of the Governor's and Mayor's influence over CUNY affairs.
One of the three candidates, Dr. Adamany, has since withdrawn, and the search committee has not met since.
Dr. Paolucci, who heads the search committee, would not comment on the events so far. She said the search firm was supposed to be finding more names, but was not finding many.
"We have good candidates," she said, "but we want to build up the list. It is a very important job."
Other members of the panel say they have heard nothing about the resumption of the search, but they and others wonder if they can even find a plausible candidate who will want the job. Some college presidents who were approached said the position involved too many political land mines.
"How do you get the kind of leadership you want when the position begins to look like a municipal appointee?" Mr. Callan asked, referring to the Mayor's role in prescribing policy. "The person has got to be accountable, but not in the same way as a municipal employee."
 
Moving Ahead In Spite of Turmoil
Beneath the turmoil at the top, the university has continued to function, often in impressive ways: the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching named a Queens College professor the state's 1998 Teacher of the Year, the third CUNY faculty member in four years to be so honored. John Jay College of Criminal Justice was rated the leading graduate program in criminal justice last year, ahead of Harvard, by U.S. News & World Report.
CUNY is also working to improve student preparation so more students can pass its placement tests when they arrive. It has expanded its College Now program to 50 high schools, so 10th, 11th and 12th graders can take CUNY's placement examinations and receive remedial help before they graduate. The university is also expanding its intensive "immersion" programs for students who fail the tests.
Officials say they are encouraged that new applications are running 2 percent ahead of last year and that applicants to the senior colleges, which are raising their entrance requirements, are better prepared than those of a couple of years ago.
The mood on campuses is varied. While some students and faculty applaud the attempts to remake the university and see the turmoil as the cost of making sweeping changes, others say they are worn down by the constant attacks on the university, using words like "battle fatigue" and "numbness" to describe how they feel.
Some who follow CUNY politics predict that no serious chancellor candidate will be put forward until summer, when Mr. Pataki has the opportunity to make new appointments to the board, solidifying control.
But Mr. Race said that the Governor's office had no such plan, and added that he believed CUNY's board was pressing ahead with its search.
Although he expressed admiration for Mr. Salins, he said the Governor had no particular candidate. "I know Peter well, and he's doing a great job at SUNY," Mr. Race said, "but I would have an interest in anybody with his qualities who expressed an interest in the job."

HEADLINE: Patient's Right to Sue

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Managed-care consumers will be fleeced if Congress adopts independent external review as a substitute for, rather than a complement to, a patient's right to go to court to seek full redress for injuries (Economic Scene, March 18). 
 Federal law grants protection from medical malpractice liability to private-sector, employer-paid insurance companies, health maintenance organizations and other managed-care organizations. Adding external review to the law would do nothing to change this corporate shield.
Because health plans can often avoid fully compensating injured patients, the law gives H.M.O.'s an incentive to deny necessary care. Allowing consumers access to state-court remedies will give managed-care companies the incentive to make sound medical decisions in the first instance.
 
FRANK CLEMENTE
Washington, March 18, 1999
 
The writer is director of Public Citizen's Congress Watch.

HEADLINE: Saner Debate on Steel

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A Divisive Steel-Quota Debate Moves to the Senate" (Business Day, March 24): The decline of employment in the United States steel industry does not necessarily correlate with the decline of the industry as a whole. Yes, the industry employs fewer steel workers, but the United States remains the second leading steel producer in the world. 
 Other countries like our trade policy because it allows them to use our market to dump steel to stabilize their economies.
But do we really want a trade policy that deliberately sacrifices domestic industry and workers for the vague goal of stabilizing the world economy? Instead of promoting export-driven remedies abroad, the United States should encourage demand-led policies that would improve the lives of the foreign workers and protect American workers from unfairly traded goods.
 
JUDITH STEIN
New York, March 24, 1999

HEADLINE: Essay;
Against Internal Aggression

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Never will so many nations inflict so much destruction with so little relish.
Because outrage is absent and the public's war spirit is lacking; because few in NATO want to see the collateral damage sure to be inflicted as bombs go astray; and because foreign policy is so foreign to our economy-fixated discourse, Americans are asking as we go in: What national interest impels us to intervene to stop an independence movement from losing?
Four categories of answers, the first three of them unhappy:
1. The simplifiers. President Clinton painfully gives the reason designed to stir emotion and rally popular support: "President Milosevic . . . has again chosen aggression over peace." Serbian forces are "burning down Kosovar Albanian villages and murdering civilians."
2. The thoughtful internationalists. Senators like Richard Lugar and John McCain are reluctant to see us lurch into combat commitment with no end in sight. They find themselves forced to support the bombing of the Serbs because to do otherwise after all our threatening would be to reveal the alliance of Western nations as a pitiful, helpless giant.
3. The anti-Wilsonians. Henry Kissinger exhibits "great unease" at NATO's decision to intervene; his conceptual framework holds Woodrow Wilson's principle of self-determination to be unduly idealistic and destabilizing. He stops short of saying we should not join the bombing because he does not want to disestablish the foreign policy Establishment.
4. The America Firsters and the quagmire-avoiders. Now that the McGovernite left has fallen silent about taking sides in a civil war, anti-war voices are mainly from the Republican right, and they alone are unconflicted. They condemn the multilateral intervention, arguing: If Serbia refuses to allow a province coveted by neighboring Albania to secede, outsiders have no right to label such defense of its national borders "aggression" and to support the rebels. Russia agrees: If NATO can help the Kosovars break away from Serbia, then it can help the Chechens break away from Russia. That's why Yevgeny Primakov had to turn around and go home.
I'm in a separate school with President Wilson, who was three generations ahead of his time. Wilson was an arrogant idealist, a troublemaking rearranger of national borders who summed up his vision thus: "Every people has a right to choose the sovereignty under which they shall live." (Great principle; bad sentence structure.)
We now live in a world of satellite-televised brutality and computer-samizdat suffering; repression is hard to hide. If a large ethnic group dominating the demography of a province wants to be independent, it can assert its desire for self-determination in a dramatic way that earns a decent respect of the Opinion of Mankind.
Sometimes this desire is misplaced, overlooking the strengths of national diversity and the blessings of the melting pot. Quebecers think about separation; unrepressed by Canada, they decide democratically to stay in. Puerto Ricans, able easily to dissolve ties to the U.S., wisely choose not to. East Timor, bloodily annexed by Indonesia, can now opt in or out.
But what happens when a people -- bonded by linguistic, cultural, racial or religious ties -- is denied the expression of its culture, and then demands sovereignty from despots? If those oppressees are ready to shed their own blood and that of their territorial hosts, their sometimes self-induced agony, projected on the world's attention screen, becomes a persuasive argument for "humanitarian intercession."
If the repressing country is powerful, the sovereignty does not change; too bad for now, Tibet.
If its leadership is savagely dictatorial but vulnerable, as in Iraq, repression is restricted from outside: We'll enforce your autonomy, you Kurds, but no independent Kurdistan lest your compatriots in Turkey and Iran get ideas.
If the villainous sovereign is relatively weak and the potential bloodshed is horrendous, then in we go (with bombs, not troops) to save the Kosovars.
Consistent and principled? Not quite. But the trend at century's end is toward self-determination, propelled by a world audience humanely averse to seeing casualties up close.

HEADLINE: Drop of 5% Is Reported In Orders for Durable Goods

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Factory orders for big-ticket goods posted the largest decline in more than seven years in February, a sign that an expected recovery in manufacturing could be a few months away, the Commerce Department said today.
"We're not out of the woods yet," said Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York. 
 Weaker demand for aircraft, electronics and industrial machinery contributed to last month's 5 percent drop in durable goods orders, the Commerce Department said. The decline, to $191.8 billion in February orders -- after gains of 3.3 percent in January and 3.4 percent in December -- was the largest since a 6.5 percent drop in December 1991 as the economy was emerging from recession.
Excluding aircraft, autos and other transportation equipment, the drop was not quite as severe, with orders falling 1.7 percent last month after rising 0.1 percent in January.
February's decline in factory orders also runs counter to signs of strength in other reports. The National Association of Purchasing Management's latest survey showed manufacturing expanded in February for the first time in nine months. And the Federal Reserve reported a gain in February industrial output.
A 14.3 percent drop in orders for transportation equipment last month dominated the overall plunge in durable goods orders, the Commerce Department said. Other major categories showed weakness as well, with a 8.5 percent decline in electronics and electrical equipment orders and a four-tenths of a percent fall in industrial machinery.
Primary metals was the only major category showing an increase, rising 7.2 percent. Steel imports fell for the third consecutive month in January. That brought them close to the level before last year's surge in shipments from overseas set off trade complaints from United States manufacturers and the Government imposed duties on certain types of imported steel.

HEADLINE: Loan Delinquencies Rose in 4th Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Delinquencies among credit card, home equity and auto loan borrowers rose slightly in the fourth quarter, yet the number remains well below record levels, the American Bankers Association reported today.
The group said 3.45 percent of credit card accounts were past due in the fourth quarter, up from 3.28 percent in the third quarter but below the peak of 3.72 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996. 
 Measured by dollar amount, delinquencies fell to 4.62 percent from 4.63 percent in the third quarter, the study said.
The association's composite ratio of eight types of consumer loans, such as auto, personal and home equity lines, showed delinquent debt rose to 1.97 percent in the October-December period from 1.83 percent. The number of delinquent accounts rose to 2.35 percent in the fourth quarter from 2.29 percent in the July-September period.
James Chessen, chief economist at the trade group, said consumers took on slightly more debt due partly to "a good job market, confidence in the economy and a rise in the stock market." Delinquencies tend to rise as debt burdens increase, he said.
A Federal Reserve study earlier this month showed consumer borrowing rose in January at the fastest pace in three years. Borrowing rose by $14.7 billion, to $1.316 trillion, after rising a revised $3.1 billion in December, initially reported as an increase of $7.3 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Fails to Join In as Nasdaq Rises From Tuesday Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Technology stocks caught fire in the last 90 minutes of trading yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to a 1.83 percent gain, a recovery of more than half of what it lost in the broad market selloff Tuesday.
The late rally did little, however, for blue-chip stocks as the Dow Jones industrial average, dragged down by American Express and oil issues, slipped 4.99 points, to 9,666.84, receding further from the 10,000 mark it flirted with last week. 
 The Nasdaq rose 42.44 points, to 2,365.28. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 6.45 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,268.59.
The session began ominously, with markets in Tokyo and Hong Kong skidding about 3 percent overnight and tension building from NATO's decision to begin bombing Kosovo.
But instead of turning to renewed selling, the market steadied. One contributor, analysts said, was Abby Joseph Cohen, the influential Goldman, Sachs strategist, who predicted the Dow would rise to 10,300 by the end of the year, up from her previous prediction of 9,850.
"We expect 1999 and 2000 to be years of ongoing profit expansion, with better aggregate gains than 1998, which was disappointing," she said in a report to clients.
Another factor may have been bullish words from Merrill Lynch & Company about I.B.M., which also announced a $3 billion order for computer parts from EMC. I.B.M., the Dow's biggest gainer, rose 4 1/8, to 169 1/2. EMC jumped 5, to 118 7/8.
A Government report of the biggest decline in more than seven years for big-ticket manufactured goods also seemed to help settle the stock market. A slowing economy implies lower interest rates.
The market mostly marked time until President Clinton announced the beginning of the bombing, apparently dispelling some of the uncertainty that Wall Street detests.
"We got a surge of buying in high-tech stocks," said Anthony O'Bryan, a market analyst at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "Perhaps that's signaling that the worst of the correction is over." Sometimes the most auspicious market turns, he added, are those touched off by no particular news, but only a sense that the pendulum has swung too far.
Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Overland Park, Kan., said a sound high-technology sector was essential if the market is to resume its advance. "It's tough for the stock market to make a lot of progress with tech bumping along," he said.
Technology issues, along with blue chips, paced the market's long rise into record territory but have succumbed of late to evidence of slackened growth and fears of overvaluation, especially compared with lesser stocks, which have mostly lagged.
The Russell 2000 index of small companies, for example, has fallen 8.9 percent this year, compared with a 7.87 percent gain for the Nasdaq and a 5.29 percent gain for the Dow.
The latest Internet deal found no shortage of buyers. Miningco.com Inc., which supplies human guides for people trying to search the Web, saw its initial public stock offering, priced at 25, soar as high as 62 1/4 before closing at 47 1/2.
Among the high-technology gainers were Microsoft, up 4 11/16, to 171 1/4; Intel, up 4 11/16, to 119 1/4; Dell, up 2 13/16, to 38 1/2, and Cisco, up 4 1/8, to 104 7/16.
 
Prices of Treasuries Rise
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices rose yesterday as investors willingly bought $15 billion of two-year Treasury notes and snapped up the record $8 billion of debt sold on Tuesday by the AT&T Corporation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury rose 4/32, to 95 30/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged down to 5.53 percent from 5.54 percent on Tuesday. The yield on AT&T's $3 billion of 30-year bonds was 89 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher. The yield on current two-year Treasury notes was unchanged at 4.98 percent.
The two-year note sale yesterday garnered a yield of 4.995 percent, as expected. Investors bid for 2.2 times the amount of securities being auctioned. At the previous 10 two-year auctions, investors bid for 2.33 times the amount of notes auctioned.
Demand was strong enough to allay concerns that people would not want the securities after buying the jumbo issue from AT&T.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In Yugoslavia, Economy Is Already Limp

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
With the Yugoslav economy already battered and trade limited since international economic sanctions were first imposed in 1992, air strikes by the United States and its NATO allies against Serbia are unlikely to cause great economic harm.
Asked about the economic impact, Andrew Kenningham, an Eastern European economist at Merrill Lynch in London, said, "It's completely irrelevant." 
 Yugoslavia's total exports in 1998 rose to $3 billion, from $2.4 billion in 1997, and of that total, only $12.6 million went to the United States. The country imported $73.9 million worth of American goods last year, according to the Bureau of the Census.
Both numbers were up from 1997, when $10.4 million of Yugoslav goods -- about four-tenths of a percent -- were shipped to the United States, and Yugoslav imports from the United States totaled about $54 million. Yugoslav exports consisted primarily of manufactured goods, machinery and commodities.
NATO said that it began air strikes against Serbian military targets in Yugoslavia yesterday because Belgrade refused to sign a peace deal on Kosovo and halt Serbian violence against ethnic Albanians there.
Although the direct economic impact of the military actions will be limited, there could be a negative impact on relations between the United States and Russia or on Wall Street if the military action rattles investors, said Morris Goldstein, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Italy was Yugoslavia's largest trading partner in 1997; taking about 12 percent of its exports. Macedonia and Germany accounted for about 9 percent of exports, and Russia, a traditional Serbian ally, accounted for 7 percent. Yugoslavia's primary exports are fruits and vegetables, chemicals, iron, steel and textiles. Before economic sanctions were imposed, the United States sent aircraft, computers and other products there.
Yugoslavia's thinly traded currency, the dinar, fell slightly to 10.66 dinars to the dollar yesterday, down from 10.7 on Tuesday. That means that one dinar is worth a little more than 9 cents. It has lost more than half its value in the year since the Kosovo conflict began, moving from 4.85 to the dollar, or about 21 cents, to its current level.
As a result of a possible devaluation, the dinar had traded as high as about 11.15 during the past 12 months, said Jamie Coleman, managing foreign exchange analyst at Thomson Global Markets in Boston. Sanctions prevent trading of the dinar in the United States.
Yugoslavia's economy is among the victims of the civil war that broke out in 1991. It is now characterized by black market dealings, bartering and hyperinflation. The breakup, which left Yugoslavia with only two republics, Serbia and Montenegro, destroyed the country's industrial sector, cutting off Serbia's large manufacturing sectors from suppliers and outlets -- a situation that was worsened by international sanctions, imposed in June 1992 and lifted in January 1996. The United States imposed sanctions again in 1998.
Few American companies have a presence in Yugoslavia. Nike Inc. has manufactured a small amount of footwear-related equipment there, a spokesman said, adding that he would have to check on the present situation.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Politically Correct Mergers;
Europe's Deal Frenzy Tends to Stop at National Borders

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 23

 BODY:
It looks, some say, like a European replay of the 1980's on Wall Street: hostile takeovers, poison pills, white knights and an endless stream of high-priced investment bankers pitching new deals.
Certainly, Europe has never seen anything quite like it. LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton is trying to buy Gucci Group of Italy. Gucci is seeking refuge by teaming up with yet another French raider, Francois Pinault. 
 Meanwhile, Olivetti, an Italian computer and communications equipment maker, is making a hostile bid for Italy's biggest phone company. And France's largest banks are in a three-way takeover brawl that has amazed both the country's financial elite and the French Government.
For all the adventurism, though, something big is missing. Despite the talk of an integrating Europe driven to get together by its new single currency, very few deals so far involve cross-border transactions between European companies.
Instead, many of the mergers seem intended at keeping foreigners -- especially other Europeans -- at bay. Indeed, many such deals are explicitly promoted on nationalistic grounds.
When Banque Nationale de Paris announced a surprise bid to take over its two main rivals, its chairman noted that "there are three main banks in France and they should remain in French hands." In Italy, the head of Olivetti appealed to the same sentiments in justifying his $58 billion hostile bid for the national telephone company.
"You still have a tendency of viewing banks or industrial corporations as national treasures," said Herbert Aspbury, head of client management at Chase Manhattan in Europe. "This is probably the first step or a necessary consolidation process, but I don't think the second step of cross-border mergers will happen quickly."
Indeed, Europe's biggest cross-border deals have been with American companies. Daimler-Benz took over the Chrysler Corporation. Deutsche Bank is acquiring Bankers Trust. Koninklijke Ahold, a big Dutch supermarket company, bought Giant Food in the Washington-Baltimore area.
Within Europe itself, national deals have been the rule. Banque Nationale de Paris shocked the French establishment two weeks ago by launching a hostile takeover attempt against Banque Paribas and Societe Generale, just a month after those two announced their own plans to merge.
The French battle follows major bank mergers in Switzerland, Spain and Germany. Indeed, Switzerland's two largest banks, UBS and the Swiss Bank Corporation, set the pace a year ago by forming the world's biggest bank.
The pattern has continued. Just last Sunday, Italy's four biggest banks announced plans for two takeovers worth about $26 billion in all.
Nationalism prevails as well in fields like car manufacturing. France has made it clear it would almost certainly block any attempt to buy Renault, in which it still owns 44 percent of the shares. But it is willing to allow Renault to buy a 35 percent share of Japan's Nissan Motor. Fiat of Italy is out of reach, because the Agnelli family retains firm control through a convoluted network of affiliated companies.
Mergers have run aground even in the defense industry, where European governments badly want their national aerospace companies to unite in a single powerful enterprise. Those plans have been derailed by deep disagreements among British, French and German companies.
The exceptions seem to prove the rule, too. In what would be one of Europe's biggest cross-border deals, Hoechst of Germany and Rhone-Poulenc of France announced plans in December to merge their pharmaceutical businesses. But that deal is on shaky ground, in part because the two companies worked so hard to be politically correct.
Not only did Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc agree to pool their shares in a "merger of equals," they also agreed to build a new headquarters in Strasbourg, as close to the border between France and Germany as it is possible to get.
That was all well and good. The problem was that most experts believe Hoechst is worth more than Rhone-Poulenc. That generated complaints from Hoechst's biggest shareholder, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, which is worried about being short-changed and has still not given its approval.
To be sure, the merger frenzy does signal a revolution in European business practices. The clubby corporate networks, in which banks and conglomerates hold each other's stocks, are breaking down. Companies that once relied on their local bank to raise money are now turning to global stock and bond markets. As a result, European executives are more exposed to unwanted takeovers if their companies' shares sink.
But the upshot is a jarring blend of new-age buccaneering and more old-fashioned national protectionism.
The tension between these impulses is particularly vivid in European banking, which has always been a politically sensitive industry.
The most recent such evidence came this weekend, when four of Italy's biggest banks announced two separate mergers. Unicredito Italiano, itself the product of a smaller merger two years ago, said it would acquire Banca Commerciale Italiana for $16 billion in stock. San Paulo-IMI, Italy's biggest banking group, said it would buy Banca di Roma for $9.7 billion in stock.
But the biggest brawl is here in Paris, where bankers and political leaders had become increasingly alarmed by the merger mania under way from Switzerland to Spain.
At a black-tie dinner hosted by France's top bank executives last December, France's Finance Minister warned the bankers they were in danger of being left behind.
"Too often in the past, infighting in France has prevailed against preparation for the future," said Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the Finance Minister. "Today, the following question is posed: How do you -- how do we -- wish to manage these indispensable reforms?"
The message was clear: the banks had to pull together or risk being brushed aside. Indeed, the three biggest had already been sounding each other out for more than a year. Michel Pebereau, the chairman of Banque Nationale de Paris, known universally by its initials B.N.P., had fruitlessly courted Societe Generale. Banque Paribas, which focuses on investment and corporate banking, had repeatedly insisted that it did not want to merge with an ordinary commercial bank.
"In France, we were very late in restructuring our banking industry," said Laurent Treca, a board member of B.N.P. "Many of the things taking place here had already occurred elsewhere in Europe -- in Italy, in Spain, in Belgium. But in France, there were no major moves on French banks."
Meanwhile, the Government was desperately trying to privatize the deeply troubled state-owned bank, Credit Lyonnais. Having bailed out the Government-owned bank from billions of francs worth of bad loans in everything from French real estate to a Hollywood studio, officials were (and still are) trying to sell off the sanitized institution and its new management.
But the French Government made it clear it did not want its big banks in foreign hands. Bidding rules for Credit Lyonnais blocked any institution from acquiring more than 10 percent, and industry executives argue that French regulators would have simply blocked foreigners from taking over one of the three big healthy banks.
Foreign rivals were certainly interested. Rolf-Ernst Breuer, chairman of Deutsche Bank in Frankfort repeatedly told analysts and investors that he wanted to form an alliance with a French bank. He even proposed buying a significant stake in Credit Lyonnais.
Though French regulators never explicitly blocked Deutsche Bank, Mr. Breuer concluded that he could never make an acceptable deal. Last month, he announced that Deutsche Bank would simply build its own skeleton structure of 10 bank branches in France.
But French banks were also under pressure from one of France's most influential financial figures, Claude Bebear, chairman of the French insurance conglomerate AXA. AXA holds about 6 percent of B.N.P.'s shares and 7 percent of Paribas's. AXA executives sit on both boards.
Mr. Bebear, who had built AXA into a global giant by acquiring companies as varied as the Equitable Group in the United States and Union Assurances de Paris, had been chafing for a merger for a long time.
"What he thinks is that French banks are too small and not profitable enough," said Christophe Dufraux, a spokesman for AXA. "If French banks want to be among the top players -- the way we did it in insurance -- they needed to change."
Industry experts say Mr. Bebear shook things up last October, when he publicly criticized Banque Paribas for failing to convince investors of the wisdom of its strategy. Though the comments were measured, French banking executives immediately interpreted them as a wake-up call for Paribas.
Andre Levy-Lang, chairman of Paribas, continued to insist throughout last fall that he still did not want to merge with a retail bank. But he apparently changed his views in private, and opened up talks with Societe Generale.
When Paribas and Societe Generale announced their plan in early February for a $16 billion merger, French Government officials were ecstatic. Mr. Strauss-Kahn called the merger "a direct response" to his wishes and said it would lead to "a strong and dynamic French financial sector."
Mr. Pebereau said very little, but hired Goldman, Sachs & Company as his investment banker to map out a response. He got some help from investors, who disliked the proposed merger and pushed down the value of both Paribas and Societe Generale in the stock market.
On March 9, B.N.P. announced an unsolicited tender offer for all the stock in both of its rivals. Mr. Pebereau, whose move stunned Government officials, was also quick to wave the French tricolor.
"Our country is capable of dominating this sector on a global scale," he said. "Through this alliance, we do not risk losing personality and culture."
 Mr. Bebear of AXA publicly sided with Banque Nationale de Paris last week. But analysts say it is far from clear that B.N.P. will prevail. The offer must still clear several hurdles with French regulators, and the target banks may well fire back with a higher offer of their own.
Regardless of who wins, the deeper question is whether France and indeed other European countries become more open to cross-border mergers.
Mr. Breuer, of Deutsche Bank, politely announced in Frankfurt last week that he would stay out of the fight unless he was invited in.
"What is happening in front of our eyes in France right now is very French," he said at a news conference to discuss his own company's results last week. "The nature of the process does not allow a foreign bank to get involved."

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
New York blazes a trail on how to handle local-phone access.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
THIS is a story of triumph by a government regulator, a triumph so unusual that every side praises the agency -- the New York State Public Service Commission -- and points to its procedures as an enviable model for states nationwide.
The Telecommunications Act of 1996 promised consumers the benefit of competition. Subject to rules that would be written by the Federal Communications Commission and negotiations with state regulators, the legislation would require local Bell companies to rent their wires, switches and phone services to competitors like AT&T, MCI Worldcom and Sprint so that they could enter the market for local service. In return, the Bell companies would be permitted to offer long-distance service. The F.C.C. issued rules, but many were set aside by the courts, leaving the states to negotiate in a legal vacuum. 
 In New York, negotiations bogged down as Bell Atlantic declared its systems ready to accommodate competition and rivals disagreed. But in the last 18 months, the commission has broken the logjam. It has won praise for putting politics on hold, overseeing a technically sophisticated staff and, most novel, sending squabbling lawyers to the sideline while the engineers and other technicians took over the task of solving problems.
The commission's basic challenge was to set rules by which customers could switch their local service from Bell Atlantic to, say, AT&T purely by having AT&T's computers talk to Bell Atlantic's. The goal was to cut as many people as possible out of the process to reduce mistakes and eliminate opportunities for Bell Atlantic to sabotage efforts by competitors to lure away customers.
The first key decision the commission took was to set up a "collaborative" process in the fall of 1997 for resolving technical disputes. Technicians from all sides were called to testify before administrative law judges. The lawyers were pushed aside. The process worked because technicians, confronted by claims that their systems did not work, wrote better software rather than engage in legal histrionics.
Next, the commission struck a clever deal in April with Bell Atlantic that guaranteed the company would relinquish its choke hold over local service no matter how the Supreme Court settled challenges to the Telecommunications Act. The commission in turn agreed to support Bell Atlantic's Federal application to enter long-distance service if Bell Atlantic could meet its commitments, including passing a test of its support systems. The test would be designed and evaluated by a third party, KPMG.
Under the test, Bell Atlantic's computer systems had to perform hundreds of tasks involved in switching customers to another phone company. For example, competitors would need to tap Bell Atlantic records to find out what services a customer used. Until the test began, Bell Atlantic contended that its software was up to the task. But now, seven months into a test that was supposed to take only about six weeks, Bell Atlantic's systems have failed more than 40 times. The problem, Stephen Minnig, a senior manager at KPMG said, "reflects the complexity of the task -- a complexity that no one anticipated."
Besides identifying glitches, the test has also "eliminated the finger-pointing, basing decisions on evidence and not paper debates," said Harry Davidow of AT&T. Mr. Davidow, chief regulatory counsel for AT&T in New York, said the test also turned Bell Atlantic's incentives upside down. "It no longer made sense for them to try to win by papering over their system deficiencies in reports to the commission. Now their only recourse was to fix their systems to the satisfaction of KPMG."
Despite spending $15 million so far on the test, Bell Atlantic has not yet fixed dozens of glitches KPMG identified. Some rivals worry that the commission will declare victory for Bell Atlantic before every one is resolved or before Bell Atlantic has satisfied other conditions set out in the Telecommunications Act that are not included in the KPMG test.
Though Bell Atlantic and its competitors remain deeply suspicious of each other, none has criticized the commission. MCI Worldcom cited the commission's record as one reason it has announced plans for aggressive marketing of local phone service in the state. And Mr. Minnig said KPMG had been under "no pressure except to do the test right." John Rubino of the commission staff dismisses fears that the agency will change course, vowing that the KPMG test will not be over until all the glitches are "appropriately resolved."
If so, Bell Atlantic will pass the test not because it pressured the commission, its staff or KPMG, but because it will have painstakingly repaired every glitch. That may not happen this month or next. But approval will almost certainly come soon, making Bell Atlantic the first Bell company into the long-distance market.
Paul Crotty, regional president of Bell Atlantic, said that the "end result will be customers who know that there has been an exhaustive process that will lead to a bulletproof conclusion that the market is irreversibly open to competition."
Regulators are not used to such praise from those they regulate. No wonder regulators in Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Texas are rushing to adopt the New York model.

HEADLINE: Disney's Studio Chief Says Competitors May Quit Animation Business

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Peter Schneider, president of Walt Disney Studios, said yesterday that he expected some movie studios that had recently entered the field of animation to leave it within the next few years because of rising costs.
Disney has had to increase the fees its pays animators as rival studios like Dreamworks SKG and Time Warner Inc.'s Warner Brothers ramp up their production of animated films and compete for the same talent pool, Mr. Schneider said at the Variety/Schroders Big Picture Media Conference in New York. 
 "Lots of studios came into the business over the last five years because they thought it was very profitable," he said. "We'll see people go out of the business in the next two to three years as the economics no longer justify it."
Disney, though, has been able to make its animated films profitable because of the numerous revenue streams it is able to generate by putting its movies on video, television and other outlets, he said.
Disney, like several other studios, has cut back on the number of movies it releases each year to reduce production and marketing costs.
The cutbacks have led to some speculation that theater owners, many of whom are building new theaters with 20 or more screens, could face a shortage of movies to fill those screens.
Still, the cutbacks are essential to improving the financial health of individual films and can work to the benefit of theaters, said Tom Rothman, president of the News Corporation's 20th Century Fox film production division.
"There are too many movies on any one weekend for the movies to get a chance," he said. "It's become a turnstile business. It's getting harder and harder for distinctive movies to take time to build an audience."
Studios have been distributing more of their films in "wide" releases, opening them on 2,000 to 3,000 screens at once. That means films generate a large part of their sales in the early weeks of the run and decline quickly as they remain in theaters. That hurts theater owners who get a larger split of the revenue when a film plays a long run.
Cutting back on the number of movies that studios release should help theater owners keep individual films on their screens longer, Mr. Rothman said.
Animators who create two-dimensional characters like those in the shows "South Park" and "Rugrats" routinely use computer graphics to replicate the hundreds of frames needed to make a character move. In animated films like "Antz" from Dreamworks SKG, the three-dimensional quality is added through the costly, time-consuming process of adding realistic lighting and backgrounds by computer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Revlon Shares Soaring On Takeover Speculation
Shares of Revlon surged $5.1875, or 30.4 percent, to $22.25, on speculation that a buyer may soon step in and rescue the cosmetics giant from its huge debt and weak performance lately in the powder and perfume business.
Revlon stock has risen 54 percent over the last two days on heavy volume. Investors are reacting to growing speculation that Revlon and the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, who controls 83 percent of its shares, may be near a deal to sell the struggling company, which makes Revlon, Colorstay and Almay cosmetics, to a larger consumer-products concern. The two names mentioned most often by bankers and analysts as potential buyers are Unilever of the Netherlands and Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati. Market Place. Page C12.
 
F.A.A. Grounds Kiwi International
A day after Kiwi International Airlines thought it had won a reprieve from a Government-imposed death sentence, the Federal Aviation Administration grounded the carrier, saying that it was unsafe to fly. B1. 

In Yugoslavia, a Shattered Economy
With the Yugoslav economy in tatters and trade limited since international economic sanctions were imposed in 1992, little more economic harm is expected from air strikes by the United States and its NATO allies. C4.
 
Orders for Durable Goods Decline
Factory orders for big-ticket goods posted the largest decline in more than seven years in February, a sign that an expected recovery in manufacturing could be a few months away, the Commerce Department said. C5.
 
More I.M.F. Aid Seen for Indonesia
The International Monetary Fund is likely to approve more financial aid to Indonesia at a board meeting in Washington today, a senior official said in Hong Kong. C4.
 
British Phone Venture May Be Sold
Cable and Wireless and the Mediaone Group want to sell One 2 One, a British mobile-phone venture worth $13.1 billion, an investment banker advising on the sale said. Options could also include an initial public offering. C12.
 
In Pact, OPEC Mixes Oil and Politics
After a decade of internecine fighting over which country should produce how much oil, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached a production-cutting accord that was underpinned by the strength of new political alliances. News Analysis. C4.
 
Technology Rally Lifts Nasdaq
Technology stocks caught fire in the last 90 minutes of trading, lifting the Nasdaq composite index 42.44 points, or 1.83 percent, to 2,365.28. The late rally did little, however, for blue-chip stocks as the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.99 points, to 9,666.84, receding further from the 10,000 mark it flirted with last week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 6.45 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,268.59. In the bond market, the yield on the 30-year Treasury fell to 5.53 percent, from 5.54 percent. C11.
 
Ameritech Buys 20% of Bell Canada
Ameritech, the phone company set to be acquired by SBC Communications, said that it would buy a 20 percent stake in Canada's leading carrier, Bell Canada, for $3.4 billion to take advantage of deregulation. Bell Canada plans to use the proceeds to invest in electronic commerce, satellite services and other fast-growing businesses. C23.
 
Expansion in Interactive Marketing
Three giant advertising agency companies -- the Interpublic Group, Grey Advertising and Leo Burnett -- are expanding operations in interactive marketing and media services. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.

Procedures used by the New York State Public Service Commission to open the local phone market to competition have won praise and could become a model for other states. Michael M. Weinstein: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: House Passes Disaster Bill Despite Threat Of a Veto

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of a veto threat by President Clinton, members of the House tonight approved a $1.3 billion emergency spending bill that included nearly $1 billion in relief to Central American countries ravaged by a hurricane and scaled back an array of Government programs to pay for the expenditures.
The final minutes of the vote, during which several Republicans who had voted against the bill changed their positions to insure its passage by a narrow margin, underscored the slightness of the Republican advantage in the House and the difficulty that party leaders may face in passing legislation. 
 The final tally was 220 to 211. Only 10 Democrats joined Republicans to support the bill, while only 11 Republicans joined Democrats to oppose it. On Tuesday, the Senate approved a disaster bill that has also drawn White House opposition.
The hours of debate over the House bill, the first spending measure taken up by the House this year, foreshadowed what are certain to be even more bitter disputes when the House turns its full attention toward the budget for the next fiscal year.
Democrats criticized the cuts in the bill as unnecessary and dangerous -- particularly a $648 million reduction in "callable capital," or money set aside to guarantee loans by international development banks, and a $150 million decrease in money for the disposal of weapons-grade uranium and plutonium in Russia.
Republicans countered that finding trims was the only way to pay for the emergency spending while keeping lawmakers' fingers out of the Federal surplus and staying within budget caps mandated by Congress in 1997.
"If anyone thinks they have heartburn over this small number of offsets, just wait until we bring the fiscal year 2000 budget to the floor," Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the Republican chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said near the start of what turned into a six-hour debate.
The reduction in callable capital in particular drew protest from the Clinton Administration. In a letter to Mr. Young made public today, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the measure "could have negative consequences beyond the current budgetary horizon for the developing world and our economy" and would probably insure a Presidential veto.
On Tuesday night, the Senate overwhelmingly passed a similar emergency spending bill that authorized $500 million more than the House bill called for. The two bills, which concern supplemental spending for the current fiscal year, will now proceed to conference, where lawmakers will try to iron out differences between them.
But the President might veto the result. Administration officials object to several provisions in the bills, including cuts in money to beef up security around American embassies and to dispose of uranium and plutonium in Russia.
House Democrats expressed particular alarm about the latter proposal, saying it jeopardized the security of the United States. Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the senior Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, called it "the most egregious and reckless of the recommendations," but an amendment Mr. Obey offered that nullified this and three other cuts in the Republican bill was defeated.
The wrangling over the bill and the final vote made clear the many factions dividing Congress. Several conservative Republicans, for example, called for even more spending reductions because the cuts proposed by the bill fell about $200 million short of its expenditures.
Republicans contended that even though emergency spending did not require concordant cuts, a failure to offset expenditures would affect the budget surplus, which they said needed to be saved for Social Security.
Democrats countered that Republicans were posturing, because the cuts their bill proposed, which essentially affected money that had been pledged but not spent, would do nothing to protect anything.
In addition to $956 million in hurricane relief, the House bill includes $100 million in economic and military assistance to Jordan and nearly $106 million to support loan guarantees to farmers. Several Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, rose to complain that the aid to farmers was too little, too late.
The House bill did not include one item that senators added to their version, a provision that would allocate $40 million to families of the 20 people killed in Italy last year when a Marine jet sliced the cable of a ski gondola.
When the time for voting on the House bill had initially expired, it did not have enough votes to pass. The time was then extended, and in the next few hectic minutes, enough lawmakers voted or changed their votes to tilt the tally.

HEADLINE: Protests in Police Killing of Diallo Grow Larger, and More Diverse

BYLINE: By KATHERINE E. FINKELSTEIN 

 BODY:
The last time Sidney Socolar, 75, a retired biophysics professor, got himself arrested was in the mid-1980's, when he sat outside Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's office to protest America's involvement in El Salvador's civil war.
But yesterday, he stood with his 82-year-old wife in a crush of demonstrators outside 1 Police Plaza, awaiting the handcuffs. "I am enraged about our Mayor's attitude toward civil liberties," he said. 
 Blocking the door was a group of 17 elderly white women, including Carolyn Goodman, 83, whose son, Andrew, a civil rights worker, was murdered in Mississippi in 1964. Ms. Goodman was escorted into Police Headquarters to be handcuffed.
She was part of the largest and most diverse group to be arrested in the 12 days of protests against the police shooting of Amadou Diallo. Among the 212 people taken into custody yesterday were 126 members of Jews for Racial and Economic Justice, including several rabbis, and representatives of three labor unions.
So many people were arrested that the police had to book the protesters in station houses in three different precincts in Manhattan.
The protesters had to wait behind police barricades and be shepherded inside, 30 at a time. Police officers told them through megaphones that they would be arrested.
The crowd chanted, sang psalms in Hebrew and held up signs that read "Stop the Death Squads" and "Arrest Giuliani." Before being led inside, Mr. Socolar described the day as a "welcome resumption" of the unity between blacks and Jews.
The Rev. Al Sharpton, whose political advocacy group National Action Network has been organizing the daily protests since March 9, proudly noted the diversity of the rally as he stood in the midst of supporters. "It robs the Mayor of his argument that we're being divisive," he said. "We've got a lot more diversity here than the Police Department has."
He renewed his call for the arrest of the four police officers from the Street Crime Unit who killed Mr. Diallo, an immigrant from Guinea, on Feb. 4. Mr. Diallo was unarmed. A grand jury in the Bronx finished hearing testimony in the case yesterday.
Another demonstrator, Dennis Rivera, the president of Local 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, which has 150,000 members, said that he came to protest the fact that the Police Department does not reflect the city's racial mix.
When asked whether he agreed with Public Advocate Mark Green that Police Commissioner Howard Safir should resign, Mr. Rivera said, "I think he demonstrated an awesome lack of sensitivity, and most likely we need a change of leadership."
He was arrested along with several other labor leaders, including Lee Saunders, the trustee in charge of District Council 37, an umbrella group representing 120,000 city workers; James H. Butler, the president of Local 420 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, and Charles Ensley, the president of Local 371, which represents 15,000 social workers.
During the protest, Mr. Safir was in the auditorium at 1 Police Plaza conducting a ceremony to announce the promotion of 64 police officers.
Speaking about the need to communicate effectively and be courteous, even when making arrests, he said: "There's also nothing wrong occasionally saying, 'I am sorry for inconveniencing you.' That's a decent thing to do."
Yesterday's arrests brought the total to 574 for the daily rallies. Among those expected to be arrested today are the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, the former Queens Congressman who has been a supporter of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and the actress Susan Sarandon, organizers said.
Some members of the Police Department are planning to hold their own rally in front of the Manhattan Municipal Building today. Led by James Higgins, a police union official planning to run for its presidency in May, the demonstration is to begin at the Municipal Building around 11 A.M., with participants then marching to 1 Police Plaza.
In a flier posted around Police Headquarters, Mr. Higgins said that a rally was necessary because "a number of political opportunists have surfaced to prejudge and crucify cops, all cops."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. Expected to Offer More Aid to Indonesia

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 24

 BODY:
A senior official of the International Monetary Fund said here today that he expected the fund to approve more financial aid to Indonesia in a board meeting in Washington on Thursday.
Hubert Neiss, the fund's Asia Pacific director, said, "the I.M.F. will propose that the existing commitments be increased." He said such an increase required the board's approval, but added, "I would expect that the board will agree." 
 Indonesia's chief economics official, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, had asked for an extra $1 billion in aid in a meeting last month with the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus.
Mr. Neiss would not say how large the increase would be. But last year, the fund approved an additional $1 billion in aid to Indonesia, raising its total commitment to $11.2 billion. All told, Jakarta is receiving a $43 billion rescue package from the fund and other international aid groups.
The fund has already disbursed $8.8 billion, and analysts said the Indonesian Government was worried that unless the I.M.F. agreed to pledge more, the country might have trouble soliciting aid from other sources.
The fund's move to release more aid is both an acknowledgment of the steps Indonesia has taken to overhaul its shattered economy and a sign of how far it still must go to join the ranks of the recovering in Asia.
Mr. Neiss said Indonesia needed the extra help because, unlike South Korea or Thailand, it was not yet attracting private capital. Analysts said foreign investors were generally steering clear of Indonesia as it made a trouble-prone transition from the Suharto era to a more democratic system.
Still, Mr. Neiss praised Indonesia for taking steps to clean up its ruined banking system. On March 13, the Government of President B. J. Habibie closed 38 banks, took over 7 and indicated it would bail out 9 others.
The move came after a sudden two-week postponement that had provoked new cries of cronyism from Government critics. The critics said that politically connected bankers had pressured Mr. Habibie to order the delay so that they could raise capital and save their banks from closure.
Mr. Neiss said that while he regretted the delay, "I prefer postponement to things going wrong." He added: "No bank owner in any country would like to have his bank closed. They will fight tooth and nail to keep it open."
Mr. Neiss made his remarks to reporters at an investment conference in Hong Kong sponsored by Credit Suisse First Boston. Earlier in the day, he sparred with a leading critic of the fund: Jeffrey D. Sachs, a Harvard economist, who has accused the fund of aggravating the Asian crisis.
Professor Sachs renewed those criticisms today, saying that the fund's insistence on high interest rates and stable currencies had deepened investor panic and capital flight in Thailand and South Korea.
Mr. Neiss replied that the fund's policies calmed South Korea when it was hit by a wave of capital outflows in late 1997. He also said the fund should not be blamed for the region's collapse. Rather, he said, the Governments did not respond quickly enough to the unfolding crisis.
In general, though, Mr. Neiss struck a mostly optimistic note. He predicted that most Asian economies would return to growth in the second half of 1999. "When we say the worst is over, we are simply stating the facts," he said. "The larger task of getting the recovery off the ground is still before us."
