HEADLINE: A 1911 Inferno With a Lesson for Today

BYLINE: By Kevin Baker; Kevin Baker is the author of the historical novel "Dreamland" and was chief researcher on "The American Century."

 BODY:
At first, passers-by thought they were seeing bundles of cloth being tossed into the street. It took them a few minutes to realize they were seeing women, their voluminous skirts billowing out as they leaped from eighth- and ninth-story windows, desperately trying to escape the fire behind them.
Within 18 minutes, 146 people, most of them young women and girls, lay dead or dying on the paving stones of Greene Street and Washington Place in Greenwich Village. It was the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire, one of the deadliest disasters in the history of the American workplace. 
 Thursday's commemoration of the 1911 fire was its second milestone of sorts in recent weeks. On Feb. 21, Bessie Cohen, nee Gabrilowich, the next-to-last survivor of the fire, passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 107.
She was a sturdy, independent woman who survived a mugging at age 89 and lived on her own until she was 93. Yet for years after the tragedy she buried her head in her arms and sobbed whenever there was a thunder or lightning storm.
Her reaction was understandable. The fire unfolded like a bad dream. The hoses inside the building didn't work, and the stairwell doors were locked. The fire department came, but its ladders were only six stories high, and the factory was on the eighth through 10th floors.
The building that housed the factory was actually fireproof. Nearly everything inside it was flammable, though. The stair doors had been locked because the factory owners feared their employees would steal bits of leftover cloth.
The fire rallied support for better, safer working conditions, and it reinvigorated the union movement. Every March 25 since, the garment unions have honored the Triangle dead and the living with a rally on Washington Place.
For many years, leading politicians would attend, and the survivors would sit on the dais -- aging women, most of them Jewish or Italian, dressed in black. At the site, bolted to what is now called the Brown Building, is a plaque proclaiming that the sacrifice of the dead made American working conditions the finest in the world.
That's a questionable assumption today. The improvements that have been made in wages and working conditions tempt us to think of the Triangle fire as something out of the distant past.
In fact, the state Labor Department has estimated that there are 2,500 illegal sweatshops operating within New York City alone. Only 37 percent of the shops employing New York's 90,000 garment workers meet Federal requirements on wages and hours, a Federal Labor Department official told me, and the rate of compliance is comparably poor in other major cities. The modern sweatshops are filled with new immigrants, some of them children, working for sub-minimum wages under conditions that invite another catastrophe.
To combat these abuses, New York State's Apparel Industry Task Force has a staff of only 35. The United States Labor Department has only 950 investigators monitoring some 6.5 million work sites, and a budget of only $120 million to police wage violations -- about $1 per worker.
Yet both state and Federal officials point out that bigger budgets and more inspectors will do only so much. Sweatshop owners have become adept at simply closing their doors and moving across town or across the country. There, they can easily set up shop again under the name of a partner or relative -- and with a new supply of easily exploitable immigrant labor.
As a result, labor regulators have focused their recent efforts on exposing illegally made goods -- that is, getting consumers to recognize and refuse to buy them. Just how viable a strategy that is in an economy where goods come to market from all over the world, under all sorts of labels, is anybody's guess.
Yet anyone who thinks we should just throw up our hands should have been at Thursday's Triangle fire commemoration. Only the faces have changed. The older Jewish and Italian women are gone now, but Washington Place is filled with a whole new generation of Asian and Hispanic Americans, still trying to build a better life.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nestle Earnings Rise 2.6%, Beating Analysts' Forecasts

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: VEVEY, Switzerland, March 26

 BODY:
Nestle S.A., the world's No. 1 foods maker, reported today that its profit rose 2.6 percent in 1998, beating most forecasts, as demand for products from Perrier mineral water to Alcon contact lens solution in the United States and Western Europe outweighed slumping income in Asia and Russia.
Profit rose to 4.29 billion Swiss francs ($2.92 billion), or 109.2 francs a diluted share, from a restated 4.18 billion francs, or 106.3 francs a share, in 1997. Earnings before interest and tax edged up to 7.1 billion francs from 7.06 billion francs. 
 Analysts scaled back their profit forecasts to a range of 3.78 billion francs to 4.20 billion francs after Nestle warned in November that the fall of the Russian ruble and high interest rates in Latin America would depress growth. Today's figures show Nestle was overcautious when it warned that full-year earnings would rise less than sales, which advanced 2.5 percent to 71.7 billion francs ($48.45 billion).
"It's encouraging to see the earnings progress in Europe, which includes Russia and Eastern Europe," said Pierre Tissot, an analyst at Lombard Odier. "Still, they remain exposed to emerging markets, so it's best to be cautious."
Nestle said it planned to raise its dividend 9 percent, to 38 francs from 35 francs, and its shares rose 35 francs, or 1.3 percent, to 2,705 in Zurich.
For 1999, the company, which is based in Vevey, said that "barring events of exceptional gravity" like wild swings in exchange rates, it expected higher sales and earnings.
Nestle restated 1997 and 1998 financial results to reflect a change in the way it calculates depreciation. Second-half profit was not provided and could not be calculated because restated figures for the first half were not made available.
So far this year, "North America is doing fine and Southeast Asia is in the early stages of recovery," Nestle's chief financial officer, Mario Corti, said. "The only area where the situation remains quite grim is Eastern Europe."
"Pharmaceuticals is an area where they're making a lot of progress," said John Keele, an analyst at Paribas who said he expected to maintain his "hold" rating on the stock. "Confectionery remains a problem," he added.
Nestle, whose candy brands include Cailler and Smarties, said operating income from sweets fell 7.4 percent as exports to Russia dried up and the operating margin slipped to 9.3 percent from 9.9 percent. That measure of profitability also fell for Nestle's drinks business, its main source of profit, dropping to 16.3 percent from 16.9 percent.
"We aren't satisfied with the returns we are generating in confectionery," Mr. Corti said. "We're focusing on increasing our sales and getting our costs down." But it will take at least a year to see results from those efforts, he said.

HEADLINE: Little Chance Seen That Fed Will Lift Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged when its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday, but the central bank remains wary of resurgent inflation because of the economy's continued strength, analysts say.
With overall price increases negligible and growth appearing to slow a bit from the blistering pace at the end of 1998, the Fed has no rationale for an immediate rate increase, economists say. 
 But the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee, meeting for the second time this year, may move toward adopting a policy bias favoring higher rates -- a tilt that would put financial markets on warning that a rate increase might be in the cards in coming months. Still, analysts put the chances of the Fed adopting a tightening bias next week at well under 50 percent.
"The Fed is absolutely on hold," Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Bank of America, said.
"While the economy is strong and the unemployment rate very low, inflation remains low and increases in wages have actually diminished," Mr. Levy said. "Then there are the international considerations."
The global financial crisis that prompted the Fed to cut rates three times in quarter-point increments last fall has eased considerably. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in Congressional testimony last month that the improved situation in the markets could eventually justify taking back some portion of those rate reductions.
But Brazil's stabilization is tenuous, and Fed officials are not convinced that Japan's economic slide has bottomed out. So the Fed, analysts say, remains wary about the effects on the rest of the world of a rate increase in the United States.
To some degree, it is the economic weakness in much of the rest of the world that is keeping the United States from overheating. The monthly trade deficit hit a record of nearly $17 billion in January, meaning that a growing volume of imports and declining exports are taking some of the pressure off domestic producers.
The hit from trade appears to be enough to slow the overall rate of growth in the economy, analysts said. Moreover, higher interest rates over the last month are beginning to slow the main engine of the expansion these days -- consumer spending -- in part by cooling what had been a red-hot housing market.
"There has to be some concern about the pace of domestic spending," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "Yet it's quite plausible that market forces themselves will bring about some kind of tempering without any active role from the Fed."
There is still a debate within the Fed over the reasons behind the unusual combination of robust growth and stable prices. On one side are those who say the economy is simply benefiting from a confluence of temporary factors that are holding down inflation for now. On the other is a faction that thinks something fundamental has changed to allow higher rates of noninflationary growth than traditional models would suggest.
Those who see the current combination of strong growth and dormant inflation as temporary point to the recent rise in oil prices as evidence that what had been an unbroken string of good news for the economy will not last forever.
But a growing number of Fed officials seem to have fallen in line with Mr. Greenspan in giving serious consideration to the idea that huge investments in technology over the last decade may have helped to tame inflation by improving productivity, or output per worker.
The economy expanded at a 6.1 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of last year, matching the fastest quarterly pace of the 1990's. While it appears to have slowed somewhat in the first few months of this year, the economy is still growing at a pace that in the past would have been expected to generate higher inflation, economists said, especially with unemployment at just 4.4 percent.
Last spring, faced with a similar situation, the Fed decided to move to a tightening bias in late March. It retained that bias until August, when Russia's debt default rocked global financial markets.
This year, though, Fed officials seem more comfortable with allowing the economy some leeway, especially since there is virtually no inflation. The Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the last three months and just 1.6 percent over the last year. Although oil prices are spiking up after a sharp drop, prices in other areas are likely to remain stable. And wages, although rising, are not gaining ground fast enough to be a serious inflationary threat, largely because productivity has been growing at a faster pace, too.
Indeed, in a recent speech, Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and one of the Fed's chief inflation hawks, appeared more open to the idea that the economy could grow faster without generating more inflation.
"While it's too soon to say for sure whether the productivity surge is temporary or permanent, two pieces of evidence do seem to point to a fundamental shift in productivity," Mr. Parry said.
First, he said, the phenomenal pace of consumer spending -- it grew 5.25 percent in 1998 -- appears to reflect an assumption among individuals, based on what they see happening at their own jobs, that their incomes will continue growing.
The second piece of evidence, Mr. Parry said, is the collective judgment of the stock market, which seems to think that companies can continue generating strong profit gains.
David Orr, chief economist at First Union Capital Markets, observed that at least half a dozen Fed governors and bank presidents have made statements in recent weeks expressing confidence that inflation is contained.
"More than I can remember in the past," Mr. Orr said, "they seem to be comfortable that if inflation is going to pick up it's not going to be sudden or anything they're behind the curve on."

HEADLINE: Foie Gras and Chips, Anyone?;
Internet Shopping Is (Sort of) Catching On in Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy

 BODY:
Maria Paola Sassella is often amused by her customers, who are experimenting with what for Europeans is still an unfamiliar practice: shopping on the World Wide Web.
For the last year, her company, Vino Please, has been selling wines on line (www.vinoplease.it). Customers click on Chianti and Brunello wines to have them delivered anywhere in Italy, and to Germany and Japan -- or indeed any country where such sales are permitted. (The United States is not among them.) 
 "Some examine my products on the Internet, then fax the order in," Ms. Sassella said, with a mix of bemusement and desperation. Many do not pay with a credit card, but pay later by making a bank transfer. Moreover, she added, with a sigh of resignation, almost all her customers are men, who so far dominate Europe's corner of cyberspace.
While Americans have embraced on-line shopping, Europeans are just now warming to electronic commerce. From designing her Internet site and persuading diffident wine growers to supply products, Ms. Sassella has received an education in how difficult it is to convince Europeans, who have plenty of small shops and age-old shopping habits, that they should shop on the Web.
On-line shopping accounted for just $1.2 billion of Europe's $1.9 trillion in retail sales last year, compared with $8 billion in on-line sales and $2.6 trillion in total sales in the United States, according to Forrester Research, a market research firm based in Cambridge, Mass.
 Yet Ms. Sassella, who is based in Milan, and other European on-line entrepreneurs have reasons to be optimistic. Internet use is rising in Europe as its cost falls, thanks in large part to the deregulation of telecommunications. Governments, troubled by Europe's lag behind North America, are pushing for more Internet use in schools, and at work and home. And the introduction of the euro in 11 European countries is giving electronic commerce an additional boost because a single currency makes billing and price comparisons easier.
As a result, on-line stores are spreading like brush fire. More than 400 operate in Italy, compared with 13 just two years ago. In Germany, more than 1,200 on-line stores now sell books, and book sales per capita rival those in the United States.
"We always start late," Ms. Sassella said, "but then it takes off."
Germany, whose 80 million people make it the largest market in Europe, now has 8.4 million Internet users, 40 percent more than six months ago, according to GFK A.G., a market research firm in Nuremberg. In Italy, there are more than two million Internet users, 25 percent more than a year earlier.
American companies like I.B.M., Microsoft and Cisco Systems are actively promoting electronic commerce among their European customers. American on-line merchants are expanding into Europe, too. Last year, Amazon.com began operations in Britain and Germany, and Barnes & Noble linked up with Bertelsmann A.G., the German media giant.
"We expect big growth, and we expect it to be pervasive," said Jean-Luc Szymanski, who is responsible for electronic commerce at IBM France. Last year, IBM France sponsored a promotion called Surf and Buy to lure French merchants like the mail-order house Les Trois Suisses and Decathlon, a chain of sports megastores, on line.
Another area ripe for growth is in electronic commerce between companies. Walter Poloni, Microsoft's program manager for electronic commerce in Italy, said that the high density of midsize companies in Europe made them rich markets for the growth of business-to-business on-line commerce. In Italy, for instance, fewer than 1 percent of the country's 3.4 million companies employ more than 500 people.
"Many of these companies are getting started, but they are one or two years back with respect to the United States," Mr. Poloni said.
Two years ago, Andreina Mandelli, marketing professor and director of the Internet Observatory at the business school of Bocconi University in Milan, was advising a student who wanted to write a paper about business-to-business electronic commerce. The student could not find an example in Italy.
"Now," Professor Mandelli said, "every day you hear of another example." In the fall of 1997, she surveyed 300 of Italy's 2,000 largest corporations and found that 76 percent were connected to the Internet; by last fall, the figure had risen to 90 percent.
To be sure, Europe has a long way to go to catch up with the United States. Compounding the reluctance of many Europeans to try on-line shopping has been poor postal service in countries like Italy. (Private delivery services can be expensive.) In addition, taxes vary significantly from country to country, which makes shipping products like wines across borders a nightmare.
Many Europeans fear entrusting credit card information to computers. Indeed, European legislation has sought to protect personal data from computer networks, in contrast to the United States, where privacy control depends largely on industry self-regulation.
There may be social and cultural barriers as well. Europeans, accustomed to cities with vibrant downtown shopping areas, tend to view shopping as a social activity, said Sheila Moorcroft, author of "European Commerce on the Internet," a report issued by Phillips Tarifica Ltd., a British market research firm. Hence they "distinguish between shopping and buying," she said, while on-line purchases "are clearly in the latter category."
To overcome such resistance, many Internet retailers emphasize tradition. Antoine Cahen sells French-language books on the Internet (www.alapage.com). His strategy is to focus on books, records and videocassettes, and he has found a market outside France, where about half of alapage.com sales originate. "That's the problem of Amazon and Bertelsmann," he said. "I don't think they want to defend local cultures. We have a reason to exist."
Mr. Cahen started in the business 10 years ago, when he joined a French schoolbook publisher to sell books on the old Minitel on-line information system. In 1997, the business went on the Web. Last year, annual sales were $670,000, and they have soared so far this year, totaling $217,000 in January alone. Mr. Cahen, 36, who runs the business with 15 employees in Paris, says he expects more than $3 million in sales for the full year. "It's not a lot, it's only the beginning," he said.
Gouts de France, another French on-line retailer, has carved out a niche selling French food products whose manufacturers lacked the resources for promotional programs.
"Local craftsmen are too small to export," said Isabelle de Montille, 38, the daughter of a Burgundy wine maker, who considered several alternatives -- a food guide or television sales -- before settling on the Internet (www.goutsdefrance.com). Since starting last September, she sells about 70 products, like potted meats and traditional French spice blends, and averages two to three sales a day.
It is in part this mushrooming of on-line retailers that has prompted experts to predict strong Internet sales growth, though the forecasts vary wildly.
In October, Frost & Sullivan predicted that European on-line commerce -- business-to-business and retail -- would grow to more than $8 billion by 2004, from $35.8 million in 1997. Forrester expects the growth to be much more explosive. In a recent report, it predicted European Internet commerce would be worth $69 billion by 2001, equivalent to almost 1 percent of European economic output. Joe Sawyer, an author of the Forrester forecast, said that he could not explain the huge discrepancy, though he added that "people in the industry criticize us for being conservative."
Nothing has done as much to accelerate electronic commerce as recent drops in the cost of using the Internet. Italy and France have successfully put pressure on Internet service providers and phone companies to drop rates.
In Britain, free Internet access providers, which aim to make money from advertising and on-line commerce, are cropping up. In January, Toys "R" Us said it was starting free service to increase on-line sales. That followed the success of Freeserve, started in September by Dixons Group P.L.C., an appliance retailer, which has since signed more than one million subscribers. Similar ventures are afoot on the Continent.
In February, European antitrust officials took a step that could lead to lower Internet prices across Europe. They began an inquiry into whether Deutsche Telekom, one of the Continent's biggest Internet access providers, was abusing its influence to keep prices up. The inquiry followed a complaint by AOL Europe, a joint venture of America Online and Bertelsmann, the international publishing and media concern based in Gutersloh, Germany. A decision against Deutsche Telekom, which holds 56 percent of Germany's market for dial-up Internet customers, could set a European precedent for on-line service costs, which are as much as five times the cost in the United States.
Igor Schlumberger has changed his Internet habits since signing up with Cybercable, a new way of getting access to the Internet via cable and one that skirts the hefty phone fees charged by France Telecom.
"Before, an evening on the Web was more expensive than going to the movies," he said.
Mr. Schlumberger, 35, who works for a software designer in Paris, made his first on-line purchase, a book for a friend who had neither Internet access nor a good local bookstore, three months ago. Since then he has bought a washing machine for the same friend and a camera for his wife.
"The more time I spend on the Web" he said, "the more likely I am to buy something."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Heavy Selling ofCorporate Debt Saps Demand for Treasuries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, as Citigroup and other companies sold $3.8 billion of debt, sapping demand for Government securities.
"Corporations are stepping up issuance," said Marc Fovinci, who helps oversee $1.8 billion at Ferguson, Wellman, Rudd, Purdy & Van Winkle Inc. in Portland, Ore. "The money is going to flow there," he added, as investors seek the higher yields on corporate bonds. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32 , to 95 4/32 , lifting its yield to 5.59 percent from 5.58 percent on Thursday.
In contrast, short-maturity Treasury securities gained today as NATO air strikes in the Balkans encouraged some investors to seek the safety of American debt, cutting the yield on two-year notes by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.98 percent.
Investors bought notes today in "a small flight-to-quality," said Sal Greco, a strategist at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which manages $14 billion of Treasuries.
Citigroup led corporate sales with $1.5 billion of global bonds. The Imperial Tobacco Group P.L.C. sold $600 million of 10-year notes.
More than $3 billion in new corporate bonds is expected next week, following about $16 billion of corporate bonds sold this week.
"There are a lot of deals," said Andrew Brenner, a director at Fimat USA Inc. "That's bringing some weakness to Treasuries."
That is because investment banks often sell Treasuries when they underwrite corporate debt. The reason is to protect against losses in case interest rates rise before the sales are completed. They usually buy the Government securities back later.
The biggest issue this week was the AT&T Corporation's record $8 billion bond sale, but it was not alone. MCI Worldcom Inc., the Associates Corporation of North America, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are also among the borrowers that have sold multibillion-dollar debt issues in recent months. This comes at a time when the Treasury is selling less and less debt, as the booming economy produces budget surpluses.
With shrinking Treasury debt, yields have fallen, lowering borrowing costs and prompting corporations to sell securities in large- enough amounts to have the potential to take on benchmark status.
Washington-based Fannie Mae, the biggest buyer of home mortgages, is expected to sell some $130 billion of debt this year, making it second only to the Treasury in terms of borrowing, a Fannie Mae official said. It has already sold more than $60 billion of securities due from 3 to 10 years under its Benchmark Note program, started in January 1998.
With their top debt ratings, large issue size and frequency of borrowing, Fannie Mae and other Government-sponsored enterprises may have the makings for a good pricing benchmark. These issues include some with maturities no longer sold by the Government -- such as three- and seven-year notes.
As the pool of existing Treasury debt shrinks, borrowers may have no choice but to find other pricing benchmarks. Three decades ago, several corporations priced their long-term debt off AT&T's bonds because the Treasury was not selling such long-term debt on a regular basis.
Many investors and corporate executives say it will be a long time before Treasury yields are replaced as a global benchmark for interest rates. Treasuries are still the only place to turn to find a wide range of issues that are actively traded and sold on a regular basis.

HEADLINE: Republicans' Resolve in Rallying Around Budget Sets Up Tougher Tests

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Republican leaders in Congress took care of the easy part of this year's budget battle in passing their tax and spending plan on Thursday.
By managing to hold their fractious caucus together and dampen rivalries between the party's leaders in the House and Senate, Republicans were able to lay out a cohesive agenda built around a sweeping tax cut, fiscal austerity, a strong military and smaller Government. 
 Passage of the budget resolutions in the two chambers sets up a clean debate with Democrats and President Clinton. Republicans say the overriding priorities as the nation decides how to divide anticipated budget surpluses should be shoring up Social Security and returning as much money as possible to taxpayers, with more money carved out as well for the Pentagon and education.
Democrats agree that Social Security should top the list, but say the remainder of the projected windfall should be apportioned among Medicare, spending on a broad range of domestic programs and tax cuts for low- and middle-income people.
But the process of turning the Republican budget guideline into tax and spending legislation that can pass Congress and be signed into law by Mr. Clinton promises to be messy, contentious and slow. Making it even more difficult are the looming problems in Social Security and Medicare, which are casting a long shadow over the budget debate and seem increasingly unlikely to be resolved this year.
If there has been any clear message this year, it is the enduring power of Social Security to shape the policies and politics of both parties. Where the deficit once constrained Republican tax-cutting efforts and forced Democrats to limit their calls for new spending, the fear among both parties of being accused by the other of raiding Social Security money has created an unlikely but far-reaching consensus.
Both parties now agree that the bulk of the surplus, roughly $1.8 trillion out of $2.6 trillion over the next decade, should not be used for spending or tax cuts. Rather, they say, it should be used only to help Social Security, either indirectly by reducing the national debt, or directly by financing a Republican-backed plan to create private investment accounts within the retirement system.
That $1.8 trillion represents the portion of the surplus generated by Social Security payroll taxes in excess of what is needed to pay benefits over the next decade. Although successive Congresses and Administrations have dipped into the Social Security surplus for years to finance general Government operations, that pool of money has quickly become so sacrosanct that the two parties are arguing about who can do more to wall it off from the rest of the budget.
"The argument that we should not use Social Security taxes for anything else has turned out to be far more compelling than most folks anticipated," said Carol Cox Wait, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a fiscal watchdog group.
Because so much of the surplus is now agreed to be untouchable, the fight over what is left is that much more intense.
In many ways it will be a nuts and bolts legislative fight, with lawmakers of both parties trying to win money for what they consider pressing needs. To hold House Republicans together in the budget vote on Thursday, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert had to mollify the powerful chairman of the Transportation Committee, Representative Bud Shuster, Republican of Pennsylvania, by promising more money for airport expansions and improvements.
In the Senate, a bipartisan majority agreed at the last minute to increase financing for child care. In both chambers, legislators made pleas for more aid for hard-pressed farmers.
The willingness of Republicans to stand by their pledges of fiscal austerity will not be truly tested until this summer, when they vote on appropriations bills that will have to slash many domestic programs to remain within tight spending limits.
Then Republicans will face the challenge of negotiating with Mr. Clinton to get their tax and spending bills signed into law. The President has proved skillful in outmaneuvering Republicans in the budget endgame in recent years, not only achieving enough of his goals to claim victory but also leaving Republicans at one another's throats.
In a memorandum sent today to the Republican leadership, two influential conservatives, Stephen Moore of the Cato Institute and Lawrence Kudlow, a supply-side economist, said the party could face a meltdown if it mishandled the budget this year.
"The G.O.P. must at all costs avoid last year's fiscal collapse, when Congress agreed to enormous election-eve spending bills, and tax cuts were scuttled altogether," the memorandum said. "Repeating those mistakes later this year will so dispirit the conservative pro-growth wing of the G.O.P. that the party will risk losing everything in November of 2000: the House, the Senate and the White House."
Mr. Moore and Mr. Kudlow would not have been heartened by a statement made by Mr. Hastert today in an on-line chat with students. Asked what kind of tax cut Republicans would pursue with the $15 billion they anticipate will be available for that purpose next year, Mr. Hastert responded that he was not sure how much would be left once the spending bills were completed.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Russia Sign Uranium Sales Deal

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 26

 BODY:
Russia and the United States have quietly signed an agreement that salvages a $12 billion deal aimed at helping Russia convert uranium from its nuclear weapons into fuel for American nuclear reactors, Administration officials said today.
The program to convert highly enriched uranium into low-enrichment fuel is the key component of a three-part package and part of the Administration's effort to stop the spread of nuclear weapons, Administration officials said. The United States and Russia have already taken steps to safeguard Russia's nuclear-weapons material and contain damage from a nuclear accident should one occur. 
 The latest agreement was signed without publicity at a ceremony at the Department of Energy on Wednesday night, just hours after cruise missiles began hitting targets in Yugoslavia. Energy Secretary Bill Richardson and Yevgeny Adamov, Russia's Minister of Atomic Energy, toasted each other with champagne.
The accord was supposed to have been announced at the end of the planned visit by Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, but he aborted his visit en route to Washington on Tuesday after NATO authorized the attacks on Yugoslavia.
Secretary Richardson said today that the new agreement put the uranium-conversion deal, which was originally signed in 1993 but quickly ran into trouble, "on solid ground for years to come."
"Russia benefits and America benefits," he added, "and that, more than anything, symbolizes our new relationship. We seek mutual security, not separate advantage."
Deeply in debt and in desperate need of billions of dollars in Western loans, Russia will now be able to sell 500 metric tons of uranium from its nuclear warheads, worth an estimated $12 billion, to the United States Government and energy companies over the next 20 years.
An Administration official said that under the 1993 agreement, Russia diluted about 30 tons of weapons-grade uranium that was supposed to be sold to the West. But the deal snagged over disputes about the terms of the sale after uranium prices plunged, and Russia stopped diluting the uranium last year.
Last fall Congress and the Administration agreed to spend $325 million to buy the natural uranium that had accumulated at market prices. The Administration then helped Russia conclude deals with three energy companies -- Cameco of Canada, Cogema of France, and Nukem of Germany. The contacts were signed two days ago, the Administration official said.
The second part of the new agreement sets up two centers for enhancing nuclear safety in Russia and the United States. The centers, which will cost Washington about $1 million to open and up to $2 million a year when fully operatings, are supposed to enable Russian and American nuclear experts to cooperate in resolving environmental issues associated with managing radioactive waste and decontaminating plants that are taken out of commission.
The American center will be located at the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental Laboratory in Idaho Falls, the historical home of research reactors and advanced test reactors. A site for the Russian center has not been determined, but it will be in Moscow.
The third part provides American assistance to help the Russian Atomic Energy Ministry establish a nuclear crisis center similar to the Department of Energy's Emergency Operations Center in Washington. The goal is to assemble experts and resources quickly to help protect people in the event of an accident at a nuclear plant.
Discussing the decision by Mr. Adamov, the Russian minister, to stay in Washington despite disagreements over the bombing of Yugoslavia, the senior Administration who described the new accord said: "We've had a lot of ups and downs, politically and economically in our relationship. But we've both kept our eyes on the importance of the shared goal of helping Russia control its nuclear material and know-how."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Back The Censure Of Beijing Over Rights

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The Administration announced today that it would sponsor a United Nations resolution next month condemning Beijing for what the resolution calls the wholesale violation of human rights.
Last year President Clinton decided to drop Washington's tradition of sponsoring such a resolution at the United Nations Human Rights Commission annual meeting in Geneva, arguing that China's behavior was improving and that seeking a public rebuke was counterproductive. 
 Shortly thereafter China signed the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, which commits Beijing to guaranteeing freedom of expression, assembly and religion.
But so far China has not ratified the convention, and as the economy has slowed and protests have erupted, the Government has imprisoned more dissidents and cracked down on all efforts to organize political opposition.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said today that in the past year, "China's human rights record has deteriorated sharply."
The new resolution was announced less than two weeks before Prime Minister Zhu Rongji is to arrive here for an official visit. The trip has already become intertwined with Washington's intensifying debate about nuclear spying, soaring trade deficits and China's efforts to win American approval for entry into the World Trade Organization.
In fact, rarely has the Administration's policy of separating trade and human rights been starker than today: even as the State Department was making its announcement, American and Chinese negotiators were trying to fashion a deal on China's membership in the trade group in time for Mr. Zhu's arrival in Washington, which is scheduled for April 8.
Administration officials insisted today that their decision to go ahead with the resolution condemning China was driven chiefly by China's crackdown on dissidents. But, speaking on condition of anonymity, they readily acknowledged that it was also linked to the increasing hostility toward China on Capitol Hill, where the questions of its rights record and fitness to join the trade organization seem inseparable.
Some in Congress have threatened to block China's entry. By sponsoring the resolution condemning China, the White House hopes to argue that it is using the Geneva forum to try to punish the Chinese -- without punishing American exporters or others doing business with Beijing.
"There's a sense that the President has to show Congress he can get tough," one Administration official said, "without sinking the whole relationship."
The State Department did not release the wording of its proposed resolution today, but if the past is any guide, the measure stands little chance of passage. Since their introduction in 1990, a year after the shootings at Tiananmen Square, similar resolutions have consistently been defeated.
That reality -- along with politically symbolic gestures by the Chinese in 1998, including the release from jail of Wang Dan and other prominent democracy advocates -- led the Administration to decide last year to skip the ritual at the Geneva meeting.
But the environment has radically changed. Economic troubles have brought on anti-Government protests in China. The State Department's rights report, released last month, condemned Beijing for a new wave of repression. But even then several Administration officials said they thought the report alone might serve to register Washington's protest. They hinted that the United States might again forgo sponsoring a resolution. In a foreign policy speech last month, President Clinton suggested that China was "moving away from the rule of fear."
The Senate, however, unanimously passed a nonbinding resolution calling for a condemnation of China at the Geneva meeting, which began this week and will continue through April. And the Administration, a senior State Department official told reporters today, concluded that was the only realistic choice.
"Having chronicled the facts and the deterioration," the senior official said, "we had no choice but to go ahead with the resolution as part of our strategy of engagement on human rights."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Setbacks in Drug Issues Send the Dow 14 Points Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday as Merck & Company and the Warner-Lambert Company suffered setbacks on profitable drugs. The Oracle Corporation and other software companies limited the decline, gaining on speculation that investors had overreacted to concern about slowing sales of personal computers.
"Merck and Warner-Lambert's pipelines aren't as rich as Bristol-Myers' or Pfizer's today," said Michael Weiner, managing director at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, which owns shares of all four of the drug makers and oversees more than $110 billion in Columbus, Ohio. "The more dominant the product, the more scared investors get." 
 Some traders said they were reluctant to hold stocks over the weekend as NATO began a new wave of air attacks in Yugoslavia.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.15 points, to 9,822.24, with Goodyear Tire and Rubber contributing most to the decline. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 7.19 points, to 1,282.80, with drug makers accounting for 18 percent of the loss. The Nasdaq composite index declined 15.63 points, to 2,419.17.
Merck fell 2 3/16 , to 80 3/8, after Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. said a European Union regulatory panel recommended that its new AIDS drug Ziagen be approved, a step toward full acceptance in what is the world's second-biggest market. The Glaxo approval adds to the list of drugs that are challenging Merck's Crixivan as a top choice for treating HIV. Viracept from Agouron Pharmaceuticals has already passed Crixivan in United States sales.
Warner-Lambert fell 1 21/32 , to 67 11/16 , after a Government scientist voiced concern to a Government advisory panel about the risks of Rezulin, the diabetes drug that helped make Warner-Lambert one of the world's most profitable drug companies.
Oracle, which had fallen 36 percent from Feb. 3 through Wednesday, climbed 13/16 to 27 1/2.
"Concern about tech earnings got a bit overblown" as the Nasdaq composite index slumped as much as 10 percent from its record in early February, said Guy Truicko, a money manager at Unity Management, which oversees $1 billion in Lake Success, N.Y. "The old leadership is starting to regain some steam."
BMC Software Inc. rose 2 1/2, to 37 11/16 . Demand for mainframe computers is still strong and concern about slowing revenue as the year 2000 approaches is excessive, said Gibbs Moody, a Warburg Dillon Read Inc. analyst who reiterated his "strong buy" rating on the maker of corporate software. He expects the stock to reach 55 in 12 months.
Goodyear fell 2 1/16 , to 49 13/16 , on mistaken investor concern over a company news releases, said Nick Colas, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston Inc., who rates the tire maker a buy. He said investors have always been concerned about capacity expansion and yesterday's statement made it sound as if the company was expanding production capacity when it was shifting production to Quebec from Alabama.
The overall earnings picture is brighter than it has been in several quarters. The First Call Corporation said analysts it surveyed expect first-quarter operating profits for companies in the S.& P. 500 to rise 6.4 percent, their biggest gain since the last three months of 1997.
Still, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company's chief global strategist, Barton Biggs, told CNBC yesterday that the 15 or 20 biggest United States stocks are the most overvalued. He also said small stocks were not likely to rally if big ones fell.
In composite trading, 156 stocks fell to 52-week lows, while 88 rose to highs. Lows have outnumbered highs on every day except one this month.
Escalating violence in the Balkans held back gains. NATO began a third wave of air attacks on military targets in Yugoslavia.
War has been bad news for stocks in the past. The Dow average fell 21 percent from July 2, 1990, through Oct. 11, 1990; Iraq invaded Kuwait in August of that year, setting off the Persian Gulf War. The United States entered World War II in 1941, and the industrials declined 30 percent from the end of 1940 through April 1942.
"The record of getting involved in Balkan wars is very poor," said Robert Stovall, who manages about $2 billion in assets for Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers Inc. While the conflict is not curbing the economy or corporate earnings, "the market won't like it if there's confusion" in the Government's top ranks, "which is likely if we have casualties," he said.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
It's Great Beisbol, but Diplomacy Lite

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Fans of the Baltimore Orioles (79-83 last season) have learned not to expect too much, and that is good advice for those looking for political fallout from the Orioles' baseball game tomorrow against a Cuban all-star team in Havana. The Orioles are the latest American athletes to be pressed into service as diplomats. But the game, part of a modest package of measures to expand American contact with ordinary Cubans, is likely to give only a slight boost to relations between Washington and Havana. Sports diplomacy has produced dramatic breakthroughs only when the governments using it were looking for one.
The most dramatic was the 1971 initiative that came to be known as Ping-Pong diplomacy. After 20 years with no contacts between China and the United States, Prime Minister Zhou Enlai invited the American table tennis team to visit China on its way home from the world championships in Japan. 
 The 15 players and three reporters who went to Beijing probably represented more American visitors than had set foot in China since 1950. The Americans said afterward that their hosts, obviously superior players, let them win many of the games. Three months after the matches the national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, made a secret visit to arrange President Nixon's triumphal trip the next year.
Undoubtedly the low point of sports diplomacy came in 1987, when Heinz Weifenbach, the owner of a cash-strapped ice hockey team in the West German town of Iserlohn, made a deal with Muammar el-Qaddafi. In exchange for the promise of $900,000 from the Libyan leader, the Iserlohn players wore jerseys advertising the "Green Book," a compilation of Colonel Qaddafi's wisdom. The book was a best seller in Libya, needless to say, but to Mr. Qaddafi's frustration had enjoyed only limited readership elsewhere.
Germany's ice hockey federation and local politicians quickly halted the arrangement, in part because the year before Libya had orchestrated the bombing of a West Berlin nightclub frequented by American soldiers, killing three people and injuring hundreds. Although Mr. Weifenbach compared the sponsorship deal to Ping-Pong diplomacy, it seems to have failed to improve German-Libyan relations.
Since then, there has been a spate of sports diplomacy lite. In 1991 North and South Korea, bitter enemies, fielded a joint table tennis team at the world championships in Japan. Last year the Stars and Stripes flew in Teheran as five American wrestlers competed, to warm applause. A month before, Iran's President, Mohammad Khatami, had proposed a program of cultural exchanges with the United States.
The Orioles' trip -- and a return engagement that the Cuban team will play in Baltimore in May -- will most likely have a similarly modest effect. Along with authorizing the baseball games, the Clinton Administration in January approved other cultural exchanges and allowed Americans to increase the amount of money they can send Cubans. But wary of alienating right-wing Cubans and their supporters, the Administration did not lift the economic embargo on Cuba or approve the bipartisan commission many senators had backed to re-examine Cuba policy.
Still, the Orioles' trip will open the door to other high-profile exchanges -- and, perhaps, to better baseball. George Steinbrenner has been invited to Cuba to talk about a visit by the Yankees.
 TINA ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Market Grows For U.S. Cars From Canada

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 26

 BODY:
American entrepreneurs have been buying tens of thousands of vehicles cheaply at Canadian dealerships and reselling them in the United States, making substantial profits and in the process sidestepping American fuel-economy rules.
This cross-border commerce is booming because cars and trucks, including those made in the United States, cost less in Canada these days -- as much as $5,000 less for big sport utility vehicles and large cars. The Canadian dollar's value has tumbled, dropping nearly 9 percent against the American dollar the last two years. Auto makers have been reluctant to raise Canadian prices to compensate because the Canadian economy is weaker and incomes are lower than in the United States. 
 Imports of new and used vehicles from Canada have risen nearly twelvefold the last two years because of the price gap and are still rising. Roughly 10,000 vehicles a month are entering the country under a special program originally intended mainly to help immigrants from Canada bring their cars here. Factories in the United States are shipping thousands of vehicles to Canadian dealers who put them on trucks back to the United States for resale as new cars by dealers here.
Canadian prices tend to be particularly low for large models, notably full-size sport utility vehicles. Canadian taxes keep gasoline prices about 20 percent higher than in the United States, limiting demand for big gas guzzlers. Most of the vehicles being brought south are large and built in the United States but are exempt from Federal rules aimed at improving the fuel economy of the nation's fleet of family vehicles.
The average American cannot simply fly up to Canada, buy a cheap vehicle and drive it back because she would face weeks and possibly months of paperwork before crossing the border. The Transportation Department issues licenses to businesses, known as registered importers, to bring in vehicles, and companies are lining up for these licenses; the number of registered importers has risen to 144 from 80 the last 15 months.
Of 74,413 vehicles brought into the United States last year, all but 400 or so came from Canada. The reason is simple: cars and trucks imported from anywhere else, including Mexico, require thousands of dollars in modifications to meet American safety and environmental rules.
But Canada has followed American safety standards for years and adopted American vehicular pollution rules as of Sept. 1, 1997. Registered importers usually just replace the Canadian speedometer and odometer, which are calibrated in kilometers instead of miles.
Most registered importers serve as middlemen between Canadian and American dealers and do not have the staff to sell vehicles to the general public. It is up to the American dealer whether to pass on the savings to customers.
The registered importers contend that they are helping consumers by providing American car dealers with a way around the steep markups that auto makers now charge in the United States, particularly on large vehicles. "All we do is relocate vehicles to someone who can help them," said Richard J. Izzo, the president of Superior Auto Sales Inc., a registered importer in Hamburg, N.Y., near Buffalo, which ships cars as far south as Florida.
Roger L. Palczewski, a milk processing company executive in Orchard Park, N.Y., and his daughter, Tracey, bought a new, Mexican-made silver Volkswagen New Beetle from Canada for her in early January rather than go on a four-month waiting list for a Beetle imported directly from Mexico. "It has been great," Mr. Palczewski said.
Dealers and individuals have been trading cars across borders in Europe for years to take advantage of currency shifts, and national differences in car prices have become a big consumer issue there. Here and in Europe, some auto makers have tried to discourage the trade.
The registered importers are exempt from American fuel-economy regulations, which require that the average fuel economy for all of the cars sold by each auto maker must be at least 27.5 miles a gallon. The average fuel economy for each auto maker's sales of sport utility vehicles, vans and pickup trucks must be at least 20.7 miles a gallon.
A computer printout supplied by the Transportation Department of virtually all the vehicles brought in last year shows that there were very few small cars and fairly few small sport utilities, pickups or minivans; the list is dominated by large, heavy vehicles with poor fuel economy.
Regulators have not calculated the average fuel economy of vehicles being brought in by the registered importers because no law requires them to do so. By contrast, direct imports from auto makers' overseas factories total about two million vehicles each year, and these are subject to fuel economy laws.
Monthly shipments of registered imports are currently equal to a little less than 1 percent of all vehicles sold in the United States, too small a number to have a significant impact on the fuel economy of any manufacturer. Still, even at the margin, from a regulatory standpoint, the shipments are helpful to the auto makers, which are under severe pressure to meet the fuel-economy targets. General Motors has been taking particularly drastic measures, like cutting short the 1998 model year of the giant Chevrolet Suburban after just five months of production to keep G.M.'s corporate average up.
Executives from G.M., Ford Motor, DaimlerChrysler and several foreign auto makers say they absolutely do not have a policy of avoiding fuel-economy rules by shipping big vehicles to Canada and then letting them trickle back into the United States. Indeed, the auto makers have financial incentives to limit the cross-border trade and are taking some steps to do so. Their profit margins are smaller on the vehicles they sell at lower markups to Canadian dealers.
James P. Holden, DaimlerChrysler's executive vice president for North American sales, pointed out that executives who deliberately tried to subvert the corporate average fuel economy rules could face criminal prosecution. "We don't play games on C.A.F.E., and I don't believe that any other manufacturer would play that game," he said.
Richard G. Wagoner Jr., G.M.'s president, said auto makers preferred to sell cars and trucks for higher prices in the United States. "If anything, the Canadians have to squeal to get their fair share," he said.
Ford's computers have been programmed to spot cases in which Ford cars originally shipped to Canadian dealers were taken in for warranty work at Ford's dealers in the United States. While Ford pays for the warranty work, it also traces the serial number to determine if the vehicle was sold across the border soon after it was shipped to Canada. If it was, Ford identifies the Canadian dealer who originally received the vehicle from the factory and charges that dealer a fee equal to the dealer's estimated profit on the vehicle's sale.
Ford sells an Expedition XLT full-size sport utility vehicle with four-wheel drive for $32,730 retail in the United States. North of the border, Ford charges the Canadian equivalent of $27,550.
Some auto makers, like Volkswagen, put no limits on the cross-border shipments.
Only one auto maker, Honda Motor, has really crimped the registered importers by limiting the availability of replacement speedometers and odometers in recent months. Art Garner, a Honda spokesman, said the auto maker wanted to make sure dealers told customers when they were buying a vehicle meant for the Canadian market, which is difficult to determine once the speedometer and odometer have been changed.
Honda, one of the few auto makers that do not have a problem meeting the average fuel-economy rules, also has an unusually stringent warranty policy. American Honda dealers who sell cars purchased from Canadian dealers are required to pay for any warranty work done on the cars anywhere in the United States.
Registered importers are furious at Honda, contending that it is limiting American dealers' freedom to acquire vehicles at the lowest possible cost. But the policy appears to have been effective. Honda started enforcing the speedometer policy with its Odyssey minivans, for which there are long waiting lists at its American dealerships; only eight Odysseys were brought in from Canada by registered importers last year, according to the Transportation Department.

NATO Launches Day Raids Against Fierce Resistance
NATO forces took their air and missile assault against Serbian targets into the daylight hours. President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia maintained fierce resistance on the ground and in the air. Two MIG-29 fighters were shot down during what NATO said was a foray into neighboring Bosnia. The sweep by Serb troops through ethnic Albanian villages in Kosovo was unabated. A1 

The Clinton Administration and a European security group said they had reports from refugees fleeing Kosovo and from others that 15,000 to 20,000 ethnic Albanian civilians were put on a forced march in Kosovo. A1
 
The Security Council rejected, 12 to 3, a Russian resolution demanding an immediate end to NATO's air attacks on Yugoslavia. A7
 
The twin-tail Yugoslav MIG-29's are among the world's top fighter jets. But NATO has radar planes to track their every move, long-range air-to-air missiles and better-trained pilots, who anticipate the Yugoslav pilots' antiquated Soviet-style tactics. A5
 
Republican Presidential contenders are divided over whether the United States should play a role in Serbia. Most said President Clinton had a misguided foreign policy that led to American entanglement there. A6

HEADLINE: Market Makeover

BYLINE: By Fen Montaigne; Fen Montaigne, a former Moscow correspondent for The Philadelphia Inquirer, is the author of "Reeling In Russia."

 BODY:

KAPITALIZM
 Russia's Struggle
 to Free Its Economy.
 By Rose Brady.
 Illustrated. 289 pp. New Haven:
 Yale University Press. $30. 
 In little more than a decade, Russia has been transformed in the minds of most Americans from menace to muddle. No realm seems hazier than the effort by Boris N. Yeltsin and company to metamorphose the Communist economy into a capitalist proving ground, an exercise some liken to putting a scrambled egg back in its shell. The 1990's present a swirl of images: bundled-up babushkas taking to the streets to peddle their possessions as free prices and inflation hit, buzz-cut mobsters rubbing one another out with Capone-like gusto, the trappings of the West's good life -- from the Golden Arches to Mercedes sedans -- flooding the country.
In fact, though we may not have grasped it, one of the most daring social experiments in history has unfolded before our eyes. And in "Kapitalizm," Rose Brady admirably chronicles, step by step, how Yeltsin's young reformers fought to dismantle the insanely complex Soviet economy and construct a free-market society in its place.
Often it is not a pretty story, but Brady is able to see past the blundering and corruption and appreciate the achievement that has taken place: Eight years after the demise of the Soviet Union, private enterprise accounts for 70 percent of Russia's economic production, and -- most important -- the psychology of many Russians has irretrievably changed. "The task, then, was to dismantle the machine," she writes of Anatoly Chubais, who led Yeltsin's privatization drive. "He had come up against fierce opponents of reform, and in the political-economic game that ensued he had not always played clean. But he had kept his eye on the prize. The prize was a non-Communist Russia in which private property dominated the economy."
The transformation of Russia's economy is a sprawling and byzantine tale, and Brady, a former Moscow correspondent for Business Week, is well qualified to tell it. As could be expected, the reform process has been a constant round of two steps forward, one step back, with Communist die-hards in Parliament and the so-called Red Directors of state factories resisting the march to capitalism. Brady skillfully relates the missteps and compromises that Yeltsin's team made along the way. Nowhere was the maneuvering trickier than in the privatization of state-owned business and industry, the cornerstone of the market makeover.
At one point, Chubais permitted several major banks, which had provided the Government with much-needed loans, to acquire large blocks of shares in industrial giants, like Norilsk Nickel, through shady auctions. Such insider deals enabled a handful of financial institutions to gain control over large segments of the economy at bargain-basement prices. But Chubais, fearful that a Communist victory in 1995 parliamentary elections might derail privatization, wanted to make the process irreversible. Unloading factories and oil companies to private investors, however improperly, did just that. The year after, Brady explains, the oligarchs showed their gratitude, plowing by some estimates $140 million into Yeltsin's victorious re-election campaign.
"Kapitalizm" is at its best when Brady takes readers behind the scenes of machinations like these, or when she recounts the rise of Russia's new magnates. Her story falls short, however, in describing the effects of the reforms on average Russians. To be sure, the book is replete with man-on-the-street interviews, but closely following one or two families over the past eight years would have been more effective.
Still, "Kapitalizm" is one of the most coherent accounts to date of the disassembly of the economy of the Evil Empire. Now, with Russia mired in its worst crisis to date, all involved acknowledge that the task has been far more daunting than they ever imagined.
"We . . . did not comprehend the enormity of the process we were dealing with," Chubais says. "We thought it was a difficult transition that would last three years, five years, seven years. Now it's clear that the transition will last decades."

HEADLINE: Ghost Town

BYLINE: By Larry Wolff; Larry Wolff teaches European history at Boston College. He is the author of "Inventing Eastern Europe: The Map of Civilization on the Mind of the Enlightenment."

 BODY:

THE BOOK OF BLAM
 By Aleksandar Tisma.
 Translated by Michael Henry Heim.
 226 pp. New York:
 Harcourt Brace & Company. $23. 
 In the opening pages of Aleksandar Tisma's "Book of Blam," the eponymous protagonist, Miroslav Blam, sets out for a stroll through the city of Novi Sad in Tito's Yugoslavia. He finds himself drawn to what was once the street of the Jews, before the war, now "the destination of many idle strollers like Blam." He is not, however, just any idle stroller, for Blam is one of the few Jewish survivors in Novi Sad, and he can remember the street when it was inhabited by the now annihilated Jewish population of the city. Following in Blam's footsteps, in a stunning literary excursion, Tisma conjures the names and fates of the former inhabitants. He recounts what occurred at each address after Hitler defeated Yugoslavia in 1941 and Hungary, Germany's ally, occupied the city of Novi Sad:
"No. 13 housed Arthur Spitzer's grocery and delicatessen. Spitzer played amateur soccer and had non-Jewish friends. Having married a Hungarian and converted before the war, he was spared persecution. He had no children of his own, but his sister sent him her 6-year-old daughter from the Independent State of Croatia, where Jews had an even harder time of it. . . . For a while his baptismal certificate, Christian wife and soccer friends protected him. On the day his young Jewish niece was to be deported, Spitzer and his wife went to the station with her, hoping to save her with their papers and connections. They were all crammed into a train for Auschwitz."
Tisma builds his novel around the fictional figure of Blam, who does escape deportation, in part because he, like Arthur Spitzer, has a non-Jewish wife. Blam becomes the focus for the literary reconstruction of a demolished urban landscape and society, represented according to the intricate historical circumstances of Eastern Europe during World War II. First published in Yugoslavia in 1972, now powerfully translated by Michael Henry Heim from the language that used to be called Serbo-Croatian, "The Book of Blam" offers a literary memorial to the former Jews of the former Yugoslavia.
Novi Sad is a name perhaps best known to the American public as the hometown of the tennis superstar Monica Seles -- cited in sports stories as a place where the scarcity of acceptable tennis courts for training inevitably compelled Seles to migrate to America at 12. Novi Sad played a considerably more complicated part in European history, its urban development dating to the 18th century, when the city grew up alongside the Danube, facing the great Hapsburg fortress of Petrovaradin. In the 19th century Novi Sad became a center of Serbian literary culture, though the city had a heterogeneous population of Serbs, Hungarians, Germans and Jews. It was the principal city of the Vojvodina province, itself a geographical crossroads of even greater ethnographic diversity, including large communities of Croatians and Romanians. Thus Novi Sad reflected the multinational character of the Hapsburg monarchy, before being assigned to Yugoslavia in the peace settlement following World War I.
Tisma traces a fictional family history of migrating Hapsburg Jews through the whole 19th century and across the map of Eastern Europe, showing how the parents of Miroslav Blam happened to settle in Novi Sad. The most remarkable of Tisma's literary historical accounts, however, is that of the massacre of 1942 in Novi Sad, perpetrated by the Hungarian military. The Hungarian population of Novi Sad lived under Yugoslav sovereignty after World War I; the Serbian population was handed over by Hitler to Hungarian rule during World War II. Tisma begins with an urban map: "Look at the map of Novi Sad, and you will see a kind of spider's web intersecting on one side with a broad ribbon in the form of a half circle but extending evenly in all other directions. The ribbon, usually colored blue, is the Danube." He then imagines the Hungarian officers plotting their murderous raid from that same map -- they divided the spiderweb of the city's streets into several hundred smaller webs, assigning patrols to each" -- and follows the patrols as they check documents and order executions. Thousands of Jews and Serbs were killed in the massacre, and Tisma attempts to convey the atrocity of the historical moment by describing what happened in a sampling of houses and neighborhoods. One of the patrols comes to the house of Blam's parents, who are promptly taken outside and shot.
Other works by Tisma also explore the experience of World War II in Novi Sad, including "The Use of Man," which has been translated into English. Some of the same regional terrain also appears in the fiction of Danilo Kis, who, like Tisma, came from Vojvodina and wrote about the situation of Yugoslav Jews during the war. Tisma himself was associated with Tito's Partisans during the war and afterward played a prominent role in Yugoslav literary life during the decades of Communism. "The Book of Blam" has a young Communist heroine -- Blam's sister Estera, who is killed in the Resistance as she throws her last grenade. Hers is one of the ghosts that haunts Blam after the war. Another is that of the novel's political villain, Predrag Popadic, a handsome young rake who collaborates with the Hungarian occupation by editing a Serbian newspaper in Novi Sad. He seduces Blam's mother and, later, Blam's wife as well (though not, of course, Estera) but attempts to use his influence to protect the Blam family under the Hungarian occupation. After the liberation of Novi Sad the victorious Communist Partisans arrest Popadic and summarily execute him beside the Danube, blowing his brains out with a dumdum bullet.
Tito's Yugoslavia was politically constructed as the federal union of six separate republics: Serbia, Croatia, Slovenia, Bosnia, Macedonia and Montenegro. The republic of Serbia included two autonomous provinces: one was Kosovo, with its large Albanian majority, and the other was Vojvodina, with its large Hungarian minority. Novi Sad was the provincial capital of the multinational Vojvodina, and the name of the city was also associated with the affirmation of cultural unity in Yugoslavia, for it was the Novi Sad linguistic agreement of 1954 that declared Serbo-Croatian to be a single language, spoken in two dialects and written in two scripts. Tisma wrote his novel in Serbo-Croatian, but today both Serbs and Croats insist on the distinction between Serbian and Croatian.
Serbian nationalists demonstrated in Novi Sad in 1988, toppling the provincial government and paving the way for Slobodan Milosevic to abolish autonomy in both Vojvodina and Kosovo. The overturning of the intricate Titoist constitution, with its calculated structure of checks and balances among the nationalities, has severely reduced the cultural protections and prerogatives of the Hungarians, as well as the several other minorities, in Vojvodina. Tisma, living in France, has bitterly condemned the brutal warfare that continues to accompany the disintegration of Yugoslavia, and "The Book of Blam," looking back to Novi Sad in World War II, explores the political pressures by which a multinational urban community became the site of murderous internecine enmity. Indeed, the various remembered and misremembered versions of what happened during World War II in Yugoslavia have certainly contributed to the violence of national conflict in the 1990's.
Tisma describes the assembling of the Jews of Novi Sad in the city's synagogue in 1944, as they awaited deportation to the concentration camps: "The Jews sat patiently within the confines of the synagogue; the guards did their duty meticulously, showing anger only in the street, when they had to disperse curious onlookers -- one group of which included a dejected-looking Blam, exempt because of his marriage.
"The only discordant note in this otherwise harmonious waiting period came from the animal world rather than the human world; it came in the form of the dogs that had trotted alongside their masters to the synagogue and that remained outside when the guards refused to let them through the gates."
Tisma thus follows the deportation from the perspective of the confused dogs, who cannot figure out the unfathomable human logic of the Holocaust. The novel returns to the synagogue for the final chapter, in which Blam attends a concert of the Novi Sad Chamber Orchestra, performed in the former temple, now best appreciated for its excellent acoustics. In the synagogue, with its handsomely surviving cupolas, pillars, chandeliers and mosaics, Blam's inner acoustical sensitivity focuses his memory with excruciating clarity on his family and their community, which did not survive the terrible course of the 20th century.

PERSON: MIROSLAV BLAM (95%); ALEKSANDAR TISMA (95%); ARTHUR SPITZER (66%);
