PUB-DATE: March 28, 1999

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2156 words

HEADLINE: The Many Messages Of the Lei

BYLINE: By JOCELYN FUJII; JOCELYN FUJII is the author of "Under the Hula Moon" (Crown), a book about style in Hawaii.

 BODY:
I BUY at least 50 leis a year. If I had the materials and the time I would make them myself, but I don't, so I buy them -- for birthdays, weddings, retirements, funerals, graduations, Lei Day (May 1), friends and their friends arriving in Hawaii from out of town, and sometimes, for no reason at all, just to place on my own shoulders.
Most of the time, how and where I buy the lei depends on the occasion and the recipient. A designer lei, ordered ahead from an artisan and wrapped in a special ti-leaf bundle, called puolo, is top of the line. Honolulu's Chinatown is the middle road, where leis are abundant and always available, and you point and pick and run off with your choice in a plastic bag. The lei stands at Honolulu International Airport, where hideous spray-painted carnation strands hang side by side with fragrant ginger and pikake, are always the last resort -- the 7-Eleven of the lei world. 
 "There are very few leis that are not good," said Marie McDonald, a well-known lei maker from Waimea on the Big Island and author of "Ka Lei," the definitive book on leis (Ku Paa Publishing). "They're all good, because the whole idea of presenting a lei is to show honor, to show high regard, love. And you can do it with every lei. But, over the years, some have become more special than others."
The lei may be the quintessential symbol of a Hawaiian greeting, but history, legend and superstition have created some arcane elements in the protocol of this beloved Hawaiian custom.
I learned about lei protocol the hard way. Many years ago, I gave a friend a lei of red hala, made from the fragrant fruit of the pandanus tree, at the start of a business venture. The lei maker in Chinatown had cut the ends of the cone-shaped fruit and strung them between the anise-scented tips of bright green lauae ferns, making an extraordinary composition of geometry, color and fragrance.
My friend expressed genuine appreciation. But my choice of lei, I was to learn, was controversial.
"Never give a hala lei at the start of a venture," a lei maker told me on a subsequent foray to Chinatown. "Only at the end. People think it's bad luck." Other lei makers disagree, saying the hala is one of the nicest that can be given, but local politicians on the campaign trail have been known to scurry off the stage at the sight of a well-wisher approaching with a hala lei.
In times before Western contact, commoners giving leis to royalty had to present them to an intermediary with a bow, observing a taboo against raising their nonroyal hands above the head of an alii. Violators could face punishment as severe as death. Western influences, particularly the tourist industry, have tempered tradition and added some flourishes, such as Lei Day, initiated in 1928 by the poet Don Blanding, an Oklahoma native living in Hawaii, in an effort to preserve the custom.
Lei Day today is a statewide celebration, with a royal court selected every year, school pageants, the ubiquitous giving and wearing of leis, and an islandwide lei making contest with the most flamboyant display of garlands to be seen in Hawaii. Even the practice of giving a kiss with a lei, commonly observed today, was established by a World War II entertainer who claimed it was a Hawaiian custom.
"Traditionally, Hawaiians embrace each other or touch noses when they give a lei," said Mrs. McDonald, the lei maker from Waimea.
"The kissing is very touristy," added Barbara Meheula, another revered lei maker on the Big Island. "The most precious thing to a Hawaiian is breath, the ha. The old-timers will put their cheek next to the person receiving the lei and softly give them the ha, the breath, because everything you have in your heart is in the ha."
The practice of throwing a lei overboard in hopes that it reaches the shore, thus predicting a return to the islands, was popularized during the 1930's through the 1950's, the heyday of the luxury liners. But Hawaiians "never throw away their leis, " Mrs. McDonald said. After it is worn, a lei is draped over a photograph or taken to the cemetery or returned to the earth as compost, but never put in the wastebasket. Most leis will keep overnight in the refrigerator, in a plastic bag. Many can be dried; a light mist of hair spray helps keep bugs away while they dry, Mrs. Meheula said.
There are dos and don'ts in receiving a lei, too.
"Don't ever take a lei off and swing it around," advised Euphemia Nagashima, former Hawaiiana coordinator for Honolulu's Department of Parks and Recreation, which organizes the annual Hawaiian Lei Contest on Lei Day. "No matter how simple, someone put a lot of love into that lei."
A more common offense is removing a lei after it has been received, which Hawaiians consider rude.
Some leis, such as hala, favored by the likes of Hiiaka, sister of the volcano goddess, Pele, were considered by the ancients to be as much good luck as bad. Hala may be "the most misunderstood of all the leis," Mrs. Meheula added, "probably because it is also the most cherished.
"For every single New Year luau, everyone in my family wears a hala lei," she said. "It's good luck for the year, because hala means cleansing, like firecrackers for the Chinese and mochi for the Japanese."
Hala represented good luck during the monthslong Makahiki season of feasting and thanksgiving. "In the old days, the only time you could get married was during Makahiki, and the lei that was often given was hala," said Mrs. Meheula. Yet the Hawaiian Dictionary by Mary Kawena Pukui and Samuel H. Elbert defines hala as "sin," "offense," and also "to pass away, to die." Hala is the ultimate flower lei for a funeral.
Leis most popularly used to greet visitors are the sweetly scented, yellow-and-white plumeria, white tuberose, ginger, pikake (Arabian jasmine), and the unscented, lavender to purple dendrobium and vanda orchids, strung in several styles ranging from prosaic to exquisite. The dainty yellow-green pakalana (Chinese violet) is less known but much loved by islanders, particularly the old-timers. ("Give me a full moon and a pakalana lei, and I'll say yes to anything," my meditation teacher, Nana Veary, used to say with a mischievous smile.)
The heavily scented blossoms (or extremely feminine ones, like roses) are usually given to women, while the unscented lei, like the feathery aalii and the cigar lei, made of the cigar flower, or kika, which can be red, orange or yellow, are typically chosen for men.
The tissue-thin ilima blossom, picked early in the morning while the buds are just opening and strung while the day is still cool, was traditionally preferred by the alii because of its beauty and sensuality, according to Mrs. McDonald. An ilima lei was once accepted as payment for taxes, along with pigs and sweet potatoes, and is still considered "the lei of distinction," she said, worn in multiple strands on special occasions such as election night.
The three most common types of lei making are the kui method, in which materials are strung end to end; haku, or plaited, and wili, or wound. Knotting and stitching are used in more ambitious creations. The kui method uses string or thread; other leis are generally made of plant material only. It can take from five minutes to four hours to make a lei, Mrs. Meheula said.
At the top of the lei hierarchy, and among the more expensive, are the native plants that were offered to Laka, the Hawaiian goddess of the dance, still honored by hula schools today. The most visible and accessible among these is maile, a green-leafed vine that is wound into open-ended strands that emit heady clouds of anise-like fragrance. At blessings to open new buildings and businesses, long strands of maile are entwined in front of the entrance and untied ceremoniously (never cut) to signify that the blessing is complete. In ancient times, maile was the lei for all people, while leis of feathers and sperm whale teeth were strictly reserved for royalty.
Maile leis also are given at graduations and other celebrations. "Parents will hike in a storm to gather maile for their child's graduation, because it signifies that the child will continue to grow and have life," Mrs. Meheula said. "Maile represents life and growth."
The most astonishing maile lei I have ever laid eyes on was made by a master woodworker on Kauai, Bob Hamada. He was well into his 70's when, for his daughter's high school graduation, he hiked into the mountains and gathered maile and mokihana -- rare, cube-shaped seed capsules also strongly scented like anise. Mokihana retains its prized scent for years. It grows only on Kauai, and it is rare to see even one strand of it, much less several. Mr. Hamada strung five very long, graduated strands of mokihana -- up to almost six feet long -- and rested them on a luxurious bed of maile, to protect his daughter's skin from the powerful "mokihana burn." So powerful is mokihana that it burns delicate skin and is often worn over clothing or a protective bed of foliage.
There are many lei connoisseurs, including Mrs. Meheula, who feel that the packaging of a lei is as important as the lei itself. Mrs. Meheula makes her own containers -- puolo -- out of ti leaves, palm and coconut fronds, and, occasionally, bamboo. When someone once ordered a lei for a blind recipient, she chose fragrant pikake for the lei and carved a bamboo container -- a tactile and olfactory extravaganza.
Brides often wear multiple strands of pikake and ginger, while bridegrooms wear maile. Although leis of ultraluxurious Niihau shells are often worn by a bride in 10 long strands, fresh flowers tend to be worn at chest length, "where the heart is," Mrs. Meheula said. "And they should always be closed, representing the eternal circle of love." The bridegroom's open maile lei, she continues, "welcomes all the good wishes of the guests and sends out the same on behalf of the family."
New styles and materials in lei making keep the art form vibrant and evolving. The Micronesian ginger lei -- white ginger buds fanning outward from stems woven macrame-style -- is a fairly recent, and economical, innovation, introduced by visitors from low-lying Micronesian islands where blossoms are less abundant. The ti-leaf lei is now in every Chinatown lei stand in Honolulu, the shiny, ropey strands paired with various nouveau materials such as berrylike red schefflera (octopus tree) flowers and rounded green sea grapes. Non-native, common and culturally insignificant, the schefflera and sea grapes -- a mokihana look-alike -- represent the more commercial aspects of modern lei making.
In contrast, the orchid lip lei, also called the feathered orchid lei, is a marvel of ingenuity, made of up to 800 dendrobium orchid petals, sewn flat in a dramatic, wavy, purple-and-white design. The lei has no fragrance but is visually stunning. Various lei makers claim to have invented this now-popular (and lavish) lei. One of them, Michael Miyashiro of Rainforest Plantes et Fleurs on Oahu, has pictures of some he made in 1988, long before they began appearing in Chinatown lei stands.
"It doesn't matter who invented it," he said when I admired the photos. "A lei is meant to be given, and it's simply a part of you, for someone else to wear and enjoy."
 
Where they say it with flowers
 
Contest
The entries in this year's Hawaiian Lei Contest, sponsored by the Honolulu Department of Parks and Recreation, will be on view on Saturday, May 1, from 12:30 to 6 P.M. at Queen Kapiolani Park in Waikiki.
 
Buying
On Oahu, lei stands line the streets of Honolulu's Chinatown. Among them are Lin's Lei Shop, 1017A Maunakea Street, (808) 537-4112; Cindy's Lei and Flower Shoppe, 1034 Maunakea Street, (808) 536-6538; Lita's Leis, 59 North Beretania Street, (808) 521-9065, and Sweetheart's Lei Shop, 69 North Beretania Street, (808) 537-3011.
Prices start around $3 for a simple tuberose lei and range up to $25 and higher for elaborate orchid creations.
The designer lei makers of Hawaii include Barbara Meheula, who arranges flowers at the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel, on the Big Island of Hawaii, (808) 882-7222, on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, from around 5 A.M. to noon. (Visitors are welcome to watch her work there.) At other times she can be reached at her Honaunau farm, (808) 328-9749. Leis must be preordered; a maile or pikake lei in a natural wrapping such as ti leaves averages $35 to $40.
On Oahu, Michael Miyashiro of Rainforest Plantes et Fleurs, (808) 942-1550, is available by phone only. His leis of dendrobium orchid petals cost around $32 to $80.
Museum-quality Niihau shell leis, the most luxurious of the permanent lei styles, are available at Kauai Heritage Center of Hawaiian Culture and the Arts, Kauai Shopping Village, (808) 821-2070. They range from $85 to $6,500, depending on the type of shell and the intricacy of the design.

HEADLINE: New Luxury Towers Are Sprouting in Chicago

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
AFTER a decade-long drought in new construction, downtown Chicago is suddenly awash in new luxury apartment towers. About half a dozen towers are currently rising on the Near North and South Sides, several in neighborhoods not previously known as high-end residential enclaves.
In the past, luxury housing in Chicago tended to be concentrated in the Gold Coast, a neighborhood a mile north of the Loop and consisting of Lake Shore Drive and three streets to the west. But none of the new buildings are in this area. 
 Instead, several are either on or just off Michigan Avenue, while the rest are in neighborhoods that for most of this century have been industrial and commercial areas.
How is luxury defined in Chicago? The most common definition is a purchase price of more than $300 per square foot.
Informally, however, brokers and developers say that a luxury apartment starts at about $1 million. All of the new buildings contain at least some apartments at that price level.
"There used to be a real difference between what you got for $300,000 and what you got for $700,000," said James Kinney, president of Rubloff Residential Properties, a leading downtown brokerage. "Now, to get that same 'wow factor' you're talking at least a million dollars."
This is relatively new ground in Chicago. Five years ago, according to data from the local multiple listing service, there were 33 sales of $1 million or more downtown. In the last 14 months, however, there have been 122 sales, with an additional 56 million-dollar-plus units currently under contract.
Why the run-up in prices at a time when inflation remains at historic lows? "There's just a lot more money in Chicago today then there was at the beginning of the decade," said Diane Swonk, deputy chief economist at Bank One Corporation here. "The economy has been booming and it doesn't take many years of 20 percent returns on assets to create a lot of disposable income."
If the numbers in the demand side of the equation are up, the numbers on the supply side are down. "This is the tightest market for luxury sales I can remember," said Joan Armstrong, a broker with Koenig & Strey who has specialized in Gold Coast real estate for more than 20 years. "There is very little to show people. If they're nice apartments, they're gone in a week, often for more than the asking price."
Of the new buildings under construction, the most notable are Park Tower, the Bristol and Riverview, with Park Tower in particular perceived as a premier luxury address.
Park Tower, on the west side of Water Tower Square at the corner of Michigan and Chicago Avenues, is a joint venture of Hyatt Corporation and LR Development. The architect is Lucien Lagrange, principal of Lucien Lagrange and Associates, a firm noted locally for innovative residential work.
The building, a streamlined 67-story Art Deco affair clad in cream-colored stone, will open in the summer of 2000. The first 20 floors will be occupied by the 203-room Park Hyatt Hotel. The rest will consist of 115 condominium units, including eight full-floor penthouses. Condominium prices range from $617,000 to $3.5 million, with an average of more than $1 million.
According to Bruce Abrams, president of LR Development, all of the penthouses have been sold and all but five of the remaining units are spoken for.
"We researched the market and found that people wanted the service and amenities that go with a hotel, but not the traffic and congestion," he said. The solution, he added, was to have two entrances -- one for the hotel on Chicago Avenue and another for the condominium around the corner on Water Tower Square. Tenants also will be able to order room service from the hotel and will have access to the hotel's lavish health club.
THE building is extravagantly scaled, with apartments up to 10,000 square feet and with ceiling heights up to 15 feet. All of the units face east and have clear views of Lake Michigan.
"We wanted the same feel you get in some of the classic Lake Shore Drive apartment buildings from the 20's and 30's," said Mr. Lagrange, the architect. "The wasted space is really what makes those old apartments special -- the galleries and vestibules and hallways and niches. These aren't spaces that you eat or sleep in, but there's something comfortable about them and also very elegant."
Mr. Lagrange is personally designing several of the apartments in the building and says the dominant style is "more Beaux-Arts than Bauhaus. People want columns and moldings. It's very classical, very traditional."
Several blocks away, at the corner of Rush Street and Delaware Place, is the Bristol, a 41-story International Style tower being developed by Golub & Company. The architectural firm is Solomon Cordwell Buenz Associates, based in Chicago. The building's 189 units range in price from $275,000 to $1.4 million. According to Michael Newman, president of Golub, about 35 percent of the units have been sold so far. The building will be completed by the end of the year.
Both the Bristol and Park Tower are within easy walking distance of the Gold Coast. The third building, Riverview, has a more adventurous location. That bulding is part of an emerging neighborhood along the north bank of the Chicago River where it meets Lake Michigan. For most of Chicago's history, this land -- within shouting distance of the Loop -- has been occupied by warehouses and factories.
It is now being developed into a mixed-use neighborhood that includes residential, hotel and entertainment facilities as well as a pedestrian promenade along the river. Riverview, which is being developed by MCL Companies, will ultimately consist of three towers with a total of about 400 units and about 30 town houses. The architect is Gregory De Stefano of De Stefano and Partners, based in Chicago.
The first phase, which will open late in 2000, consists of a 98-apartment tower and nine town houses. The tower units start at about $285,000 and go up to $2 million while the town houses, which face the river, start at $1.1 million and go up to $2.1 million. According to Daniel McLean, president of MCL, 35 tower units and four town houses have been sold. "The site is spectacular -- you're surrounded by water on three sides," he said.
What do you get for a $1 million today? "Over 3,000 square feet of space, fancy kitchens with granite countertops, hardwood floors throughout, marble bathrooms, nine-foot ceilings and great views of the lake and downtown," said Mr. McLean.
The new luxury buyers, say developers, are a different crowd than in the past in that suburbanites make up a much bigger part of the mix. "In the 80's, maybe 10 to 15 percent of the downtown buyers were suburbanites," said Mr. McLean. "Today, it's 40 or 50 percent. Many are empty nesters in their early 50's with high incomes. They want to be downtown where there's lots to do."
"We're getting a surprising number of suburbanites -- probably 35 percent -- who are either moving to the city or are buying a second residence downtown," said Mr. Newman.
One such buyer is Harvey Kinzelberg, who, with his wife, Mary Ann, recently purchased a 4,000-square-foot penthouse at Park Tower. Mr. Kinzelberg, who is 54, is the founder of Sequel Capital Corporation, an industrial leasing firm based in suburban Deerfield.
Mr. Kinzelberg, who currently lives in Glencoe, a tony North Shore suburb, says he is ready for a change. "The children are grown and we want to experience the city -- the restaurants, the museums, the wonderful architecture. The city's vibrant and exciting. It's time for us to have some fun."

HEADLINE: Making Philadelphia More Friendly For Its Orchestra

BYLINE: By ANNE MIDGETTE; Anne Midgette writes frequently on international art, music and theater.

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
ASK a Philadelphian to name the most beloved building in the city, and chances are, the answer will be the Academy of Music. An elegant brick edifice on Broad Street, the Academy opened in 1857 and is the oldest continuously operating music hall in the United States. It has a passionate following among music lovers, many of whom regard it as virtually synonymous with its oldest resident company and landlord, the Philadelphia Orchestra.
Yet love can be blind, or in this case, deaf. The hall's acoustics are poor, at least for orchestral music. Built as an opera house, the Academy has a proscenium arch that traps the sound, which comes across in the auditorium as dry. As a result, said Peter Dobrin, a music critic for The Philadelphia Inquirer, "Philadelphians have never really heard the Philadelphia Orchestra." 
 He is not the first to notice. An emphatic article in a newspaper here stated that the Philadelphia Orchestra, the only major American ensemble to play on a proscenium stage, should have a proper hall of its own. That was in 1908. Successive generations have taken up the cry. Plans for a new hall were drawn up during the music directorships of Leopold Stokowski, Eugene Ormandy, Riccardo Muti and now Wolfgang Sawallisch.
Finally, a plan may be realized. Ground was broken last November for a new Regional Performing Arts Center, with a 2,500-seat symphony hall and a 650-seat recital theater, scheduled to open in 2001. The current project has also served to spotlight some of the orchestra's difficulties as it approaches its centenary season and tries to keep pace with the modern world.
In fact, the center, in its final form, is not an orchestra project at all. The Philadelphia Orchestra will move into its new home as a tenant, not a landlord. And the orchestra was ultimately glad to be rid of the responsibility. The question remains whether the center's new administration, will be able to repeat the success of other performing arts centers, from Lincoln Center in the 1960's to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center more recently, in revitalizing the community.
None of this was quite what the orchestra had in mind when it announced plans for a new hall in 1986. It purchased a site on Broad Street, a block south of the Academy, and commissioned the Philadelphia-based architect Robert Venturi to design the building, assuming that Philadelphians would flock to donate the $140 million needed to realize the project. But fund-raising efforts, marred by a degree of hubris, soon slowed.
"We raised $25 million and hit a plateau," said Joseph H. Kluger, who has since become the orchestra's president. "There was a latent emotional resistance from those attached to the idea of the Academy and the orchestra in it."
Among them were the leading philanthropists Walter H. Annenberg and R. Anderson Pew, who also sat on the orchestra's board. The Annenberg Foundation refused to give any money to the new hall project, and the Pew Charitable Trusts offered $1.5 million, which the orchestra undiplomatically rejected as being too low.
Indeed, Mr. Pew and Mr. Annenberg did have funds for another project, proposed in 1994: a thorough overhaul of the Academy, at a projected cost of $44 million. Renovation was certainly overdue. The building's technical facilities were outdated, and its very structure proved increasingly unsound. Yet the renovation initially planned was so high-tech that it would have compromised the building's architectural integrity.
The unspoken goal was to turn the Academy into such a modern hall that the orchestra would have no reason to leave. The Pew trust chipped in $7.5 million and the Annenberg Foundation $10 million for the project. The renovation is still in progress, although the plan was ultimately scaled down to focus on restoring, rather than transforming, the Academy, to the tune of $31 million.
Plans for a new hall, meanwhile, seemed to have ground to a halt. The orchestra was having problems of its own, culminating in a debilitating 64-day strike in 1996. The strike ended with both sides working on constructive changes, like instituting a range of players' committees to give musicians a more active role in the orchestra's business life.
At that point, Philadelphia's colorful, charismatic mayor, Edward G. Rendell, assumed a major role. Since taking office in 1991, Mr. Rendell has overseen the transformation of a sleepy Philadelphia, a conservative city that abhorred change, into a more active place. Center City, as the downtown area is called, is dotted with construction sites, including 15 new hotels to accommodate visitors to the five-year-old convention center. All of this has bolstered the city's morale, and both Mr. Rendell and Willard G. Rouse, the developer responsible for the convention center and other major buildings, enjoy widespread popularity.
One of Mr. Rendell's pet projects is the Avenue of the Arts, which has basically redefined South Broad Street by developing its theaters and other arts facilities. Mr. Rendell is motivated less by a great love of the arts -- he prefers sports -- than by his idea of the changing definition of a city in today's world: no longer a necessary hub of commerce and industry, in an age of telecommunications, which have effectively decentralized business activity, but a "destination," a place for tourism and conventions.
"When I came to office, we were desperate to get out of economic crisis" Mr. Rendell said. "One way to do that was to build up Philadelphia's status as a destination. We need to make Philadelphia attractive for companies."
Whatever his motivation, Mr. Rendell became an energetic champion of the new hall, and he marshaled a group of community leaders, including Mr. Rouse, to find solutions that would enable it to be built. It was this group that developed the idea of acquiring both the Broad Street site and the Academy from the orchestra and managing both facilities for a number of resident companies, including the opera and the ballet. And it was this group that ultimately became the board of the Regional Performing Arts Center in 1997, with Mr. Rouse as chairman.
Adding other arts companies to the mix afforded further justification for civic involvement, demonstrating that the new hall project was about more than just the orchestra's wish for better acoustics. Philadelphia suffers from a chronic lack of performance space. In a 1992 study analyzing the number of seats in performing-arts facilities in 15 major American cities, Philadelphia, the fifth-largest city in the United States, came in last. San Francisco has about 8,400 seats per million residents; New York, 6,000; Philadelphia, between 600 and 800.
The Academy is desperately overcrowded. It has two resident companies besides the orchestra -- the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Opera Company of Philadelphia -- both straining to get more time. The thriving opera company, restricted to 30 evenings a year, has had to turn away would-be subscribers. The ballet performs "The Nutcracker" as many as three times a day to make the most of its window of opportunity; when it can't get into the Academy, it wanders from hall to hall, like other arts institutions in the city.
What's more, larger touring ensembles, from orchestras to Broadway shows, pass Philadelphia by. "When you think about the Vienna Philharmonic coming to this country and not coming to Philadelphia," said Stephanie Naidoff, the new center's president, "it leaves you salivating."
Ms. Naidoff, a corporate lawyer, and the center's other administrators have little experience in the arts, but thanks to Mr. Rouse, they knew about building. They threw out the Venturi plans and commissioned the architect Rafael Vinoly to design the new center. His plans, with two individual halls inside a glass barrel vault, were unveiled last April and became one of those rare things that Philadelphians agree upon. The enthusiasm generated $50 million in donations by the time of the groundbreaking, six months later.
BUT the price tag has gone up considerably over the years, and the center, despite having received $73 million of state and city funds, is still $50 million short of its $255 million goal. And the Annenberg and Pew foundations are still withholding support.
"Certain large trusts have yet to recognize their responsibilities," said Sidney Kimmel, the chairman and director of Jones Apparel Group and, with a pledge of $15 million, the largest private donor to the center. "I see it as that, a responsibility."
Mr. Annenberg, a 91-year-old publishing magnate and former ambassador to Great Britain, who declines comment to the press, is evidently simply opposed to the idea of a new hall. In 1992, according to an article in The Philadelphia Inquirer, he specified that none of his $20 million donation to the Avenue of the Arts should go toward the new hall project.
With the Pew trust, the issue is different. Conscious of its leading role as a patron of the arts in the United States, the foundation in 1997 introduced new guidelines for the distribution of funds to Philadelphia organizations. This Cultural Leadership Program has made waves by cutting off longtime recipients that fail to meet new criteria, like "fiscal stability." The orchestra briefly lost its financing in 1997, and the ballet was turned down in 1998.
"Over time, they cannot be running a significant deficit," said Rebecca W. Rimel, the president of the Pew trust. "There is no ambiguity about the rules, and while a lot of people might not agree with them, I don't think anyone would say we are exercising our stewardship in an arbitrary or capricious way."
The center, Ms. Rimel added, has yet to make it over Pew's bar. "We are supportive of having a new facility in Philadelphia. And we think it's a beautiful building. Our concerns boil down to, after it's built, what will it cost to run it? And what is going to be the impact on these already fragile arts organizations when their rents go up? If those two questions can be answered, our board would be very willing to consider the grant."
The Pew trust's questions about finances seem not altogether unreasonable. The center's administration has so far been long on rhetoric and short on concrete figures. It is still not clear, for example, how much companies will have to pay to use the spaces.
"I'm waiting for answers," said Robert B. Driver, the director of the opera company, which would like to increase its presence in the Academy to 50 evenings a year. "They say I'll be paying approximately what I'm paying now. That's not enough. I'm paying too much as it is."
But most people believe that prices not only for the Academy but also for the two new halls will have to be considerably higher than the current norm to keep the center running.
"We didn't know the specifics of scheduling policies and booking policies, and how we were going to run the box office, and things like that," Ms. Naidoff said. "We had to get everyone to recognize that the definite agreements will come somewhere down the line. I learned early on, don't promise things you're not sure you can deliver."
Although it no longer officially controls the center, the orchestra is still intimately involved with the project. A players' committee meets regularly with the center's design team -- Mr. Vinoly, the acoustician Russell Johnson and the theater consultant Richard Pillbrow -- to outline the orchestra's needs in its new hall, from rehearsal rooms to door sizes. And the chairman of the orchestra's board, Peter A. Benoliel, sits on the center's board, as does the donor Mr. Kimmel.
One thing still to be negotiated, evidently, is where the center's responsibility begins and the orchestra's ends. It is not even clear when and how the center will take over the Academy from the orchestra, though it is to happen by next year.
The public's identification of the center with the orchestra can only be strengthened by moments like the intermission of a concert conducted by Sir Simon Rattle last month. Sir Simon has been cited as a desirable replacement for the departing music director, Mr. Sawallisch, but was reported in January to have given a clear no to the possibility. Mr. Rouse, the center's chairman, offered a toast to the "best conductor in the world," informing Sir Simon that "Philadelphia is not a town that takes no for an answer."
Technically speaking, any offer to Sir Simon should be the responsibility of the orchestra rather than the center, though like any ardent suitor, Mr. Kluger, the orchestra's president, is happy for all the help he can get.
THE center needs the orchestra as much as the orchestra needs it. For the orchestra remains the principal guarantor that once the new center is built, there will be something to put in it. Resident chamber and dance companies may occupy the recital theater, but they will hardly fill the larger auditorium. And while the center's administration dreams of presenting a range of touring ensembles, it lacks the experience necessary to pull it off.
"Quite frankly," Ms. Naidoff said, "if this thing is going to work up to the world-class standards that we want for it, we're going to have to bring in professionals who have worked in these areas before."
With right of first refusal for dates in the new center, the orchestra is effectively getting its long-desired new hall without taking a significant financial risk. "There is a difference between renting as tenants and having your own space, after 40 years of autonomy, even if it makes sense intellectually," Mr. Kluger said. "On the other hand, if there's a deficit, it's their problem, not our problem."
For the orchestra musicians, construction of the center, now that it has started, is not a topic of burning relevance. "This orchestra has been hearing for 10 years that it's going to get a new hall," said David Cramer. a flutist. "O.K., so now they've dug a hole, but it's down the street. People don't see it every day."
Of more immediate concern are the search for a new music director and the renegotiation of the players' contract, which comes up for renewal this year. Management would presumably like to follow the New York Philharmonic and other orchestras in extending the traditional three-year contract to five years or more. The Philadelphia Orchestra could then negotiate the transition to the new hall and a new music director without the threat of labor disputes.
Philadelphia's Regional Performing Arts Center highlights America's increasing recognition of the arts as an essential part of a city's makeup. From Los Angeles to Newark to Miami, the arts are touted for their potential economic benefit, so that community leaders without a specific interest in the arts, like Mr. Rouse and Mr. Rendell, are stepping forward like Renaissance dukes to support them.
But in order for a center to live up to this economic potential, there has to be creative excitement as well. And while Philadelphia administrators focus on fund-raising in their efforts to complete the new center, it will take quality performances as well as attractive architecture to insure that Mr. Vinoly's cello-shaped hall and airy atrium join the Academy on the list of Philadelphia's most-beloved buildings.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
Attracting Industries From Manhattan to Jersey City

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
THE PATH trains run literally in the back yard of the old industrial building at 190 Baldwin Street, and the owners of the now-empty structure hope to use that proximity to transportation to attract printers and other graphic arts companies that are being squeezed out of lower Manhattan.
This is not the Jersey City of the Hudson River waterfront, where developers like Hartz Mountain and the Lefrak Organization are putting up new Class A buildings to attract financial companies with the lure of large floorplates, up-to-the-minute telecommunications and fantastic views of New York. 
 This building is near the top of the hill that most of the city is perched on, with no view except the aging apartment buildings and two-family houses that make up the neighborhood. The attractions of 190 Baldwin are strictly utilitarian: sturdy, reinforced concrete floors that can support 250 to 300 pounds per square foot, and four freight elevators that can lift 5,000 pounds apiece. The building has 70,000 square feet of space.
The comfort of being only a few PATH stops from their old locations in Manhattan may be more psychological than anything else, said executives of Crown Properties, the owner of the building. "Most of those printers don't know about the industrial space that's available in Jersey City," said Douglas Kanter, one of the principals in the firm. "It's almost like they need a passport to come out here."
But economic pressures, and especially the annual cost per square foot of renting space, have a way of severing old emotional ties, Crown executives say. "In New York they are paying on the order of $10 a foot, but in Jersey City its more like $5 a foot," said Warren Waters, another principal.
Although no leases have been signed at the Baldwin Street building or another the company is marketing at 1561 Kennedy Boulevard, the Crown executives said they have been actively showing the buildings to prospective tenants that have included printers and engravers. Speaking of the Baldwin Street structure, Mr. Waters said: "We may call it the Graphic Arts building if things work out."
Printers and allied trades are good, stable tenants because relocation is difficult. Moving means transporting and reassembling machines that are as large and heavy as they are expensive and delicate. "These people definitely have a long-term attitude," Mr. Waters said. "They want 10- and 15-year leases."
A broker who recently arranged to move a printer from Manhattan to Jersey City is Benjamin H. Katz, who is with Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company. His client, Cunningham Graphic, is relocating from the old Port Authority building at 111 Eighth Avenue, at 16th Street, to 150,000 square feet at 5 Burma Road near the Liberty Science Center.
"Cunningham did not want to go far, so now they will be two miles from their existing location," Mr. Katz said.
This desire to be as close to the old location as possible is typical of companies leaving Manhattan the first time, said Frank Caccavo, a director in the northern New Jersey office of Cushman & Wakefield, the big real estate services company.
"As a general statement, Manhattan companies want to stay as close a possible -- they want to be near the tunnels," he said. "After the second or third iteration, then they will consider moving south or west."
Mr. Caccavo said more industrial companies are likely to head to New Jersey as owners of buildings like 111 Eighth Avenue replace them with computer-based operations capable of paying higher rent. "There is going to be a significant wave of transactions over the next two years as leases roll over," he said. "The owners have already given them notice, and they are out here looking."
The increasing interest in industrial properties in New Jersey comes at a time when the geographical and transportation advantages of the state's older cities are being rediscovered. In one of the biggest industrial leases of last year, Marcal Paper company took 260,000 square feet on Getty Avenue in Paterson, a city once almost left for dead.
"ALL the industrial markets in New Jersey are enjoying a tightening of vacancy," Mr. Caccavo said. According to a year-end report by Cushman & Wakefield, the vacancy rate for industrial property declined to 7 percent in the northern part of the state, while annual rents increased by 6.8 percent to an average of $5.20 a square foot.
Although their center city locations will probably make the Crown properties more attractive to manufacturers than distributors, they are nonetheless part of a market that is heavily oriented toward warehousing.
"New Jersey, due to its central location within the northeast corridor of Boston to Washington, its vast interstate highway infrastructure and its access to the deep water port of the Port of Newark and Elizabeth remains an ideal location for warehouse distribution," according to the Cushman & Wakefield report.
A similar report by another real estate services company, Grubb & Ellis, notes that over 60 million consumers in 12 states are an overnight's drive from New Jersey.
Although industrial properties in Jersey City are less glamorous than the waterfront, the two are connected in reality, Mr. Katz said. Printers, companies that service business machines and provide telecommunications services need to be close to their more glamorous customers, but cannot afford the mid-$20's annual rents per square foot that prevail along the Hudson River.
"The waterfront is off limits to anything that is not expensive," said Mr. Waters. "Users who cannot afford $25 a square foot have to come to places like Journal Square and JFK Boulevard." Journal Square is the symbolic heart of Jersey City and is not far from the Baldwin Street property.
Mr. Katz said the growing number of immigrants in New York from Asian and Caribbean countries is increasing demand for industrial space to warehouse food imported from those regions. And importers of perishable foods need to cluster near the port and the airport to quickly retrieve their cargoes and get them to their ultimate destinations.
"There are a lot of food companies that want to be close to the Holland Tunnel for the access to lower Manhattan," Mr. Katz said. "It's too bad there are not more buildings available." He said activity in Jersey City may push redevelopment south, to Bayonne.
Indeed, the shortage of available space in more established areas is prompting some businesses to look in areas previously shunned, including the once-industrial south side of Newark.
"Newark has the best logistical services of any place in the state," said Joseph R. Romano, executive vice president of the New Jersey offices of Grubb & Ellis. "It's got the port, the airport, train lines, highways and the access to New York. That's giving people incentives to overcome the negatives, which are mostly imaginary anyway." Nevertheless, fear of crime is an issue for some companies.
Mr. Caccavo said that "Newark has a phenomenal geographic location, and the growth of business at the airport is causing people to look at neighborhoods they did not want to look at before."
Real estate executives said the success of the Newark arts center, which draws in people who live in suburbs, and efforts to establish minor league baseball and shift the Nets basketball team to the city have done much to improve its image.
In Jersey City, an earlier development by Crown's affiliate, Miller Construction Company, called the Montgomery Industrial Center, has been largely filled with food-related companies. They include Jetro Cash & Carry, a wholesaler for small grocery stores, Jamac Frozen Food and Wei-Chuan, U.S.A., a distributor of canned goods.
Mr. Waters said that as long as the economy remains strong, he expects a steady flow of tenants coming out of Manhattan, as well as companies from outside the region seeking locations close to the city. Because clearing land to build is difficult in a densely packed place like Jersey City, he said, Crown is likely to acquire older buildings.
"We're interested in buying, but we are selective," he said. "We want buildings that are in good shape that tenants can use almost immediately." For example, he said no structural work was needed on the Baldwin Street building.
"I see us as acquirers over the next 10 years," he said.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 4; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1451 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Opening the World of Business to Children

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
IT started with a quarter. Karen Tenenbaum's daughter, Allison, put the coin in a vending machine. Out dropped a plastic egg with a fake quarter inside. Allison, then 6, was thrilled. But Mrs. Tenenbaum, 39, is a tax lawyer and an accountant. She was "horrified," she said.
"I couldn't believe she thought she had a good value," she said. "I had to do something to teach children about money." 
 A lemonade stand just wouldn't do.
Mrs. Tenenbaum approached the assistant superintendent for instruction at the Levittown School District, who hooked her up with the Southeast Nassau Partnership for Change, a consortium of nine public school districts and of business partners and community leaders. One meeting led to another.
The result was Commerce Plaza, the Children's Business Center, a school-to-career program. A step beyond the take your daughters to work day concept, it is a virtual village, a scaled-down, student version of the working world. After learning the principles of business in class, fifth graders fill out job applications, then take a field trip to a simulated mini-mall for a hands-on introduction to the free enterprise system.
Mrs. Tenenbaum's economic laboratory will be ready for Long Island schoolchildren this fall. She has a 14-member board of directors, architectural drawings, a planning board, an eight-week curriculum and help from local businesses. The European American Bank, which will be the host of a student-run branch, donated $25,000 to the project; Xerox gave $10,000. The model is based on Enterprise Village, a 20,000-square-foot educational facility in Largo, Fla.
Last week, the Plainedge school district came to terms with the consortium on a temporary space to accommodate 8 to 10 pint-sized businesses. Though the day trips are geared to fifth graders, the center will be open to students at any level in all of Long Island's 127 school districts.
And Nassau County has jumped on the bandwagon to have Navy Building 14, which is Federal property, converted for use by Commerce Plaza. "It would make a logical adjunct to museum row," said Dave Vieser, press secretary to the Nassau County Executive, Thomas Gulotta, who has written to Senator Charles E. Schumer and Representative Carolyn McCarthy about the project.
High school youngsters will serve as mentors, said Ellen Krammer, administrative director of the Farmingdale school district, who helped develop the curriculum. Middle school children will staff kiosks, selling beaded bracelets, potholders and other entrepreneurial products. Kindergarteners start learning the basics of profit and loss.
"If they could do it in Florida, why can't we do it on Long Island?" said Mrs. Tenenbaum. She runs her East Meadow practice and recently founded Money Masters Inc., a private company, to teach children about money through CD-Roms, toys and books. And Allison, now 10, has a sometimes-thriving neighborhood business selling rocks.
"What better way to teach somebody than to have them do it?" Mrs. Tenenbaum said of Commerce Plaza. "We want them to experience the world of work. Children see their parents leave in the morning and go to work, but do they really know what they are doing once they are there?"
So the students will learn how to budget, write checks and purchase inventory. To simulate reality, they'll stop at the bank to apply for a loan, then meet with an under-aged real-estate agent to sign a lease.
Crews from a power and light company will have meters to read. Telephone company employees will install lines and create a directory. There will be a mayor, a warehouse with stock clerks, managers and bookkeepers running retail shops, a fast-food restaurateur and, no doubt, a lawyer. Meanwhile, reporters will scramble for newspaper stories, disk jockeys will spin out tunes from a radio station and a roving television reporter will record the scene.
"They are making decisions," Mrs. Tenenbaum said. "They are using math skills, they are using reading skills. They are applying everything they learned in school in a way they never had to apply it before. By the end of the day, the children understand the ethics of working. They have realized either a profit or a loss."
The school-to-work initiative began in 1994 with the School-to-Work Opportunities Act, a federally financed program that funnels grant money over five years to states and local partnerships to help bridge the gap between education and employment. Developing workplace skills and learning about careers starts as young as kindergarten.
Long Island's three school-to-career partnerships have received more than $2.6 million of a $60.3 million five-year grant from New York State. Of the Southeast Nassau Partnership's $900,000 in planning and implementation grants, about $40,000 has gone into Commerce Plaza, which is only one of the consortiums six initiatives, said Mark Wenzel, project director of the Partnership for Change.
"Children are always asking, 'Why am I learning this?' The answer is very obvious when you get to Commerce Plaza," Mrs. Tenenbaum said. "They are all skills that you need every day of your life. It's helping Long Island business. We're training tomorrow's work force."
 
New Village Hall
No one doubted that Kings Point needed a new village hall. No one even quarreled over the extra $60 to $75 annually per house in property taxes the proposed $3.2 million new building would cost.
The only question was what the new village hall -- at 12,000 square feet not much larger than many homes in the surrounding residential neighborhood -- would look like.
"This place is literally rotting away," said Michael Kalnick, Mayor of this village of 4,900 at the tip of the Great Neck peninsula, standing in the shabby courtroom of his current headquarters during a break in a recent board of trustees meeting. "If we don't do something quickly, it's going to fall down around us. Something has to be done."
Not long ago, a police officer fell through a hole in the floor of the village hall, a 1920's Dutch colonial house built for Walter Chrysler's daughter next to his estate, now the United States Merchant Marine Academy. A stop sign now covers the hole.
The building houses the village's police department, courthouse and administrative offices. It was last renovated back in the 60's, when Mr. Kalnick's father, Benjamin Kalnick, was Mayor.
So Mr. Kalnick did what his father had once done. He called in an architect and fellow Kings Point resident named Spector.
"It's a giveaway project," said Michael Spector, president of the Spector Group, the North Hills architecture firm that has designed almost a third of a billion dollars' worth of Long Island buildings. "I live here. I said I would do it as long as it was fun."
His father, Charles Spector, reworked the old village hall.
That building, the younger Mr. Spector concluded, was functionally obsolete and couldn't possibly be saved. It would be easier to tear it down and start from scratch. So he designed a new village hall to be situated on an open tract of land across the street from the old one, closer to the main road. A parking lot would replace the razed facility.
And the new design? "It's a village hall, it's not a house," Mr. Spector said of his one-story contemporary design with a series of pyramid-like peaks and a 35-foot communications tower. "It will emit that feeling of security, not aloofness. Not commercial, not glitzy, not to infringe on the psychological or visual environment around it."
Not according to Don Dillon, an architect and jazz musician who lives across the street from the site, who liked the interiors but thought the building needed a more countrified appearance. Like a house. So he redrew Mr. Spector's elevation with a softer, lower-pitched Prairie-style roof line and showed it to the board.
"People who live right in the immediate area wanted something that reflected a little more of a residential feeling rather than a real cold-faced commercial feeling," said Louise Sloane, who lives nearby and compared the rendering to a "car dealership in Palm Beach."
The communications tower, she said later, reminded her of a "concentration camp or a military installation."
"The main criticism was trying to maintain a more rural flavor to this portion of Kings Point that so many people seem to cherish," she said.
Mr. Spector said: "Everybody has different opinions," as he viewed the alternative rendering. "That's what makes horse racing."
The latest rendering, with the same roof line but a new, meandering driveway, will be unveiled at Monday night's board meeting. Construction is scheduled to begin this summer.

PUB-DATE: March 28, 1999

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3104 words

HEADLINE: Places of the Heart;
Historic Houses of Worship, From Soaring Spires to Simple Quaker Meeting Houses

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
BERNARD A. FLANAGAN fell in love with the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart when he was a child.
It was in the mid-1940's, and the cathedral was still incomplete after decades of on-again, off-again construction. Playing in a schoolyard in the shadow of the cathedral's shell, Mr. Flanagan often wondered what beauty and mystery dwelled within. In 1954, when the great bronze doors finally opened to reveal the completed church, he was awe-struck. 
 "It had a beautiful interior harmony," he says, recalling his first impression. "There was a sanctity. It did what a cathedral was supposed to do: impress people with the great dignity of God."
Mr. Flanagan, a 63-year old offset operator in the print shop of the Newark Library and a devout Catholic, has never lost his special feeling for the cathedral, and for 20 years has been giving regular tours, even though he moved out of the parish 18 years ago. "It's like giving something I love away, and by teaching other people to love it, I'm helping to protect its heritage," he said.
Each year 11,000 people visit the cathedral, the spiritual center of the Archdiocese of Newark and one of the finest examples of French Gothic architecture in the Western Hemisphere. It was designated a minor basilica -- or church of special prominence -- by Pope John Paul II during a visit in 1995.
There are numerous other houses of worship in New Jersey, some 4,180 churches and synagogues alone, according to "Churches and Church Membership in the United States 1990," that are architecturally or historically significant or have a special place in the hearts of the people like Bernard Flanagan, who visit them to pray and seek solace.
From synagogues to mosques, from simple Quaker meetinghouses in the southwestern part of the state to the stalwart Dutch Reformed Churches of the northeast, from majestic cathedrals like Sacred Heart to the most humble storefront churches, these houses of worship reflect the state's racial, ethnic and religious diversity and a yearning to be one with a greater being.
Robert C. Broderick in "Historic Churches of the United States," (Wildred Funk, New York, 1958) wrote that houses of worship, more than any other buildings, express a society's most worthy aspirations. "They are not only an expression of the artistic conception of any point in our history," Mr. Broderick wrote. "Sociologically, some historians maintain, churches provide a key to the quality of life and thought in any community."
But in these rapidly changing times, the existence of many is threatened, especially older structures dating back hundreds of years, victims of the weight of time itself and the high cost of maintaining them. Fire, vandalism and changing demographics have caused many to be abandoned, demolished or put to secular use. And with them have gone valuable human and social services sheltered in them.
Each house of worship has its own story; and each sect has struggled -- some more than others -- to put down roots in an often hostile environment.
There is, for instance, James Caldwell, the minister at the First Presbyterian Church in Elizabeth and a fervent critic of British rule who carried loaded pistols to the pulpit with him.
Or the countless Irish laborers who gave their meager earnings from the silk mills and train works to build the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist in the old Dublin section of Paterson, a church whose parishioners now are predominantly Hispanic.
These stories are as much a part of the fabric of these places as the worn wood and the stone of which they are made.
 There are about 140 religious properties in New Jersey listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart being one of them. But there are only three New Jersey churches that have attained the status of National Historic Landmark.
One of them is the "new" St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Burlington, a one-story, brownstone building with spire and Gothic details, dating to between 1846 and 1854. It stands next to one of the oldest existing churches in the state, "old" St. Mary's Episcopal Church, a one-story brick structure that was built in 1703.
THE other landmarks include Grace Church in Newark (1847) and All Saints Church in Navesink (1864).
The three were designated national landmarks because of their "architectural design significance," and all were designed by Richard Upjohn, said William C. Bolger, national historic program manager of the northeast region of the National Parks Service in Philadelphia.
Upjohn was a devout Anglican who borrowed heavily from the style of the 13th and 14th centuries to design about 150 churches, including Trinity Church in Manhattan.
A church must be an act of devotion and that devotion "must be mixed in the very essence of the mortar between its stones," wrote the architect John Stewart Detlie in "Religious Buildings for Today," (An Architectural Record Book, F.W. Dodge Corporation, 1957).
The Dutch were the earliest settlers in New Jersey, getting a foothold in 1660 in Jersey City, where they established the Bergen Reformed Church of the Dutch Reformed denomination, "the oldest organized church congregation west of the Hudson River," according to Ellis L. Derry in his two-volume history, "Old and Historic Churches of New Jersey."
Better known as Old Bergen Church, the first structure was built in 1680. The current church, a brick and brown sandstone structure with Doric portico and Greek Revival details, was built in 1841.
In 1664 the English wrested control of New Amsterdam from the Dutch, and the first English settlement in New Jersey was established in 1675 at Salem by Quakers who in 1681 bought a log house as a permanent location for their meetings.
The existing Salem Friends Meeting House, a brick two-story rectangular structure, was built in 1772. Western New Jersey was predominantly Quaker for years, and many meeting houses were built in the southern and western sections of the state.
The oldest Episcopal parish in New Jersey where services have continually been held is St. Peter's in Perth Amboy, Mr. Derry wrote. It held its first service in 1685 and built its first church in 1721. William Franklin, Benjamin Franklin's son who was the governor of the Province of New Jersey, was a vestryman. The current St. Peter's was built in 1852.
By the mid-1700's half of the residents of New Jersey were English, with roots in Scotland, Ireland or Wales and with sizable numbers of Dutch and German descendants and smaller numbers of Swedish and French people, according to Richard P. McCormick, in the pamphlet, "New Jersey: A Student's Guide to Localized History," Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, 1965).
The major religious denominations, Mr. McCormick wrote, were Presbyterian, Quaker, Baptist, Dutch Reformed and Anglican with some German Lutheran, Swedish Luther and Methodist congregations.
Ellis Derry wrote in the second volume of his "Old and Historic Churches of New Jersey," (Plexus Publishing Inc., Medford, 1994) that religious liberty in the Colonies meant freedom from a state-controlled church. In Europe, he wrote, people were required to follow the teachings of the church of their country, but, even after fleeing this restriction, many continued the practice in the new world. Newark, for example, was founded as a theocracy by Connecticut Congregationalists in 1666.
But New Jersey, along with Rhode Island, Pennsylvania and Delaware resisted establishing a state church. Mr. Derry explained. "Despite these high principles, religious toleration did not always exist in New Jersey."
Indeed, it wasn't until a new State constitution was drafted in 1844 that Catholics were allowed to run for public office, according to "New Jersey: A Guide to Its Present and Past," compiled by the Federal Writers Project of the Works Progress Administration, 1936.
The first Catholic church in the state, was not built in Trenton until 1814. The oldest Catholic church still in use is St. John's Church in Newark, built in 1828 and enlarged over the years after Irish immigrants began pouring into the city.
In 1858, after towers were erected, the brown stone church in the English Norman style was dedicated, the first consecrated Catholic church in New Jersey, according to Mr. Derry.
A year later, Bishop James Roosevelt Bayley, the first bishop of the Newark diocese, commissioned the construction of Sacred Heart Cathedral, which would not be finished for nearly 100 years.
The congregation of St. John's has dwindled to a handful, but since 1974 its mission of feeding the hungry has increased the number of people it touches. And for several years, its pastor has been holding a noon mass for business people in a room in the Gateway Center office complex.
Jewish people did not begin arriving in any number until the 1800's. The first congregation in the State dates to 1847 when a group of German Jewish businessmen established B'nai Jeshurun in Paterson. A year later, another B'nai Jeshurun was established in Newark.
Both congregations conducted services in a series of rented spaces before they could build their own synagogues. In 1878, the Paterson congregation, which was incorporated as an Orthodox Jewish synagogue but later became part of the reform movement, acquired its first permanent building on Van Houten Street.
But businessman, philanthropist and mayor, Nathan Barnert, after whom the synagogue came to be named, contributed land for a newer grander synagogue, one in the Moorish style, which was built in 1892 on Broadway and Straight Street.
PRESIDENT WILLIAM McKINLEY, whose vice president, Garrett A. Hobart, came from Paterson, visited Mayor Barnert in April 1900. He attended the Passover service at the temple, passing through a crowd of a thousand people who had gathered to see him, said Dorothy Starr, who is writing a history of Barnert Temple.
In 1965 the congregation opened a contemporary modern brick building on Derrom Avenue near Broadway that was designed by the architect Percival Goodman, dean of the graduate school of architecture at Columbia University. The old synagogue on Broadway was demolished in 1971.
Among other things, Mr. Goodman was renowned for designing the first truly modern synagogue in the country, Congregation B'nai Israel in Millburn in the early 1950's.
Avram Kampf in "Contemporary Synagogue Art," (Union of American Hebrew Congregations) called the Millburn synagogue "a significant milestone in synagogue art and architecture in the United States," because it was the first time an architect called on modern artists in the design of a house of worship in which esthetics was paramount.
The B'nai Jeshurun congregation in Newark built three synagogues in the city to keep up with growth, one at Washington Street and Maiden Lane in 1858, a second on Washington Street near William Street in 1868, and the third on High Street and Waverly Avenue in 1915.
In 1888, it became the first congregation in New Jersey to be admitted to the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the umbrella organization for reform congregations. In the 1960's, the congregation began looking for a site outside Newark and in 1968 built its current synagogue on South Orange Avenue in Short Hills.
The synagogue, one of the more spectacular modern synagogues in New Jersey -- a brown brick building with a stained glass window that rises its full height of 80 feet -- was designed by Pietro Belluschi, the dean of the School of Architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
"It's monumental; it's enormous in scale and size," said James Goldstein, a member of the congregation who is a partner in Goldstein Partnership Architects of West Orange. "Yet it has a transcendent quality about it: the use of the materials and spectacular stained glass, the sense of daylight permeating the sanctuary."
The Paterson congregation moved in 1987 into a new building on Route 208 in Franklin Lakes in neighboring Bergen County. This synagogue too, like the one it left in Paterson, was designed by Mr. Goodman.
The synagogue on Derrom Avenue that had opened in 1965 was sold. In 1990 it became the Islamic Center of Passaic County, one of nine mosques in Paterson alone, according to its president, Riad Mustafa.
Exterior modifications were minimal: a metal dome and a crescent on the side, Mr. Mustafa said.
Interior changes were more extensive: carpeting was laid, separate sections were built for men and women and adjustments were made so worshipers faced Mecca. A bookstore was added, dedicated to Islamic teaching in Arabic, Spanish and English.
The Islamic Center can hold 2,000 people, most of whom come from Passaic County.
"It's an excellent building," Mr. Moustafa said. "It's very sound and very beautiful."
Robert W. Craig, principal historic preservation specialist for the New Jersey Historic Preservation Office of the state' Department of Environmental Protection, says there is a challenge to congregations to maintain their buildings, which can be costly. "I sense that's a widespread situation," Mr. Craig said.
It is especially true as poorer congregations take over houses of worship from more prosperous ones, said Bob Jaeger, co-director of Partners for Sacred Places, a national nonprofit organization based in Philadelphia that helps congregations and communities maintain and use their houses of worship.
"The new congregation does not have the economic resources that their predecessors did and so repairs are put off in favor of day to day needs," Mr. Jaeger said. "This can accumulate from decade to decade."
Eventually, by removing a tower here, a window there, and closing off a section of a church, the whole building ends up being lost, he said.
"It is only after the building is gone that people recognize what has been lost -- something far more valuable than a place of worship," wrote Marilyn J. Chiat in "America's Religious Architecture: Sacred Places for Every Community," (Preservation Press; John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1996.) "Often it was the cornerstone of a neighborhood."
New Jersey is blessed with fine houses of worship. Amid the hustle and bustle of lawyers and prosecutors and defendants moving in and out of the Bergen County Court House in Hackensack, there is the quiet presence of the First Reformed Church, or Church on the Green as it is called.
It is the oldest congregation in Bergen County dating from 1686. The first church was built in 1696. The current building, in the Dutch Colonial style with a steeple of octagonal design, was built in 1791 with many of the original stones of the old church placed in the east outer wall. In 1848 and 1869 the building was lengthened. Many pioneers are buried in the church yard, including Enoch Poor, one of Washington's generals, and a statue of him stands near the green.
Then there is the Quaker meeting house in Crosswicks where Hessians took quarters; there is still a canon ball in its north wall.
There is Old Tennent Church on the Monmouth Battle Field in Freehold, where legend has it that Molly Pitcher took her fallen husband's place behind a cannon.
There is St. James Chapel in Long Branch known as "the Church of the Presidents" because seven of them -- Grant, Hayes, Garfield, Arthur, Harrison, McKinley and Wilson -- worshiped there while taking a day at the shore. Garfield died across the street.
And for Bernard Flanagan, there is the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart which has so filled his life. On a recent Sunday he spoke its facts and praises to a small group of tourists.
He told them it is 365 feet long and 165 feet wide, the fifth largest cathedral in the country. The foundations were begun in 1898, the cornerstone laid in 1899, and work ended in 1927. It did not resume until 1950. The nave and ambulatory columns are of granite with granite capitals. Indiana limestone is used throughout, creating a brilliant lightness in the church. He told them each of three rose windows had approximately 50,000 pieces of glass.
And afterward, one of those who took the tour, Ralph Allora, a lawyer from Little Falls who thought to take his mother-in-law to visit the Cathedral for the first time, said: "It's inspiring because it shows what can be done through faith. The people who worked on the cathedral, it wasn't just a job for them. It was devotion to make it the structure it is."
 
Saving Churches, and Souls, Along the Way
It once was called the High Street Presbyterian Church, built in 1850 in Newark, but since the mid-1940's it has been called St. James A.M.E. Church.
And like many old churches, it needed help if it was to continue to be a healthy building.
To the rescue came Annabelle Radcliffe-Trenner, an architect who works on restoring old buildings. Among her projects, besides other churches, is Morven, the former official residence of New Jersey's governors.
"I think the problem is there aren't many people helping these churches plan," said Ms. Radcliffe-Trenner of Princeton. "Churches like St. James get so wrapped up with outreach and providing community services they don't have time to look up and see water pouring through the ceiling."
Bob Jaeger, co-director of Partners for Sacred Places, a national, non-profit group in Philadelphia devoted to helping congregations and communities save and actively use older religious properties, said this is a common problem.
"These buildings are in trouble, which means not only is the architecture at risk -- and this is what hits people in a neighborhood hard -- all the social programs that these buildings house are also at risk."
A survey by Partners, which it published last year as a pamphlet, "Sacred Places At Risk," found that the value of such services as day care, food and shelter for the poor and after school programs to a community averages $140,000 a year per congregation. Mr. Jaeger said that this is triple the annual budget of many congregations.
The survey also found that the average congregation faces from $200,000 to $300,000 in repairs.
Several weeks ago, Ms. Radcliffe-Trenner, an Englishwoman who studied architecture with a specialty in preservation at Edinburgh University in Scotland, finished $1.25 million worth of restoration work at St. James, paid for in part by the New Jersey Historic Trust and through funds raised by the congregation.
A new slate roof was put on, the stonework was stabilized and the sanctuary was re-opened. A Tiffany rose window is still under repair. GEORGE JAMES
