HEADLINE: Returning Life to an Urban Neighborhood

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
WASHINGTON PARK, nestled in a low-income neighborhood on Bridgeport's East Side, embodies much of what the city's cognoscenti say is its metropolitan character. Once the crown jewel of neighborhood parks in the Park City, its faded glory speaks of lost wealth, sophistication, industrial might and fashionable style, and the inimitable P. T. Barnum, perhaps the city's most famous personage.
In the latter half of the 1800's and the first decade of the 1900's, Washington Park was one of the most desirable places to live between Boston and New York. Circling the seven-acre park is as fine a collection of grand Victorian houses as can be found in Connecticut, a result of a successful, early example of visionary urban planning. 
 Time has not been kind to the park and its environs. Most of the 20th century has seen it slipping into decay, a process greatly accelerated in the last dozen years by the forces of drugs and poverty. But a new project has recently begun to restore some of the historical glamour of the park as well as its economic health.
The Washington Park Association, a neighborhood residents' organization, plans to renovate 10 of the structures with painstaking historical accuracy, supported by Federal tax credits, government and foundation grants, and a bank loan. When completed, the 10 buildings will offer 35 apartments for rent, and their residents will be able to get a sense of the high style of the Victorian Age of a century ago.
"The buildings will look pretty much the way they were the day they were built," said Charles Brilvitch, the city's historian who helped prepared the project's application to the Department of the Interior for tax credits.
Restoration of the buildings will take a great deal of work; some, for example, have been severely damaged by fires. The total project is estimated at $4.8 million, about $137,000 per apartment.
"All of the buildings have unusual hardwood detail woodwork that's very difficult to replicate these days," said David Barbour, the project's architect. Thick layers of lead-based paint must be stripped off chestnut moldings, entryway grand staircases must be both restored, asbestos siding must be torn off one house and replaced with pastel stucco, and clay tiles must be found to replace missing and broken tiles on the roof of another building.
The original color schemes -- vivid golds, greens, reds, browns and burgundy -- will be restored. "It will visually be quite stimulating, and historically accurate," Mr. Barbour said.
Robert Halstead, president of the association, said that the park and its neighborhood "are so historically significant, so special, that we just can't let it go." The first of the properties, the Fitzgerald House at 480 East Washington Avenue, is already under renovation.
The Washington Park neighborhood was originally conceived of by Barnum, who had a vision of constructing a "New City on the Pequonnock." In 1851 the showman bought 225 acres of undeveloped land across the Pequonnock River from the city with money he had made from his traveling shows and exhibitions, laid out the community's streets and subdivided the land, reserving a square in the center for the park.
To induce its rapid development, Barnum sold every other building lot at the price the land cost him, requiring that houses, stores or other buildings constructed on them meet high standards for design and construction quality. He also built a covered bridge over the river to allow traffic to the city's business district.
Barnum hired a young Bridgeport engineer named James C. Lane to design the park as a formal English country square, with a focal point in the center and trees planted in matched pairs. (Lane later served as a general in the Civil War.)
After a few years, many large stylish houses had been built, greatly increasing the value of the lots that Barnum still owned, and he wound up richer than ever. He later said he made more than $1 million on the development.
"It was the high-class neighborhood of Bridgeport," Mr. Brilvitch said. Many residents were prominent business executives, manufacturers and professionals. Among them were George and Joseph Irving, brothers who emigrated from Ireland during the potato famine and made a fortune as carriage makers.
The architecture reflected every high style of the times, including Victorian gothic, Italianate, French Second Empire, Georgian and New York-style brownstone rowhouses. "There are 10 different kinds of Victorian architecture there, all facing out on the park," noted Mr. Halstead.
A bandstand was built in the center of the park where the Wheeler and Wilson sewing machine company's band would play popular music every Saturday evening during the warm months. Local residents would dress up in their finest clothes and stroll on the walks amidst the elms. "It was the picture of refinement," Mr. Brilvitch observed.
The neighborhood began to slip out of fashion around World War I. Victorian architecture went out of style and the invention of the automobile allowed factory owners and other wealthy people to live out of town and commute to their offices. In the 1920's and 30's, new owners carved the grand, old houses into apartments and rooming houses to capitalize on the fast-growing city's housing shortage.
After World War II, the middle class began moving to the suburbs. They were replaced by lower-income families, particularly Puerto Ricans and Southeast Asians, who arrived just as most of the factories that had sustained the economy of Bridgeport's East Side closed or moved elsewhere.
The recent history of Washington Park is told in microcosm by the fate of the Fitzgerald House. Built in 1901 by Dr. Edward Fitzgerald, it was bequeathed to the United Way of Eastern Fairfield County by his widow in the 1970's. In 1977 the house was sold for $18,300 to an immigrant resettlement agency.
In the real estate boom of the mid-1980's, the East Side attracted owners who bought properties there as investments. Robert Ryffel and Richard Hoefle bought the Fitzgerald House in 1985 for $65,000. Mr. Ryffel bought out his partner in 1989, taking a $110,000 mortgage from Goldome Realty Credit Corporation, an out-of-state lender.
But the crack epidemic of the 1980's attracted street gangs to the neighborhood. Washington Park became a market for drugs and prostitution. The Cat Posse, a Jamaican gang, set up headquarters in an apartment fronting on the park. At the same time, the air went out of the real estate bubble, and East Side property values crashed. Absentee owners, whose mortgages now exceeded the value of their properties, abandoned them to squatters and criminals, who tore out the plumbing to sell as scrap, further reducing their value.
Mr. Ryffel finally joined them after confronting a trespasser in the Fitzgerald House. Both drew weapons and Mr. Ryffel shot the other man dead. His creditor foreclosed on the property in 1995 and resold it to East Side Properties, an investment group of Lebanese immigrants, for $19,000, about 17 percent of what Goldome had loaned Mr. Ryffel.
"That was definitely casino speculation," said Ray Hutchinson, vice president of the Washington Park Association. East Side Properties, in fact, bought up several buildings around the park, gambling on the prospects that a casino would be built at the site of the Bridgeport dog track, a few blocks away. But the casino was not approved, giving the association the opportunity to buy them from the investment group.
"It was better that somebody owned them," observed Mr. Halstead. He said several other properties in the association's project had been abandoned by their owners, whose creditors refused to foreclose, making it difficult to establish clear titles for the properties. New state laws had to be passed to allow the city to acquire them through condemnation so they could be transferred to the association for $1.
Acquisition and bureaucratic costs were underwritten by government and foundation grants and gifts from philanthropists, but the main portion of the construction costs were met using a $3.5 million loan from a Chase Manhattan Bank subsidiary, the Chase Community Development Corporation. Once the project is completed, it will receive Federal tax credits from the National Equity Fund that will leave $790,000 to be paid back to Chase over 18 years.
David Watson, vice president of Chase Community Development, said the bank has financed other projects of the kind in New Haven, Hartford and Stamford. Although the Washington Park project has the smallest number of apartments of the four, it has the greatest historical significance.
At the Fitzgerald House, Washington Park Association officials laughed as they recalled their struggles to keep the project going. Often, people working on it proceeded simply with promises that they would be paid someday, said Frank Callahan, the project manager. They keep hitting financial and bureaucratic hurdles, and somehow managed to clear them all, he said.
"We were like Mr. Magoo," said Mr. Halstead, "walking on beams, and when he gets to the end of one beam another would come along."
The city's planning and economic development director, Michael Freimuth, said he thought that for two reasons the Washington Park Association's project would succeed where other efforts at renewal of the park area had failed. One is that the renovated buildings will be owned by the association, people who live there instead of absentee developers "who found it much easier to walk away when the going got rough."
The other reason is that the effort is comprehensive and concentrated, unlike the piecemeal, scattered-site projects of the past. "This eliminates the problem where recently renovated buildings are worn down by distressed properties next door," Mr. Freimuth said.
Mr. Halstead said the association also intends to use one of the apartments in the renovated buildings to house a neighbor-to-neighbor helping hand office. Our aspiration is to see an office there that will serve the people's needs, so that people will be glad to live there, not feel like they're stuck there," he said.
The association wants Washington Park to be "all the things a city can be," he said. "This is a miracle project."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 3433 words

HEADLINE: In All 5 Boroughs, A Robust Market

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
FROM the heights of Manhattan's luxury towers to the wood-framed and aluminum-sided homes of its more proletarian neighborhoods, New York City's residential real estate market saw prices continue to rise last year -- riding the crest of the nation's record-breaking housing expansion and the region's ongoing rebound from the moribund days of the early 1990's.
The residential market throughout the five boroughs last year was one in which the old real estate adage about location being of prime concern could well have been recoined: "Inventory! Inventory! Inventory!" 
 There just wasn't enough to go around. So prices climbed.
It is not as though sales volume was down. Sales in nearly every neighborhood were certainly good, and in many excellent, but they could have been better had there been more listings. Many buyers -- from those with considerable assets to those less affluent, yet confident of a vibrant economy and hoping to avail themselves of some of the lowest mortgage rates in decades -- were frustrated by the lack of homes to see.
Brokers -- who, of course, would savor a universal game of musical chairs in which everybody got up and moved -- were both stirred and stymied by the possibilities of a hot market in which, at the same time, it was so difficult to nail down more deals because sellers could be so choosey.
The sellers counted their blessings -- until confronted by the cost of their next purchase.
Average prices in every apartment category in Manhattan except studios were up in 1998, according to one of the most comprehensive surveys of the market, the Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report, which looked at co-op, condominium and town house transactions. Costs for the most expansive residences -- those with three bedrooms or four or more bedrooms -- bounded up by 18.2 percent and 15.7 percent, respectively.
The average price for a three-bedroom below 96th Street on the East Side and 116th Street on the West Side, the report showed, rose from $1,296,964 in 1997 to $1,532,981 in '98. For the 156 deals in the four-plus bedroom category, the average price rose from $2,966,068 to $3,431,469.
And, according to data compiled by Case Shiller Weiss, which conducts an annual repeat-sales survey, prices appreciated last year in every one of the 130 ZIP-code areas in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island (the survey does not include Manhattan). In 1997, by comparison, 14 areas saw prices drop, and in 1996 the number was 30.
Leading the city's upsurge outside of Manhattan last year, the Case Shiller survey showed, was the Bronx, where 14 of the borough's 25 ZIP-code areas saw prices rise by 10 to 12 percent and another five jumped at least 12 percent. In Brooklyn, 18 of the 36 ZIP-code areas experienced price increases of at least 8 percent.
So while, by just about any measure, 1998 was a robust year for New York City's residential market, the lack of inventory -- a condition bemoaned by broker after broker -- and the upward squeeze on prices kept a lid on many people's hopes.
In what one real estate executive labeled "bracket creep," prices once commonplace in the city's more expensive enclaves radiated through neighboring communities with a far-reaching ripple effect.
"What is driving the neighborhoods adjacent to prime brownstone Brooklyn is bracket creep," said Christopher Thomas, the William B. May Company's senior vice president for Brooklyn. "Since demand has so exceeded supply, and since so many people have unsuccessfully bid on property in neighborhoods of their first choice, they have seen prices rise beyond their threshold."
"So there are many, many buyers in the $600,000 to $800,000 range," Mr. Thomas said, "and that no longer buys a good house in Brooklyn Heights." The result, he said -- citing such areas as Boerum Hill and Prospect Heights -- "has been the gentrification of neighborhoods that people had not heretofore flocked to."
Even in poorer communities like Bedford-Stuyvesant and East New York, the effect has been felt. "Houses in certain areas of Bed-Stuy are going for between $250,000 and and $300,000," said Jacob Shayovitz, president of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors. And in the once embattled South Bronx, where bricked-up tenements have been bulldozed to make way for an increasing number of suburbanesque tracts, the price of a single-family home reached about $180,000 last year, according to one broker who conducts a detailed survey of the borough.
For many people, the consequences were considerable.
"Traditionally, home ownership has been the route by which people first amass assets," said Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. "These very high housing prices make it difficult for low- and middle-income households to begin their journey up that ladder."
To reach the first rung, said Mr. Shayovitz, "people have to stretch themselves."
Still, a lot of people -- whether on a national, regional or local level -- stretched in 1998, and records were set.
There were 4.78 million sales of existing homes in the nation last year, breaking the record of 4.21 million set in 1997, according to the National Association of Realtors. There were 888,000 sales of new homes last year, according to the Census Bureau, breaking the national record of 819,000 set in 1977. Consequently, the nation's home-ownership rate set a record, the Census Bureau reported, with 66.3 percent of all households owning their own homes.
E SSENTIALLY, for the housing industry, the economic and demographic stars were in full alignment," said James Hughes, dean of the Rutgers University School of Planning and Public Policy. New York City, Dr. Hughes said, "experienced strong income gains, reinforcing the basic trajectory of the economy."
Home-buying, obviously, is correlated to employment. In New York City, said John Weiting, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, 77,000 jobs were created last year, raising employment to 3,061,000. "That matched the job growth in 1997," Mr. Weiting said, "with the past two years marking the city's strongest job performance since 1951."
Equally obviously, home-buying is correlated to a propitious mortgage market. "Mortgage rates touched 31-year lows and climbed back only to 20-odd-year lows in the last 12 months," said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage statistics company in Butler, N.J. The rate dropped to 6.68 percent in October -- a low last hit in 1967. Last Wednesday, the rate stood at 7 percent.
And so, in virtually every neighborhood of the city, lots of people took the house-buying leap -- if they could see somewhere to land.
In those Manhattan locales where real estate prospects are tightly tethered to the quarterly report and the year-end bonus, the residential market weathered a chill last fall after the bottom dropped out the Russian economy, the so-called Asian contagion sent shudders through South America and, on Aug. 31, the Dow plunged 513 points, to 7,379. Virtually overnight, Manhattan's high-end buyers hit their pause buttons.
Savvy New Yorkers, however, seem to have soon seen the 513-point drop in perspective. For in fact, at the time, that 500-plus drop represented only a 6 percent decline in the Dow. And although there had been a 500-plus plunge 11 years earlier, on Oct. 19, 1987 -- so-called Black Monday -- the 508 points back then constituted a nose dive of 22.6 percent.
So the nation's economy, refocusing on the firmest fundamentals in decades, roared back in the fourth quarter of 1998, the Dow began flirting with the 10,000 mark and home-buying resurged.
"Everybody seems to have recovered their courage," said Clark Halstead, founder of the Halstead Property Company. "It's all psychological."
"The bidding wars, they're back," Mr. Halstead said, "and the prices being achieved are like the lead car at Indianapolis, with the rest of the market drafting -- that's an auto-racing term, where you get behind the leader and the air currents drag you along."
Dragged along, but also squeezed upward by the dearth of inventory.
Professor Schill at N.Y.U. pointed out that the city added roughly 120,000 households to its population between 1980 and 1996, but only 53,400 housing units, with the trend continuing over the last three years. "So demand has outstripped supply by more than 2 to 1," he said.
The crunch was indicated in the 1998 Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report. The report, prepared by the Miller Samuel appraisal company, surveyed 7,542 sales south of West 116th Street and East 96th Street, an increase of 4 percent over the 7,249 sales in 1997. The pattern of low inventory and high price, said Jonathan Miller, the president of Miller Samuel, was clear for all apartment sizes except studios.
In the one-bedroom category, sales inched up only 0.6 percent, from 2,709 to 2,725. "Yet the average price increased 14 percent, from $210,275 to $239,613," Mr. Miller said. "That reflects the lack of inventory."
In the two-bedroom category, sales declined 4.1 percent, from 2,951 to 2,829, but the average price increased 14.3 percent, from $529,479 to $605,312.
The three-bedroom market "showed a similar pattern," Mr. Miller said, posting a 2.7 percent decline in sales, from 367 to 357, and an 18.2 percent increase in average price, from $1,296,964 to $1,532,981.
And the number of sales for apartments with four-plus bedrooms increased 1.3 percent, from 154 to 156, but average prices jumped 15.7 percent, from $2,966,068 to $3,431,469.
The Elliman report's findings for Manhattan studios did not conform to the pattern, largely because of an influx of young buyers, particularly those flocking to jobs in the burgeoning financial and information-age industries of the downtown area. Studio sales increased 46 percent, from 933 in 1997 to 1,360 last year, while the average price declined 8.7 percent, from $132,195 to $120,676 -- "indicative of the wider price range and smaller size of studio apartments, especially those below $100,000," Mr. Miller said.
Divining real estate trends by the numbers is, at best, a murky exercise. To begin with, co-op sales are not officially recorded because, technically, they are securities transactions involving the selling of shares, and not transfers of title. Condominium sales, however, are officially recorded. As a result, studies of co-op data compiled by brokerage houses and appraisal concerns do not claim to include all transactions in the market. Still, the numbers, along with anecdotal impressions, can serve as barometers of market patterns.
Prices are "a moving target," said Barbara Corcoran, chairwoman of the brokerage that bears her name. "Whatever we were selling two months ago, we're now selling for 10 percent more."
"The song of last spring," Ms. Corcoran said, "was customers complaining about not seeing enough. This year, they complain about not seeing anything."
Groans are emanating from brokers, too, so many of them bobbing for the same apple at the same time. "Brokers aren't tripping over each other," Ms. Corcoran said, "they're knocking each other down: get into the apartment first, get the seller to sign. The reality is that it's so hard to get your teeth into that apple."
IF the northernmost reaches of Central Park used to be a sort of demarcation line for high-end Manhattan, the line is blurring.
R. Kenyatta Punter is president of the Greater Harlem Real Estate Board and of the brokerage that bears his name. There are homes in the area, Mr. Punter said, now listing for $650,000 to $700,000. "A single-family in Hamilton Heights," he said, "might have sold for $475,000 in 1997, but recently there was a sale on Hamilton Terrace for $650,000."
Asked what a city bus driver could do facing those elevated prices, Mr. Punter said there are new condominiums coming on line at about $225,000. "If you have a bus driver who makes $40,000 a year and his wife makes $35,000," he said, "you're talking about income that most banks will underwrite for that $225,000."
Farther north, in Washington Heights, said Gus Perry, owner of Stein-Perry Real Estate, "We're getting pretty pricey, too."
"Pretty much everything that was available in the early- to mid-90's has been absorbed up here," Mr. Perry said, "and prices have increased since 1996, I would say, by 30 to 40 percent." A two-and-a-half-bedroom co-op "with a river view in Castle Village, which is our best complex here in Hudson Heights -- that's our new tag for that area -- sold in '96 for $201,000. Today, it could certainly fetch over $300,000."
In Brooklyn, where he was forced by one client's sticker shock to calculate the costs of gentrification, Mr. Thomas of the William B. May Company called the market "twitchy, because deals are so fragile, hard to keep together."
"A seller who is thrilled to receive multiple, full-price offers the first day," Mr. Thomas said, "is confronted on the second day with the question, 'Where do I go from here?' -- literally -- and discovers that he will be bidding against the disappointed buyers who could not buy his house."
Neighborhoods increasingly farther afield from Brooklyn Heights have seen "startling increases" in prices in recent months, Mr. Thomas said.
"I went out with a client the other day to whom I had sold a house two years ago in Park Slope," he said. "I was showing him property in Fort Greene, where he had looked when I sold him his first house. Prices had more than doubled."
To prove that the jump was not an aberration, Mr. Thomas checked records and found that in early 1998, a four-story, two-family town house on Clinton Street in Brooklyn Heights sold for just under $1 million. "Now, the least expensive one in Brooklyn Heights is $1,150,000," he said.
In neighboring Cobble Hill, in the beginning of 1998, a four-story town house could be purchased for just under $800,000, Mr. Thomas said. Current offerings in Cobble Hill range from $1.1 million to $1.4 million.
And in Prospect Heights, on the east side of Flatbush Avenue, a town house sold last year for $525,000. "This week," Mr. Thomas said, "a similar house nearby listed at $750,000 and had several bids at at least its asking price."
There are three multiple listing services in Brooklyn, and no central data source. But another measure of the market, the Case Shiller survey, confirms the price surge.
The survey is based on a table showing the average price for all single-family homes sold in ZIP-code areas, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1998, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP-code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price the house brought the last time it sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1997. The 1998 prices for homes within each ZIP-code area were then compared with the estimated 1997 prices to compute the average change.
In Brooklyn, where there are 36 ZIP-code areas, the survey showed that one area saw prices rise 4 to 6 percent, 17 by 6 to 8 percent, 13 by between 8 and 10 percent and five by 10 to 12 percent.
Some of the steepest increases were recorded in some of the poorest neighborhoods, like East New York and Brownsville. And as Mr. Shayovitz, the president of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors, said, "Bed-Stuy is no longer considered a poorer section for the purposes of real estate."
Asked what people priced out of those neighborhoods do, Mr. Shayovitz said: "You buy in East Flatbush for $130,000; but they are going to be smaller-type houses, 18-footers."
The low-inventory, higher-price scenario played out in Queens, too.
The borough, which comes under the aegis of the Long Island Board of Realtors, saw sales slip to 3,617 last year from 3,804 in 1997, a 4.9 percent drop. The average price, however, rose by 9.3 percent, from $163,718 to $179,018.
Of the 57 ZIP-code areas in Queens, according to Case Shiller, two saw prices rise by up to 4 percent, 14 by between 4 and 6 percent, 21 by 6 to 8 percent, 18 by 8 to 10 percent and two by 10 to 12 percent.
Barbara Frechter, president of the Long Island Board of Realtors and owner of Glenjay Realty in Forest Hills, said that inventory has been so tight that, "just as an example, we had an open house on a Saturday and my partner had 60 sets of people show up."
According to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, which covers Queens, the median price (meaning half the sales are above that figure and half below) in Forest Hills was $238,000 in 1997 and $257,500 last year, an 8.1 percent increase. In Jackson Heights, the 1997 median was $206,000; last year it was $231,700, or 12.1 percent higher. And in Jamaica, the median price rose from $120,000 to $126,000, or 5 percent.
Gone are the days, Ms. Frechter said, when the co-ops of Queens "were crashing around us."
"So many buildings were in trouble five years ago, and you could buy a studio for $15,000," she said. "In Briarwood, there were so many foreclosures that the foreclosure price became the market price." Back then, the typical co-op in Queens sold for $30,000 or less, Ms. Frechter said, "and now they are probably up to $50ish."
If there is an anomaly in the city, it is Staten Island, with its suburban expanses and its semirural South Shore, struggling to find an appropriate balance with the demands of development. Those demands are reflected in the 2,431 sales recorded last year, a 23.4 percent increase over the 1,969 in 1997, according to the Staten Island Board of Realtors.
The board does not provide comprehensive prices for the borough, only by house type, said its president, Thomas Maira, owner of Maira Real Estate. The median for a single-family house was $189,000 last year, Mr. Maira said, a 6.2 percent increase over the $177,300 in 1997. For single-family semiattached homes, the median was $171,500, or 6.5 percent more than the $161,000 in 1997. And an attached home was $125,000 in 1997 and $132,000 last year, up 5.6 percent.
Of the 12 ZIP-code areas on Staten Island, one experienced price appreciation of between 4 and 6 percent, eight rose by between 6 and 8 percent and three increased by 8 to 10 percent, the Case Shiller survey reported.
NOWHERE is the city's housing rebound more pronounced than in the Bronx.
The statistics kept by the Bronx Board of Realtors are incomplete. But one broker, Haniff Baksh, vice president of ERA Besmatch, conducts his own survey, based on deed transfers recorded by the city's Department of Buildings.
Last year, total sales of one- to six-family homes in the Bronx reached 2,236, a 39.1 percent jump from the 1,607 in '97. Single-family home sales, taken alone, rose 37.7 percent, from 588 to 810.
"Inventory is a problem," Mr. Baksh said, "because if we look at the deed transfers -- an increase of 629 properties sold -- that would probably be the oversupply that has been on the market for most of the 90's; we've eaten up the oversupply. And, of course, that favors the sellers."
Indeed, the Case Shiller survey showed that every one of the 25 ZIP-code areas in the Bronx experienced price increases of at least 6 percent last year. One increased by 6 to 8 percent, five by 8 to 10 percent, 14 by between 10 and 12 percent and -- unlike any other areas in the city -- five jumped by at least 12 percent, including Riverdale and Eastchester.
"But something to note here," Mr. Baksh said, "is that in the South Bronx, where private builders are buying up land and building -- mostly two-families -- those properties would probably go for $225,000, and in some cases upward." With the supply-demand crunch, "buyers can no longer get into the market," Mr. Baksh said. "People who figured they could get a bargain look at many properties before realizing that that's not the reality, not in the Bronx any longer. They have to get their family together and pool their resources."
According to New York City's 1996 Housing and Vacancy Survey, nearly one out of four low- and middle-income households pays more than 50 percent of its income for housing costs. "This is an extraordinary housing-cost burden," N.Y.U.'s Professor Schill said. "The impact of rising home prices is a two-edged sword. On the one hand, it can make middle-income homeowners wealthy overnight; on the other hand, it is freezing out many middle- and lower-income families, particularly young families just starting out."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
FromUnemployed To Interview-Ready

BYLINE: By ALEX PRUD'HOMME 

 BODY:
THEY were 19 men down on their luck, and they came to the penthouse of the Times Square Hotel in New York at 1 P.M. on a rainy January day to get a big boost in their search for work.
A 20th man showed up at 2, one hour late, and was turned away. "Punctuality is expected in the real world," said Wayne Fletcher, director of the Jobs Cooperative Program at Grand Street Settlement and a member of the welcoming committee. "It's tough love." 
 If that sounded unforgiving, what happened next was like a gift from the gods. Each man got a haircut and grooming tips from professional stylists with Red Salon, an upscale chain, and each received about $1,700 worth of business clothing, including a trench coat, a suit, a dress shirt, a tie, a Coach watch and a pair of socks and Rockport shoes. The items were donated by the manufacturers and distributed by a new nonprofit organization called Career Gear that so far has raised just $4,000 toward its projected annual budget of $235,000.
David C. Woolard, 40, the vice chairman of Career Gear and a costume designer, fitted each job candidate individually before sending the suits to an express tailor shop for free alterations. As Mr. Woolard pinned his sleeve, Mikhail Murodov, an economist from Uzbekistan, said: "I'm feeling very emotional right now! So many people helping so many people."
Another participant, Samine Gibson of the Bronx, was having his beard trimmed. "I feel like a million bucks," exulted Mr. Gibson, who wants to enter music engineering. "It's my first suit since I was little. It makes me want to go out and get a job right now."
Then the men had their pictures taken. Brian Gurganious, a former postal clerk and a single parent of two girls, struck a pose and said, "I don't know why, but I can't stop smiling."
The American economy may be a giant job machine these days, with unemployment falling to 30-year lows and labor shortages developing in many parts of the country, but many employers still shun job seekers they view as undesirables. These include unskilled workers, recent immigrants and people who have coped with personal or family traumas. It is for them that Career Gear was formed late last year. Its simple premise is that a job seeker can greatly increase his chances of landing a job if he wears crisp business attire to the interview.
"The psychology of clothing is very important in our society," Mr. Woolard said. "Judgments are made in the first five seconds. When these guys put on a new suit, it's like putting on a suit of armor."
 OTHER groups, like Dress for Success in New York and the Bottomless Closet in Chicago, have provided "interview appropriate" clothing to women for years. Now, the movement is crossing the gender border with the formation of groups like Career Gear in New York and the Street Clothes Project in Philadelphia.
Career Gear was founded in October by Gary L. Field, 39, who recently quit his job as director of services for the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill in New York to devote all his attention to the project. Mr. Field said the need to teach the chronically unemployed the ins and outs of job-hunting has intensified with the spread of workfare programs aimed at moving people off welfare and into paying jobs.
"A lot of the people on welfare are totally unprepared to make the transition into a professional environment," he said. He added that he hopes to build a network of peers and mentors to help his clients cope with workplace problems and "deal with tricky things like office politics."
People are referred to Career Gear after learning job-seeking skills -- like how to write a resume and answer interview questions -- at work-readiness programs including the Employment Training Program for Recovering Alcoholics, the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty and the Federation of Employment and Guidance Services.
Today, two months after their makeover, some members of Career Gear's first class have found work while others are still looking. Mr. Gurganious, the single father, is one of the lucky ones, finding employment as a hardware store clerk. "I wore my suit to the interview, and I guess it worked," he said. "This job makes me feel like a brand-new person. The suit is my good-luck charm. It stays in the closet."
Gary Waytes, a fellow alumnus and former co-owner of a multimedia production company who said he has struggled with addictions, jail time and homelessness, landed a job at a mental-health clinic. "When you've been out of work, it's frightening to look for a job," he said. "My self-esteem was low. It's amazing how a change of clothes can make you feel so much more optimistic and confident."
Mr. Field knows how these men feel. Once addicted to drugs and alcohol himself, he said, he joined a program for recovering alcoholics, bought a $50 suit at a thrift store and regained control of his life. At 37, he graduated from New York University with a master's degree in social work, and eventually volunteered at Dress for Success. At the urging of Mr. Woolard, he created a similar program for men.
"I understand our clients because I am them," Mr. Field. "I tell them I should have been dead by age 30, and I say, 'If I can do it, so can you.' "

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
New Home For a Lost Generation Of Innovators

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
LIKE a growing number of young Asian entrepreneurs, Nobuhiro Michishita saw a future for himself in cyberspace but felt that he had to go to the United States to pursue it.
"We are trying to develop a business model for the future, and it is much easier to do it here than at home" said Mr. Michishita, 38, a computer scientist from Japan. "Computer people in their 20's and 30's, they don't look to Japan but to Silicon Valley for ways to work the Internet." 
 In America, Mr. Michishita has become something he was unlikely to be in Japan: a serial entrepreneur. Operating out of the International Business Incubator, a joint venture of San Jose State University and the San Jose city government, he has given life to N & S Consulting, an Internet consultancy that also has offices in Tokyo; Cyberspace Navigation, which sells Japanese-made toys on the Web from a base in nearby Los Altos, and other ventures.
The incubator, a modest downtown high-rise, has become a magnet for a dozen or so entrepreneurs from Asia who, like Mr. Michishita, left home frustrated at the costs and obstacles in the way of new ideas there.
Mr. Michishita tried starting a business in Japan but lost patience with delays and governmental paperwork. He hired an expediter to help him navigate the bureaucracy, but his application for a business license was rejected over technicalities. Not so in America. "When I went to Los Altos City Hall to incorporate, right away they gave me a paper and said, 'Congratulations and good luck,' " he said.
Japan, too, has business incubators meant to foster new technology enterprises, but Mr. Michishita said the bureaucrats who run them care more about edifices than entrepreneurs. "An incubator in Japan is basically a big building; they still are oriented around the hardware," he said. "There is no knowledge, no exchange of information."
Only a decade ago, Japan and its East Asian neighbors were seen as a technological juggernaut that would soon overtake the United States, with powerful companies like Matsushita, Sony and Samsung in the lead and young scientists like Mr. Michishita expected to follow. But the Internet has changed all that. Fleet-footed entrepreneurs in America are now out in front while Asia's corporate giants and the countries that bred them struggle to adapt.
Although use of the Internet is growing in Asia, the gap with the United States remains wide. Japan, Asia's dominant economy, has about 9.6 computers connected to the Internet for for every 1,000 people, half as many as in the United States, according to Jupiter Communications, a consulting company that compiles Internet statistics.
In on-line commerce, Asia is even further behind, according to the International Data Corporation. In 2001, Asia is expected to account for 17 percent of all Internet commerce, while the United States will have more than 60 percent.
In the past, Asian countries closed technological gaps by making huge investments in research and development. But the Internet poses a challenge not easily overcome with engineering and money, according to Sung Kim, who came to San Jose from South Korea last year to found Nextream, a software company.
"In the past, we saw a technology from a U.S. company and followed it," said Mr. Kim, 38, of his days at Samsung, his former employer. "Now it's not a matter so much of getting the technology; it's the ideas about how to use it that matter. Take a company like Yahoo. It's not really a technology, it's about an idea."
 NEXTREAM develops software to link mainframe computers to the Internet and sells it mainly to Korean banks and other financial institutions. But like Mr. Michishita, Mr. Kim said he had to leave a stifling environment -- in his case, the world of South Korea's giant chaebol conglomerates -- to embark on the venture.
The top-down management style and emphasis on manufacturing at Samsung led executives there to think of products as ideas conceived by executives and then executed with precision by engineers, Mr. Kim said. He and his fellow founders of Nextream's small Seoul-based parent company, Cheong Ji, wanted instead to emulate the more flexible and informal management style popular in Silicon Valley.
Mike Morishita, formerly with Nippon Telephone and Telegraph, points to another problem: Many top Asian executives personally know little about the Internet. In a recent Andersen Consulting survey, only 13 percent of Japanese top executives said they were "comfortable" or "familiar" with the Internet, compared with 46 percent of their American counterparts. Nearly 3 in 10 Japanese executives said they did not even have access to cyberspace, compared with just 1 percent of the Americans.
As a result, Mr. Morishita said, Nippon Telephone tends to treat the Internet not as an opportunity but rather as a reason to increase rates. In the United States, local calls to an Internet service provider are typically free, but in Japan they are usually toll calls, adding $100 a month to the phone bill of someone using the Internet for an hour a day. High-speed lines for businesses also cost much more in Japan than in America.
"It's too expensive to do this business in Japan," said Mr. Morishita, who now, at 32, has a successful computer consulting business, MM Systems, in the Los Angeles suburb of Torrance. MM Systems designs Web sites for a mix of Japanese companies including Imperial Hotel, Nissin Foods and even Nippon Telephone, as well as American companies like Earthlink Network, an Internet service provider based in Pasadena, Calif.
But the biggest problem for Internet companies in Asia may be the cultural adhesion that helped propel the region's economic growth for three decades, according to Akira Tsurukame, a business consultant in Los Angeles. "Japan is a place where the ties between people are very strong and people like to do business with people they know personally," he said. "The Internet is about networking strangers to talk to each other," which is a threat to the interlocking networks of suppliers and distributors on which big Japanese companies depend.
But it would be wrong to assume that Japan will stay that way forever, he said. He and Mr. Michishita have started an organization called Business Cafe to attract Japanese Internet entrepreneurs to the San Jose incubator this year, with the goal of sending the new cyberculture back to the home islands. Applications have come in not just from young entrepreneurs but also from well-placed executives at Mitsubishi Electric, Toshiba and Sony.
"A lot of people are feeling frustration with Japan now and want to find a different way to make things work," Mr. Michishita said. "People see the value in coming to Silicon Valley."

HEADLINE: Harlem After Dark Is Cooking Again

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL

 BODY:
ONCE, clusters of dapper night owls would zigzag down the broad, limestone-lined avenues of Harlem, from jazz joint to rent party to cabaret. In 1929, during the Harlem Renaissance, Variety reported: "When it comes to pep, pulchritude, punch and presentation, the Harlem places have Broadway's nightclubs distanced. Celebrities in all walks of life 'make' the Harlem joints every night. You'll likely see a Lady Mountbatten on the ringside of the Cotton Club, a David Belasco at another and a diplomat in the next."
Those who live in the 50 or so blocks above Central Park like to term what's happening in the area today Harlem's Second Renaissance, with the return of black professionals, new businesses, increased tourism and a rebirth of night life. While the term may be strained, it is not far from the truth. Economic development, historical preservation and plummeting crime rates in the area have contributed to a kind of boom. 
 Visiting Harlem's clubs, restaurants and bars now is like watching a small bud begin to bloom. In a few years, said Berta Alloway, a music promoter for some of the night spots, Harlem may come to resemble its old self again.
"A lot of people are moving back to Harlem, and they have money, and they'd rather spend it here," she said. "There's money coming back up here, and people are coming back out to the clubs also. They're coming from all over. A lot of Caucasian people are coming back uptown, and they're not afraid to hang around. I look around at night and say, 'Didn't the tour bus leave?' and they say, 'We're not going anywhere.' "
Al Howard, one of the two owners of Showmans, since 1942 a staple of Harlem night life, which moved to a new address on 125th Street in August, said that more than half of his clientele on any given night are from out of town or from Manhattan below 110th Street.
"We do get a lot of trade from downtown, a lot more than people realize," he said. "Once people come here, they see how safe it is, they come back, and they tell their friends."
In the last five years, there has been a 77 percent decrease in homicides in the area surrounding the 28th Precinct in central Harlem, according to the Police Department. (The citywide murder rate has decreased 67 percent in the same period.)
The Harlem scene today is part nostalgia, part novelty. Some of the recognizable places, like the Apollo Theater, the Cotton Club and even the famous Sylvia's Restaurant, maintain a steady tourist trade but don't attract local residents in the same numbers. Other traditional joints, like Showmans, the Lenox Lounge, Perk's Fine Cuisine and St. Nick's Pub, have found ways to maintain their popularity through new events, like a gay night at the Lenox Lounge; with theme evenings, like jazz, rhythm and blues and calypso at Perk's every Thursday, or by sheer force of will.
At the same time, new clubs and cafes like the Sugar Shack, Miss Mamie's Spoonbread Too, Emily's Restaurant and Bar, Londel's Supper Club, Cafe Largo, the Gishen Cafe and the Audubon Bar and Grill, are luring a different crowd, with tap dancing, open-mike poetry nights, even comedy.
"There's tremendous opportunity up here right now," said Marc Calcano, who opened Cafe Largo on Broadway near 137th Street last June and just began presenting live jazz on Sunday and Monday nights. "The volume of traffic here now is tremendous. Harlem was vacant for a very long time, and it's about half filled now, and I believe that in the next two to three years, tops, it's going to be filled to capacity again."
Still, not everyone is convinced of the inevitability of Harlem's comeback. A few years ago, Robert De Niro and his restaurateur partner, Drew Nieporent, announced plans to reopen Minton's Playhouse, a legendary jazz hall known as the birthplace of bebop, by late 1997. But today, there is no Minton's. The project has stalled, Mr. Nieporent said, because investors are wary of signing on to this $3.1 million project.
Even without Minton's, there is no lack of excitement at clubs operating now. At 2:30 A.M. on a recent Monday, while the musicians at St. Nick's Pub were gearing up for another set, Ms. Alloway, dressed in leopard-skin eyeglass frames, a floppy black hat and a leopard-skin velvet shirt, surveyed the boisterous and packed room, where the cabaret tables were piled high with full ashtrays, empty beer bottles and plates of oxtail stew. "No one should have to work on Tuesdays," she said, pitying those who had to get up in the morning.
Harlem's night life begins, like the workweek, on Monday. At around 8 P.M., those with a taste for gumbo, banana pudding and Diana Ross gather at Miss Mamie's Spoonbread Too, a restaurant sprung from a well-known catering company. The decor is a cross between the Southern kitchen and pop art, with a bold red and yellow checkered floor and 1950's-style kitchen tables. In front of the large windows, a pianist playing a small upright leads the crowd in a sing-along or allows poets to share their craft.
About the same time, a more sophisticated crowd is settling in at Wells Famous Home of Chicken and Waffles, where the 16-piece Harlem Renaissance Swing Band packs into the main dining room. The house specialty is fried chicken and waffles, once an after-hours breakfast treat, now a main course on the evening menu. Dancers from the New York Swing Society, led by Frank Manning, occupy the front table and take the floor by turns.
The long tables where everyone sits together are packed with white and black groups, small clusters of tourists from Japan or France, as well as an occasional celebrity just off a film shoot. The dress code ranges from tube tops to floor-length furs, but within an hour, when the food and drinks start flowing, everyone is talking to everyone else.
The dancing picks up around 11:30, when the novice swing dancers are lubricated enough to brave the floor next to the professionals and old-timers. But by then, it's time to move on to St. Nick's Pub on St. Nicholas Avenue and 149th Street, where you can still snag an empty table before the jam session starts to bubble. At St. Nick's, a narrow dive a few steps down from the street, free jazz, accompanied at times by singers and occasional tap dancers, begins at 11 P.M. and goes on until 3 A.M., and many notable musicians -- Stevie Wonder, Etta Jones and James Carter among them -- have been known to drop in for a round.
"The musicians that play downtown and play abroad, they don't play our club for the money," said Ms. Alloway, who also goes by the professional name Berta Indeed. "But they come up because it's like home. They'll come up and sit in with us."
By 3 A.M., part of the audience from St. Nick's or Wells has arrived at the counter at M & G Diner, 383 West 125th Street, which advertises itself in hot pink neon as "Old Fashion' but Good." The R-and-B jukebox pumps out Billie Holiday or the Spinners, and a pat of bright yellow butter shimmers in a plate of grits like the rising sun.
Then there's Tuesday night, which is gay night at the Lenox Lounge, beginning around midnight. "You take a nap when you get home, and you take another nap after you get home from work," one patron, a Brooklynite, 36, explained. He was seated on the crescent-shaped red leather couches that line the Art Deco bar.
The Lenox Lounge has been a neighborhood mainstay since it was opened at Harlem's hub, Lenox Avenue and 125th Street, in 1942. But two years ago, a young promoter calling himself Cris Is Bliss put together gay night, with live deejays spinning funk and hip-hop. The steamy Zebra Room fills up by 12:30, and sleek black bodies pack the dance floor until about 4. The lounge is the only club open to the public that caters to gay men (Emily's has a ladies night for women), although up to 15 years ago, Harlem had a handful of gay clubs.
"It's been a long time since I've known about a place like this in Harlem," said the Brooklynite, who did not want to be identified, adding that as the quality of services improves in the neighborhood, he expects to see more such places. "There's better policing, and there are more companies like Duane Reade up here, and people feel more comfortable getting off the train and walking around."
On Wednesdays, the Sugar Shack offers an open-mike poetry slam, where performers in dreadlocks or with shaved heads recite verses or read raplike meditations to drumbeats, keyboard and flutes. Odell Holland Fincher, 27, who opened the club in January 1998, hoped to create a blend of uptown and downtown that was "spiritual to a certain extent, but not overbearing," he said, adding, "I wanted it to be homey, so people could come and feel they were sitting in their grandmother's living room."
The large, open, Southern-style kitchen, which prominently displays boxes of Quaker Oatmeal, serves up candied yams, smothered chicken and hearty soup. The rest of the club is clearly inspired by a SoHo look, except for the kente cloth tacked on a couple of walls.
Later in the evening, the Audubon Bar and Grill, which opened in 1996, lures people uptown to a comedy night, with Angelo Lozada as host. The roundup presents comedians who have performed on HBO, Comedy Central and late-night television shows, including Greer Barnes, Eric Nieves and Patrice O'Neal. The large, brightly lighted club serves chicharones, yuca fries, chicken wings and other bar food, as well as mixed drinks for $3, but warns "no hoodies, no hats and no sneakers," if you want to get in.
Thursdays might find a night owl at Perk's, a narrow bar joined to an equally narrow white-table-cloth restaurant, where a jazz, rhythm and blues and calypso band performs so close to the front entrance that it is hard to get in or out. Thursday is also a good night at Showmans, where tap dancers and jazz musicians perform for an older crowd dressed in three-piece suits and fedoras.
LeRoy Myels, a former tap dancer, who has spent evenings at Showmans, on stage and off, since 1942, said he is pleased to see a new generation venturing to Harlem clubs. In 1949, he said, Showmans was the unofficial meeting place of the Copacetics tap dance group. Today, it attracts dancers from the recently closed long-running Broadway musical "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk."
"Kids now are a little different, but the tap is still the same," Mr. Myels said. "The crowd has definitely increased since they moved."
The weekend picks up, with live jazz and blues or deejays spinning dance mixes at almost every spot, including St. Nick's, Showmans, Perk's, the Lenox Lounge, Wells, the Cotton Club, the elegant but spare Londel's Supper Club and a new Ethiopian restaurant, the Gishen Cafe.
On Sunday, the action grinds to a halt. But then, on Monday, it starts all over again.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS to COURTLAND COX;
Strength In Diversity, And in Unity

BYLINE: By PAUL SWEENEY 

 BODY:
IT is not unusual for businesspeople with a common background to join together to promote economic development and entrepreneurship in their community, forming groups like the Asian American Business Development Center in New York.
Now these groups are finding that they can magnify their effectiveness by banding together into minority-group coalitions, a move encouraged by the Minority Business Development Agency of the Commerce Department. 
 Courtland Cox, the director of the agency, was in New York last week for the release of a research report by the Asian center. The report calls for greater economic collaboration among Asian, Hispanic, African-American and other minority groups, which together command $1.1 trillion in consumer purchasing power, according to John Wang, the center's president.
Mr. Cox discussed the report's findings and the challenges of minority business development. PAUL SWEENEY
 
Q. Do you see small-business development and entrepreneurship as the best route out of poverty?
 
A. Yes. The real issues minorities face are economic rather than social. People try to deal with illegitimacy and crime and drug addiction, but these are the effects, not the root causes, of problems. It is important to develop a business and economic infrastructure that can deal with the real issues of jobs, economic development and the creation of wealth.
When I look at a map of where murders take place in Washington, basically it is east of 16th Street Northwest, where there is more poverty and higher unemployment. There are almost no murders west of 16th Street, where the wealth is. Where you have access to opportunity, you have less crime.
If you're a minority businessperson, it's an exciting time, because you're in a dynamic growth area. The United States population is expected to grow by 120 million people over the next 50 years, and 90 percent of that growth will be in the minority community. If you look at where the markets for the future are, it's clear that's where they will be.
 
Q. Does minority entrepreneurship translate directly into more jobs for minority workers?
 
A. Yes, the numbers will show you that. Recently I went up to Detroit to see Bing Manufacturing. Dave Bing, the former basketball player, has an automotive assembly operation that included 15 percent of employees who were ex-offenders, predominantly nonwhite. Detroit also has Mexican Industries, a $300 million company that has hired about 2,000 people, most of them Hispanic, who make parts and do assembly work for G.M., Ford Motor and Chrysler.
These are private-sector initiatives. A lot of big companies realize that markets change and they have to include minorities, not because it's nice or legal, but so that they can sell into the market. I.B.M. just created its first minority distributorship. These guys aren't stupid. They want to be where markets are.
 
Q. Researchers say lack of access to financing is a roadblock to minority business creation, and the Administration has responded this year by proposing tax credits and Government loan programs for struggling inner-city areas. What should the private sector be doing?
 
A. We need a mechanism for banks and other financial institutions to sell off their loans to minority enterprises, instead of waiting for them to mature before they can lend more money. There is now much more mortgage money because banks are selling off mortgages and securitizing them. We need to apply the same principle to business loans.
 
Q. Your agency is encouraging coalitions among different minority groups, like the Minority Business Coordinating Council in Washington. How far has this cooperation advanced? Will it be hampered by past tensions between some groups?
 
A. This is a new concept, and it's just in the discussion stages. We still have a ghetto mentality, where people fight over crumbs. Many people still think the world is their block and don't see the possibilities in the larger world. But I don't think groups will be that far apart once they understand the opportunities that exist. People are crossing all sorts of ethnic and national boundaries, and business is more important than ethnic prejudices.
 
Q. Do you agree with John Wang that in a global economy, American entrepreneurs of Asian or Hispanic background may have an advantage in dealing internationally?
 
A. America has the diverse population to position itself internationally. I have people in my office who have the feel for different countries. In an international economy, we need people who understand different languages and different cultures.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Corporate Profits Are Tasty, But Artificially Flavored

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE winter quarter ends on Wednesday, and as the crocuses emerge, public attention turns to profits. The stock market in the coming weeks will ride -- up or down -- on the quarterly profit reports that will spew forth soon from corporate America. Will those reports signal continuing economic strength? If so, is corporate America reporting its profits truthfully?
That may seem a startling question to pose in the United States. Crony capitalists in emerging countries may inflate profits irresponsibly without raising eyebrows. But the phenomenon is popping up right here in disciplined America, and not just among a handful of black-sheep companies. "I fear we are witnessing a gradual, but noticeable, erosion in the quality of financial reporting," Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said last week, repeating a diagnosis that first appeared in his speeches last fall. 
 That icon of business, Warren E. Buffett, has also weighed in, rather bluntly. Like Mr. Levitt, he blames the stock market for pressuring chief executives into reporting ever higher earnings so that their companies' stock prices will keep up with the ever-rising market, like a cat chasing its tail. They try to achieve the necessary earnings legitimately, Mr. Buffett wrote recently, but when they fail to do so, they "resort to unadmirable accounting strategems" that "manufacture the desired 'earnings.' "
The potential damage is alarming. Profits have climbed rapidly in recent years, and this growth has contributed mightily to the stock market's euphoria and to the impression that corporate America has outclassed other countries in the global economy. Rising profits, in fact, have become an emblem of the nation's apparent success. And now the emblem may be less than advertised -- considerably less, if enough companies, prodded by the S.E.C., find themselves forced to change their accounting practices.
"There is no doubt that, on average, reported profits are overstated," said Baruch Lev, a professor of accounting at New York University's Stern School of Business. "My intuition tells me that profitability in the United States is basically solid, but there is a layer of earnings that is illusionary."
No one has quantified how many billions would disappear if accounting practices changed, but there are hints. One gimmick involves the stock options that corporations increasingly award to executives as a way to fatten pay. Under current accounting rules, those options do not have to be listed as a cost and subtracted from earnings. Last year, the large companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gave out $10.4 billion in options without reporting them as compensation expense. That was 3 percent of the companies' $325 billion in after-tax earnings, so their actual earnings were closer to $315 billion.
Stock options are relatively easy to track; they appear as footnotes in reports filed with the S.E.C. Jack Ciesielski of R. G. Associates in Baltimore, which researches accounting issues, came up with the $10.4 billion figure by going through the filings.
A bigger source of overstated profits -- corporate restructuring charges -- is harder to unravel.
Consider a big corporation that announces a $2 billion restructuring charge to cover the cost of integrating a newly acquired company and the cost of severance for laid-off workers. The $2 billion is all charged against this year's earnings, making them look bad, although the actual costs are spread out over two or three years. But the $2 billion is intentionally overestimated; the actual cost turns out to be $1.5 billion. And the company has a de facto $500 million reserve that is fed gradually into quarterly earnings reports, making net income seem to rise robustly.
From news reports last year, Mr. Ciesielski's firm tracked 1,400 restructuring charges totaling $76 billion. "I think that is a light figure," he said. "We probably missed quite a few."
 And there are other ways to make profits seem bigger.
Corporate executives increasingly manipulate charges related to research and development and to depreciation, the accounting device that recognizes the gradual wearing out of machinery and other assets.
Or they stop the clock, as Walter P. Schuetze, chief accountant of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, noted in an acerbic speech last December. He cited one company that had "turned back its computer clock that recorded and dated shipments so that out-of-period shipments, and consequently revenue, would be recorded" in the just-ended quarter, fattening that quarter's profit.
 SUCH deeds do not just affect shareholders of the business. Some well-known companies -- for example, Sunbeam, Sensormatic and Livent Inc. -- have had to restate earnings in recent months, correcting one or another accounting misstep. Such announcements have often caused a company's stock to plunge, contributing to the market's considerable volatility.
There is a broader concern. The robust growth in corporate profits in recent years has been billboard advertising for the American market system, which has seemed more successful than the less prosperous, and more regulated, European and Japanese models. Now the American billboard needs a warning label, one that using Mr. Ciesielski's words might say: "Earnings gaming is widespread."

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
The Time-Killing 1040

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years will appear the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IF there is any time of year that most of us would love to skip, this is it. Taxes are due in less than three weeks, and only two weekends remain for us to lock ourselves away and get the chore done. The pressure is on.
Although the amount of taxes we pay is cause for much debate, the time required to prepare the forms can be just as vexatious. Of the estimated 126.2 million individual tax returns that will be filed this year, almost half will be completed by taxpayers themselves, not accountants. And even those who use professional help must spend many hours compiling their records. 
 Either way, it is a big job. And the burden falls hardest on baby boomers. According to the Tax Foundation, a research organization in Washington, boomers will pay 70 percent of the $877.4 billion tax bill for individuals this year. And, because their finances tend to be complex, the foundation estimates that they will spend about a third more time preparing Form 1040 and its many schedules than the average American -- 40 hours instead of 30.
"They are at the peak of their earnings and have children and houses," said Patrick Fleenor, a foundation economist. "Younger and older people tend to have much simpler filings."
That raises questions beyond whether the tax system is fair. Considering that boomers, now into middle age, are at the height of their earning power, creativity and productivity, there must be a social cost in forcing them to spend millions of hours a year at their kitchen tables trying to maneuver through the tax code.
THE opportunity cost of the time they're spending is very large," said James M. Buchanan of George Mason University, winner of the 1987 Nobel Prize in economics. "It's a waste."
Mr. Fleenor called it "brilliance lost."
"This is the whole reason tax reform proposals have weight," he said. "Tax preparation doesn't add anything to society's worth. Nothing positive is coming out of it."
There is, of course, no way to measure what could have been; would boomers really use the extra time more productively, or would we just lie around listening to old Beatles albums? But we can measure the opportunity noted by Mr. Buchanan. The Tax Foundation estimates that the time Americans spend doing their taxes robs the economy of $18 billion.
A TAXPAYER in Malibu, Calif., who requested anonymity, said he spent about 90 hours on his taxes. Throughout the year, he said, he is meticulous about record-keeping because he runs a business out of his home.
"I have several careers," he said. "One of them is doing my taxes. It's a tremendous waste of my time. I should be spending it with my family or out making more money."
David P. Mulford, a computer programmer and musician in St. Louis, said he usually puts off doing his taxes until April.
"I dread doing them more than I do paying" the taxes owed, he said. "It's such a headache. When I get home from work, I don't want to spend three or four hours doing my taxes. I want to visit with friends or work on my music."
Mr. Buchanan said he was a recent convert to proposals for a simple-to-calculate flat tax, with no deductions. Others critics of the current system are calling for a national sales tax. And the other day a friend jokingly suggested requiring high-school juniors to fill out the nation's tax returns, giving the youngsters the chance to make their math skills relevant while freeing up time for their elders.
It seems that everyone has an idea for cleaning up the tax mess, but as Mr. Fleenor observed, the history of the tax-overhaul movement is not reassuring. Within years of any move to simplify the process, he said, Congress bows to special interests and complicates it all over again.
"When people are just playing around with the tax code, trying to find ways to avoid paying taxes, they are not engaged in creating wealth," he said. "People's time could be much better spent inventing the better mousetrap."
Or the better tax system.
